DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Mission Going `Satisfactorily'
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis streaked toward a Sunday landing after its crew put into orbit a spy satellite designed to fly over parts of the Soviet Union never before observed from a shuttle-launched craft, NASA sources said. The five-man, all-military crew released the $500 million, 37,300-pound satellite from the shuttle's cargo bay Thursday, a day after liftoff, the sources said. ``The crew is doing well and orbiter Atlantis continues to perform satisfactorily,'' the space agency said in a statement. Because of a Pentagon blackout on the secret mission, the only other word from NASA was that the shuttle is expected to land Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Sources speaking on condition of anonymity put landing time at 1:34 p.m. EST. NASA technicians planned to spend several days assessing the shuttle's solid rocket boosters, which arrived Thursday at a NASA hangar at the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, said agency spokesman Bruce Buckingham. The boosters dropped off two minutes after launch, as expected, as the spacecraft lifted off early Wednesday on the highest inclination ever traveled by a shuttle. The boosters fell into the Atlantic 169 miles from Kennedy Space Center and were towed back by two ships. A failed joint in a booster was blamed for the Challenger disaster in 1986 that killed seven astronauts. The 62-degree inclination allows the satellite to cover most of the Soviet Union, including far northern regions with heavy concentrations of ships and submarines and several missile bases. The satellite is designed to take high-resolution photographs and eavesdrop on electronic communications around the world, sources said. The satellite and other reconnaissance spacecraft will be important in verifying whether the Soviets are complying with U.S.-Soviet arms agreements. The Soviets have similar satellites over the United States. Atlantis is the sixth of 34 shuttle missions dedicated solely to the military. Navy Capt. John O. Creighton is Atlantis' commander. The other crew members are Air Force Col. John H. Casper, the pilot, and mission specialists Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane and Navy Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot.

DOC.HEAD: Fire That Started in Tent Destroys Luxury Hotel; 16 Dead
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with family confirming identity of American victim, details, edits to conform. Picks up 5th, `The hotel...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CAI7
DOC.TEXT: Fire broke out in a luxury hotel's tent restaurant early Thursday and wind-whipped flames leaped to the main building, killing 16 people and injuring about 70. An American retiree was among the dead. Frantic guests at the six-story Heliopolis Sheraton jumped out windows and clambered down bedsheets that were tied together. Many of the injuries were broken bones suffered in falls. While a U.S. Embassy spokeswoman refused to release any information on the the victim, the American was identified late Thursday as Robert D. Cresap of Houston, said his sister-in-law, Mrs. Alfred Cresap of Sioux City, Iowa. Cresap, 67, was a retired accountant who had arrived Wednesday in Cairo with his wife, Helen, his sister-in-law told The Associated Press in a telephone interview. Three Americans were seriously injured, said police Brig. Abdel-Rehim el-Kenawy in the blaze, which broke out at 1 a.m. and burned for nine hours. By early afternoon, after the last flames had been put out and the smoke extinguished, guests were returning to retrieve belongings. As people carried soggy luggage out of the ruined building, rescue teams were seen carrying out at least four bodies. The hotel northeast of Cairo had no fire alarms or a sprinklers, and many guests heard of the fire from other guests. Tourism Minister Fuad Sultan said the blaze started accidentally in the Nubian Tent restaurant _ a cotton canvas tent attached to one of the three blocks of the T-shaped hotel. The head of Cairo's fire brigade, Maj. Gen. Adel Nigm, said such tents are fire hazards and the Sheraton put it up without consulting the fire department. Sparks jumped from a clay oven to the ceiling of the tent, igniting flames that quickly spread to the hotel, said Sultan. Cairo Gov. Mahmoud Sherif told the official Middle East News Agency the use of such tents at hotels would be reviewed. A fire broke out in a similar tent at the Nile-side Guezira Sheraton about a year ago but was quickly extinguished with no casualties. The Helioplis Sheraton, about 10 years old, is the only one of Egypt's six Sheratons without an alarm system or sprinklers. Sultan said they are not mandatory under Egyptian law, but most first-class hotels began installing them in 1987. Winds of nearly 25 mph fed the flames, which destroyed much of the 630-room hotel, including its restaurants and elaborate lobby, where live birds flew among tropical plants and trees. Later in the day, people crowded around the still-standing front desk, asking for passports and belongings. There were about 1,000 guests and 300 employees in the hotel at the time of the fire. It was not known how many people were inside the Nubian Tent, where belly dancing and other entertainment is featured. Interior Ministry spokesman Maj. Gen. Bahaa el-Din Ibrahim said the 16 dead included eight French nationals and two Finns. British Embassy spokesman James Short said four British nationals were unaccounted for. At the hotel, a senior security official, Maj. Gen. Ali el-Kubtan, said rooms had been ``90 percent checked'' and left open the possibility that more victims might be found. ``I was at the counter when I saw smoke coming from the direction of the Nubian Tent,'' a hotel receptionist said. ``In just five minutes the entire lobby area was on fire. The flames spread very, very quickly.'' Fred Pirkey of Atlanta said he was asleep in a sixth-floor room when his wife got up and noticed ``some orange flames outside the window.'' From there, they made it through the smoke to the third floor, where a man was tying bedsheets together to attach to a windowsill, he said. ``With his help, we got around 20 people down to the roof of the ground floor below, from where we jumped to safety,'' said Pirkey, 57, who is on a two-week vacation. ``We are very fortunate to be alive.'' One of those who climbed down the makeshift rope was Robert Louis Toohey, 72, of Battle Creek, Mich. He passed out on his way down, but a man on the ground caught him. He was hospitalized for smoke inhalation. ``One problem was that some guests opened their windows to see what was going on,'' said Victor Lewis, assistant manager of the Cairo Sheraton, flagship of the chian's six hotels in Egypt. ``As a result, sparks went into their rooms driven by the strong winds.'' Uninjured Heliopolis Sheraton guests sat together in the lobby of a nearby hotel, some still in nightclothes. Annick Poussard of Paris, who was sightseeing with her three children, described the fire as an ``inferno.'' ``I saw flames from my window,'' she said. ``At first I thought they were lights from the nightclub, but then the music stopped. I opened the door and heard people shout fire. It was getting hot.''

DOC.HEAD: Politicized Military is Backbone of Sandinista Power
An AP Extra
With PM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: It's the Sandinista People's Army, not the Nicaraguan army; it's the Sandinista Police, not the national police; and it's Commander of the Revolution Tomas Borge's personal fiefdom, not an apolitical Interior Ministry and secret service. The name, nature and size of Nicaragua's powerful and mammoth military and paramilitary machine make up perhaps the touchiest issue between the unseated Sandinista Front and the victorious United National Opposition alliance. The leftist guerrilla group that has become a political party and the coalition led by civilians and business people that swept Sunday's elections each has its own idea of what a country's army and paramilitary forces should be. And the two ideas could not be further apart. ``Within the framework established by the political constitution, the Sandinista National Liberation Front will defend the integrity of the Sandinista People's Army and the Interior Ministry,'' President Daniel Ortega told about 15,000 Sandinista supporters Tuesday. Coming from the leader of a defeated political party, that statement alone served to show how much the Sandinista Front regards the army and the ministry as private property. The crowd's reponse was just as telling: ``One single army!'' When Sandinistas chant ``People power'' and ``One single army,'' they mean the merging of party, state and army, and the generous distribution of weapons among the common folk, a concept that riles civilian-minded UNO leaders. Weapons are plentiful and easily obtained. It seems every household has an AK-47 or a Soviet-made Makarov pistol. ``The UNO government is a government by the will of the people and not because of Mr. Ortega's decisions,'' said Vice President-elect Virgilio Godoy. ``Let that be very clear.'' Recruits receive political indoctrination along with military training in both institutions, which are commonly regarded as two separate armies _ one under Ortega's brother, Defense Minister Humberto Ortega, and the Interior Ministry under Borge. The setup was not coincidental. Borge is a hard-liner compared to the Ortega brothers. The two sides headed different factions of the Sandinista Front before the July 1979 triumph of the revolution. Once in power, lines were drawn and the two forces were established under different leaders to balance each other out. But President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of UNO made a campaign promise to trim Nicaragua's armed forces, the largest in Central America with an estimated 150,000 men and women and a heavy drain on state resources, taking up to 40 percent of the national budget. UNO leaders also want the armed forces depoliticized and the name changed to reflect the values of a Western-style government, where the armed forces remain in place regardless of which party is leading the government. They want the two-year draft for boys age 16 dropped. It reminds Nicaraguans of the setup under dictator Anastasio Somoza, for whom army, police and secret service were all one and the same and serving him personally. Borge, who will be 60 in August, commands fierce personal loyalties in the Interior Ministry. ``He is concerned about your well-being, he listens to you, he asks about your family; you can see that he really cares about you,'' a Sandinista cadre who occupies an important position in the ministry said of Borge. ``I'd follow him anywhere.'' Each army and ministry unit has a political officer, whose rank may be lower but whose authority is always higher than the unit leader. ``El politico's'' job is to impart doctrine, watch for deviations in ideology, and handle outside inquiries, such as by journalists. The Interior Ministry controls the Sandinista Police and also cloak-and-dagger departments such as State Security, in charge of domestic spying; Foreign and Clandestine Operations, and the sinister F-8 Mass Organizations department. F-8 organized the feared turbas, shock troops used to break up opposition demonstrations and stage ``spontaneous'' violent protests against Sandinista opponents. President Ortega once called them ``turbas divinas'' or divine mobs, and Nicaraguans spliced the two words into ``turbinas,'' or turbines, a spontaneous attempt by the populace to deal with the terror those groups inspire by mocking them. When Ortega threatens opponents with unleashing ``the people's ire,'' every Nicaraguan knows he's refering to the turbinas. Former President Jimmy Carter, who has been mediating between UNO and the Sandinista government to smooth the road to transition, said Gen. Ortega and Borge agreed to step down when Mrs. Chamorro is inaugurated April 25. Some Nicaraguans, veterans of 10{ years of Sandinista rule, are skeptical. ``They promise you one thing today and if it's not in their interest tomorrow, they'll deny ever having even spoken to you,'' said one housewife. ``They'll never give up their weapons. That's the basis of their power.'' She insisted her name not be used. Such is the feeling of intimidation that remains.

DOC.HEAD: Silent Orbit, A Final Mission
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The writer began covering America's space program for The Associated Press in May 1959. He has covered more than 2,300 rocket or missile launches, including every U.S. manned mission. On Wednesday, he retired, but not before covering his 65th manned space flight.

Appropriately, a manned rocket blasted off on the day of my retirement. I almost believe those who kidded me that NASA delayed Atlantis all those days so it could be that way. Manned rockets have been a great part of my life during the 31 years I have written about space for The Associated Press. It started with the first one _ Alan Shepard's in 1961 _ and continued through all 64 others, as Mercury, Gemini, Apollo and the space shuttle streaked across the pages of history. I have been fortunate to report on a whole new era of mankind, the Space Age, from its very outset to the present. My memories would fill volumes, but there are a few _ most happy, some very sad _ that stand out. There was Shepard's brief leap across the threshhold of space; John Glenn's epic orbital flight in 1962; the rendezvous, docking and space walk missions of the Gemini program that perfected the techniques for going to the moon; the close call with death that Neil Armstrong and Dave Scott had when Gemini 8 spun out of control. Then, there was the 1967 launch pad fire that killed the first Apollo crew; the recovery from the fire and the remarkable series of Apollo flights, including Apollo 8's circling of the moon on Christmas Eve, that led to man's first landing on the lunar surface in 1969; the near-tragedy of Apollo 13 when an oxygen tank ruptured near the moon and three men had to battle for their lives for three days to get safely back to Earth. There were the Skylab space station flights lasting up to 84 days; the joint U.S.-Soviet mission in 1975; the string of 24 space shuttle science, technology and science delivery and rescue flights that ended with that terrible explosion of Challenger and the death of seven astronauts in January, 1986. And there was the rebound from that disaster and the beginning of a new string of shuttle successes that reached nine with Atlantis' launch early Wednesday. The public focus has been on the astronaut flights. But I hold special fondness for the unmanned satellites and spacecraft that opened new frontiers and discovered unknown worlds and wondrous things out there. There was the Echo in 1960, a giant balloon shining like a star in the sky and pointing the way to a communications revolution in space; the first Tiros weather satellite and the startling weather photographs it radioed back; the early Explorer satellites that mapped the radiation belts and other phenomena encircling our globe; the Pioneer, Mariner, Magellan, Viking and Voyager robots that probed the planets, revising centuries-old scientific theories. The highlight of all those years had to be the moment Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin stepped onto the moon's Sea of Tranquillity on Sunday, July 20, 1969. For eight years, ever since President Kennedy had set this nation on a course to the moon, almost everything launched from Cape Canaveral was a stepping stone to that goal. Mercury proved man could survive in space. Gemini developed the procedures for getting there. Almost every unmanned satellite carried devices to measure radiation and other potential hazards along the route. The unmanned Ranger, Surveyor and Lunar Orbiter spacecraft scouted the lunar landing sites. When Armstrong and Aldrin set foot on the moon, it didn't hit me at first. I was too busy writing. But hours later, as I stepped outside the AP office, I looked up at the moon, felt a lump, and said, ``By gosh, we did it.'' Yes, the memories are there. After Wednesday's Atlantis' launch, several people asked me if I would miss it. Yes, I said, I would. For 31 years I've covered one of history's best stories. But at some point one has to assess his life and say its time to move on and make way for someone else to cover the history yet to come. And there is much to come. There will be space station Freedom in the middle of this decade, and early in the next century astronauts could be back on the moon and embarking for Mars. Those will be exciting days and I wish my successor, Marcia Dunn, the best of luck. I'll still be close to the space program. On Thursday, I will change hats and become executive director of the Mercury 7 Foundation, founded by the six surviving members of the original seven astronauts to raise money for science and technology scholarships. I will be located in the new Astronaut Hall of Fame Museum just outside the gates of the Kennedy Space Center. The foundation president and my boss will be Alan Shepard. Who would have thought it 29 years ago when I watched him take wing? It's been a facinating ride.

DOC.HEAD: At Least Five Arrested During Bush Visit
With AM-Bush
DOC.TEXT: A raucous mob set a fire and brawled outside the hotel where President Bush was speaking during his visit Wednesday, and police made at least five arrests, authorities said. Bush spoke at the post St. Francis Hotel at a fund-raising dinner for Republican Sen. Pete Wilson's run for governor. Outside the hotel in the heart of San Francisco's busy Union Square shopping and theater district, about 1,000 people gathered to protest or cheer the president. The crowd was well-behaved for a time. But riot police moved in when two dozen torch-bearing protesters, some wearing bandanas as masks, set a bonfire and watched the flames creep to within two feet of a parked television van while cheering wildly. Police escorted firefighters in to extinguish the flames. Several protesters got into the hotel and hung a banner from a window 12 stories above the street, reading ``Viva FSLN.'' FSLN is an acronym for the Sandinistas in Nicaragua, who lost the presidential election Sunday in that Central American nation. Protesters also hurled about 300 pro-Sandinista leaflets into the lobby as firecrackers popped outside. Five people were arrested, police said. Earlier, about 50 anti-Sandinista Nicaraguans chanted ``Violeta'' and ``Uno,'' referring to Nicaragua's president-elect, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, and her National Opposition Union party.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Gives Safe Conducts to Noriega Relatives, Associates
DOC.TEXT: The government is letting Manuel Antonio Noriega's wife and three children leave the country, but demanding that four of the ousted dictator's former associates surrender to authorities. Gen. Noriega's wife, Felicidad Sieiro, and daughters Sandra, Lorena and Thais were among 10 people granted safe conduct abroad on Wednesday, said Foreign Minister Julio Linares. Noriega's wife and daughters had taken refuge at the Cuban Embassy residence after the Dec. 20 invasion that overthrew Noriega. All have been granted political asylum by the Dominican Republic. Three former Noriega officers, accused of killing conspirators in a failed Oct. 3 coup against Noriega, and a former legislator, also accused of murder, were refused safe conduct out of the country, Linares said. Luis Antonio Suarez, a radio station owner who led a group that attacked opposition groups, also was given safe conduct. Others accused of minor crimes and granted safe conducts were: Baltazar Renaan Aizpurua, a former leader of the journalists' union and telephone company spokesman under Noriega; Zelideth Rosales de Aizpurua, who had a women's group that supported Noriega; Humberto Lopez Tyrone, a Noriega politician who organized street gangs that attacked the opposition; Marcela Tason, Noriega's secretary; and Edgardo Lopez Grimaldo, Noriega's press secretary. They had been staying at the embassies of Cuba, Ecuador, Nicaragua or Peru. Linares said Panama would ask for the extradition of any of those given safe conduct if they are needed to testify at trials. Asked to surrender were: Capt. Asuncion Eliecer Gaitan, who was Noriega's chief bodyguard and took asylum at the Vatican Embassy; Maj. Gonzalo Gonzalez, chief of the Macho del Monte battalion that came to Noriega's rescue in the Oct. 3 coup attempt, and Capt. Heraclides Sucre. Gonzalez and Sucre have been in the Peruvian Embassy. Luis Gomez, a leader of the paramilitary Dignity Battalions and a former congressman, also was refused safe conduct because two charges of assassination have been filed against him, Linares said without elaboration. Noriega was ousted following the U.S. invasion and is being held in Miami pending trial on U.S. drug trafficking and money laundering charges. He was replaced by Guillermo Endara, recognized as the winner of elections in May. Noriega nullified that election.

DOC.HEAD: New Zealand Town Takes Hilary Foretich To Heart
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Not many 7-year-old girls have a lawyer, a psychiatrist, and two names. Hilary Foretich _ the focus of an international custody battle _ does, and Christchurch has reacted to her plight with the protectiveness of an oversized country town. Hilary, or Ellen Morgan as she is known to schoolmates here, now is the best-known child in New Zealand as well as Page One news in the United States. When her maternal grandparents ran away to Christchurch to harbor the child from her father, they chose an apt sanctuary. Not only does New Zealand's revamped family law system aim to act in the best interests of the child at all times, so do the people of Christchurch, who have taken Hilary to heart. Hilary's mother, Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, sent the child off with her parents after a Washington D.C. judge ruled that the girl's father could have unsupervised visits with Hilary. Dr. Morgan has accused estranged husband Eric Foretich of sexually abusing the child, a charge Foretich denies. She went to jail for 25 months rather than reveal the child's whereabouts. Foretich, a dentist from Falls Church, Va., spent more than two years trying to track his daughter and his efforts finally paid off as private investigators tracked down the girl last month. He arrived in Christchurch today but, at the local Family Court's request, won't see Hilary. He says he wants to see his daughter, but will abide by the court's temporary injunction. Hilary reportedly has not seen either parent for two years. Her mother was released from jail last fall after Congress passed a law tailored for her that limited imprisonment for civil contempt in the District of Columbia to a year. Even though Hilary's identity became known to her acquaintances in late 1989, when a television documentary on her parents' bitter custody battle was broadcast, the people of Christchurch were happy to keep the secret. It was a secret that had previously been revealed only to Hilary's doctor and the headmistress of the exclusive private school she has attended since arriving in New Zealand in July 1988. The Morgan family said this week that they never lied about their identity, they just ``froze people out'' when they asked about ``Ellen's'' background. Foretich would not respond today to the allegations about him, but said he would try to keep Hilary's privacy and dignity. ``I'm not going to get involved in scintillation and retaliation,'' he told reporters at Christchurch airport before being ushered into a waiting car and driven away with journalists' vehicles in pursuit. The Family Court, which is to rule on the custody case, has warned journalists that they could be fined or jailed if they publish details of the custody case. Even Prime Minister Geoffrey Palmer has become involved, warning that U.S. reporters covering the case will have to stick to New Zealand laws. New Zealand's contempt of court laws are starkly different from thos in the United States, barring any discussion of a case before its conclusion. So far, both sides of the family have taken their lawyers' advise and kept quiet. The citizens of Christchurch, a quiet city with a population of under 300,000 which lies 190 miles south of Wellington, have shown their displeasure as the foreign media descended on the city this week. Not much news comes out of Christchurch outside of sheep farming _ the major industry here. Hotel staff and cab drivers can't recall the last time journalists took over the town. ``Leave the poor, wee girl alone,'' ``Leave her alone, you mongrels'' are typical remarks, along with obscenities, shouted to journalists staking out Hilary's school or home. Even rock star Elton John exhorted fans at a Christchurch concert Wednesday night to ``run the foreign media out of town.'' Hilary's grandmother, Antonia Morgan, said the child was feeling ``haunted'' by the battery of photographers and journalists. The Christchurch Star newspaper commented: ``As perhaps never before in its history, Christchurch is the center of international media attention. The matter raises anew the recurring question of how far the media should go in fulfilling their duty to report the facts to the public. ``The media in New Zealand could not ignore a subject of such major human interest when it suddenly landed on their doorstep. Inevitably, Hilary is a victim of such attention. ``The public have been given enough by now to meet any reasonable appetite for information. Hilary's story and her parents' stories, have been told from many angles. Now, for the child's sake if for no other, the matter should be left for the courts to decide.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Dustin Hoffman's new lead role is real-life drama: He's helping a terminally ill student who needs a bone marrow donor. The Oscar-winning actor has made a six-figure donation and a plea for Allison Atlas, who learned in August she had three to six months to live unless a marrow transplant checked her leukemia. ``If we find a donor, we'd literally be taking someone off death row,'' said Hoffman, winner of Academy Awards for best actor in last year's ``Rain Man'' and the 1979 ``Kramer vs. Kramer.'' Hoffman on Tuesday said something about Miss Atlas, a 20-year-old business major at New York University and a resident of Bethesda, Md., got him involved. ``It's hard to explain. It picked me,'' he said. The Atlas family made a public plea in November. Since then, more than 16,000 people offered to be donors. Because of the family's efforts, 25 to 50 potential donors were found for other people in her situation. ``It's just a matter of getting the right person to come to one of our drives,'' said Miss Atlas, one of 9,000 people awaiting a donor. Of Hoffman's support, she said: ``I don't know if it's fate or what. It's my only hope.''

President Bush has found a rich vein of joke material: the divorce battle between Donald and Ivana Trump. On a fund-raiser for a Republican candidate in a Staten Island congressional election, Bush said his visit to New York had put him in the midst of ``one of the greatest contests of 1990,'' a battle with ``a lot at stake, a lot of money spent on both sides, a lot of press attention.'' Pause. ``But I'm not here to talk about the Trumps.'' The president, who received a good deal of positive press when the first dog, Millie, had a White House litter, also offered advice to congressional candidate Susan Molinari: ``Puppies: worth 10 points easy.''

George C. Wallace isn't bothered about being called ``the late governor'' by NBC commentator John Chancellor, a spokesman says. ``Newsmen have been making mistakes about George Wallace all of his life,'' Elvin Stanton said. ``It's something he brushes off.'' During Chancellor's commentary Tuesday night, he quoted Wallace as once saying governors were nothing more than ``ornaments.'' Chancellor then said, ``Well, it's too bad the late governor wasn't here in Washington this week'' for a governors conference. NBC spokeswoman Katherine McQuay said the mistake was corrected during the 6 p.m. CST feed of the national news. Stanton said he did not call NBC because he knew enough people were aware Wallace was still alive. Wallace, who lives in Montgomery, has kept a low profile since leaving office in 1987 after four four-year terms.

Gonzo journalist Hunter S. Thompson has been charged with sexually assaulting a female writer who was attempting to interview him. Thompson, 52, surrendered to the district attorney's office Monday and was freed on $2,600 bail. He is charged with sexual assault for allegedly grabbing the woman's breast and simple assault for allegedly punching her during an argument about whether the interview should take place in a hot tub. Thompson, whose ``gonzo'' journalism is laced with drug references and wild hyperbole, said he is innocent and believes the woman wants publicity for her new venture, which he said is selling sexual aids and lingerie. Officers from the district attorney's office said they searched Thompson's house on Monday and found a small quantity of suspected cocaine and marijuana. The woman pressing the charges was identified as a 35-year-old self-employed woman from St. Clair, Mich., who said she attempted to interview Thompson on Feb. 21. Thompson is the author of several books, including ``Fear and Loathing On the Campaign Trail.''

The Walt Disney Co. threatened legal action against the source of a bogus news release that claimed Michael Jackson had signed a five-year movie deal with Disney. Disney said it began an investigation to find the author of the release, used as the basis for a story in the Hollywood Reporter. Among other things, the story said Jackson was negotiating to leave CBS Records for Disney's new Hollywood Records and would design theme park rides for Disney. ``We fully intend to take action against the person or persons responsible,'' Walt Disney Studios Chairman Jeffrey Katzenberg said. ``This company has a reputation for protecting its name and taking legal action when necessary.'' The paper ran a front-page article Wednesday saying it had been the victim of a hoax. Jackson stars at Disneyland in the 3-D movie ``Captain EO,'' which opened in 1986.

Paul Newman is heading back to court for another trial to decide whether a delicatessen owner deserves of cut of the profits from Newman's Own salad dressing. Julius Gold claims he was promised 8 percent of the profits for helping develop and market the dressing. But Newman, who lives in Westport, contends he developed the dressing in his home and decided the profits should go to charity. The first trial, in 1988, ended in a mistrial because jurors inadvertently were given material ruled inadmissible. Newman testified at the trial, at one point pounding a bottle of his dressing on the stand. Jury selection begins March 7 in the second trial.

DOC.HEAD: Strong California Earthquake Does Widespread Minor Damage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 25 grafs to UPDATE with injuries, scientist comment, emergency advisory, editing; picks up 22nd graf, `U.S. Geological ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LA6, LA9
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake rocked a 200-mile swath of Southern California on Wednesday, triggering rock slides onto highways, causing scattered structural damage and frightening thousands. Two people suffered broken legs and a woman went into early labor, said City Councilman Tom McGilloway, Upland's acting mayor. The quake had a magnitude of 5.5 on the Richter scale. The temblor, felt from San Diego to Santa Barbara and swayed high-rise buildings in Las Vegas, 230 miles to the east, sent 70 people fleeing a collapsing warehouse wall and forced evacuation of patients from a hospital. It was the most severe temblor in California since the October 1989 earthquake in the San Francisco Bay area that killed 67 people and awakened fears of the massive quake scientist predict in the state in coming years. In terms of ground shaking, it was about 40 times less severe than the World Series quake, which measured 7.1, said Lucile Jones of the U.S. Geological Service. Aftershocks of varying magnitude occurred hours after the earthquake. The strongest, a 4.8 shaker that rattled the Upland City Hall where the City Council was meeting to discuss measures to take in the aftermath of the quake, struck at 7:24 p.m. The quake, centered three miles northwest of Upland and about 40 miles east of Los Angeles, struck at 3:43 p.m., and was measured at 5.5 on the Richter scale on instruments at the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. The U.S. Geological Survey gave the same magnitude, but a preliminary reading by University of California Seismographic Stations at Berkeley put the magnitude at 6.0. Such measuring differences are common. A quake of magnitude 5.5 is capable of causing considerable damage. Scattered damage was reported in the region east of Los Angeles. In La Verne, a few miles from the epicenter, 70 workers fled as a wall collapsed at a warehouse. Workers leaped out windows and dove off a loading dock, but no one was seriously hurt, even though two workers were pulling stock along the 20-foot by 80-foot wall at the time. ``Everything happened so fast trying to get 70 people out of the warehouse it's amazing nobody got seriously hurt,'' said supervisor Stan Sokolowski. Pomona Valley Hospital evacuated 60 patients due to broken water lines, said Nancy Hardaker, spokeswoman for the state Office of Emergency Services. The hospital could not be reached by phone. At Harvey Mudd College in Claremont, about five miles from the epicenter, the quake broke a window and toppled wall-mounted bookcases in the president's office, said Burt Tashman, at the school. ``I'm on the second story and boy, I tell you, things started shaking,'' Tashman said. ``Glass fell from the wall of the president's office and fell all over the place. Pictures fell. The pane broke. That sort of thing.'' Windows shattered at City Halls in Upland and nearby Pomona. At Ontario International Airport, a few miles from the epicenter, ceiling panels and signs fell, and windows cracked in the operations tower, said manager Michael DiGirolamo. A small rock slide on Interstate 10 in Pomona, not far from the epicenter, startled motorists, causing minor accidents, the Highway Patrol said. Another small rockslide closed the road through Soledad Canyon, 35 miles northwest of Los Angeles. A boulder twice the size of a car fell onto Angeles Crest Highway in the San Gabriel Mountains, blocking half of the two-lane rural road. The San Francisco area quake struck Oct. 17, as the third game of the World Series was about to begin. In addition to the 67 deaths, the quake injured about 3,000 people and did $7 billion in damage. The worst recent Southern California quake struck the Whittier area Oct. 1, 1987. It measured 5.9 on the Richter scale and, together with a 5.3-magnitude aftershock Oct. 4, killed eight people, injured more than 200 and caused $358 million in damage. Wednesday's quake, felt as a rolling motion in Los Angeles, came three hours after a smaller quake in the same area. The main shock was followed by 16 aftershocks of magnitude 2.3 or greater within 2{ hours, Caltech said. Several hours after the main quake, the state Office of Emergency Services issued a carefully worded advisory saying that a quake as large as, or somewhat larger could occur in the area. The agency, pointedly noting that no specific prediction had been made, said authorities in San Bernardino, Riverside, Los Angeles and Orange counties had been advised to remain prepared. U.S. Geological Survey scientist Lucile Jones said that based on historical records of past California earthquakes there was a 5 percent chance the main shock would be followed by a larger quake within three days. However, the odds drop off rapidly so that by Thursday morning the likelihood of such a quake probably would be at most 2 or 3 percent, she said. Southern California Edison said 6,000 electrical customers lost power but only 1,300 remained without service 90 minutes after the main shock. Southern California Edison Co., operators of the San Onofre Nuclear Generating Station just south of San Clemente, reported an ``unusual event'' to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Both reactors at the plant continued to run and power supply was uninterrupted, said Edison spokesman Bob Goodlow. An ``unusual event'' is the lowest of four emergency designations for nuclear plants. Phone service to thousands of customers was disrupted, but Cati Flynn of Pacific Bell said it was likely caused by callers jamming lines. ``It felt like somebody picked up the building and dropped it a couple of times,'' said police Lt. Don Manning at the station in nearby Ontario, where false ceilings fell. ``It was like we went up a foot, then down a foot, then up again.'' Broken windows and minor structural damage were reported in Ontario, Manning said, the worst to an old three-story brick theater and office building. ``We had a dandy earthquake. It was a bumpy, jerky kind of earthquake,'' said Holly Jones of Hacienda Heights, a Los Angeles suburb. ``My china cabinet and several glasses fell out and broke.'' It was felt as far north as Santa Barbara, nearly 100 miles northwest of Los Angeles, and as far south as San Diego, 150 miles to the south. It was also felt in Palm Springs, 100 miles to the east. People reported feeling the quake in Barstow in the Mojave Desert and Bakersfield at the south end of the San Joaquin Valley. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. Thus a reading of 7.5 reflects an earthquake 10 times stronger than one of 6.5. An earthquake of 3.5 on the Richter scale can cause slight damage in the local area, 4 moderate damage, 5 considerable damage, 6 severe damage. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage; 8 is a ``great'' quake, capable of tremendous damage. The San Francisco earthquake of 1906, which occurred before the Richter scale was devised, has been estimated at 8.3 on the Richter scale.

DOC.HEAD: Temblor a Reminder of State's Quake-Prone Geology
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with injuries, advisory on aftershocks; picks up 6th graf, `The Pacific plate ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-LA Quake
DOC.TEXT: The earthquake that rumbled across Southern California on Wednesday was another reminder that the state straddles two gigntic plates of Earth's constantly moving crust. ``California sits on the boundary between the Pacific and North American plates, which are moving with respect to each other at about two inches per year,'' said Kate Hutton, a seismologist at the California Institute of Technology. ``That motion causes strain or deformation to happen in the crust. When something snaps under that strain, it's an earthquake,'' she said. Wednesday's earthquake, considered moderate with a magnitude of 5.5 on the Richter scale, was felt from San Diego to Santa Barbara. Two people suffered broken legs and a woman went into early labor in Upland, near the epicenter, and there was scattered structural damage. Sixteen aftershocks strong enough to be felt occurred within 2{ hours of the 3:43 p.m. main shock and a 4.8 aftershock struck at 7:24 p.m. The state Office of Emergency Services issued an advisory saying equally strong or more powerful aftershocks could occur over the next three days. The Pacific plate underlies the Pacific Ocean and much of Southern California. It is slowly grinding northwest past the North American plate, which underlies the rest of the continent. The 600-mile San Andreas Fault generally is considered the boundary between the two plates, but the plate motion also triggers earthquakes on a complicated series of faults that riddle California. The movement of the Pacific plate creates many parallel faults that run northwest to southeast and include the San Andreas, the San Jacinto and a series of offshore faults. But others, including the unnamed fault that caused Wednesday's quake, run perpendicular to the plate motion, or from northeast to southwest. Those faults also are created by the plate movements. Both types of faults are known as strike-slip faults in which ground on one side of a fault moves horizontally past ground on the other side. California's seismic map is even more complex. As it slides past the North American plate, the Pacific plate also presses against it. That compression can cause thrust faults, where ground on one side of a fault moves vertically with respect to ground on the other side. Thrust fault motion has caused several destructive earthquakes in California in recent years, including the 1987 Whittier Narrows quake east of Los Angeles, the 1983 Coalinga earthquake in the San Joaquin Valley, and the 1971 San Fernando earthquake that killed at least 58 people in the Los Angeles area. A strike-slip jolt, Wednesday's earthquake occurred three miles northwest of Upland at the base of the San Gabriel Mountains, which themselves were created by compressive thrust motion. It was centered at least 15 miles from any of the region's major faults, said Lucile Jones of the U.S. Geological Survey. Until the Whittier quake, which with a major aftershock killed eight people, scientists thought the major seismic threat in California was posed by strike-slip quakes. But Whittier made them realize that hidden thrust faults may pose an equal or more serious threat, regardless of the type of earthquake. Wednesday's jolt ``is a reminder of the seismically active area we live in,'' said Paul Flores of the California Office of Emergency Services. ``The shaking most people felt was minor as opposed to what we know can happen. Therefore people need to take the necessary precautions to prepare in reducing hazards at home and in the workplace.''

DOC.HEAD: `Maid of Orleans' Sung at Carnegie
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: Tchaikovksy's ``The Maid of Orleans'' was presented at Carnegie Hall by the Opera Orchestra of New York, founded 20 years ago by Eve Queler to perform concert versions of rarely heard operas. The performance Wednesday, the title role brilliantly sung by mezzo-soprano Delora Zajick, followed one last Saturday by the same orchestra at Brooklyn College. That one, with a different cast, was called the New York premiere of the opera and the U.S. premiere of the opera in Russian. ``The Maid of Orleans'' has some glorious music, especially in the first two of the four acts. The libretto reads as though there isn't much action, so a concert version may be the best way to hear it. And, in this opera, Joan of Arc isn't burned at the stake because of an accusation of witchcraft but because she falls in love with _ and doesn't kill _ the last English officer left alive. Other Englishmen kill him, as a traitor, and capture her. Joan is a wonderful role for mezzo-soprano and Miss Zajick made the most of it. She has a big voice, which can pour forth a solid column of sound, and she can sing with sweet softness. At any volume, she has a purity of sound appropriate for Joan. Near the end of Act 1 she has an aria saying goodby to the fields of home. In the incredibly melodic ending to Act 2, she has another wonderful aria, recounting her visions. The other two outstanding voices in the cast were soprano Marvis Martin in a rather small role as the French king's mistress and Finnish baritone Jorma Hynninen as the English officer. We also liked tenor Fan Jing-ma, who began his musical studies in China, singing Joan's early suitor and bass Sergei Koptchak of Czechoslovakia who sang her father. Miss Queler obviously knew what she wanted from the music and her orchestra responded glowingly to her conducting. The New York Choral Society directed by John Daly Goodwin was the excellent large chorus on stage. A band of minstrels also is called for and the Yale Russian Chorus, led by David-Marc Finley, took that role, arriving down an aisle and crossing in front of the stage, singing with harmonious blend as they went. Heavenly voices and trumpets were heard several times during the evening from the top balcony.

DOC.HEAD: Help Pledged to Develop Free Press in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Western journalists pledged fellowships and advice on circulation and advertising to help their East bloc colleagues develop an independent press. At a conference Wednesday, a U.N. agency also backed a Polish proposal to establish an center in Warsaw dedicated to training a new generation of journalists in independent reporting and helping to nurture a free press. Hard-line Communist rulers in Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland and Romania had manipulated reporting for decades, but with the popular upheaval that toppled them last year came a demand for independent journalism. In several East bloc countries, fledgling independent newspapers are competing with well-funded organs still under Communist control. At a two-day UNESCO meeting, Eastern European journalists sought everything from typewriters to printing presses from Western colleagues. The editor of the Swiss magazine Hebdo, Jacques Pilet, put the Western reponse succinctly when he said, ``Don't expect a sudden shower of dollars or trucks rolling in with bales of newsprint.'' But he said there is a real desire to help ``with training and advice.'' The Poynter Institute of St. Petersburg, Fla., a private foundation, offered eight fully funded fellowships to journalists from the East bloc. Representatives from USA Today, the Times of London and the British newspaper The Guardian said they would look into getting information to Eastern European news people on the training of personnel in advertising and circulation as well as in journalism. The U.N. Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization is ``going to try to establish a network'' of contacts, exchanges and information on training and media operations, said its information director, Alain Modoux. He also said UNESCO decided to provide $20,000 to establish the Central European Center for Communication in Warsaw. The International Federation of Journalists said it would contribute another $10,000 to start the school. Other East bloc journalists also supported the school, said Katarzyna Kolodziejczy of the Polish Journalists Association. At a news conference following Wednesday's end to the meeting, Modoux did not say what action, if any, UNESCO would take in response to the apparent decision by Soviet authorities to bar independent journalist Sergei Grigoryants from traveling to Paris to attend the conference. Grigoryants sent UNESCO a telegram in which he said that although he had a French visa his passport was confiscated an hour before his departure. He blamed the KGB for the move. ``This incident, which is usual in the USSR, once again emphasizes the real value of numerous (Soviet) statements about widening contacts with the West,'' his message said. He said it also emphasized the difference between the official and independent press in the Soviet Union. Leaders from official Soviet publications such as Ogonyok magazine editor-in-chief Vitaly Korotich and Vladislav A. Starkov, editor of the weekly newspaper Arguments and Facts, participated in the conference.

DOC.HEAD: Banker Pleads Guilty and Cooperates in Case Against Imelda Marcos
DOC.TEXT: Weeks before the start of Imelda Marcos' racketeering trial, a banker accused of helping the former Philippine first lady transfer stolen funds has struck a plea bargain and agreed to help prosecutors. Rodolfo T. Arambulo pleaded guilty in federal court Wednesday to the lesser charge of conspiracy to commit mail fraud. Arambulo, 57, is the former president of the California Overseas Bank, a Los Angeles-based bank indicted with Arambulo, Mrs. Marcos, the late Ferdinand Marcos and Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi in the racketeering case in 1988. Mrs. Marcos' trial with her co-defendants begins March 20. Arambulo, a fugitive until his surrender Monday to FBI agents in New York, admitted to a scheme to fraudulently obtain insurance from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. for the bank, which prosecutors say was secretly owned by Marcos. Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles LaBella would not say whether Arambulo would be called as a witness at Mrs. Marcos' trial, but his cooperation agreement said he would be required to testify at proceedings related to the case. The conspiracy charge against Arambulo carries up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine. The indictment had charged him with racketeering and racketeering conspiracy, which carry up to 20 years in prison each. The indictment accuses the Marcoses of siphoning more than $100 million from the Philippine treasury to buy New York City real estate and art. They also were charged with embezzling $165 million from several banks. Marcos died in exile in Hawaii on Sept. 28 at age 72. Arambulo's plea came after U.S. District Judge John Keenan refused to dismiss the indictment against Mrs. Marcos on a claim that she and her husband were abducted from their homeland by U.S. officials during his overthrow in 1986. The judge noted that the Marcoses were accompanied to Hawaii by an entourage of 122. ``This was more akin to a troop movement than a kidnapping,'' he said. Mrs. Marcos had claimed that at no time did she agree to leave the country. In rejecting the kidnapping claim, Keenan quoted a statement by Marcos two days after their arrival in Hawaii in which the ousted dictator said he was there ``under the hospitality'' of the U.S. government.

DOC.HEAD: NYC Transit Authority Uprooting Subway Benches to Remove Homeless
DOC.TEXT: Bench warfare has broken out in the city's subways, as the Transit Authority yanks seats from stations to force the slumbering homeless to find other accommodations. Not all stations _ just in those where officials say the homeless congregate, using benches as places to sleep and worse. ``These benches are not used by the general public,'' said Transit Authority spokesman Bob Slovak. ``These are benches that have been taken over by the homeless, benches that have been defecated on, urinated on.'' The effort started last week, when 10 benches were removed from three stations. The program drew immediate condemnations from an unusual coalition of homeless advocates and commuter groups. ``Moe, Larry and Curly really are running the MTA,'' said Keith Summa, advocacy director of the Coalition for the Homeless. ``What the Transit Authority has to do is acknowledge that homeless folks aren't going to go away unless they are helped with housing and increased rehabilitation facilities,'' said Joseph Rappaport, coordinator of the Straphangers Campaign, a commuter group. The program was conceived by a task force formed to shore up Operation Enforcement, a program to improve subway ambience. When Operation Enforcement began in October, the Transit Authority and its parent, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said they intended to enforce strictly a ban on littering, panhandling and loitering. The program has lagged from the start. Police say for the record that they support Operation Enforcement, but privately they admit that in a transit system plagued by a record number of felonies last year, they have no energy or time to go after beggars or loiterers. Transit Authority officials insist that they are not persecuting the homeless; they point to programs they have launched to persuade homeless people in the subways _ a population estimated at 2,500 by the authority and at 4,000 to 5,000 by homeless advocates _ to find shelter elsewhere. Gilbert Morales, who lived in the subways for seven years, scoffs at any suggestion that authorities have the best interests of the homeless at heart. ``They just want to get the homeless out on the street,'' said Morales, who now has a home and a job as a messenger. ``If the city shelters were safer, people would get out of the train stations.'' Commuters, he said, never used the benches anyway. Many other homeless people said they didn't use the benches either _ that the tunnels and crannies of the subway system are more likely homes to the homeless. Mike, who has spent the past year in the subways, sat on a plastic milk crate in Grand Central Terminal, near the subway entrance. Mike, along with police and others, disputed assertions that the homeless left bodily waste on the benches. The best places to sleep are the tunnels, he said, despite warnings that the tunnels are dangerous. ``It's heated, brother, believe me. But you have to know where they are,'' Mike said. As for the removal of the benches, ``It ain't going to prove nothing, they're just going to sleep on the floor,'' Mike said. ``They ain't doing anything but hurting the commuters.'' Some commuters were eager to give up the seats. ``Take them out,'' said one woman who would not give her name. ``They're disgusting.'' But Sharon Gary, who lives near a station where benches have been removed, said the removal of the benches was horrible; the homeless, she said, caused no safety problem. Besides, she said, she had ``a real heavy backpack and I need some place to put it.'' ``They don't seem to have a policy. It's piecemeal,'' said Sidney Feldman, a communications consultant, as he passed through Grand Central. ``The basic problem is they don't have any place for the homeless to go where they feel safe. They just move them around.'' That, say homeless advocates like Summa, is the problem. Summa said that similar efforts to dislocate the homeless were unsuccessful in Grand Central, also run by the MTA, where benches were removed or closed off and ammonia poured into telephone booths to keep loiterers from settling in. ``Homeless people are still there,'' Summa said. ``The TA has to relearn everything that was learned at Grand Central.'' He said the only way to get rid of homeless people ``is to provide additional services, a decent place for them to go.''

DOC.HEAD: Ratings Sweeps Result in NBC's Eighth Victory
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, `The sweeps ...' to RESTORE dropped `of.'
DOC.TEXT: These are the prime times that try CBS' soul. Preliminary ratings from the just-ended February ``sweeps'' period show the network still in last place, facing its third consecutive season as No. 3. But as expected, first-place NBC scored its eighth straight victory in the sweeps, averaging a 15.1 rating, handily beating the 13.0 average of ABC. CBS averaged a 12.6. Each rating point represents 921,000 homes. The sweeps period that ended Wednesday is one of four periods of audience measurement in 211 cities by the A.C. Nielsen Co. The results are important to local stations, which use them to help set advertising rates. On Wednesday, Alan Wurtzel, ABC senior vice president for research, said the Nielsen returns he provided lacked the last two days of the February sweeps period, but ``I don't see any major changes'' in the outcome. He spoke at a news conference. Smiliar sessions to discuss the sweeps race are being held here today by NBC and ABC executives. Speaking of the ratings slide of the once-dominant ``CBS Evening News'' and the rise of ABC's ``World News Tonight,'' Wurtzel predicted that the latter's string of victories will continue. ABC's broadcast, anchored by Peter Jennings, has won the ratings race for seven consecutive weeks and been victorious in 19 of the last 20 weeks, according to ABC. ``The CBS Evening News'' with Dan Rather has been in third place for five of the last eight weeks, and tied once this year with Tom Brokaw's ``NBC Evening News'' for second place, CBS estimates show. ``In essence, what we see is that CBS and NBC will be fighting it out for second place position for some time to come,'' Wurtzel said. On another matter, he said it's simplistic to think that the Andy Rooney controversy and Rooney's suspension from CBS' ``60 Minutes'' caused that top-rated show's drop in the ratings for the past three weeks. Wurtzel said he had no research that would show if the dispute caused the decline, but ``it's very simplistic and one-dimensional to think that any one event triggers things like that. I think it's a much more complicated thing.'' On Feb. 8, CBS News suspended Rooney for three months without pay after a gay magazine attributed racial remarks to him. The humorist denied making any such statements. In ratings for the week before his suspension, ``60 Minutes'' was fifth. Then it slipped to 10th place, then 11th. Last week, it was No. 18, beaten in its time period Sunday by a rerun of the premiere of ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' However, Michael Eisenberg, a CBS research vice president, said that ABC's Sunday show drew viewers because ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' now a high-rated series, is ``a pretty hot show and would do well wherever you put it.'' He noted that ``60 Minutes'' still is sixth in ratings averages for the season to date, averaging a 20 rating and 33 per cent share of audience. Wurtzel ducked a question on whether he thought CBS' show is going to continue to decline in the ratings. Noting that ``60 Minutes'' has been on the air since 1968, he said it's ``still a strong show. But I don't think I'm surprised to see that there's been a certain amount of slippage.'' He cited as factors the cyclical nature of television and competition against CBS' newsmagazine series from ``an enormous proliferation of similar types of programs'' in recent months.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Democrats, GOP Protect Constituencies in Peace Dividend Fight
DOC.TEXT: Senate Democrats are the winners in the year's first congressional face-off over the ``peace dividend,'' as both parties signal they want to use the money to help their own core supporters. The chamber's majority Democrats won a pair of votes Wednesday on a topic expected to dominate this year's budget battle: what to do with funds siphoned from the Pentagon as the Cold War thaws. The so-called peace dividend would be used to whittle down the federal deficit, according to a Democratic measure the chamber adopted 79-19. That would make cuts in social programs _ which Democrats traditionally protect _ less likely as Congress seeks ways to reduce the federal deficit. Senators rejected 50-48 a Republican alternative that called for the money to be used for tax cuts. The GOP plan called for lowering the capital gains tax rate and extending corporate tax breaks for research, leading Democrats to label the proposal an effort to help the wealthy. Both measures were non-binding resolutions, meaning the votes were symbolic. But the afternoon's maneuverings highlighted the themes the two parties are likely to employ throughout the year. ``It's going to be up to Congress to carve out a peace dividend,'' said Sen. James Sasser, D-Tenn., a sponsor of the Democratic measure and chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. That was Sasser's way of chiding President Bush for proposing a Pentagon budget of $292.1 billion for fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1. That figure is $5.3 billion higher than this year's total, but $3.9 billion less than would be needed to stay even with inflation. Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, sponsor of the GOP proposal, argued that the Democratic plan simply would allow the government to spend the money. That would be ``a throwback to the failed policies of the past,'' Gramm said. Underpinning Wednesday's debate was the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction law, which Gramm helped write and which sets a $64 billion target for next year's budget shortfall. That means Congress and the White House will have to find about $37 billion in savings or face automatic spending cuts in most programs. If defense spending is cut and the money is used to reduce the deficit _ as Democrats want _ there would be less pressure to slash domestic programs. But if defense savings are distributed to taxpayers _ as the Republicans proposed _ there would be nowhere else to turn for savings but domestic programs. The rejected GOP proposal called for the savings to be ``returned to America's taxpayers'' in the form of lower tax rates, a refundable child care tax credit, a larger tax break for corporate research and development and other breaks. ``Who can we trust to invest in America's future, the federal government or the families of America?'' Gramm asked. But Democrats accused the GOP of favoring tax advantages for the rich. The Democratic plan said that besides deficit reduction, some savings should be spent on national problems such as education and drugs, and for tax breaks ``for working men and women.'' ``We need to take this peace dividend and we need to apply these funds wisely,'' Sasser said. The term ``peace dividend'' can be misleading. With the government running persistent deficits, reductions in the Pentagon's budget will not leave the government with surplus dollars to spend. The Congressional Budget Office projects next year's deficit will be $138 billion. Most Democrats and some Republicans want defense cut below Bush's proposal, but few of them want those reductions to exceed a few billion dollars next year. The savings will grow in coming years, however, as high-price weapons systems and other projects that take several years to build fall by the wayside. In the face of certain approval of the Democratic proposal, 25 Republicans joined 54 Democrats voting for passage. Seven Republicans then joined 43 Democrats in rejecting the GOP measure.

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas to the Pollsters, Oppositionists at the Polls
DOC.TEXT: U.S. pollsters who anticipated an election triumph for Daniel Ortega say they failed to take account of the distrust ordinary Nicaraguans might have for strangers with clipboards asking questions. Nor did U.S. policy-makers anticipate that the polls would turn out to be so skewed. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, in the days before Sunday's elections, allowed himself to be drawn into speculation about U.S. policy toward a post-election Ortega government. ``We shouldn't assume this,'' Baker said in an appearance before a congressional hearing, but he went on to lay out _ on the assumption that Ortega would win _ tough terms the Sandinistas would have to meet before normal relations could be restored. The expectation that Ortega would overwhelm his opponent, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, colored television coverage too. Said NBC's Ed Rabel from Managua on Feb. 21 over a picture of Ortega: ``This is the man, pollsters say, who will be elected overwhelmingly this weekend. ... The election observers say the Bush administration may have itself to blame for Daniel Ortega's rise in popularity among the votes. The reason, they say, is the U.S. military invasion in Panama. ... It was a close race until the U.S. invaded.'' ``Almost certainly,'' said Ted Koppel of ABC two nights later, ``the Sandinistas will still win.'' Post-election analysis showed that polls conducted by organizations from Venezuela, Argentina and Costa Rica correctly saw Mrs. Chamorro as the leader. In fact, The Washington Post noted, of 27 polls released in the last months of 1989 and this year, 14 showed the Sandinistas ahead and 13 gave the lead to Mrs. Chamorro's coalition. But the big American polls pointed to an Ortega landslide. The Washington Post-ABC News poll had Ortega leading by 48 percent to 32 percent with the rest scattered, undecided or unwilling to declare themselves. A poll conducted for the Spanish-language television network Univision had Ortega ahead 53-35. A poll conducted for Hemisphere Initiative, an observer group, by Greenberg-Lakes Associates put the Sandinistas in the lead, 44-27, in December and 51-34 in late January. When Nicaraguans voted Sunday, they turned those polls on their heads. Mrs. Chamorro won overwhelmingly, 55 percent to 41 percent. ``Many of the people we interviewed in Nicaragua were simply unwilling to allow themselves to be identified as an enemy of the Sandinista government,'' says Rob Schroth of Bendixen & Schroth, which took the Univision poll. ``In Nicaragua, the government plays a very major role in the everyday lives of the average citizen and people simply weren't going to take any chances that interviewers might be agents for the government,'' Schroth said. Then, too, the government prohibited the release of polls in the 30 days before the election, when anti-Sandinista sentiment may have been coalescing behind Mrs. Chamorro. Mark Penn, who has worked extensively in Latin America but did not poll in Nicaragua, said the situation was too unstable for accurate polling. ``Polling is helpful in a stable democracy but in a place where there is no history of democracy it is unreliable,'' he said. ``You are going to have to say there are limits to polling.'' Some analysts say the election was cast in pro- or anti-Sandinista terms with insufficient attention paid to economic discontent. ``No government associated with hyper-inflation is going to win an election,'' said Laurence Birns, executive director of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a liberal research group critical of U.S. policy toward Nicaragua. For all that, Birns miscalculated; he predicted a narrow Sandinista win. Pollster Stanley Greenberg of Greenberg-Lake Associates says Ortega may have lost the election in the last few weeks. ``He conducted a glitzy American-style campaign and it backfired,'' said Greenberg. Ortega put himself in a losing proposition, Greenberg said, by asking voters to choose between his own austere personality and Mrs. Chamorro's warmth. ``Our surveys showed a large bloc trying to preserve what the Sandinistas had brought and worrying that the opposition would turn the clock back, but once the Sandinista campaign centered on the cult of personality, once the advertising was rock music and the youth culture, I wonder if the campaign didn't trivialize the issues,'' Greenberg said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration Starting From Scratch on Nicaraguan Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Baker testifies 10 a.m. EST before House Appropriations foreign operations subcommittee; may be led
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is starting from scratch in devising a U.S. aid plan for Nicaragua because it did not expect opposition presidential candidate Violeta Chamorro to win, a senior official says. ``Nobody has a clue'' how much money is needed to get Mrs. Chamorro's new government started and help her impoverished country's economy begin to recover from a decade of war and misguided economic policies, said an administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``You've really got a basket case,'' the official said Wednesday. ``It's going to take a top-to-bottom look at what the government needs to get back on its feet.'' The Bush administration will begin by waiving trade sanctions imposed on Nicaragua in 1985 and perhaps other inexpensive and largely symbolic actions designed to indicate support for Mrs. Chamorro, the official said. Members of Congress have suggested the United States begin by pouring $200 million to $300 million into Nicaragua this year, but the administration will be unable to come up with its own recommendation before Mrs. Chamorro is sworn in as president April 25, the official said. Meanwhile, Secretary of State James A. Baker III, declared Wednesday in testimony on Capitol Hill that ``the war is over'' in Nicaragua despite lingering mistrust by longtime foes. President Bush held what he called a constructive telephone conversation with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on a range of issues that included Nicaragua. Bush said later in a speech that ``from Moscow to Managua, change is in the air.'' ``The world has undergone another upheaval, but this time there is no war and there are fewer tyrants in the world than before,'' Bush said at a San Francisco fund-raiser for Sen. Pete Wilson, R-Calif., who is running for governor. The president called Gorbachev _ whom the administration credits with playing an important role in encouraging free elections in Nicaragua _ a bold leader who was undertaking daring reforms. In Managua, officials began to address the problems of the country's first peaceful transfer of power to a democratically elected government, including how to demobilize the U.S.-backed Contra rebels who have been fighting the leftist government since 1981. President Daniel Ortega said in a Wednesday interview on the MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour that the Nicaraguan elections occurred under a threat from the United States. ``The U.S. was virtually saying to the Nicaraguan people `If you don't vote for UNO (the opposition), then the war and the economic sanctions are going to continue.''' In contrast, he said, the Soviet Union has been ``respectful of the sovereign decision of the Nicaraguan people.'' Ortega said the Sandinistas ``will support everything in the UNO government that is geared toward the national interests, toward the people's interests.'' Former President Jimmy Carter, who led a large election observer group and mediated between the two sides after the voting, met with Baker on Wednesday and called on the rebels to lay down their arms. Carter said what happens to the Contras was ``the key unresolved factor'' in Nicaragua. ``If you have an army on the edge of your country or in your country that still threatens military action, that's obviously a very destabilizing factor,'' Carter told reporters. ``I don't think there is going to be a guarantee of an orderly transition as long as the Contras are a military force threatening the country.'' Baker, in his testimony Wednesday, noted that a bipartisan policy agreement between the administration and Congress last year called for ``voluntary reintegration'' of the rebels under safe and democratic conditions. With Sunday's election victory by Mrs. Chamorro and a request by her and Ortega for the rebels to disband, Baker said, ``those conditions are now rapidly being created.'' However, he added that years of distrust had produced ``legitimate fears on both sides that should be addressed.'' Baker said he hoped Roman Catholic Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo in Managua ``would be able to play a role in resolving this issue,'' along with the United Nations and the Organization of American States. Carter also seemed optimistic. Having spoken with most of the Sandinista leaders, including Defense Minister Humberto Ortega, Carter said the Chamorro-led National Opposition Union and the Sandinistas were working harmoniously on a transition of power. Carter said the Sandinistas acknowledged the results of the election, as well as Mrs. Chamorro's right to choose her own ministers of defense and interior, which control the army and security forces. Still, he said the Contras, who fought with American weapons and money to bring down the Sandinistas, had ``legitimate concerns that must be met.''

DOC.HEAD: Proposed Panama Aid Program Too Large, Panel Chairman Says
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's request for an emergency $500 million to restart Panama's stalled economy is catching trouble from several directions on Capitol Hill even before it comes up for formal consideration. Bush requested the aid in a Feb. 6 letter to House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., proposig to pay for the assistance by borrowing from several Pentagon accounts. But the proposal ran into problems with members of Congress whose pet defense programs and projects would be affected by the money transfer, and that sent the bill back to the drawing board. ``There were massive problems, up and down the list,'' said one administration official, speaking on condition of anonymity. But the official said the attempted cuts of congressional projects had been ``no accident.'' On Wednesday, Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee which deals with foreign aid, vowed that he would cut the aid sharply because it was too much to give to Panama. ``I guarantee you that's not going to happen,'' Leahy said, referring to the aid package. ``There will be no half a billion dollars in that supplemental'' for Panama. ``I wouldn't support that, and I'm not sure many others will,'' he said in an interview. ``Nobody ever asked anybody up here (on Capitol Hill), do you think it's a good idea? I think somebody just had a speech to make.'' He added: ``I'm getting very, very concerned that our foreign policy, especially in the foreign aid area, is being conducted more on symbolism than on what should be the goals of the United States.'' Leahy said lawmakers would prefer to give some of the money, if it is available, to emerging new democracies in Eastern Europe. And he would like to see more go to meet humanitarian needs in Africa, Leahy said. He said he told Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger the administration should put the brakes on making aid promises to new democratic governments, including the newly elected opposition coalition in Nicaragua. As far as Panama is concerned, Congress will expect to see progress made toward reforming the country's tight bank secrecy laws that have provided cover for drug money laundering, and toward a new and more benign role for the Panama Defense Forces, Leahy said. The supplemental appropriation measure for Panama likely will be an attractive target for lawmakers looking for a must-pass vehicle for other pet proposals. Leahy and Sen. Robert Kasten, R-Wis., want to add $400 million in credits for Israel to build housing for an influx of Soviet emigres. And Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., announced plans Wednesday to add $125 million to encourage farmers in Peru, Bolivia and Colombia to grow something besides the coca leaf used to make cocaine. Despite the problems, the Bush administration believes it eventually will win passage of some money to help Panama pay past-due debts and restart its stalled economy. ``We'll get less than we wanted, but more than (Leahy) wants to give us,'' the administration official said.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutors Issue New Subpoenas in Barry Case
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors are pressing their investigation of Mayor Marion Barry by issuing a new series of subpoenas for city records, as Barry prepares for a June trial on charges of cocaine possession and perjury. Barry pleaded innocent Wednesday to five misdemeanor cocaine charges and three felony perjury counts at a federal court arraignment. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson scheduled a June 4 trial. ``We will not plea bargain, and the mayor is not considering resigning,'' Barry's attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, said after the nine-minute court proceeding. ``The mayor is confident he will be vindicated at trial.'' U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens would not comment on the possibility of a plea bargain, but said the probe was continuing ``with respect to a variety of allegations'' involving Barry and various city services. Meanwhile, a top city government source said prosecutors have delivered subpoenas to ``at least a dozen'' city agencies that have had dealings with eight of Barry's close friends. The city records of those Barry associates were subpoenaed last week. The new subpoenas were issued to determine whether there were any irregularities in any contracts the mayor's friends have received, sources said. Subpoenas were also issued Wednesday for a number of Barry's telephone records, including the period surrounding Barry's arrest at a downtown Washington hotel in January, a top city government source said. The subpoenas for the mayor's office and car telephone records include the periods from Jan. 1, 1988, through March 31, 1988, and Jan. 1, 1989, through Jan. 23, 1990, the source said. Barry was arrested and charged with cocaine possession in an FBI sting at a downtown Washington hotel Jan. 18. He left for a Florida substance abuse treatment center Jan. 22. The mayor is now enrolled in a substance abuse treatment program at the Fenwick Hall hospital outside Charleston, S.C. A senior Barry aide who spoke on condition of anonymity said Barry, who returned to Washington on Tuesday, was returning to South Carolina on Wednesday. Mundy said the mayor's treatment for alcoholism was going well and that Barry was in good spirits. Barry, 53, did not speak to reporters as he entered and left the courthouse. All but one of the charges stem from a 14-month investigation into Barry's ties to convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis, who has testified that he supplied the mayor with crack cocaine in December 1988. One possession charge involved the mayor's sting operation arrest in January. If convicted of all charges, Barry could face a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison and a $1.25 million fine. Before Barry's arrival at the courthouse Wednesday, 18 Guardian Angels paraded outside. Many carried signs reading, ``Mr. Mayor, do the right thing _ resign.'' All chanted: ``Barry, it's the time, it's time for you to resign.''

DOC.HEAD: DA Says No Criminal Charges Against Covenant House Founder
DOC.TEXT: The Manhattan district attorney says no charges will be brought against the Rev. Bruce Ritter despite dubious financial dealings by the founder of the nation's largest network of runaway shelters. The Roman Catholic priest resigned as head of Covenant House on Tuesday amid allegations of financial and sexual misconduct involving young runaways. Ritter, 62, was involved in ``some questionable financial transactions'' in his expenditures for a male prostitute, District Attorney Robert Morgenthau said Wednesday. Morgenthau also said the law may have been violated when Covenant House supplied the 26-year-old prostitute, Kevin Kite, with a false identity using the papers of a dead 10-year-old. But in neither circumstance was there enough evidence to file charges, said Morgenthau, who declined to elaborate on what his investigators found to be questionable in Ritter's financial dealings. Morgenthau said he was not concerned with sexual misconduct because Kite is an adult and the allegations involving other youths were beyond the statute of limitations. The sexual allegations are the subject of a church investigation. Nothing in the probe ``cast into doubt the merits of Covenant House's programs, which are widely _ and deservedly _ praised,'' Morgenthau said. ``Although Covenant House has had to endure a brief period of adversity, I am confident that it will emerge from this episode a stronger and more effective organization,'' he said. Ritter first put a few runaways up at his apartment in 1968. Covenant House now has 17 shelters in the United States, Canada and Latin America that care for 25,000 children. Nearly all of its $85 million budget comes from donations. A private audit has concluded that money spent on Kite was properly documented and appeared to be appropriate to Covenant House's mission. Former New York schools chancellor Frank Macchiarola, who had been running Convenant House since Ritter took a leave of absence Feb. 6, also resigned Tuesday. Macchiarola said he was forced out because he advocated outside investigations into allegations of wrongdoing at Covenant House. ``I was the guy with the light and they said, you know what, it's too bright in here,'' he said. But board chairman Ralph A. Pfeiffer Jr. said the board has begun implementing Macchiarola's suggestions, including an audit and an investigation by a former law enforcement official of any allegations concerning Covenant House staff. The board named James J. Harnett, the executive vice president, to run the organization until a permanent successor is found. Published reports have said contributions to Covenant House have dropped since the allegations against Ritter surfaced, but Harnett said the organization was in good financial condition.
