DOC.HEAD: Commodity Price Index Down
DOC.TEXT: Sharp declines for milk and eggs helped push down the Agriculture Department's monthly commodity price index in February, according to preliminary figures. Lower prices for lettuce and wheat also contributed to last month's drop of 0.6 percent from the January average, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said Wednesday. Even so, the index averaged 2.7 percent above the year-earlier level. Higher prices for cattle, broilers and tomatoes partly offset the decline for the other commodities during the month. ``Tomato prices for February were at the highest level of records,'' the report said. ``During the past two months prices have been about twice the previous record established in March of 1985.'' The price climb was due to short supplies caused by the December freeze in Florida in December, the report said. The drop in milk prices paid to farmers, which had been at record levels, was the largest month-to-month decline ever recorded. The egg price drop was said to be the third-largest on record. The report did not include new figures on farm expenses, which are computed every three months. In January, however, new quarterly figures showed that prices paid by farmers were up 1.1 percent from October, the previous reading, and averaged 2.9 percent more than a year earlier. Department economists say the net cash income of farmers in 1990 may be in the range of $52 billion to $57 billion, compared with about $53 billion in 1989. Net cash income is the money nationally that farmers have left from gross cash income during a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year. In another method taking into account changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during a calendar year shows that 1990 net farm income may be in a range of $44 billion to $49 billion, compared with $48 billion last year. Consumer food prices are forecast by USDA economists to rise 3 percent to 5 percent this year after posting an average gain of 5.7 percent in 1989, the sharpest rise since 1981. Based on the preliminary figures, the February price index for livestock and poultry was down 0.6 percent from January but was up 8.2 percent from February 1989. Milk prices dropped 80 cents from January to $14.90 per 100 pounds but were still $1.80 more than a year ago.

Food processors will have to be more specific on their labels when certain flavorings are used in meat and poultry products, the Agriculture Department says. Federal rules are being changed, effective today, to require ``proteinaceous material'' derived from livestock, poultry, eggs, milk, plants and yeast to be listed on labels by their names. In the past, such substances could be listed simply as ``flavorings'' or similar terms. For example, a popular ``flavor agent'' or enhancer used for years in hot dogs will have to be labeled ``milk protein hydrolyzate.'' Lester M. Crawford, administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service, said Wednesday that the new rule, proposed in August 1987, was adopted ``to better protect the public health and serve the consumer's right to know'' what's in food products. ``For many years, the agency has required labels for meat and poultry products to list all ingredients,'' he said. ``However, an exception was made to allow `natural flavoring' and similar terms to designate substances which are often added as flavor enhancers, emulsifiers, stabilizers, binders, extenders and nutrient sources in products such as frankfurters and bologna.'' Crawford said the exception was allowed because the additives were primarily flavorings in meat and poultry products and did not make a significant nutritional contribution. But he said the agency's ``paramount concern is public health'' and that it was found some people can have severe allergic reactions to those substances. ``The agency is also concerned about a marked increase in the use of these ingredients during the last decade,'' Crawford said. ``Some manufacturers may be using the substances inappropriately as low-cost meat replacements.'' Now, he said, consumers with allergies to certain substances can tell if the product contains those ingredients. Crawford said meat and poultry processors will be allowed to make label changes over six months, although the agency is working closely with the companies to speed it up. At least one company is adding a stick-on label to its regular packaging to further define the product ingredients, he said.

China has bought an additional 160,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat under an Agriculture Department price-subsidy program. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said Wednesday that three private exporting companies made the deals under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Delivery of the wheat is scheduled for June, he said. The sales were part of 1 million tons authorized China under EEP on Feb. 8. Previous allocations had been exhausted except for 1,050 tons. Under EEP arrangements, private exporters can sell U.S. commodities at reduced prices and then collect free government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest subsidies averaged $6.95 per ton, or about 19 cents per bushel. The subsidized sales were handled by Central States Enterprises Inc., 40,000 tons; Continental Grain Co., 29,700; and Cargill Inc., 90,000.

DOC.HEAD: Chamorro Insists On Civilian Control of Armed Forces
DOC.TEXT: President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro is insisting the Sandinistas ``turn over everything,'' including control of the army, but the opposition appears to be backing down on its plan to denationalize the banks. ``I'm the one who is going to give orders,'' Mrs. Chamorro said Wednesday at her first news conference since she upset the leftist Sandinistas in Sunday's elections. Mrs. Chamorro made it clear that Gen. Humberto Ortega, President Daniel Ortega's brother, would not be kept on as defense minister. She did not say whether he would lose his rank or his second post as commander of the army. ``They have to turn over everything,'' she said, adding that ``the minister of defense will be a civilian.'' The leader of the victorious opposition coalition spoke as transition talks began between teams headed by Humberto Ortega and Antonio Lacayo, Mrs. Chamorro's son-in-law and campaign manager. Control of the armed forces is a key issue for the transition teams to settle before Mrs. Chamorro is inaugurated April 25 for a six-year term. It appeared her United National Opposition (UNO) had decided to give in on another key issue when a top aide said UNO would accede to Sandinista insistence on keeping the banking system under government control. ``The banks will stay nationalized,'' Francisco Mayorga, an economic adviser to Mrs. Chamorro, said in an interview. Privatizing the banks had been one of UNO's campaign planks, but on Tuesday the Sandinistas outlined a series of positions for transition negotiations that opposed that plan. UNO's platform also calls for selling off many inefficient state-owned companies and freeing the economy from state restrictions, moves the Sandinistas oppose. Mayorga said he would travel to the United States seeking funds to help Nicaragua climb out of an economic tailspin. Due in part to a U.S. trade embargo that the Bush administration now says it will lift, Nicaragua became one of the poorest nations in the Western Hemisphere during the 1980s. Negotiations over the military may be a more difficult problem, with UNO insisting on at least the appearance of control. President Ortega and his party have insisted army and security forces must maintain their strength and their political connection to the Sandinista party, especially while the U.S.-backed Contra rebels are still a threat. Both Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro have called on the Contras to disband immediately, but the Contras have said they will not disband until Mrs. Chamorro takes office. ``The causes of civil war in Nicaragua have disappeared,'' she told the news conference. By government count, about 60,000 people have been killed or wounded in the 9-year-old war. Meanwhile, Ortega said he had ordered a halt in offensive military operations, restoring a cease-fire that had ended Nov. 1. Ortega said the United States should help pay for demobilizing and resettling the 10,000-man Contra army, which is based in neighboring Honduras. U.S. funding for the Contras ran out Wednesday, although there are probably enough supplies in the pipeline to keep aid flowing at least a month or more. The United States has provided only non-lethal aid to the Contras since February 1988. Former President Jimmy Carter, who had been serving as a mediator between the Sandinistas and UNO, returned Wednesday to the United States but other members of international observer teams remained behind. Former U.S. Attorney General Elliot Richardson dismissed UNO complaints that the Sandinistas were trying to rig the vote in the National Assembly to prevent UNO from getting the 60 percent it needs to make constitutional changes. ``Everything is normal,'' he said. Current projections show UNO getting 52 seats in the assembly to 39 for the Sandinistas, including a seat for Ortega as a losing presidential candidate who received more than 1 percent of the vote. One other presidential loser, Moises Hassan of the Revolutionary Unity Movement, was on the edge of 1 percent; if he makes the cut the legislature will number 92. The atmosphere in Managua appeared to relax as it became clear the two sides were getting down to business, but in the city of Masaya about 3,000 Sandinistas held a three-hour march Wednesday night. The demonstrators, waving flags and wearing the red-and-black neckerchiefs that symbolize the Sandinista movement, chanted ``Traitors to the firing squad!'' and ``They betrayed Daniel!'' as they marched through the streets. Masaya, 18 miles southeast of Managua, is considered the cradle of the Sandinista revolution that overthrew dictator Anastasio Somoza in 1979. At least two people that the crowd suspected to be UNO supporters were roughed up during the march, but no serious injuries were reported.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 33,829.58, down 762.41 points, or 2.20 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Ag Official Say Low-Dose Irradiation Could Reduce Contamination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Embargoed for release 6:30 a.m. EST; time set by source
DOC.TEXT: A senior Agriculture Department official said today that low-dose irradiation of meat and poultry could help reduce contamination of the U.S. food supply by bacteria and other organisms. ``The U.S. government does not believe its role is to advocate food irradiation over other technologies,'' said Lester M. Crawford, administrator of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service. ``However, we do view it as a viable method for ensuring a safe and wholesome food supply, and want to ensure that food processors have access to it.'' Crawford's remarks were in a speech prepared for delivery today at a conference in London. A text was released here by the agency. The Food and Drug Administration is expected to approve irradiation for poultry products sometime in March, said Jim Greene, a spokesman for Crawford. No irradiated meat or poultry products are sold in the United States, Crawford said. Federal approval was granted in 1986 for the treatment of fresh or previously frozen pork to control trichinae, microscopic parasites that can cause trichinosis if contaminated pork isn't cooked properly. ``Since that time, no firm has expressed an interest in irradiating pork,'' he said. `` Therefore, further development of the (USDA) regulations has been halted.'' Crawford said his agency filed a petition with FDA in late 1986 asking for approval of ``ionizing radiation on packaged, fresh or frozen poultry to reduce some food-borne pathogens'' such as salmonella, a common micro-organism that can cause food poisoning. ``We filed the petition because microbial reduction on raw products could have an important public health benefit, and a technology with that potential deserves close attention and study,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Law Enforcement Officials Hail Opinion on Foreign Searches
DOC.TEXT: Law enforcement officials, including a prosecutor of ousted Panamanian leader Manuel Noriega, are hailing a Supreme Court ruling that bolsters U.S. authority to conduct searches in foreign countries. ``Drug traffickers and terrorists will take no cheer from the court's opinion,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said after Wednesday's decision. The ruling, he said, ``recognizes the right and need of law enforcement officers to have lawful, practical means of dealing with international drug trafficking operations.'' The court said U.S. agents don't need warrants from American judges to search the homes of non-U.S. citizens living abroad. ``We're happy to see it come,'' said U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen in Miami, whose office is prosecuting Noriega. ``It's generally known that that's our position in the Noriega case, and it's good news that the rules won't change.'' Noriega surrendered after U.S. troops invaded Panama in December in an effort to capture him. Noriega was brought to the United States to stand trial on drug-trafficking and money-laundering charges. There has been speculation Noriega's lawyers might argue that U.S. armed forces illegally seized evidence in the invasion. Noriega defense attorney Steven Kollin said Wednesday before reading the court opinion that it apparently would not apply directly to Noriega's arrest, only material seized during searches in Panama by U.S. authorities. The justices, by a 6-3 vote, upheld the warrantless search of the home of a suspected Mexican drug smuggler. But some civil libertarians said the ruling does not give U.S. agents a free hand to raid the homes of foreigners living abroad. Opinions by some justices suggest there might be five votes to throw out evidence if agents act unreasonably, said Steven Shapiro of the American Civil Liberties Union. ``It's a mistake to read it as carte blanche for authorities to do whatever they want,'' he said, adding it the ruling is still disappointing. ``Our view is that when American agents seize evidence for use in an American trial in an American courtroom that can lead to imprisonment in an American jail their behavior should be subject to constitutional review,'' Shapiro said. In other rulings Wednesday, the court: _Gave police broad new authority to conduct sweeping searches in this country after making arrests in private homes. Voting 7-2 in a Maryland case, the justices said police may search a house when they have a reasonable suspicion there is a hidden danger to the arresting officers _ even if authorities lack a search warrant or probable cause to believe there is a danger. _Said states may make the death penalty the only punishment for some murderers without violating the Constitution's ban on mandatory death sentences. The court, by a 5-4 vote, upheld a Pennsylvania law. In the drug-smuggling case, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist said constitutional protection against unreasonable searches and seizures does not apply to foreign property of aliens. ``Situations threatening to important American interests may arise halfway around the globe ... (that) require an American response with armed force,'' he said. ``If there are to be restrictions on searches and seizures which occur incident to such American action, they must be imposed by the political branches through diplomatic understanding, treaty or legislation.'' Justice William J. Brennan, in a dissenting opinion, said: ``If we expect aliens to obey our laws, aliens should be able to expect that we will obey our Constitution when we investigate, prosecute and punish them. Lawlessness breeds lawlessness.'' The court ruled against suspected drug smuggler Rene Verdugo Urquidez, convicted in California in 1988 of taking part in the 1985 kidnapping, torture and murder of DEA agent Enrique Camarena and his pilot. The search warrant issue arose in a separate but related, prosecution in which the DEA searched his home in Mexicali, Mexico, in 1988 with cooperation of Mexican authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Warns That Infant Mortality May Increase
DOC.TEXT: The nation's infant mortality rate may rise sharply if poor health trends aren't reversed, a national panel says. ``The negative maternal and child health trends of the 1980s cast a shadow on our children's future,'' said former Sen. Lawton Chiles, a Florida Democrat who is chairman of the bipartisan National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality. Smoking, drinking and drug use by pregnant women caused a significant part of the infant death problem, the independent panel said in a report Wednesday. Lives and money could be saved if greater access to prenatal and pediatric care were provided to pregnant women and young children, the report said. ``Progress in reducing infant mortality has stalled,'' Chiles said. ``In the 1990s, we may see more infants die per year than the 40,000 we now lose before their first birthdays.'' The report said progress in reducing the infant mortality rate slowed from 4.7 percent per year in the 1970s to 2.7 percent per year in the 1980s. It also cited: _An increased number of high-risk pregnant women. Use of crack cocaine, women with AIDS and syphilis, and births to unmarried mothers all increased during the 1980s. A 1988 survey found 11 percent of pregnant women use illegal drugs. _An increase in the black-white infant mortality gap. Black infant mortality has been twice the white rate for years, and recently the black rate has declined at a slower pace, resulting in a widening of the gap. _Low birthweight infants. There was no improvement in the 1980s in the percentage of infants born under 5.5 pounds. _Inadequate prenatal care. The number of women obtaining late or no prenatal care increased between 1980 and 1987. The increase was 17 percent for whites and 26 percent for blacks. In 1987, more than 74,000 pregnant women received no prenatal care _ a 50 percent increase over the 1980 rate. The commission cited figures showing the United States ranked 20th among developed countries in the rate of infant mortality in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Some Drug Companies Offered Illegal Gratuities, Testimony Shows
DOC.TEXT: Transcripts of testimony by a former Food and Drug Administration official paint a picture of illegal gratuities and bribe attempts by some generic drug companies trying to get their products approved. Martin Seife, former director of the FDA's generic drug division, told a House investigations subcommittee that in 1974 he was sent a $300 color television set by a generic drug company. He returned the TV set. He also told the panel of two instances in which FDA employees were given envelopes of cash _ ``many thousand dollar bills'' in one case _ by a consultant to a generic drug company. Seife testified in secret before the House Energy and Commerce investigations subcommittee May 3, before he retired from the FDA. He was a principal source for the subcommittee, which uncovered fraud and bribery in the FDA's generic drug division and has led to convictions of three generic drug company executives and three former FDA employees. Of the 1974 incident, Seife said he received a package in the mail at his home from Bolar Pharmaceutical Co. Inc. of Copiague, N.Y., and when he unwrapped it, he was ``shocked and chagrined'' to find a color TV set. He said he sent it back immediately and ``nobody ever approached me in this manner again.'' Included in the transcripts was a letter to Seife from Robert Shulman, then president of Bolar, apologizing ``for an unfortunate incident that I'm sure embarrassed both of us.'' Shulman recently resigned as president and chief executive officer but remains on Bolar's board. The letter explained: ``I just meant to say thank you to someone I felt had shown us some understanding and compassion that he didn't have to.'' Eugene Pfeifer, a Washington, D.C., attorney representing Bolar, said he was aware of the incident but added, ``We have no reason to believe it was a practice. ... We're not aware of anything else like that.'' Such a gift would be considered an illegal gratuity. Though the statute of limitations on prosecution has expired, the transcripts have been turned over to the U.S. attorney in Baltimore for determination of whether it represents part of a pattern of conduct, said a subcommittee source who spoke on condition of anonymity. Seife said two FDA employees reported attempts to bribe them by a generic drug company consultant. In one of the cases, the man ``dropped an envelope with many thousand dollar bills'' on the desk of one of the agency's consumer safety officers in early February 1988. The safety officer, Harvey Greenberg, ``became quite dismayed and chased this fellow into the men's room and stuffed the envelope back in his pocket,'' and reported the incident to Seife the next day, Seife said. Greenberg has appeared before a federal grand jury in Baltimore that has been investigating the generic drug scandal. The scandal became public last spring. The investigation also uncovered evidence that some drug companies had cheated on FDA potency tests, which prompted recalls of dozens of generic drugs, including both generic versions of the widely prescribed high blood pressure drug Dyazide. Bolar recalled its version of Dyazide in January after the company's lawyers said documents supporting claims about the drug appeared to be falsified.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Says Indian Remains Belong With Tribes
DOC.TEXT: The skeletal remains of Indians belong with their tribes, say panel members who spent a year trying to settle the controversy about who has the right to bones and burial objects held by museums. ``I am told that at the outset the positions of tribal leaders and the museum community were worlds apart,'' Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Indian Affairs, said at a Wednesday news conference announcing the panel's findings. The panel was appointed after anthropologists joined the American Association of Museums two years ago in opposing legislation that would have returned the remains and objects to tribes. After a year of discussions, the panel is proposing Congress pass a law to assure that remains are handled properly. The process, Inouye said, would emphasize that ``respect for Indian and native human rights is the paramount principle to govern repatriation claims.'' Under the process suggested by the panel, tribal leaders would request the remains and burial artifacts they know to belong to their ancestors. Museums are expected to comply. The panel also said museums should start inventories of Indian remains and materials and begin talking to tribes about repatriation. President Bush signed a bill in November requiring the Smithsonian Institution to return the remains it holds to the proper tribes. ``Unfortunately, the old policies of the rest of the federal government, as well as non-federal museums or similar institutions which receive federal funds, are not affected by this law,'' said panel member Walter Echo-Hawk. ``These agencies and institutions continue to remain free to withhold untold thousands of native dead from proper reburial by their tribes and peoples of origin.'' Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., who oversaw the work of the panel, said the report and recommendations would make it possible to proceed with legislation. However, a McCain aide said no bill had been written. McCain said the group didn't reach full consensus on repatriation of remains and objects from tribes that no longer exist. ``We will continue to try to resolve this issue,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall, Dollar Rises Sharply in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plunged again Thursday while the dollar rose sharply against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 762.41 points, or 2.20 percent, to close at 33,829.58. The dollar closed at 149.78 yen, up 1.26 yen from Wednesday's close of 148.52 yen. After opening at 149.35 yen, the currency moved in a range of 149.35-149.90 yen. ``The largest concern among market players is the foreign exchange situation,'' said Yoshiro Inoue of Nomura Securities Co. In addition to the weaker yen, securities dealers attributed the fall in the Nikkei to profit-taking by investors, who took advantage of gains in the previous two days. ``There was substantial selling by those eager to unload their holdings which were badly depreciated during the stock market debacle in the past week,'' said Ichitaro Watanabe of Nikko Securities Co. Share prices on the world's most affluent market made a dramatic recovery over the last two days after Monday's second-largest single-day plunge. On Wednesday, the stock market's leading indicator had gained 694.04 points, or 2.04 percent, topping a 576.08-point rise on Tuesday. On Monday, the index fell 1,569.10 points, its worst since the October 1987 ``Black Monday'' global crash. The index is down more than 10 percent this year. Falling Japanese government bond prices also discouraged stock investors, Inoue said. Lower bond prices boost interest rates, which makes stock investment less attractive. However, he said there weren't many aggressive sellers during the morning and that there was no notable amount of arbitrage selling. Analysts have blamed computer-aided arbitrage selling, which profits from price gaps between actual stocks and stock-index futures, for the market's recent decline. The Tokyo Stock Exchange advised 10 foreign and domestic major securities firms after Monday's big drop not to file arbitrage-sell orders after trading sessions begin if the indicator is falling. In the currency market, dealers said the dollar's sharply higher opening was a carry-over from its overnight surge on overseas markets. In New York, the dollar rose to 149.08 yen, up from 148.73 late Tuesday as traders. ``The dollar is higher not only against the yen but also against almost all the other major currencies,'' said a trader with the Bank of Tokyo, speaking on condition of anonymity. Market players are trying to see how much higher they can push it, he said. In the preceding six trading days, it had climbed a total of 4.51 yen, reaching its highest level since last June. Falling Japanese government bond prices resulting from the yen's continuing plunge and the stock market's downswing this morning also made the yen less attractive to investors, he said. ``The dollar is likely to rise to around 150-yen before long,'' the trader added. The Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, has been intervening heavily in recent days, selling dollars in an attempt to support the yen. The bank does not officially comment on its monetary actions. An official at the central bank said the bank will continue to intervene for the time being, but ``we will consider other measures as deemed necessary'' to stem the fall of the yen, Kyodo News Service reported.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Stethoscope as Good as Electronic Monitor During Childbirth
DOC.TEXT: In a confirmation of time-honored ways, a study today concludes that the old-fashioned stethoscope is just as good as electronic monitors _ and maybe even better _ for checking babies during birth. The researchers found signs that cerebral palsy may be more common among infants whose births are electronically monitored, possibly because the monitors led doctors to wait longer before acting to rescue a baby in distress. But they cautioned that this finding could be a statistical fluke. Experts said, moreover, that monitors are likely to remain in use, in part because they require less manpower in the delivery room. Electronic fetal monitors were introduced in the early 1970s and now are a fixture of delivery rooms everywhere. Still, doctors have only recently begun rigorous testing to see if the machines help produce healthier babies. ``It's our view that although widely used, electronic fetal monitoring during labor and delivery of high-risk infants appears to have no effect on children's survival or neurological health,'' said Dr. Kirkwood K. Shy of the University of Washington in Seattle. His study, published in today's New England Journal of Medicine, was performed at the University of Washington Hospital in Seattle, Grace Hospital in Vancouver, British Columbia, and Madigan Army Hospital in Tacoma, Wash. The monitors are used to listen to the unborn baby's heart. The electronic blip-blip of the fetal heartbeat is typically broadcast through the delivery room. If abnormalities are heard, doctors may choose to rescue the baby with a Caesarean section or forceps. Dr. Benjamin Sachs of Boston's Beth Israel Hospital called the latest findings ``very significant,'' but added: ``It's unlikely that the fetal monitor will be abandoned. We have an enormous investment in fetal monitoring equipment and a whole generation of physicians who have been trained in the technique.'' In addition, he said, a monitor requires fewer nurses than the more laborious practice of regularly checking with stethoscopes, so ``it is cheaper and more efficient.'' Shy notes that in part, the successful use of stethoscopes results from two decades of experience with electronic monitors. The two methods provide essentially the same information, and the wide use of electronic monitors has taught doctors what warning signs they need to listen for with their stethoscopes. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists advises that mothers giving high-risk births have either continuous electronic monitoring or be checked with stethoscopes every 15 minutes in the first stage of labor and every five minutes in the second stage. The latest study was conducted on 93 children whose mothers had been randomly assigned to undergo electronic monitoring or checking with stethoscopes. All their babies were premature and weighed less than four pounds. Tests of mental and physical development showed that the babies in both groups were about the same 18 months after birth. But 20 percent of the babies in the electronically monitored group had suffered cerebral palsy, compared with 8 percent of those checked with stethoscopes. Cerebral palsy is partial loss of muscle control that can result from many causes, including brain damage during birth. Whether the premature babies in the electronic monitoring group suffered this condition more often because of poor blood flow to the brain during birth is unclear. However, doctors were quicker to perform Caesareans when they heard heartbeat abnormalities through their stethoscopes than on the electronic monitors. On average, electronically monitored babies in distress were delivered about 45 minutes later than were those checked with stethoscopes. ``We can only conjecture'' why doctors waited longer with electronic monitoring, Shy said. ``One explanation is that somehow the presence of information given from a machine was overly reassuring in the labor room.'' He added that because only 23 children in the study had cerebral palsy, ``we can't exclude the possibility that the result may have occurred on the basis of chance alone.''

DOC.HEAD: Kohl: Germanys Should Make Formal Declarations Supporting Polish Border
DOC.TEXT: Seeking to soothe domestic and international critics, Chancellor Helmut Kohl says he recognizes Poland's desire for a legal guarantee that a united Germany would not seek to return to its prewar borders. However, Kohl on Wednesday night reiterated his view that only the government of a reiunified Germany could have final say about a possible treaty giving formal German recognition of the current border. Speaking in an interview with East German television Wednesday night, Kohl seemed annoyed over worries, even among his allies, about his stance on the border issue. ``In many speeches I have said that no one wants to connect the unity of the Germans with moving the borders. I don't know what more I can say,'' Kohl said. Kohl has come under sharp criticism abroad and at home for what is seen as an unclear position on lands east of the Oder and Neisse rivers once held by Germany and now part of Poland. The land _ about one-third of present-day Poland _ was awarded to Poland after the defeat in 1945 of Adolf Hitler's Third Reich. In an apparent effort not to alienate his most conservative constituents, Kohl has never formally stated that a united Germany would not lay claim to that land and this is viewed as a major difficulty in the unification process. Poland, the United States and Britain, among others, have expressed concern over what they consider Kohl's lack of action. Kohl, apparently seeking to ease the criticism, told his Cabinet Wednesday he ``understands the Polish wish for a legally binding recognition'' of Poland's western borders, said government spokesman Dieter Vogel. The chancellor also said he sees the possibility that after East Germany's elections on March 18, the parliaments of both Germanys could issue declarations on the matter, said Vogel. Vogel said such a declaration could confirm a resolution already passed by the West German parliament on Nov. 8 stating that Germans ``neither now nor in the future'' will attempt to change the border. Kohl said only that the ``highest sovereign German power in the case of reunification'' could conclude such a treaty. He also dismissed any fears of the rise of a ``Fourth Reich'' as ``rubbish.'' ``The Germans are completely immersed in international responsibility,'' Kohl said. Kohl has sought to allay the worries of Poles, whose country was devastated by the Nazis, but at the same time has insisted that only a united Germany could take an official stand on the border issue. The opposition Social Democrats have charged that with such pronouncements, Kohl is endangering international support for German unification. Hans-Jochen Vogel, head of the Social Democrats, said Wednesday that Kohl's statements about the border issue have been ``irresponsible and detrimental ... to German interests.'' At the other end of the argument is West Germany's 2 million-strong Association of Exiles, which says it would take legal action if a united Germany formally recognized Poland's western border. In East Germany, the president of the government-run bank announced Wednesday that it planned to switch to a Western-style banking system, with an autonomous central bank aiming for monetary stability by controlling the monetary supply. Such a move would make it more compatible with West Germany's Bundesbank and other Western European central banks. Horst Kaminsky's comments were carried by ADN, the East German news agency. Since ousting hard-line Communist rulers last fall, East Germans have adopted economic reforms to encourage free enterprise and foreign investment and facilitate better integration with West Germany's economy.

DOC.HEAD: Reform Effort Tested as Councils Fire Principals
DOC.TEXT: The city's sweeping education reform effort is getting its first major test as principals learn whether they're being rehired or fired by parents. Although the process is being declared a success at most schools, teachers and students in the nation's third-largest school system are protesting some firings, and accusations of backroom deals and bigotry have surfaced. These disruptions have raised doubts about the effectiveness of the councils that were elected in October as part of a package to improve Chicago's troubled schools by putting more power in the hands of local communities. Under the 1988 reform law, half the 540 community councils _ one for each of the 71 high schools and 469 elementary schools _ decide this year whether to terminate their principals' four-year contracts. The 270 other councils vote on their principals next year. About 10 percent of the principals under consideration are expected to lose their jobs, said School Board spokesman Ken Moses. The councils have until April 15 to announce their decisions. The School Board said it has no figures on how many principals have been notified so far. The reform law was passed because of the double-digit dropout rate, poor test scores, violence and other ills that led William Bennett, then the federal education secretary, to label Chicago's school system as the nation's worst in 1987. The councils consist of six parents and five other members, including teachers and the principal at each school in the 410,000-student system. The principals have no say on their own contracts, which range from about $40,000 to $70,000 a year, and fired principals have no recourse other than reconsideration by the councils, said Bob Saigh, another board spokesman. David Peterson, principal at the Wells High School for 13 years, is among the principals fighting their dismissal notices. Many of the 1,700 students at the mostly Hispanic school staged a sit-in Tuesday to protest the firing, announced the day before. The faculty has written to Superintendent Ted Kimbrough, who has said he would intervene if it appeared councils acted improperly. Assistant Principal Miguel Trujillo said Peterson ``has the support of the community, the student body, the faculty and the staff.'' ``The councils are using hidden agendas ... regardless of how the school community feels,'' Trujillo said. Peterson said the councils are being asked to act too quickly, without enough information. ``One council member said I was too strict, another said I was too easy,'' he said. ``One said she was looking for a Hispanic.'' ``I've never felt that I had a divine right to be principal of anything,'' Peterson said. ``But I don't believe that local councils were set up to turn schools into bastions of racism or ethnicity.'' Dan Solis, executive director of the United Neighborhood Organization, a community group active in the reform effort, said the racism charges were false. ``It's just presenting the bogeyman out there,'' Solis said. Allegations of discrimination also have surfaced at Burns Elementary School, where council members said they voted not to renew principal Donald Kriz's contract because he wouldn't cooperate with them. ``They want him out because he's not Hispanic, and that's the bottom line,'' said fifth-grade teacher Lorraine Stepanek, who was among teachers picketing Wednesday outside the school in a mostly Hispanic district. Donald Moore, whose Designs for Change group helped shape the reform package, said the protests are ``part of a process called democracy.'' ``We're talking about schools that are failing miserably across the city,'' he said. ``There is need for new leadership in many schools and it's totally predictable that people ... at risk of losing their jobs are going to try to hang onto them.'' The School Board defends its decision to empower the councils. ``This is the first year this has been done,'' Moses said. ``Whenever you have a new system ... somebody's not going to be pleased. But if you can manage to satisfy the majority, then I think you can call it a success.''

DOC.HEAD: Hard-line Government Summons Students, Engineers Abroad
DOC.TEXT: Communist North Korea has summoned about 2,000 of its students and engineers from Eastern Europe and sent them to isolated rural areas to halt the spread of ``ideological taint,'' a newspaper reported today. The Kookmin Ilbo newspaper quoted South Korean government sources as saying the students and engineers were held in a re-education camp outside the North Korean capital of Pyongyang for up to two months before being sent to remote education facilities or factories. The North Koreans were ordered to return from East Germany, Romania, Hungary and three other Eastern European countries undergoing democratic upheaval, the Seoul newspaper said. Popular uprisings toppled hard-line Communist rulers in Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary, Poland and Romania last year. The newspaper said North Korea also wants about 500 students studying in the Soviet Union to return this year because pro-democracy protests are now occuring there but authorities took no action for fear of stirring a diplomatic conflict. North Korea has stated that it has no intention of changing its current political course and that its society would not be affected by changes in Eastern Europe. No official comment was immediately available. South Korean officials have said North Korea has tightened ideological control since neighboring China crushed a pro-democracy uprising led by students in June.

DOC.HEAD: Judaism Scholar Nahum Glatzer Dies at 86
DOC.TEXT: Nahum N. Glatzer, a scholar, editor and author of numerous works on literature and Judaism, has died at 86. The Watertown, Mass., resident, who wrote more than 250 books and articles on subjects ranging from Franz Kafka to Jewish prayer, died Tuesday after several days in a coma in Tucson, where he was spending the winter. A founder of Schocken Books in Germany, he remained an editor after the publishing company moved to the United States during the Nazi era. Glatzer was born in Austria and in 1931 earned a Ph.D. from the University of Frankfurt, where he was philosopher Martin Buber's successor as lecturer on Jewish religious history and ethics. In 1933, Glatzer and his wife fled to Palestine, where he taught literature. They moved to the United States in 1938. Glatzer began teaching at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., in 1950 and was chairman of the department of Near Eastern and Judaic studies for 11 years. He later became a professor of religion at Boston University. Among his works are ``History of the Talmudic Age,'' ``The Beginnings of Post-Biblical Judaism'' and ``The Dimensions of Job.'' He is survived by his wife, Anne; a son; a daughter, and two grandchildren. Funeral services were set for today in Lexington, Mass.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Sues to Keep Divorce Out of Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: The Newport Daily News is fighting a lawsuit by a woman who wants to keep the paper from publishing her name once her divorce is final. A lawyer for the woman, identified only as Jane Doe, said she is not a public figure and that a divorce notice would violate her right to privacy. ``Unfortunately, divorce carries with it, albeit for personal or religious reasons, a social stigma,'' said Thomas W. Kelly. ``She fears that the mere publication of her name intrudes on her life, her husband's life and her future.'' The suit, filed Tuesday, is designed to force the news media ``to scrutinize the information and to prevent them from publishing information about marital breakdowns unless there is a reasonable element of newsworthiness.'' The Daily News for years has published monthly the names and addresses of people for whom final divorce decrees were entered in Newport County Family Court. Editor David B. Offer said in a statement Wednesday that publishing information about divorces, ``which are on the public record for all to see, is a normal and important practice for newspapers all over the country.' ``For very good reasons, the right to provide this information to readers is protected by the First Amendment,'' he said. The U.S. Supreme Court has ruled that newspapers cannot be barred from publishing truthful information from open court records. But Kelly said the court signaled its willingness to allow exceptions with a ruling last June. In that case, the court said a rape victim could not recover damages against a paper that published her name in violation of a Florida ``rape shield'' law. But Kelly said the court also stated that ``case-by-case analysis of press-privacy conflicts by the court is appropriate.''

DOC.HEAD: CDC Says Foreigners With AIDS Should be Allowed to Visit U.S.
DOC.TEXT: The Centers for Disease Control says foreigners who have AIDS or virtually any other contagious disease should be allowed into the country. Along with AIDS, the CDC is recommending removing from the list all other contagious diseases except infectious tuberculosis, a federal official said Wednesday. The CDC recommendation on AIDS is largely symbolic, however, because the list still would include infection with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS. That restriction was imposed by Congress. The recommendation by the CDC to remove AIDS is seen as ``signaling Congress that they should take HIV off'' the list as well, said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The immigration regulations concerning AIDS have been protested by AIDS activist groups, including the National Commission on AIDS and the World Health Organization. Several groups, including the National Association of People with AIDS, have said they will boycott two major AIDS conferences in the United States this year unless the restrictions are changed.
DOC.HEAD: FDA Asked to Strengthen Warning on Birth Control Pills
DOC.TEXT: A private health group wants the Food and Drug Administration to require stronger warnings on labels of oral contraceptives. The Public Citizen Health Research Group said Wednesday that its review of 13 studies published since 1977 shows women under 45 who use birth control pills for many years may be at increased risk of developing breast cancer. An FDA advisory committee, in January 1989, recommended no changes in use of the pill, saying research on a possible link to breast cancer was inconclusive and more study was needed. More than 13 million women in the United States between the ages of 15 and 44 use oral contraceptives. Fourteen studies published in the past decade found no link between the pill and breast cancer, but few of these examined women who began using the pill at a young age and continued for many years, the group said.
DOC.HEAD: Bass Moratorium Goes Into Effect Today
DOC.TEXT: New Jersey's commercial and sport fishermen face $1,000 penalties and seizure of their vessels beginning today if they catch or sell striped bass in coastal waters. The state's failure to meet a Wednesday deadline for protecting the striped bass with catch limits prompted two federal agencies to impose the sales and fishing moratorium. The federal agencies said the moratorium would be lifted when the state comes into compliance with the Atlantic Striped Bass Conservation Act. According to Bob Itchmoney, assistant director of the New Jersey Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife, the state assembly's Conservation and Natural Resources Committee scheduled a hearing for this morning on striped bass legislation. In the meantime, a special task force of agents from the Fish and Wildlife Service and the National Marine Fisheries Service are ready to enforce the moratorium, with help from the Coast Guard. The striped bass began receiving federal protection after a decade-long population decline. The Fish and Wildlife Service, working with Maryland and Virginia, has stocked more than 3 million hatchery-raised striped bass in the Chesapeake Bay since 1985 to help bring the fish population back.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Fear, Both Sides Seem Determined to Defuse Tension
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: The aftermath of Sunday's election has been surprisingly calm, and a lot of that has been to President Daniel Ortega's credit. The Sandinistas agreed to the rules of the game, and they haven't changed their minds just because it didn't work out as expected. ``If you have elections, you run the risk of losing those elections,'' Ortega said Wednesday, speaking to members of international groups who support the Sandinistas. Ortega was beaten in the vote by Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in an upset that stunned his party, which never imagined it could lose. While the Sandinistas have been adjusting psychologically to defeat and a life in the opposition, Mrs. Chamorro's 14-party coalition has been trying to make things as easy as possible. ``We have to leave them alone; we can't push them. They're tense and it's dangerous to push them now,'' said a senior strategist for her United National Opposition (UNO). UNO has asked its supporters to go straight home after work and not to gloat in victory or even provide a target for an incident. The victorious coalition had predicted widespread aggression and intimidation by Sandinista militants _ something that has occurred in the past. Others thought the Sandinistas, with roots in Marxist and Leninist ideology, would not give up state power under any conditions. Neither fear has been realized. Although there have been isolated incidents _ a drunken bottle-tossing clash; an UNO campaign headquarters occupied; a murder-suicide between neighbors _ there has been no sign of a systematic effort to subvert the election results. And both sides have begun to show a businesslike side as they begin difficult negotiations over the terms of a transfer of power. The decisive contribution has come from Ortega. He commands loyalty and love from much of the party, which remains the strongest and most cohesive political force in Nicaragua. ``If he concedes defeat, there's nothing the others (Sandinista leaders) can do. It's in his hands,'' UNO political strategist Alfredo Cesar said shortly before the voting. With the army and security forces under close party control, with arms distributed to labor unions, agricultural cooperatives and other rank-and-file groups, the Sandinistas could have tried to hold on by force. But that was not the point, Ortega said Wednesday. ``The big question is this,'' he said. ``Did the FSLN (Sandinista Front) make the revolution to maintain itself as the only governing party in Nicaragua; or did the FLSN make the revolution to open a democratic space that never before existed in this country?'' Although Ortega's answer has been clear, not all his supporters have agreed. Early in the week Sandinista radio stations were flooded with calls from party members urging Ortega to ignore the election results. In his speeches since his defeat, Ortega has both recognized that passion and tried to calm the waters. ``To these inflamed people who shout that they (those who voted for UNO) sold themselves, that they betrayed us, I say that the people can't betray themselves, but they can make a mistake,'' Ortega replied. In six years, when Mrs. Chamorro's term is up, the worm will turn, he said. Besides, Ortega noted, the Sandinistas remain the largest single party in the country and will be able to defend themselves in the National Assembly. The word went out after a meeting of 1,500 party leaders from around the nation on Wednesday. The Sandinista discipline asserted itself. ``It's bad for our morale, bad for our morale,'' said Mario Ramirez, a member of a Sandinista neighborhood committee. ``The people were tricked. The peasants, the people Daniel favored, they were fooled. ``But we'll do them in in six years,'' he said. On a practical level, there remain tough and potentially inflammatory issues to negotiate before Mrs. Chamorro takes office. While UNO wants control of the army, the Sandinistas don't want the army changed while U.S.-supported Contras still roam the hills. But the two sides showed signs of working together. When former President Jimmy Carter suggested that Ortega and Mrs. Chamorro call for immediate Contra disbandment, both did so within hours. UNO already appears to be pulling back from a platform plank calling for denationalization of the banks. Even the issue of army control may be subject to compromise. Mrs. Chamorro said a civilian would replace Ortega's brother, Gen. Humberto Ortega, as defense minister, but a knowledgeable source suggested the civilian might be a Sandinista selected by UNO.

DOC.HEAD: List of Obstacles to Smooth Transition
With PM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The list of major obstacles to a smooth transition of power from the Sandinista party to the United National Opposition alliance is short but deep: _ Military: The Sandinistas want the Sandinista People's Army and the Ministry of the Interior left intact, especially while the U.S.-backed Contras remain a force in being. UNO wants to trim them, de-politicize them and change the Army's name. _ Contras: President Daniel Ortega has demanded immediate demobilization of the U.S-backed rebels, and President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has agreed. But the Contras themselves say they will not dismantle until Mrs. Chamorro is sworn in April 25. _ Economy: The Sandinistas want the highly nationalized economic structure left intact; UNO has already agreed not to re-privatize the banks. But their plan calls for decentralizing Nicaragua's economy and selling off inefficient public enterprises, something that may cost jobs _ anathema to the Sandinistas. _ Confiscations: The Sandinistas want the lands, houses and companies confiscated during their 10{ years in power kept by the state or those to whom the properties were given. UNO will probably leave confiscated lands in present hands, but wants to return companies to their private owners.

DOC.HEAD: Minn. Abortion Bill Stays in Committee; Consent Bill Signed in S.C.
DOC.TEXT: A Minnesota Senate committee dealt a setback to a bill that would ban virtually all abortions, while South Carolina's governor signed a law requiring girls under 17 to get permission from a judge or parent to have an abortion. Gov. Carroll Campbell said Wednesday that the new law ``has to do with the family. It has to do with government saying the family should be included in decisions and not excluded by government, and I think that's important.'' In Minnesota, a bill prohibiting abortions for ``birth-control reasons'' received a tie vote from the 16-member Senate Health and Human Services Committee. Bills need a majority vote to clear committee. ``A bill is always alive as long as the session is on,'' said Sen. Gene Waldorf, the legislation's Senate sponsor. The bill was drafted as model legislation by the National Right-To-Life Committee following last summer's U.S. Supreme Court's Webster decision, which gave states more leeway to restrict abortions. Witnesses on both sides said the legislation would be the toughest anti-abortion measure in the nation, prohibiting an estimated 93 percent of the abortions performed in the state, a stronghold of anti-abortion sentiment. The new South Carolina law says that beginning in June, girls must have the permission of a judge, parent or guardian to have an abortion. Incest victims are not subject to the law, but rape victims are. Previously, South Carolina law required girls under 16 to obtain a parent's consent for an abortion. But similar laws without a so-called judicial consent option have been declared unconstitutional in other states.

DOC.HEAD: Army Called Out to Stop Clashes Following Elections
DOC.TEXT: The army was called out to stop election violence in a constituency where police gunfire and battles between political rivals left at least 13 people dead, police and news reports said today. Wednesday's deaths in Haryana state's Meham district raised to 98 the number of people killed during voting for eight state assemblies and scattered by-elections in the world's most populous democracy. Incomplete results showed the Congress Party of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi losing heavily as the governing National Front coalition and its electoral ally, the Hindu right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party, made sweeping gains. The United News of India said the National Front and the Bharatiya Janata Party had won 563 of the 775 contests for which results had been announced. Congress had won just 147. Other seats went to left-wing groups and independents. The election deaths include at least 80 people killed Tuesday in the eastern state of Bihar, known for its organized criminal gangs. Other deaths have been reported from the states of Gujarat and Maharashtra, which also went to the polls Tuesday. Rival political supporters fought pitched battles in Meham on Wednesday when an another vote was ordered in some polling centers following allegations of electoral fraud. A police spokesman in Chandigarh, the Haryana state capital, said three people died in the fighting, and another 10 were fatally shot when police opened fire to control rioting mobs. Voting was suspended and the army called out to maintain peace after the killings, said the spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. Newspapers have blamed most of the vote fraud in Meham on Om Prakash Chauthala, Haryana state's chief minister and the son of India's deputy prime minister, Devi Lal. Chauthala was a National Front candidate for the Haryana state assembly from the Meham district. The Hindu newspaper said armed gangs ``were seen to be moving from booth to booth in the chief minister's constituency and getting the ballot papers stamped in his favor.'' Chauthala was named Haryana's chief minister, the state's top elected administrator, after his father resigned from the post in December to join the federal government. Under Indian law, any person appointed to a state or the federal cabinet has up to six months to contest an election. The appointee must win the poll for his selection to be ratified. Results from the polling show the Congress Party being voted out of power in at least five of the eight states where elections were held this week. The United News of India said the National Front and the Bharatiya Janata Party had won most of the seats in Orissa, Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat, Himachal Pradesh and Rajasthan states and were set to form governments. Complete results from Bihar, Arunachal Pradesh and Maharashtra states are not expected until Friday. A total of 1,610 seats were at stake and the Congress Party had fielded candidates in all but 30 of them. The National Front and the Bharatiya Janata Party fielded about 1,000 candidates each, agreeing to ``friendly contests'' in some constituencies.

DOC.HEAD: Winds Whips Fire Through Luxury Hotel, Killing 10
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thuout with guests jumping from upper floors, three Americans among those injured, reax from terrified guests. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto Covering
DOC.TEXT: Fire spread by high winds from an outdoor tent heavily damaged a six-story Sheraton hotel early today, and authorities said 10 people were killed and about 70 injured. Guests, some in pajamas or underwear, jumped from upper floors of the luxury hotel or attached bedsheets to windowsills and slipped down to safety, the newspaper Al-Akhbar said. Police Brig. Abdel-Rehim el-Kenawy said two of those killed were French nationals. At least three Americans were among those seriously injured, a hospital official said. The front of the modern 630-room Heliopolis Sheraton Hotel, including lobbies, restaurants and other facilities, was destroyed and about a third of the hotel was blackened. About 1,000 guests and 300 employees were at the hotel when the fire broke out, Al-Akhbar reported. There was no immediate word on the cause of the fire. A hotel official said it had been receiving _ every few months _ anonymous threatening letters demanding that alcoholic drinks be banned and that the hotel's nightclub be shut down. Such demands are customarily heard from extremist Moslem fundamentalist groups. But there were no indications so far linking them to the hotel fire. Fardos Mohammed el-Sayed, staying at the hotel with her husband, a newly married son and his bride, said the family had to leave their two-room suite in bedclothes. ``We were going to sleep when suddenly we heard foreigners shouting in English `Fire! Fire!' and we heard people running in corridors,'' said Mrs. el-Sayed. ``We went down thinking it was a small thing and left everything behind.'' With more than 30 fire units on the scene, including some from the army, the fire still burned eight hours after it broke out at about 1 a.m. Helmeted riot police carrying shields ringed the hotel as firefighters and rescue teams worked. Victor Lewis, assistant manager of the Cairo Sheraton, flagship of the chain's six hotels in Egypt, said the blaze began in the Nubian Tent, a restaurant where tourists watch belly-dancing and other traditional Egyptian amusements. The restaurant is in a tent adjacent the hotel's outer wall. Winds quickly spread the fire. ``One problem was that some guests opened their windows to see what was going on,'' Lewis said. ``As a result, sparks went into their rooms driven by the strong winds,'' which spread the fire into the building. The injured were taken to nearby Heliopolis Hospital and the Palestine Red Crescent Hospital. Dr. Samiri Sultan, director of the Heliopolis Hospital, said he received seven dead and 31 injured. Sultan said six of the 17 badly injured were from France; three each from the United States, Britain and Egypt; one from Finland; and one had dual Mexican-Lebanese citizenship. At the Palestinian Red Crescent Hospital, Dr. Hassan Kamil said nine people, including two Canadians and a Dane, had been admitted with bone fractures, smoke inhalation and bruises. A spokesman from Egypt's emergency medical services said about 70 people were injured. Sheraton officials said some slightly injured guests did not go to hospitals but received first-aid treatment after being transferred to other hotels. About 10 years old, the Heliopolis Sheraton is near the Cairo International Airport. The hotel's lobby was among the most elaborate in Cairo, designed in the motif of a tropical greenhouse with live birds flitting among the plants.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Decline, Dollar Gains
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's leading index shifted from dramatic recovery back to sharp decline today as declines in the bond market and the yen's value discouraged investors. After a two-day rise, the 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average fell 762.41 points, or 2.20 percent, closing at 33,829.58. Meanwhile, despite central bank intervention, the dollar rose by 1.26 yen, closing at 149.78 yen, its highest close since 151.30 yen last June 15. Despite a pause in its climb on Wednesday, it has gained 5.26 yen since Feb. 19. The dollar opened today at 149.35 and ranged between 149.35 yen and 149.90 yen. On the stock exchange, ``the largest concern among market players is the foreign exchange situation,'' Yoshiro Inoue of Nomura Securities Co. said. The weak yen makes Japanese shares less attractive, and also affects the bond market _ another influence on the stock exchange. Ichitaro Watanabe, a dealer with Nikko Securities Co., said, ``There was substantial selling by those eager to unload holdings that depreciated badly during the stock market debacle in the past week. ``Computer-aided selling by arbitrageurs accelerated the decline,'' he added. But he said a market crash was highly unlikely because the recent decline has not been caused by panic selling. In arbitrage dealing, traders aided by computers spot price gaps between different markets, for example the spot and futures markets _ and seek to profit from them. Arbitrageurs today sold shares in the spot market to take advantage of a fall in the Nikkei futures index, dealers said. The Nikkei index for the spot market fell 1,569.10 points on Monday in its second-largest one-day plunge ever and its worst since the October 1987 global crash. But it bounced back with gains of 576.08 on Tuesday and 694.04 on Wednesday. After Monday's plunge, the Tokyo Stock Exchange asked 10 major foreign and domestic securities not to file arbitrage selling orders after trading sessions begin if the indicator is falling. In the currency market, dealers said the dollar's sharply higher opening in Tokyo Thursday followed its overnight surge on overseas markets. In New York, the dollar rose to 149.08 yen, up from 148.73 late Tuesday, as traders sold the West German mark for the dollar. The dollar's strength carried over into dollar-yen trading. ``The general perception in the market is that there won't be an interest rate hike in West Germany for some time and that encouraged the mark selling in New York,'' said a dealer with Daiichi Kangyo Bank, speaking on condition of anonymity. A trader with the Bank of Tokyo, also requesting anonymity, said the dollar's climb is expected to continue for some time as market players see how high they can push it. The Bank of Japan, the nation's central bank, has been intervening in the market intermittently, selling dollars in an attempt to support the yen. The bank does not comment on its specific exchange market activities. A Bank of Japan official said, however, the bank will continue to intervene in the market for the time being, but ``we will consider other measures as deemed necessary'' to check the yen's decline, Kyodo News Service reported.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Prosecutor Hails Supreme Court Ruling
DOC.TEXT: The government's case against Manuel Noriega has been reinforced by the U.S. Supreme Court's decision granting agents broader authority to conduct searches in foreign countries, the lead prosecutor says. ``We're happy to see it come,'' U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen said of the ruling Wednesday that U.S. authorities do not need a warrant to search a foreign site in a case involving a non-U.S. citizen. ``It's generally known that that's our position in the Noriega case, and it's good news that the rules won't change.'' Noriega contends his arrest after the Dec. 20 American invasion was illegal, as was the U.S. seizure of evidence from homes and offices. The ousted Panamanian dictator is accused of taking payoffs to protect the cocaine trade. One of Noriega's attorneys, Steven Kollin, said that he had not read the opinion but that the ruling apparently wouldn't apply directly to Noriega's arrest. He said it might relate to material seized by U.S. authorities. Yet Samuel Burstyn, attorney for Noriega co-defendant Luis del Cid, said the ruling also could encompass the issue of illegal arrest. ``This is a blow to (that) defense,'' he said. Burstyn also said the case seemed to undermine, in part, previous Supreme Court rulings that authorities could not benefit from illegal searches or arrests. ``The judge should punish the prosecution for doing something illegal, but now they are refusing to do so,'' the attorney said. The Supreme Court decision helps in joint overseas operations because U.S. agents will now be bound by the same law used in the host country, Lehtinen said. ``We think it's important that you don't have a double set of rules,'' Lehtinen said. ``What a contrary opinion would do is to say their own law is not good enough for their own country.''

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Cheer, Boo President Outside Wilson Fund-Raiser
With AM-Bush
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators scuffled over U.S. policy in Central America, started a bonfire and scattered leaflets at a hotel as President Bush spoke at a fund-raiser. At least five people were arrested, police said. Later, police fired three shots in a chase of a stolen car a half-mile from the president's motorcade, police said. Bush, traveling to a waiting Air Force One at San Francisco Airport, was unaware of the incident, authorities said. Two youths were arrested for investigation of drunken driving, possession of a stolen vehicle and auto theft, police said. Police had opened fire after they refused to pull over, said Highway Patrol Sgt. Fred Bowe. No one was hurt. ``It was bad planning on (their) part. They definitely could have picked a better time and place,'' Bowe said. About 1,000 people had gathered outside the St. Francis Hotel to cheer Bush or protest his visit on behalf of Sen. Pete Wilson's gubernatorial campaign. Riot police broke up fistfights and shoving matches between protesters favoring Nicaragua'a lame-duck Sandinista government and those cheering the opposition party that won Sunday's election. Two dozen torch-bearing protesters, some wearing bandanas on their faces, set a bonfire, cheering wildly as the flames crept to within two feet of a TV van. Police escorted firefighters in to put out the flames. Several protesters got into the hotel and hung a pro-Sandinista banner from a window. They hurled about 300 leaflets into the lobby as firecrackers popped outside.

DOC.HEAD: 3 Million Ethiopians Could Die of Hunger Because of Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, bgng The Soviets, and 8th graf, The Ethiopian, to FIX style on Tigre province; picks up 9th graf, The Eritrean
DOC.TEXT: About 3 million Ethiopians could die of hunger this year because government and rebel forces refuse to stop fighting long enough to allow delivery of food shipments, State Department officials say. The officials briefed two House subcommittees Wednesday about efforts to arrange a cease-fire and coordinate food shipments to starving residents of northern Ethiopia. Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen said the United States had been holding high-level talks with the Soviet Union, which arms the Ethiopian government, on the increasingly dire situation. The Soviet supplies, which last year amounted to $600 million, are ``on a downward curve,'' he said, as the Kremlin extricates itself from financial support of Third World governments and channels resources to domestic needs. The Soviets have pulled half of their 2,000 military advisers out of Ethiopia and have urged the government of Mengistu Haile Mariam to discuss peace with the two main insurgent groups in the provinces of Tigre and Eritrea, he said. But there has been no progress in the effort to get talks going under the mediation of former President Jimmy Carter, Cohen said. The United States, he said, has not been ``impressed by the commitment of either side in Ethiopia to peace and relief efforts.'' The Ethiopian government must offer concrete proposals for a loose federation of states that would keep the country whole yet preserve the character of Eritrea and Tigre, he said. The Eritrean People's Liberation Front ``must accept some measure of responsibility for the increased risk of famine and mass starvation'' because of the offensive it launched Feb. 8 that cut off food supplies through the port of Massawa, Cohen told the committees. There are unconfirmed reports that about 45,000 tons of U.S. food were destroyed in the offensive and subsequent government bombing of the town, said Andrew Natsios, director of the State Department's Office of Foreign Disaster Assistance. Perhaps as many as 3 million people ``are now trapped by the fighting with no access to relief food,'' he said, adding that unless the fighting stops, ``a catastrophe of terrible proportions will be visited upon the Ethiopian people again, comparable to 1984-85, when 1 million people died.'' He said hundreds of thousands could die if no food reaches them within three or four weeks. Cohen said support from foreign governments, such as the Soviets and Israel, must stop. ``We have been very staunch in our opposition to any arms supplies, whether from the Soviet Union, Israel, or any other country,'' Cohen said. Israel, which recently re-established diplomatic ties with Ethiopia, has assured the United States its supplies to Mengistu are minimal, consisting of small arms and trainers, Cohen said. Israeli officials have denied reports that they are providing Mengistu with cluster bombs, but concede they are helping the government because they want Mengistu to allow more than 20,000 Jews to leave the country. Mengistu has been seeking to replace the declining Soviet deliveries with weapons from North Korea, China and Brazil, said Cohen, but so far has not been successful. The United States is looking to the United Nations to be more active in organizing international relief supplies to Ethiopia, including using airlifts and ensuring the sides hold their fire to allow deliveries of food, he said.

DOC.HEAD: New Japanese Talent Jumps Gun On Winter Shows
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Jun in designer's name and Auguste are correct.
DOC.TEXT: The big ready-to-wear winter fashion shows don't begin until mid-March, but a new Japanese designer named Jun Inoue jumped the gun with a low-key collection of coordinates. His adorable trapeze mini-coats, well-cut buttoned jodhpur pants, beautiful fabrics and excellent cuts, displayed Wednesday, would be good news in any collection for next winter. Jun Inoue, working under the name ``Jun, July, Auguste,'' is just the latest Japanese designer trying to make it in Paris. Kenzo came into his own over 18 years ago, Hanae Mori turned into a ``French'' couturiere about 20 years ago, Issey Miyake has shown in Paris for years, and Rei Kawakubo stunned her audiences with clothes shot full of holes for ``Comme des Garcons'' more than a decade ago. Opting for a quiet show in the cellar of his small boutique near the Louvre that will open officially next summer, Jun was modest but hopeful for a big future in Paris and all over the world. ``Paris is the place to be,'' said Jun, 37. ``I've lived here 15 years, and get my inspiration here.'' ``I thought he did a wonderful job,'' said Jean-Paul Gaultier, for whom Jun worked eight years. The way-out wonder boy of French fashion, Gaultier said he liked the details like a shirred mini-dress in soft fabrics worn over a silky turtleneck undershirt. Inoue's small collection was smart and young in every way. He led off with well-cut black cuffed shorts worn with a high-waisted long jacket nipped in by a drawstring with a high waistline, the outfit topped with a jaunty sailor's beret. The high waistline, often buckled at the side, was a kind of signature for Jun's leggy look that was always paired with matching or contrasting opaque tights _ exclusive productions for Jun _ and little flat suede oxords. While the gamine mini look was young, there was a lot for women of all ages who want a bit of originality in their closets. The softly belted trench coats, the checked pants suits with narrow jodhpur-style trousers buttoned up from the ankle could be worn by almost anyone. Details can make or break a collection, and Jun found some excellent touches. His mother-of-pearl buttons with a dangling pearl to doll up dark blazers and coats are not seen anywhere else. One dress sure to make a hit was a camisole slip-like mini number with a heavy eyelet embroidered decor on the top and hem, worn with a slinky T-shirt top and contrasting tights. The same eyelet detail on collars pepped up shortie coats with their flared skirts. The fabrics were soft but warm for winter, the color combinations autumnal and artistic. Besides navy and black, there were touches of dusty rose or blue, ochre, khaki and aubergine or burgundy, often worked together in appealing combinations. One of the real originals in the collection was a brown velveteen dress shirred around the scoop neckline and at the waist, worn with a silky high-necked green shirt underneath. For dressier moments, Jun also used chiffon to fashion fly-away minis over matching tights, beautiful in deep blue and ochre. Other ideas included his strict black tuxedo with narrow chino pants, the jacket lapels made of a ribbon effect over a polka-dotted blouse. Whether working with taffeta or elasticized wool jersey, Jun seemed right at home with his fabrics, showing exquisite tailoring and cut. ``Jun, July, Auguste'' has Japanese backing by the Five Fox retail group, and they hope to do well in France before starting marketing in the United States. The clothes will be manufactured for the French market by Chofflet-Style in Moulins in central France, who also make clothes for well-known names like Paco Rabanne, Azzedine Alaia and Popy Moreni. Priced around $475 to $700 for a long jacket or coat, the clothes may sound expensive. But by high-quality luxury ready-to-wear standards these days, they're almost a steal for anybody who wants original touches in a fashionable wardrobe.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Given Alcohol Dies After Respirator Removed
LaserPhotos DN3,FW2
DOC.TEXT: A young man could face murder charges in the death of a 5-year-old who was given 10 ounces of bourbon and told to ``drink it like a man,'' a prosecutor says. Raymond Thomas Griffin II died Wednesday after his family agreed to disconnect a life support system. He suffered seizures and went into a coma after drinking the bourbon and beer at a party Friday night at his home in Overman. Anthony Darron Jimerson, 21, of Forest Hills had been jailed on $100,000 bail on charges of causing injury to a child, punishable by up to 99 years in prison. ``It's possible that he'll be indicted on murder now that the child has died,'' said Assistant District Attorney Gary Medlin. Police said Jimerson told the boy to drink the alcohol ``like a man.'' The boy had a blood alcohol level of .55 percent, or five times the legal limit for driving in Texas, and suffered irreversible brain damage, doctors said. The boy's father, Raymond Griffin of Myrtle Beach, S.C., was at Tinky's deathbed, the first time he had seen his son in nearly two years. He is separated from the boy's mother, Patricia Griffin. ``I used to read to him a lot and I didn't read him comic books. I read him Time, books about leadership, books about my work in the Army. He was going to be brilliant,'' he said. Police said they may seek charges against Mrs. Griffin and five others at the party.

DOC.HEAD: Heating Oil Leaks Into Waterway from Barge
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard today used booms to try to contain a 27,000-gallon oil spill near the Statue of Liberty that caused black gobs to wash ashore at Coney Island in the area's second such accident this year. New York Attorney General Robert Abrams said a criminal investigation of Wednesday's spill in the Kill Van Kull, a busy waterway separating New Jersey from New York City's Staten Island, had been ordered. The spill ``once again points out the desperate need for us ... as a total society, to examine the way petroleum oil is shipped, delivered and transferred,'' he said. The No. 6 heating oil leaked as private contractors loaded it onto a damaged barge at an Exxon Corp. terminal here, the Coast Guard said. The waterway remained closed today while Coast Guardsmen placed booms to soak up and contain the slick. Environmentalists worried that tides and wind could move the slick into areas of New York Harbor where migratory waterfowl breed. Black oil slicks late Wednesday spanned the 3{-mile length of the Kill Van Kull, and a sheen was spotted near the Statue of Liberty, about five miles to the northeast. Globs of oil washed up on Staten Island and at Coney Island, in Brooklyn. The oil leaked through a 12-by-6-inch hole in the barge, Coast Guard Lt. Jeff Crawley said. State officials said the hole was caused by a tugboat trying to position the barge, but Coast Guard officials could not confirm that. Coast Guard records show the barge has been involved in at least five other oil spills in the New York-New Jersey area since 1985 and one in December near New Haven, Conn., The Star-Ledger of Newark reported today. Exxon offered to help with the cleanup but said the barge, owned by Eklof Marine Corp. of New York, was not a company vessel. State officials agreed that Exxon was not responsible. A secretary at Eklof's offices said the company had no comment. The spill occurred a few miles from the confluence of the Kill Van Kull and Arthur Kill waterway, site of a Jan. 1 spill of 567,000 gallons of heating oil from an Exxon pipeline. Exxon was indicted by a federal grand jury Tuesday in Alaska in the nation's worst oil spill, the March 24 grounding of the Exxon Valdez that sent nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil gushing into Prince William Sound.

DOC.HEAD: 7 Die in Early Morning House Fires
