DOC.NOTE: Eds: Christor in 6th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: More than 40 firefighters worked all day to remove the bodies of four children and three adults killed in a fire that engulfed a house. The fire quickly burned out of control around before dawn Wednesday and causd the roof and floor to fall into the basement, making it difficult to reach the bodies, said Fire Chief Victor Hilbert. The cause of the fire wasn't known. A neighbor who called the Fire Department said it was impossible to get close enough to attempt a rescue. ``It was all in flames when I came out. The windows were popping out,'' said Larry Riker. Killed were David Forquer; his wife, LeAnne, 25; their children, Michael, 8; Christor, 6; Nona, 5; and Louis, 3, and a man whose identity was not released.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Rain in Southeast, Cold Temperatures in North
DOC.TEXT: Cold rain fell in the Southeast early today, while a cold front dropped temperatures into the teens and single digits in the Northeast. Much of the nation had dry weather. Heavy rain was expected on the West Coast on Friday and Saturday, and snow was forecast for this weekend in the Sierra Nevada. A storm system brought snow late Wednesday to Oklahoma and Missouri. Earlier, the storm dumped about 4 inches of snow in Wichita, Kan. Rainshowers extended across Arkansas and much of eastern Texas and western Louisiana. A few thunderstorms were over south-central Texas. More than an inch of rain fell Wednesday at Corpus Christi, Texas. Strong winds ushered cold air into the southern Plains. High temperatures early today were only in the 30s in much of Oklahoma and west Texas. Temperatures on Wednesday remained below freezing all day in the Great Lakes region and the Northeast. Temperatures climbed into the 70s in many southern regions, with lower 80s in southern Florida and the lower Rio Grande Valley of Texas. Temperatures also reached into the 70s and 80s in southern Arizona and Southern California. The high for the nation Wednesday was 89 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.SECOND: PM-LA Quake-Other Quakes, 1st Ld - Writethru, a0483,0237
DOC.HEAD: Other California Quakes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS lead to show that October quake was not in Los Angeles area.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-LA Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Wednesday's quake was the strongest to hit California since a deadly tremor rocked the San Francisco Bay area Oct. 17, killing 67 people and stirring new fears of the ``Big One'' long predicted for Southern California. That quake measured 7.1 on the Richter scale, far stronger than Wednesday's quake, which seismologists estimated at 5.5 to 6.0. The worst recent Southern California quake struck the Whittier area Oct. 1, 1987. It measured 5.9 and, together with a 5.3-magnitude aftershock Oct. 4, killed eight people, injured more than 200 and caused $358 million in damage. The last magnitude-5 quake in the region struck Jan. 19, 1989. Centered offshore, 30 miles southwest of downtown Los Angeles, it shattered windows in Malibu and knocked out power to 100,000 customers. One minor injury was reported. Other recent tremors: _ Last June 13, twin quakes measuring 4.5 and 4.3 struck Los Angeles, injuring one person and causing minor damage downtown and in suburbs to the east. _ Last April 27, a tremor measuring 3.5 and centered in the Pacific Ocean nine miles west of El Segundo rattled the Los Angeles metropolitan area. _ Last March 9, a quake registering 3.1 shook part of the suburban San Fernando Valley.

DOC.HEAD: Television Networks to Share Election Polls, Projections
DOC.TEXT: The major TV networks have agreed to jointly conduct exit polls and project winners on Election Day to save money and lessen the competitive pressure to call a race before the polls close in the West. Cable News Network, which has not conducted exit polls before, joined ABC, CBS and NBC in the consortium, to be known as Voter Research and Surveys. The agreement was announced Wednesday. The organization will survey a random sampling of voters as they leave polling places each Election Day, providing its findings on local, state and national races to the networks and other media. It also will project winners, based in part on the exit polls. Competitive pressures at times have led networks to project winners in presidential races before polls closed in the West, prompting complaints from voters there. Sharing projections is intended to lessen those pressures. Cost-cutting spurred discussion of the consortium. The four founders are to pay $3 million apiece for exit polls through the 1992 elections, saving each network at least $9 million. Critics of joint polling are concerned it will provide less information than competing polls, which sometimes raise different subjects and phrase questions differently. And because individual polls can be wrong, competing surveys serve as a check on polling accuracy, they said. ``I have mixed emotions,'' said Harry O'Neill, vice chairman of the Roper Organization polling concern and president of the National Council on Public Polls. ``Competition keeps everybody on their toes. That would be lacking.'' ``All polls are subject to measurement error,'' said Andrew Kohut, former president of the Gallup Organization, now with Princeton Survey Research Associates. ``When there are more attempts at measuring something, you get a better sense of what the dynamics of the issue are.'' However, O'Neill said a single poll done very well could be more valuable than separate ones conducted haphazardly. And other polling experts said the joint poll could create a standard for comparing voting trends. Joseph Angotti, a senior vice president for news at NBC, said each partner in the shared exit poll would ask essentially the same questions they would have asked in their own surveys, so no less information would result. On polls serving as a check on one another, he said: ``It boggles my mind to think that there are people who feel that two conflicting polls, or three conflicting polls, is somehow better for the republic than one poll.'' Participants will continue to conduct other polls individually, including pre-election polls on voter sentiment and general public opinion surveys. Warren Mitofsky, director of the election and surveys unit of CBS News, will direct Voter Research and Surveys, reporting to a board of directors named by the four network partners. Network executives said they did not expect the U.S. Justice Department to object to the consortium on grounds it would unfairly limit competition, because, they said, any other news organization can subscribe.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Die from Negligence in Hospitals
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 7,000 hospital patients died because of medical negligence in New York state in 1984, but only 26 doctors were disciplined, according to a Harvard University study. The results of the survey released Wednesday were seized upon by both sides of the debate over a proposal to provide no-fault malpractice insurance. Although the survey involved only New York state and was commissioned by the Legislature for its review of malpractice reform, researchers said they expect a nationwide survey would find similar results. Opponents of the no-fault policy, which has been proposed by Dr. David Axelrod, the state health commissioner, said the figures show the prevalence of malpractice and the need for doctors to be held accountable for their misdeeds. ``How can this be no one's fault?'' asked Elaine O'Rourke, pointing to her son, who went into a hospital for a bed-wetting problem and came out brain-damaged and in a wheelchair. She attended a news conference at which the findings were released. Axelrod said the survey's finding, that only 2 percent of patients injured because of negligence filed malpractice lawsuits, showed the faults in the system. A no-fault system compensate victims without a judicial finding of negligence, making it easier for victims to receive compensation. A spokesman for the Medical Society of the State of New York, which supports Axelrod's call for reform, said the current system is a ``grotesque failure.'' ``It overcompensates some but tragically it fails to compensate many, many people who are the victims of inadequate medical care,'' Gerard L. Conway said at the news conference. No-fault proponents believe it would protect doctors from the increasing insurance premiums that are driving many specialists from their fields, especially obstetrics. Axelrod said he believed no-fault insurance also would lessen doctors' fears that reporting negligence by colleagues would bring lawsuits upon themselves or their hospital. Doctors and hospitals are required by state law to report all cases of possible medical misconduct. However, the state received only 1,525 reports of possible misconduct in 1984, and only 161 came from physicians or hospitals, said Peter Slocum, a Health Department spokesman. The four-year study reviewed the records of more than 30,000 patients from 51 randomly selected hospitals in New York state. The researchers found that 1 percent of all hospital patients in the state were treated negligently. It projected a total of 13,000 hospital-caused injuries that led to deaths, and said slightly more than half of the fatal injuries were due to negligence. The study noted that ``many of the deaths occurred in patients who had greatly shortened life expectancies from their underlying diseases.'' The researchers stressed the findings could not be applied to hospitals today, since most have taken steps since 1984 to improve patient care.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher against most major foreign currencies today in calm European trading. Gold prices were lower. Dealers said the dollar is expected to continue benefiting, by default, from weakness in the West German mark and the yen. The Japanese currency stumbled after the Tokyo stock market dropped sharply today and dealers said the mark will remain weak while the West German central bank refuses to increase interest rates. ``The mark is a bit weakly,'' said a trader at a bank in Dusseldorf. ``The costs for reunification are again in the forefront.'' On top of this, said Graham Leverton, senior dealer at the Bank of America, the dollar is likely to get a boost from January's U.S. purchasing managers' index scheduled for release later today. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 1.26 yen to a closing 149.78 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 149.52 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _1.7085 West German marks, up from 1.6955 _1.4995 Swiss francs, up from 1.4900 _5.7770 French francs, up from 5.7300 _1.9015 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9070 _1,261.50 Italian lire, up from 1,250.00 _1.1905 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2072 In London, the dollar rose against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6739, compared with $1.6895 late Wednesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $405.75 a troy ounce, down from $407.90 bid late Wednesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $406.25. In Zurich, the bid price was $406.20, down from $407.79 Wednesday. Earlier in Hong Kong, gold fell $3.33 to close at a bid of $405.59. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.13 a troy ounce, from Wednesday's $5.10.

DOC.HEAD: 370-Year-old ``Hamlet'' Stolen, Recovered
DOC.TEXT: The FBI recovered a 1611 edition of Shakespeare's ``Hamlet'' worth up to $1 million and five other rare classics that had been stolen from a University of Pennsylvania library, police said. A part-time employee of the Van Pelt Library, Kathleen Wilkerson, 33, was charged with theft Wednesday night, police said. The FBI recovered the books Tuesday from a rare bookseller. The ``Hamlet'' edition, printed five years before Shakespeare's death and eight years after the play was first published, is worth between $500,000 and $1 million, police said. The other books were 1619 editions of Shakespeare's ``The Merchant of Venice'' and ``Henry V,'' worth between $100,000 and $250,000 each; a 1491 edition of Dante's ``Divine Comedy,'' a 1542 edition of Geoffrey Chaucer poems worth up to $10,000 and a 1776 copy of Thomas Paine's revolutionary pamphlet ``Common Sense,'' valued at $50,000-$100,000. Police were unable to put a value on the Dante edition. About 20 copies of the ``Hamlet'' edition and about 30 copies of ``The Merchant of Venice'' are believed to exist, said Elizabeth Niemeyer, acquisitions librarian at the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington, D.C. Investigators and school officials said they were unsure when the books were stolen. Patricia Renfro, assistant director of libraries at the university, said some of the books were found missing about 11 days ago. The books were spotted last Saturday at Bauman Rare Books by a book dealer, Steven Lowentheil of Baltimore, who suspected they were from the library, police said. On Monday, he notified university officials and the FBI. The proprietor of the bookstore, Natalie Bauman, was out of town Tuesday and Wednesday, police said. Wilkerson was charged with theft, receiving stolen property and theft of library books, police said.

DOC.HEAD: China May Not Recognize Hong Kong Residents' Foreign Passports
DOC.TEXT: In a statement likely to intensify the flight from Hong Kong, China indicated today that it may not recognize foreign passports held by Hong Kong Chinese after Britain returns the colony in 1997. The statement, read by Foreign Ministry spokesman Li Zhaoxing, said any Chinese citizen seeking foreign citizenship must first get Chinese permission to ``forfeit his Chinese citizenship.'' China regards Hong Kong as part of China, even before 1997, and considers ethnic Chinese living there to be Chinese citizens. The statement did not indicate the possibility of dual citizenship. Li also said China ``reserves the right to take appropriate measures'' in response to Britain's decision last year to issue British passports to 225,000 of the 5.8 million Hong Kong residents. Li called Britain's action a ``unilateral decision ... (to) change the citizenship of some Hong Kong residents,'' and urged Britain to ``refrain from this wrong practice.'' Britain's action was intended to stem emigration from Hong Kong by guaranteeing key civil servants the safety of British consular protection after 1997. However, Li's statement seemed to indicate that China reserves the right to nullify those passports. The effect would be to encourage the holders to emigrate to Britain. China may be betting that Britain will take back its passport offer now, rather than risk a massive influx of Hong Kong residents. A British newspaper, The Daily Mail, said today that Britain had won promises from seven other European and Asian countries to follow its example and offer passports to thousands of Hong Kong residents as a confidence-boosting measure. Fear of living under Communist rule has caused an estimated 1,000 Hong Kong residents to emigrate each week. Many of the colony's ethnic Chinese residents fled there to escape Communist rule on the mainland. Fears compounded after June, when the Chinese army crushed pro-democracy protests in mainland cities. China refused to guarantee it would not take similar action in Hong Kong, and reserved the right to crush any ``subversive'' activities there after 1997. Li refused to explain his statement, telling reporters to read it and figure it out themselves. ``It takes serious attention to get a proper understanding of this question and note it down,'' he said sarcastically in response to questions. ``I can repeat my answer and tell my interpreter to go even slower.'' He then re-read the seven-sentence statement, stopping midway to admonish his interpreter to speak ``more slowly for the benefit of my ... friends.'' The British Embassy in Beijing said no officials were available today to comment. In January, a Chinese official involved in drafting Hong Kong's post-1997 law, Lu Ping, said ethnic Chinese in Hong Kong with British passports would not be treated as British citizens. At that time, British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd insisted the official was wrong. Li's new statement, however, appeared to confirm Lu's comment. At present, ethnic Chinese in Hong Kong hold passports as ``British dependent territory citizens,'' which do not grant British citizenship or the right to live in Britain. The 225,000 passports Britain plans to issue Hong Kong Chinese would provide for full citizenship with the right to live in Britain. It made the offer in the belief that few Chinese would actually move to Britain, where there is strong popular resistance to non-white immigration. In Hong Kong, the territory's lawmaking body today approved a motion expressing disappointment that China's draft constitution for Hong Kong does not include a more democratic political system. The Legislative Council overwhelmingly rejected a motion deploring a Chinese-appointed committee's proposed constitution as an ``extremely undemocratic political model.'' Supporters of the defeated motion said greater democracy was needed to stem emigration. Under the constitution, one-third of the seats in the council will be decided by direct election in 1997, rising to one-half by 2003. The remaining seats will be chosen by interest groups and an electoral college.

DOC.HEAD: 5 Killed, 16 Injured in Bomb Explosion on Train
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Mathew John cq
DOC.TEXT: A powerful bomb exploded today on a passenger train stopped at a northern Indian railroad station, killing at least five people and injuring 16, officials said. Mathew John, a railway safety official, said the train had started its 780-mile journey in Amritsar in Punjab state, the center of a violent Sikh separatist campaign. United News of India said authorities have not ruled out the involvement of Sikh extremists in the blast, which occurred at Meerut station, 35 miles north of New Delhi. John said: ``I refuse to hazard a guess (about the culprits' identity) as it could have been anybody.'' He said the bomb exploded in a sleeper coach of the Chateesgarh Express during a scheduled stop at Meerut in Uttar Pradesh state. The train left four hours later for its destination, Bilaspur, 540 miles southeast of Meerut in Madhya Pradesh state. Sikh extremists, alleging cultural and political discrimination by the Hindu-dominated government, have killed at least 318 people this year in their quest for a separate nation in Punjab, a rich farming state bordering Pakistan.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Confers With ANC Exiles, Guerillas May Meet Defense Forces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To drop extraneous word, SUB 12th graf, `The presence ... of things.' Picks up 13th, `No specific ...' ^By ANGUS SHAW
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela held his first formal talks today with exiled leaders of the African National Congress, and a top military official expressed a willingness to meet with rival South African military commanders. The talks could bring some indication of whether the black nationalist leader, released by South Africa's white-led government last month after 27 years in prison, will be given a formal role or enhanced position in the ANC. Chris Hani, the second in command of the ANC's military wing, told reporters that preliminary talks with President F.W. De Klerk's government might include contact with the South African military. After Mandela was freed on Feb. 11, the ANC promised to send a delegation to South Africa for such talks though a date has not yet been set. Guerrilla leaders believe any talks could not be limited to political leaders alone and Hani said he envisioned a time when military officers from both sides would meet to work out ``the modalities of a cease-fire''. Hani and Joe Modise, the top commander of the ANC military wing Umkonte We Sizwe (Spear of the Nation), were among 32 exiled leaders belonging to the 35-member national executive committee who began formal discussions with Mandela in Lusaka. The national executive meeting, chaired by acting president Alfred Nzo, began with an emotional ceremony in which Mandela raised a clenched first salute joined in the singing of the nationalist anthem Nkosi Sikelele Afrika, or God Save Africa, in Mandela's native Xhosa language. Mandela, 71, was flanked by Nzo and Joe Slovo, a ranking white ANC official who is also the secretary-general of the South Africa Communist Party. Hani said the first business meeting with Mandela since he arrived in Zambia on Tuesday to visit ANC headquarters would focus on a broad agenda of issues, including Mandela's role in the organization. ``Already, he has brought a new dimension to our struggle. I am sure the national executive will be more precise about the sort of role he is going to play,'' Hani said. Since his release, Mandela has been given no formal position in the ANC. ``The presence of Mandela in our midst is a tonic. It strengthens all of us. We feel we are really moving forward. He is a great leader,'' Hani said. ``We are sure the ANC will move from strength to strength with Mandela as one of the comrades at the helm of things.'' No specific agenda was released for the two-day meeting at Lusaka's Mulungushi Hall. But Hani said conferees, including former longtime political detainee Walter Sisulu, 77, and other ANC officials from South Africa, would discuss the lifting of a 30-year ban on the ANC that de Klerk announced Feb. 2. Amid calls from church leaders in South Africa and President Kenneth Kaunda of Zambia for the ANC to suspend its guerrilla actions, Hani said the organization's leaders would discuss ``what is happening in the armed struggle and a clear strategy on that ... We will be looking at how to take forward the process of negotiation.'' The executive meeting is expected to select at least 10 names of delegates it wants to hold preliminary talks with de Klerk to clear obstacles in the way of full-scale negotiations on writing a new constitution that gives South Africa's 28 million black majority political rights. The ANC is demanding the lifting of the state of emergency, in force since June 1986, and the the release of all political prisoners, including those convicted of acts of violence.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Critical of Bush Action on Military Personnel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, The plan, to CORRECT 195,000 in central Europe and 30,000 elsewhere, sted the reverse, and delete extraneous word ``leave;'' inserts Trost's title in 17th graf, Adm. Carlisle
DOC.TEXT: Military officials and the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee are expressing concerns about the Bush administration's agreement to cut American and Soviet forces in Europe. The White House moved to reaffirm its support for the troop cut plan, announced by Secretary of State James A. Baker III last month in Ottawa, and denied one military official's statement that the agreement is still ``being reviewed'' within the administration. The plan to cut troop levels, which must be ratified by the Senate, would allow the United States to deploy 195,000 troops in the central European zone and 30,000 troops elsewhere in Europe. ``I believe we are very seriously inhibiting our future flexibility,'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the armed services panel, said at a hearing Wednesday. Air Force Secretary Donald Rice said there were also concerns within the military, telling Nunn he understood military commanders ``would prefer to see, and I think all of us would prefer to see'' the agreement modified. He said it was being reviewed by administration officials. Gen. Larry D. Welch, the Air Force chief of staff, said the United should get an exemption to the agreement allowing for reinforcements beyond the 30,000 level in case of an emergency. White House officials said later Wednesday that modifications to the agreement are not under consideration and the agreement Baker negotiated with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze is not being reviewed. Meanwhile, Nunn attacked President Bush for failing to exclude military personnel from required budget cuts and then calling on Congress to help him avert massive layoffs. Nunn said at the hearing that the administration played games with the budget, indicating last year that it could handle the reductions but then requesting a shift in funds to avoid dismissing tens of thousands of military personnel. ``The administration is the one who clearly laid the bed of thorns and is now pointing the finger at Congress, saying, `Help us to get out of this situation,''' Nunn told reporters. Nunn and Sen. John Warner of Virginia, the panel's ranking Republican, said they favor granting the Defense Department the authority to move $852 million from other accounts to personnel to avoid the layoffs. But Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said his committee would not take up the issue of shifting the funds, thus dooming the Pentagon's request. Such ``reprogramming'' of funds must be approved by the House and Senate Armed Services Committees and the House and Senate Appropriations Committees. At Wednesday's hearing, Nunn questioned the service chiefs about why Bush did not exempt military personnel from the cuts, an option that the president could have exercised in August under the law. ``The Defense Department evidently did not come down strong on exempting personnel. If they did, they failed within the administration,'' Nunn said during the committee hearing. ``Now ... everybody in the administration is pointing at Congress, saying, `Save us from what we've done, and it's your fault if you don't save us from what we didn't do.' ``That's a curious position to be in,'' he said. Adm. Carlisle A.H. Trost, chief of naval operations, said all the service chiefs argued for exempting military personnel but were assured by administration officials that any cuts from Gramm-Rudman would be softened by a request to shift funds. Nunn said the administration shouldn't have given those assurances based on the belief that officials could later persuade four congressional committees to accept the transfer of funds. ``Somebody should have checked with the four committees because, obviously, the House wasn't plugged into that,'' Nunn said. He said he hoped the fund transfer could occur, but Aspin, in an interview later in the day, said the chances of his changing his mind were ``zero.'' ``You'll see a lot of wheeling and dealing, but it's not going to work,'' Aspin said in an interview with several reporters.

DOC.HEAD: `Injured' Workers Return After Threat of Being Videotaped
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-eight city employees have stopped taking workers' compensation since officials announced a plan to crack down on fraudulent injury claims by catching cheaters on videotape. The employees began returning to work last week, city Finance Director Ben Hayllar said Tuesday. Hayllar said last week that the city is watching and taping some employees who claimed their injuries left them unable to work. Some were seen roofing their homes and doing strenuous yard work, Hayllar said. ``I'm the Ernest Angley of Pittsburgh,'' he said, referring to a television evangelist who engages in faith healing. Most employees who are hurt on the job return to work as soon as possible, but 10 to 15 percent of the city's $17 million annual workers' compensation expense results from fraud and abuse, Hayllar said. About 300 employees remain on workers' compensation, he said.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa Reportedly Trading With Most Black African Nations
DOC.TEXT: South Africa has extensive trade and aid ties with nearly every black African nation, despite efforts to isolate Pretoria, according to a report today. Business Day newspaper said that Rusty Evans, deputy director general of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, told a meeting earlier this week that South Africa trades with all members of the Organization of African Unity, the main grouping of African states. Evans told the Institute of International Affairs trade was worth several billion dollars. The report cited other officials as saying the value of South African trade to black African nations was worth about $2 billion dollars a year. Many black African nations have bans on political, economic and other ties with South Africa to protest the policies of the white-minority government. But South African officials have said in recent months that many black nations are ignoring the bans and trading with Pretoria. Evans said South Africa is also administering scores of aid projects in many black African nations, including agricultural, medical and educational programs, the report said. He said South Africa wanted to improve relations with neighboring black nations and the opportunity had been created by reduction in Western European aid to Africa, the report said. Many Western European nations were diverting aid to East Europe, and black African nations needed South African aid to compensate, he was quoted as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Jolt a Reminder of Southern California's Quake-Prone Geology
With PM-Earthquake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The earthquake that shook up Southern California was the latest reminder that the state straddles two gigantic plates of Earth's constantly moving crust. ``The shaking most people felt was minor as opposed to what we know can happen,'' Paul Flores of the California Office of Emergency Services said of Wednesday's quake. ``Therefore people need to take the necessary precautions to prepare in reducing hazards at home and in the workplace.'' California sits on the boundary between the Pacific and North American plates, which move about two inches per year in relation to each other, said Kate Hutton, a seismologist at the California Institute of Technology. ``That motion causes strain or deformation to happen in the crust. When something snaps under that strain, it's an earthquake,'' she said. Wednesday's earthquake, considered moderate with a magnitude of 5.5 on the Richter scale, was felt from San Diego to Santa Barbara. It caused scattered structural damage, but no serious injuries were reported. Sixteen aftershocks strong enough to be felt occurred within 2{ hours of the 3:43 p.m. main shock. A 4.8 aftershock struck at 7:24 p.m. The Pacific plate underlies the Pacific Ocean and much of Southern California. It is slowly grinding northwest past the North American plate, which underlies the rest of the continent. The 600-mile San Andreas Fault generally is considered the boundary between the two plates, but the plate motion also triggers earthquakes on a complicated series of faults riddling California. The movement of the Pacific plate creates many parallel faults that run northwest to southeast and include the San Andreas, the San Jacinto and a series of offshore faults. Others, including the unnamed fault that caused Wednesday's quake, run perpendicular to the plate motion, from northeast to southwest. Those faults also are created by plate movements. Both types of faults are known as strike-slip faults in which ground on one side of a fault moves horizontally past ground on the other side. California's seismic map is further complicated by the fact that as the Pacific plate slides past the North American plate, it also presses against it. That compression can cause thrust faults, where ground on one side of a fault moves vertically with respect to ground on the other side. Thrust fault motion has caused several destructive earthquakes in California in recent years, including the 1987 Whittier Narrows quake east of Los Angeles, the 1983 Coalinga earthquake in the San Joaquin Valley and the 1971 San Fernando earthquake that killed at least 58 people in the Los Angeles area. Wednesday's strike-slip jolt occurred three miles northwest of Upland at the base of the San Gabriel Mountains, which were created by compressive thrust motion. It was centered at least 15 miles from any major faults, said the U.S. Geological Survey.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Upholds CIA Agreement With Author
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to restore state to dateline; ADDS graf on end with names of judges taking part in decision. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Former CIA agent Frank W. Snepp III must get permission from the agency before publishing a manuscript about his experiences in Vietnam, a federal appeals court ruled. A three-judge panel of the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals on Wednesday affirmed a ruling by U.S. District Judge James C. Cacheris of Alexandria. Snepp, a CIA agent in Vietnam for eight years, resigned from the agency and in 1977 published a book about his experiences called ``Decent Interval.'' The government sued Snepp for violating an employment agreement to submit all writings in advance to the CIA and the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in favor of the agency in 1980. Snepp and the CIA subsequently have agreed on publication of 18 of his manuscripts. The latest lawsuit arose out of a disagreement over Snepp's plans to write a script for a television miniseries on his experiences in Vietnam. After prolonged negotiations, the CIA approved the script but the television deal had fallen through. Snepp sued to place the burden on the CIA to initiate judicial proceedings if he and the agency could not agree on a manuscript. The appeals panel held that condition would alter the 1980 Supreme Court ruling. The three members of the appeals panel were Fourth Circuit Judges J. Dickson Phillips Jr. and Francis D. Murnaghan Jr., and U.S. District Judge Joseph Young of Baltimore, who was assigned to the appeals case in a routine move to help the circuit court deal with its workload.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun's Tanks Battle Rival Militia; At least 14 Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE casualties. Pickup 7th graf pvs, `The confrontation...'
DOC.TEXT: Fires blazed out of control and shells exploded in east Beirut today as renegade Gen. Michel Aoun's troops tried to break through the lines of a rival Christian militia. Police said 14 people were killed. Police reported savage street battles on the north and northeastern edges of the militia-held residential districts of Ashrafiyeh and Nabaa. The command of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia said in a communique that it repulsed several attempts by Aoun's M-48 tanks to smash its defenses. A police spokesman said Aoun's tanks, advancing behind a curtain of heavy howitzer shelling, ``made little progress'' on the edge of Nabaa, where the terrain is flat, but could not penetrate the militia's defenses on the slopes of Ashrafiyeh. The spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said Aoun's advance in Nabaa was ``very costly. The army has many casualties, including an officer, but we don't have details.'' He said at least 14 people were killed and 50 wounded in the day's battles. By police count, the showdown for mastery of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave has killed 708 people and wounded 1,984 since it began Jan. 30. The confrontation, the fiercest among Christians in the nearly 15-year-old civil war, also has inflicted property damage estimated at $750 million. Aoun's attack shattered a relative, 12-day lull in the Christian enclave since Feb. 17, when a Christian mediation committee called a cease-fire. On Wednesday, Christian religious leaders called for a full cease-fire and the withdrawal of rival forces from the streets of the Christian enclave before a political dialogue between Aoun and Geagea. The attack by Aoun's troops ``is the general's way of saying no to the renewal of efforts by the mediation committee to stabilize the cease-fire,'' said a Christian source close to the mediation committee. The source refused to be further identified. The pro-Geagea Voice of Lebanon radio station said its 12-story building in Ashrafiyeh took several direct hits in Aoun's howitzer shelling of the district. However, no casualties were reported among its staff, who continued to operate from shell-proofed basement studios. The police spokesman said Aoun's gunners were pounding Ashrafiyeh and Nabaa from 130mm Soviet-made howitzers at the rate of 20 shells a minute. At least a half dozen fires were blazing out of control in Ashrafiyeh and Nabaa. Because of the fierce shelling, fire engines could not leave their basement garages to combat the blazes, the spokesman said. Aoun's 19,000-strong army controls the southeastern sector of east Beirut, the eastern suburbs of Baabda, Hazmiyeh and Fayadiyeh as well as the northwestern Metn mountains. Geagea's 6,000-member militia controls two-thirds of the Christian enclave, including the two isolated pockets in east Beirut as well as Kesrouan and Byblos provinces north of the city, and part of Batroun province, which borders Syrian lines in north Lebanon. Geagea's militia controls maritime supply lines linking its Beirut war council headquarters with the port of Jounieh, provincial capital of Kesrouan. The military source said Aoun chose a rainy and stormy day to launch his new offensive in an apparent effort to ``benefit from the rough sea'' to disrupt the Lebanese Forces' maritime supply line. Geagea's militia had about 2,000 fighters deployed in the two Beirut pockets. It has made use of the 12-day lull to stockpile weapons, ammunition, medicines, food, water and fuel supplies, according to the police spokesman. Aoun has rejected parliament's election last fall of President Elias Hrawi, who has pledged to enact a peace pact. Aoun says he opposes the peace plan because it does not require the pullout of 40,000 Syrian troops, deployed under a 1976 Arab League mandate to keep the peace in the civil war. Hrawi fired Aoun as army commander, but Aoun refused to step down.

DOC.HEAD: British Spy Greville Wynne Dead At 71
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of Khrushchev in grafs 14-15 and spelling of Lubyanka Prison in 9th graf. Pickup 10th, `After his...'
DOC.TEXT: Greville Wynne, who spied on the Soviet Union for Britain during the Cold War and who spent 18 months in a Moscow prison after being caught, has died of throat cancer, hospital officials said today. He was 71. Wynne died at London's Cromwell Hospital on Wednesday, the British domestic news agency Press Association reported, quoting unidentified close friends. Hospital spokesman Tony Prescott said he was admitted with ``a well-known pre-existing condition.'' He would not elaborate. The wealthy businessman, who described his exploits in two celebrated memoirs _ ``The Man From Moscow'' and ``The Man From Odessa'' _ worked for Britain's MI6 Secret Intelligence Service. He said he acted as the intermediary for Soviet double agent Col. Oleg Penkovsky, a senior military intelligence officer who passed Moscow secrets to MI6 and the CIA. Opposition Labor Party legislator Ted Leadbitter said of Wynne in a statement to reporters Wednesday night: ``How many secrets has this man taken to his grave?'' Wynne set up his own business as an exporter of industrial engineering products in 1950. It involved a lot of foreign travel, including trips to Soviet bloc countries, and thus provided ideal cover for spying. He was arrested during a business trip to Budapest, Hungary, in November 1962 and taken to the Soviet Union. He was put on trial in Moscow on May 1963 for spying and sentenced to eight years imprisonment. Penkovsky, who was tried with him, was sentenced to death for treason. But he reportedly committed suicide in a Soviet labor camp. Wynne served 18 months in Moscow's Lubyanka Prison. However, he was freed in 1964 in exchange for Soviet spy Conon Molody, or Gordon Lonsdale as he called himself in Britain. After his release, Wynne revealed details about his espionage career. British officials have never officially commented on his accounts. He said he first joined the British security services in 1938 and worked for them during World War II. He began working for MI6 in 1960, making contact with Penkovsky. In his memoirs ``A Man From Moscow'' published in 1967 and in a later book, ``The Man From Odessa,'' Wynne revealed further details of his spying activities. He described Penkovsky as possibly the West's most valuable agent. He said Penkovsky provided him the names and photographs of about 300 East bloc intelligence agents details of Soviet missile sites, and an analysis of Soviet military manpower and weapon production. He said the double agent also told him Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev had allowed important guidance equipment to be sent with Soviet missiles being installed in Cuba. The affair developed into the 1962 Cuban missile crisis. Khrushchev later backed off and ordered the Soviet missiles returned to the Soviet Union after President John F. Kennedy ordered a naval quarantine of Cuba. Wynne said he was subjected to severe beatings and psychological pressure by the Soviet KGM. But he said his training with the MI6 was even worse. He said he was motivated by patriotism and a dislike of the Soviet system. After his release from prison, he prospered as a property developer. He was married twice. His first wife, Sheila, was present throughout his Moscow trial but divorced him after his release. They had one son. His second wife, whom he married in 1970, was Herma van Buren, his constant companion, secretary and interpreter who spoke eight languages. They separated several years ago. Funeral arrangements are incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Rules Out Palestinians From Jerusalem in Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today ruled out the participation of Palestinians from Jerusalem in peace negotiations, saying it would jeopardize Israel's claim to the holy city. ``It's clear that whoever lives in east Jerusalem will not be able to participate in these negotiations,'' said Shamir. Shamir also expressed anger at suggestions, apparently from U.S. officials, that Israel should not settle Soviet immigrants in the predominantly Arab sector of Jerusalem. ``We are very upset by some statements about the immigration of Soviet Jewish people saying that they not be permitted to live in East Jerusalem,'' he said. Shamir's hard-line remarks in an interview with The Associated Press raised questions about the prospects of success for U.S. efforts to start a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue. Such efforts are at a critical juncture with Shamir because he is under pressure from the rival Labor Party to make a decision by March 7 on whether to accept U.S. proposals for starting talks. He is also facing a major revolt by hawks in his Likud Bloc who oppose the negotiations. Shamir claimed he had support from ``80 percent or more'' of his party. He vowed to resolve the issue and provide the Israeli Cabinet with his final position ``in a few days or weeks.'' Reclining in an easy chair in his office here, the 74-year-old Israeli leader listed Jerusalem as the main stumbling block in bringing Israeli and Palestinian teams to the table in Cairo. ``Jerusalem is a key question without any doubt. We will not permit any attempt to undermine our position that Jerusalem, all of Jerusalem, will be the united capital of the state of Israel. Jerusalem will not be a subject for negotiations with the Arabs,'' he said. Israel annexed the east part of Jerusalem after capturing the predominantly Arab sector from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war. The United States and most Western countries do not recognize Israel's claim to East Jerusalem. Shamir rejected the position of Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek of the liberal Labor Party that participation of east Jerusalem Arabs was a technical problem that did not call into question Israel's claim to all of Jerusalem as its capital. ``It is naive to say that any participation of inhabitants of East Jerusalem will not have an impact on the status of Jerusalem,'' Shamir said. ``We will see to it that the inhabitants of Jerusalem will not take part in this election.'' Palestinians, who seek to make the city the capital of an independent state, have demanded that Jerusalem's 130,000 Arabs be allowed to participate in proposed Palestinian elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The balloting would chose representatives to negotiate an interim self-government plan for 1.7 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, where a 27-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation has left hundreds of Arabs and about 40 Israelis dead. The right-wing premier indicated he was not persuaded by U.S. proposals to get around his objections by naming to a 10-member negotiating team some Arabs from East Jerusalem who have alternate residences in the West Bank. ``It doesn't change the situation,'' said Shamir, who stressed that the principle of safeguarding Jerusalem's status was at issue rather than individual names being floated as possible negotiators. Speaking on army radio, Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Shamir's Likud Bloc said U.S. officials in Washington this week suggested to him that settling Soviet immigrants in East Jerusalem was improper. In light of such comments, Netanyahu said he questioned whether ``a framework exists today to continue the peace process.'' ``These things raise doubts regarding the basis of understanding with the Americans,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Deserters Say Thousands Of Vietnamese Troops Still in Cambodia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th pvs, `The two...' to ADD location of Khmer base relative to besieged town of Svay Chek. Pickup 6th, `I left...'
DOC.TEXT: Two Vietnamese deserters claimed today that thousands of Vietnamese soldiers are in Cambodia bolstering government forces who are besieged by guerrillas in the northwestern provinces. Interviews with the deserters added to mounting evidence that Vietnamese troops secretly stayed behind or returned after Vietnam announced the withdrawal of its last troops in September. This week, Vietnam and its allied government in Cambodia denied any Vietnamese troops are in Cambodia. Also today, more than 2,000 guerrillas attacked positions around the strategic town of Svay Chek in northwestern Cambodia, but government forces responded with thousands of rounds of heavy artillery. The attack occurred one day after peace talks in Jakarta, Indonesia, broke down between the Vietnamese-installed government and a coalition of three guerrilla groups: the communist Khmer Rouge, the Khmer People's National Liberation Front and fighters loyal to Prince Norodom Sihanouk. The two Vietnamese deserters were interviewed through a translator at Boeung Trakuen, a Khmer People's Front base about 10 miles northwest of Svay Chek and near the Thai border. ``I left Cambodia in September, but was sent back in November,'' said Phu Long Hip, who is from Vietnam's An Veng province. ``They told us we had to come back because we had not completed our mission.'' ``Mostly we are infantry troops, but Vietnamese officers also command tanks and artillery,'' the 25-year-old deserter said. ``There are 300 men in my battalion and we are based at Kompong Puoy, Battambang province.'' Nguyen Yang Minh, 28, said he was stationed in Bolang district, also in Battambang, since 1982 and stayed after the announced withdrawal. Minh said he was from Vietnamese Division 330, which the guerrillas claimed never left Cambodia but rather was integrated with Cambodian government units. ``In April, we switched to Cambodian uniforms,'' he said. On one of Minh's arms was a tatoo which said, ``Kampuchea 8-82,'' the date he said arrived in Cambodia. On the other arm another tatoo said, ``I have left home, but I am still close to my mother.'' He said he deserted because he was tired of being a soldier. ``I'd like to live anywhere in the world but Cambodia or Vietnam,'' he said. Commanders of the guerrillas who attacked Svay Chek today said more than 1,000 Vietnamese soldiers were helping government forces defend the town, including officers leading artillery and tank units. ``It is 100 percent that the Vietnamese are back,'' said Gen. Pan Thai, chief of staff of the Khmer People's National Liberation Front. ``Everybody knows it now.'' The guerrillas seized at least two key villages around the town today, but retreated from them under the artillery bombardment. Two guerrillas were killed as heavy rounds pounded a guerrilla command post in the jungle about six miles east of Svay Chek. The Khmer Rouge guerrilla group had claimed capturing several Vietnamese soldiers just days after the September withdrawal. Thai and Western intelligence sources say there has been a sharp increase in recent weeks of reports of Vietnamese troops in Battambang and Banteay Meanchey, another western province. ``There are numerous reports of Vietnamese troops,'' said a Western diplomat in Bangkok, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``We have no hard proof, but the gut feeling is that there are. There is too much evidence.'' While attending Cambodian peace talks in Indonesia this week, Vietnamese Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach denied any Vietnamese troops remained in Cambodia. A Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, Ho The Lan, said the same thing at a weekly news conference in Hanoi today, the Voice of Vietnam radio said. The civil war has gone on since Vietnam invaded in late 1978 to oust the Khmer Rouge. During the Khmer Rouge's 3{-year rule, hundreds of thousands of Cambodians were killed or died of famine.

DOC.HEAD: New York State to Double Bunk in 10 Prisons
DOC.TEXT: Medium-security inmates will be doubled up in bunk beds for the first time next week in a move to relieve the backlog of state prisoners now held in county jails, authorities said. Corrections Commissioner Thomas Coughlin, long an opponent of double bunking, announced the plan Wednesday. It affects 10 prison dormitories, not individual cells. The move comes in the wake of several state prison disturbances that guards have linked to the housing of inmates in makeshift quarters in prison gymnasiums. Prison official say the gymnasiums will indeed be cleared under the plan but that that is not its main purpose. On Monday, prison officials will begin to house up to 90 inmates in dormitories that have been housing 50 inmates, Coughlin said. In all, about 2,240 inmates will be double-bunked over the next three months. He said the move was necessary to comply with court orders that require New York state to take convicted inmates out of county jails more quickly. ``There are 1,200 convicted felons now housed in county jails across New York who belong in state prison,'' Coughlin said. As of Wednesday, there were 51,853 inmates in the state's prisons system, 21 percent more than the prisons were designed to hold. New York's prison population has more than doubled since 1983, when Gov. Mario Cuomo took office. The prison guards' union, Council 82, was filing an improper practice charge over the plan and looking at other possible forms of litigation, said its executive director, Joseph Puma. ``This addition of over 40 percent to the inmate population of dormitories, which are already at or over capacity, is an invitation to disaster,'' he said. Currently, inmates in the medium-security dormitories sleep in three rows of single beds, one row down each side of the dorm and one down the middle. Under Coughlin's plan, bunk beds will be installed for the two outside rows, said James Flateau, a spokesman for the state criminal justice department. The center row of beds will be left single for security reasons, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Construction Spending Increased 1.8 Percent in January
DOC.TEXT: Construction spending increased 1.8 percent in January, the government said today, as unseasonably warm weather provided the biggest gain in more than a year. The Commerce Department said residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $424 billion in January, up from December's 0.1 percent decline and the largest advance since a 2.3 percent gain in December 1988. Total spending in December, which was the fourth coldest on record, was revised upward from the 0.6 percent decline originally reported last month. January was the warmest since the government began keeping records 96 years ago. The January spending was boosted by jumps of 5.9 percent in non-residential building and a 2.9 percent gain in residential construction. Non-residential construction, which represents about 30 percent of the total, rose to a seasonally adjusted $100.8 billion including a 15 percent surge in industrial construction. Residential construction, which accounts for about 50 percent of construction spending, totaled a seasonally adjusted $195.8 billion. Single-family construction was up 2.4 percent to $117.9 billion. Apartment building was unchanged at $20.4 billion. The volatile government sector, on the other hand, fell 4.2 percent to $90.9 billion after rising 6.8 percent in December. It represents the remaining 20 percent of spending. The total construction figure was up 0.2 percent from the level of building a year ago.

DOC.HEAD: Councilman Withdraws Drug-Distribution Proposal
DOC.TEXT: The City Council unanimously repealed a decision to study the idea of distributing free cocaine and other narcotics to drug users in treatment. The repeal Wednesday night followed nearly a week of criticism from law enforcement officials and politicians, including Mayor W. Wilson Goode, who called the study a waste of time. District Attorney Ronald Castille said a free-drug program would violate state and federal laws. Councilman John Street had proposed the study, saying he believed the city was ``totally losing the war'' against drugs. Last week, without discussion, the council approved Street's request for studies of the legal and medical implications of treating various drug addicts with a system similar to the methadone clinics for heroin addicts. After a storm of criticism, two councilmen circulated resolutions to kill the study before Street offered his own, which passed unanimously.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 18 Killed By Army Gunfire in Kashmir
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 11, `There have...' to CORRECT overall death count. Pickup 12th, `Most of...
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers shot to death at least 18 Moslem protesters today who were marching toward a prayer ground for a pro-independence demonstration. The government said the shootings were in self-defense. In another incident today in Jammu-Kashmir state, a senior state government official, P.N. Handoo, was shot to death. Police blamed Moslem separatists. Ghulam Rasool Mir, who said he was injured by the army gunfire, said the trouble started when some soldiers passing by the procession in trucks snatched a flag held by march leaders. The crowd retaliated by hurling stones, and the troops fired into the air and then on the crowd, said Mir, who was admitted to Soora Medical Institute in Srinagar with injuries in the head and legs. In New Delhi, a government spokesman said the army opened fire after the mob attacked one of the vehicles. ``The firing was more in self-defense because the mob had become violent,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity in line with regulations. The spokesman confirmed 18 deaths in the army firing. ``The situation is very bad, very tense,'' he said. Dr. Sultan Khuroo, a senior physician at the Soora institute, put the death toll at 21. He said six people were brought to the hospital dead and another 11 died after being admitted. Four people died in other hospitals, and 15 were wounded, most suffering head and chest injuries, Khuroo said. The shootings occurred at the Zakura Nishad crossing, six miles from Srinagar. A witness who was among the injured, Abdul Gani Dar, said the marchers had gathered from neighboring towns and were heading to the Idgah prayer center where they planned to merge with a larger procession, which other witnesses said numbered in the hundreds of thousands. The witnesses said the second group marched from Idgah to the U.N. Military Observers office in Srinagar chanting: ``What do we want? Independence!'' There have been daily protests in Srinagar for the past week promoting the Moslem secessionist movement. With today's reported deaths, 135 people have been killed since the government began a crackdown on Moslem militants Jan. 20. Most of the victims have been Moslems killed by soldiers. Jammu-Kashmir is the only Moslem-dominated state in India, which is mostly Hindu. Kashmir was divided between India and Pakistan after the two countries were partitioned following the end of British colonial rule in 1947. Kashmiri militants had earlier campaigned for union with Pakistan, but now they are demanding independence. Handoo, an assistant director of the state information department, was shot as he was about to get into his car outside his home in the state capital, Srinagar, said officials who spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: National Assembly Passes Law on Direct Election of President
DOC.TEXT: The Hungarian people, not the legislature, will elect the country's president under a constitutional amendment overwhelmingly approved today by the National Assembly. The Assembly voted 309-13 for the amendment, reflecting widespread sentiment that the highest office in the country should be filled by a candidate who has true popular support. There were nine abstentions. The office of president did not exist under the Communists but was revived last year during talks between the opposition and the ruling Communist Party, which has since reconstituted itself into a socialist party with democratic ideals. The two sides at that time revived the office by reinstating a 1946 law that gave legislators the power to elect a president. Today's vote amended that to give the vote to the Hungarian people. No date has been set for the election. One person who has already announced he will be a candidate is Imre Pozsgay, a reformer who was instrumental in the transformation of his Communist party into a socialist party. Hungary was one of the first East bloc countries to undergo the change from a Communist-ruled nation to a multiparty system. The first free national elections since the Communists took power in 1947 will be held March 25. Also today, legislators voted to amend the education law to permit private and church-run schools and universities for the first time in more than four decades. The vote was 257 for the change, with 33 opposed and 38 abstaining. Another motion automatically giving the representatives of national minorities _ Gypsies, Croatians, Germans, Romanians, Serbs, Slovaks, Slovenes and Jews _ one seat each in the chamber was approved by 279 legislators. Opposed were 20, and 34 abstained. The number of legislators present for the various votes varied, accounting for the different totals.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Announces Sunday Landing for Shuttle; Flight Going `Satisfactorily'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with sources saying satellite deployed this morning, giving landing time as Sunday morning California time. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `NASA officials...'.
DOC.TEXT: Atlantis' all-military crew deployed a $500 million spy satellite early this morning and now plans to return to Earth at midday Sunday, sources said today. The sources, who spoke on condition that they not be identified, said the satellite was smoothly placed into orbit this morning and that Atlantis is now set to land at 10:34 a.m. PST Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Because of a Pentagon-imposed news blackout on the Atlantis mission, NASA will give no details on activities of the five-member crew. But in a three-sentence statement released today, NASA confirmed that the ``expected landing day'' is Sunday. The agency did not say what time the landing would be. ``The (Atlantis) crew is doing well and orbiter Atlantis continues to perform satisfactorily,'' the Mission Control announcement concluded. The cargo carried into orbit by Atlantis was a 37,300-pound satellite capable of taking super-sharp photographs and listening in on electronic communications around the world, according to sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. NASA officials said that a news blackout about the mission means all was well with the astronauts and that the silence was to continue unless a serious problem occurred. After five postponements, Atlantis finally got the green light to launch from Cape Canaveral, Fla., early Wednesday. As the shuttle rocketed into space, the blue, white and red light of its rockets was visible as far up the East Coast as Washington, D.C. Liftoff was delayed five times _ one short of a record for the most shuttle launch postponements. Two delays were caused by the commander's illness and uncertain weather, two were due to bad weather and a one was due to a computer failure. Atlantis was in an orbit that sources said covers a greater area of the world than any previous shuttle. In that orbit, the satellite can be put in a position to observe military bases and missile bases in northern regions of the Soviet Union, sources said. By covering most of the Soviet Union, the satellite would be important in verifying Soviet compliance with arms agreements. The mission is expected to last 4{ days, ending with a landing at Edwards Air Force Base in California. Atlantis' crew is commanded by Navy Capt. John O. Creighton. The other members are Air Force Col. John H. Casper, the pilot, and mission specialists Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane and Navy Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot. The flight is the 34th shuttle mission and the sixth dedicated solely to the military.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Say Hanford Reactor Shutdown Would Jeopardize U.S. Partnership
DOC.TEXT: Japanese physicists say U.S. plans to shut down a test reactor at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation would violate an international agreement and jeopardize future scientific partnerships between the two countries. In a letter to Energy Secretary James D. Watkins made public today, officials for the Japan Atomic Energy Reserach Institute said the administration's intention to shut down the Fast Flux Test Facility at Richlanot help but impact negatively efforts toward future cooperation.'' Sigeru Mori, chairman od, Wash., ``cannf the institute's Fusion Power Coordinating Committee, said discontinuation of FFTF would kill Japanese tests at the facility and more than five years of ``intense international collaboration'' on solid breeder materials for fusion blankets. ``It appears obvious that with the intent to shut down FFTF that you would imply an intent to break the agreement, since no other U.S. reactor has equivalent capabilities,'' Mori wrote in the Feb. 22 letter. The letter was made public today by aides to Rep. Sid Morrison, R-Wash., whose district includes the 560-square-mile nuclear reservation. FFTF, a 400-megawatt, sodium-cooled reactor, began testing fuels and materials for new types of reactors in 1982. Scientists Wed.'s sales 50,000. Wed.'s open int n.a.

At New `Dog Wash,' It's Heavy on the Suds and Hold the Wax
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS thhroughout to CORRECT name to Tri-State sted Tri-Star and specify in 2nd graf that suburbs are of Washington
DOC.TEXT: Dog owners weary of lugging Bowser into the bathtub for his Saturday night sudsing are driving to Washington's new ``dog wash,'' where the customers exit with hair ribbons instead of a slap on the bumper with a soggy towel. At Tri-State K-9 Service, which offers a sort of self-serve car wash for canines in the southern Maryland suburbs of Washington, D.C., it's heavy on the shampoo and flea dip and please hold the wax. ``At home, it gets so messy in my bathroom,'' said Jean Burson, who was grooming her freshly bathed Irish setter, April. ``I was always drenched, and there was dog hair everywhere, clogging the drain. ``This is not April's favorite thing of the day, but it makes it a lot easier for me.'' Tri-State's owner, Craig Jolly, said he opened the dog wash at his boarding kennel and obedience training school in December for the convenience of owners who want well-groomed pets without the fuss of bathing them at home. There's no heavy lifting here. Doggie customers climb wooden ramps that deposit them effortlessly into porcelain bathtubs equipped with overhead hoses. ``I know people who've gotten a bad back from lifting their 150-pound dogs into the bath,'' Jolly says. ``A pregnant woman came in here recently with a 120-pound Rottweiler, so she sure didn't want to wash that dog at home.'' The $9.99 price of the dog wash includes use of shampoos and dips, brushes, scissors, grooming shears, nail clippers and shoulder-harness blow dryers for the owners' use, along with plastic aprons to keep them dry. Jolly also supplies spray colognes for pooches with stubborn body odors, and keeps a glass jar full of brightly colored hair bows to pin on poodles and other small dogs as they prance out the door. Jolly got the dog wash idea from a trade magazine article about similar facilities that opened a few years ago in Chicago, then in California. But when business picks up in the spring, Jolly plans to add some luxurious touches worthy of a Beverly Hills spaniel spa. ``I'm going to get an exercise treadmill,'' he said, ``and a whirlpool bath for arthritic dogs. And over against that wall, I'll set up a little dog deli with chewy bones and toys, liver treats, dog milkshakes and beef rawhides that look like hamburgers and link sausages.'' Tri-State's motto is ``Dogs Are Our Only Business,'' but a woman telephoned recently to inquire whether she could bring in her very dirty cat for a wash. ``I said this is for dogs only and besides, I thought cats washed themselves,'' said manager Arthur Hamer. ``She said she'd call me back, and hung up. ``Somebody is probably going to bring in a cat or a pet rabbit someday,'' Jolly said. ``I'll let them use the dog wash if they want to try.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Marla Maples to Christen Trump's Taj Mahal
DOC.TEXT: Marla Maples, the alleged other woman in Donald Trump's divorce, will come out of hiding to accompany the billionaire at the opening of a casino hotel, a gossip columnist reported today. Bringing the actress-model to the gala the first week in April at Trump's Taj Mahal in Atlantic City, N.J., was Trump's idea, Cindy Adams reported in the New York Post. Trump didn't comment to the Post except to respond, ``Use your own imagination,'' when asked whether the appearance would be a publicity stunt or Trump's way of presenting his purported girlfriend to the world. In the past, he has said that he and Ms. Maples were just good friends. Taj Mahal spokeswoman Karen Tuso said today that she did not know about any plans for Ms. Maples to appear with Trump at the casino, which is scheduled to open April 2, with a formal ribbon-cutting three days later after a shakedown period. On April 4, the day Adams said the appearance of Trump and Maples is scheduled, Trump is scheduled to be at a real estate dinner in New York City, Ms. Tuso said. Trump's attorneys say he plans to divorce his wife, Ivana, under a prenuptial agreement that entitles her to about $25 million. But her attorneys say Mrs. Trump should receive a much bigger slice of Trump's reported $1.7 billion fortune. Mrs. Trump's lawyer, Michael Kennedy, presented a letter to Trump's attorney Wednesday claiming a December 1987 update of the prenuptial agreement contains an important omission. It refers to ``separate property,'' which under New York law means holdings held by the partners before a marriage, and makes no reference to ``marital property,'' which means assets accumulated during a marriage, the letter said. ``If he insists that Mrs. Trump has waived or released her rights to marital property, it will be necessary for us to undertake appropriate action on behalf of Mrs. Trump,'' Kennedy wrote. In other words, Mrs. Trump's attorneys might try to use the omission as the basis of a court challenge to the agreement. Trump's lawyers, Jay Goldberg and Stanford Lotwin, said in a statement that the maneuver by Mrs. Trump's side was ``pathetic.'' The Daily News reported that the 1987 agreement between Trump and Mrs. Trump gives her the right to stay in the couple's Trump Tower apartment as long as the marriage is in effect, but offers a $4 million ``housing allowance'' if she leaves before the divorce is final.

DOC.HEAD: Icy Winds and Snow Bring New Misery To Storm-Battered Europe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs UPDATING with another death in Switzerland, raising European total to 80. Pickup 7th, ``In Denmark...''
DOC.TEXT: Icy winds and heavy snow brought new misery today to storm-battered Europe where this week's turbulent weather has claimed 80 victims from Ireland to Greece. Britain, France and West Germany suffered the highest casualties and the worst damage from uprooted trees, downed power lines, blocked roads and flooded villages. Some towns along Denmark's North Sea coast were also flooded. The popular Swiss ski resort of Zermatt remained cut off by snow. Gale-whipped seas devastated the seaweed harvest off Wales, denying Welshmen their traditional St. David's Day breakfast delicacy of Laverbread which is made with the plant. Eighteen people were reported killed in Britain, 17 in France, 16 in West Germany, nine in Belgium, seven in Switzerland, six in Italy, three in East Germany, and one apiece in Austria, Greece, Ireland and the Netherlands. In Denmark, the search for a 32-year-old West German and his 6-year-old son who ventured out on a fishing trip in a small boat Monday was called off and the two were presumed drowned. Winds up to 95 mph hit much of West Germany today, disrupting rail, streetcar and automobile traffic. In Munich, schools were closed and stretches of the Autobahn around Frankfurt were blocked for hours, delaying thousands of people heading to work. Four people died, including a 48-year-old Turkish man killed when his car swerved to avoid a falling tree, and many were injured, West German police said. Prince Charles and Princess Diana interrupted a week-long skiing holiday in Switzerland and flew to Wales in freezing rain and driving wind to meet some of the 800 residents evacuated from the seaside resort of Towyn after its sea wall broke. ``Things like this always bring out the best in the British,'' said the 41-year-old heir to the British throne after visiting nearby Bodelwyddan Castle where 150 people had taken shelter. ``I saw a lot of damage and floods. It is very worrying, particularly for the elderly people who don't want to leave their homes,'' said the Prince of Wales. Snow in northern and eastern England closed roads and caused a spate of accidents. Strong winds and exceptionally high tides resulted in suspension of ferry services from Dover to France for 80 minutes. In Switzerland, authorities warned of increased avalanche risks in many parts of the Alps due to high winds. French authorities reported four more deaths _ including two firemen who were killed by an uprooted tree _ during Wednesday's storms. Another Frenchman died today when he tried to steer his car around a fallen tree, police said. President Francois Mitterrand and other officials visited two hard-hit coastal towns in Normandy to inspect wind damage. In Belgium, police said two children died Wednesday night in a house fire in Meerbeek near Brussels when firemen, blocked by trees obstructing the road, could not reach the burning home. Traffic was disrupted on at least six railway lines and some main roads in Belgium and many areas had no power, including half of the country's largest province, Luxembourg. Gale-force winds, peaking at 112 mph, buffeted western and northern Austria and claimed that country's first victim today, a 26-year-old brewery worker whose car was hit by a falling tree, police said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Baker Agreeable to Cuts, With Conditions
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration would go along with cuts to the two largest recipients of U.S. foreign aid _ Israel and Egypt _ if it were part of a broader, across-the-board reduction in aid to other friendly countries, Secretary of State James A. Baker III told Congress today. ``We're willing to stand up and be counted'' on such a cut in aid if Congress allowed the administration more flexibility to use the limited money where it is most needed,'' Baker said. Responding to a question by Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, Baker said administration support would ``depend on whether we do it in a non-discriminatory manner.'' In recent travels in the Middle East, Baker said, he has not found any significant reduction in the threat to peace. But he added: ``At the same time, we must find a way to respond to changes in Eastern Europe, in Panama and in Nicaragua.'' Baker said he did not want to see a repetition of the current year's budget crunch, in which some friendly countries that expected U.S. aid got little or nothing because 90 percent of the aid budget was already earmarked by Congress for certain other recipients. ``We ought not to be hidebound by what's been done over the past 10 years,'' Baker said. His comments marked the first time the administration has specifically said it could accept cuts to Israel and Egypt, which get the largest slice of U.S. aid as a result of their participation in the Camp David Middle East peace accord a decade ago. Israel is receiving a total of $3 billion this year and Egypt $2.1 billion, out of a roughly $10 billion overall budget for bilateral aid. The administration has asked Congress for the same amounts for both countries next year. Earlier this year, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., proposed cutting 5 percent from the top five aid recipients to create more money in the budget for emerging democracies and other needs. The administration denied planting the idea with Dole at the time but expressed agreement with its goal of increased flexibility in distributing aid money.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Strike Could Hurt Mostly Poor, Elderly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with talks today, union accusations, CORRECT spelling of Sprague, CORRECT name of organization to United Bus Owners of America. Picks up 8th graf, `A decline...'. A longer version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Drivers at Greyhound Lines threatened a strike at midnight against the only nationwide intercity bus company, a move that could hurt travelers least able to afford it. ``You may not see a lot of three-piece-suiters feeling bad that one aspect of public transportation has been hurt, but you will see a whole lot more people care about it, in round numbers, than if Amtrak closed its doors tomorrow,'' said Steve Sprague, spokesman for the United Bus Owners of America. The Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, which represents 6,300 drivers and 3,075 office and maintenance workers, said it would strike at midnight tonight unless talks in Scottsdale, Ariz., produced a new contract. Talks involving subcommittees continued today, but union spokesman Jeffrey Nelson said, ``We are more are more concerned than ever that Greyhound management simply is not prepared to negotiate in good faith, that they are not interested in attaining a fair and equitable contract.'' Nelson said that because the full negotiating committees are not face to face, the talks cannot be characterized as negotiations. The company said the chief negotiators for both sides are discussing the main economic issues, and management objected to characterizations of the talks as ``low-level.'' The main issues revolve around salary, with the company offering a first-year raise of 6.9 percent. The company says the union wants a 33 percent increase in the first year. Nelson called this figure misleading and false but would not supply the union's estimate. Greyhound drivers earned an average of $24,743 last year, the company said. Greyhound said it will use drivers hired in the past two weeks to operate a limited schedule. It plans to be back at full strength by the end of the month. The company also said it will turn over some routes to regional carriers. ``There are 500 airports and 500 train stations, but buses serve just over 10,000 communities in the country,'' Sprague said. ``For rural communities, it is lots of times the only lifeline existence.'' A decline in bus service ``will be felt unfortunately by a class of people who really don't have alternatives, some because of price and some because of the destination they go to is not served any other way,'' he said. Greyhound figures show 26 percent of its passengers are 16 to 24 years old and 15.1 percent are over 65. Just under half have a household income of less than $15,000 a year. Dallas-based Greyhound was formed three years ago by Fred G. Currey, who led an investor group that paid $270 million to Greyhound Corp. for its operation. Four months later, Currey's group paid $80 million for faltering Trailways Lines Inc. Greyhound had 22 million passengers last year, when the company says it earned its first profit, about $730,000 on about $1 billion in revenue. Greyhound went through two strikes while a subsidiary of Phoenix-based Greyhound Corp., the most recent a 1983 walkout that lasted 48 days. In Michigan, rural Suomi College braced for a strike by chartering two buses to give its 200 students a way home when spring break begins Friday. ``We just decided we wouldn't wait to hear and have a bunch of students stranded,'' said Debbie Lyttinen, secretary to the dean.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting for all needing.
DOC.HEAD: Citrus Pioneer Ben Hill Griffin Dead at 79
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to CORRECT dateline to Avon Park, sted Frostproof, ADD political career, run for governor, philanthropic activities. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Florida citrus baron Ben Hill Griffin, listed in Forbes magazine as one of the 400 richest Americans, died at his home today after a long illness. He was 79. His secretary, Donna Respress, said Griffin died early today. She had no other details, but said services would be announced later today. Forbes' October 1989 issue put him 261st on the list of wealthy Americans, and said he was worth $390 million. Griffin was a Democratic member of the Florida Legislature for 12 years, serving in both the House and Senate between 1956 and 1968. He ran unsuccessfully for governor in 1974, losing to the incumbent, Reubin Askew. Griffin studied agriculture at the University of Florida in the early 1930s and went on to become the school's largest benefactor. His gifts totaled $14.7 million. Griffin started his citrus empire in 1933, when his father gave him 10 acres of groves as a wedding present. His company, Ben Hill Griffin Inc., owned more than 10,000 acres of citrus groves and 85,000 acres of ranch and timberland in Central Florida. The Griffin family sold its packinghouses and a huge juice processing plant to Procter & Gamble Co. in 1981, which introduced its juice under the Citrus Hill brand name. Doug Bournique, executive vice president of the Indian River Citrus League, described Griffin as one who ``personifies the citrus spirit, the citrus legacy in the state of Florida.'' Last year, Hill resigned as president but remained as chief executive of publicly held Alico Inc., which controls more than 175,000 acres of Florida land managed of leased for various uses, including rock mining, oil and mineral exploration and citrus production. Both companies are now headed by his son, Ben Hill Griffin III.

DOC.HEAD: Vatican Delegates To Meet in Soviet Union Over Orthodox Issue
DOC.TEXT: Two archbishops representing the Vatican will hold talks in the Ukraine aimed at reconciling the Catholic and Russian Orthodox churches in the Soviet Union, Ukrainian church officials said Thursday. They said the talks will begin in Lvov on March 7.
