Representing the Vatican will be Archbishop Miroslav Marusyn, a Ukrainian Catholic who is secretary of the Holy See's Congregation for Eastern Churches, and Archbishop Stephen Sulyk, of the Ukrainian Archdiocese of Philadelphia and metropolitan of Ukrainian Catholics in the United States. A top-level Vatican delegation met in January in Moscow with Orthodox and Catholic leaders. Dictator Josef Stalin suppressed the Ukrainian Catholic church, forcing it to merge with the Russian Orthodox church in 1946. But the Ukrainians kept the church alive by going underground and have now been demanding both legal recognition and return of seized property. The Russian Orthodox church has been resisting the moves. The Ukrainian officials in Rome said the talks were aimed at resolving ``the practical problems connected with the normalization of the Ukrainian Catholic Church in the Soviet Union.''

DOC.HEAD: Ethiopia Appeals for Planes, Trucks for Famine Relief
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopia appealed Thursday for 14 cargo planes and nearly 600 trucks to haul food to famine victims in its northern provinces. Yilma Kassaye, the relief and rehabilitation commissioner, estimated the cost of the airlift and trucking operation at $14 million a month, above the cost of the food. The United Nations estimates that 1.1 million tons of food will be required to feed 4 million drought victims in danger of starving in the northern provinces of Eritrea, Tigre, Wollo and Gondor in the next six months. The United Nations had planned to ship most of the food through the Red Sea port of Massawa, but it was closed last month by renewed fighting between the government and the secessionist Eritrean People's Liberation Front. Kassaye said food could be shipped to Ethiopia's only other port at Assab, near the border with Djibouti, and trucked and flown to the affected areas. The government and a second rebel group which has controlled Tigre for nearly a year have agreed to allow church groups to distribute food there.

DOC.HEAD: 22 Missing After South Korean Fishing Boat Sinks
DOC.TEXT: A South Korean fishing boat capsized in the South China Sea early Friday, and 22 crew members were missing, Japan's Maritime Safety Agency reported. The 100-ton Hanaho sank about 300 miles west-northwest of Okinawa, Japan's southernmost island prefecture, said Hajime Awano of the agency's Okinawa station. One agency ship was in the area searching for survivors along with six South Korean fishing boats, and another agency ship was on its way, Awano said. There were no immediate signs of survivors, he said. Awano said he did not know the cause of the accident but said it was believed the Hanaho was hit by large waves.

DOC.HEAD: Corcoran Gallery Curator Moving to National Gallery
DOC.TEXT: Curator Franklin Kelly is leaving the Corcoran Gallery of Art, which has been the target of criticism over cancellation of a controversial photography exhibition, to return to the National Gallery of Art as research curator of American art. Kelly's resignation as the Corcoran's curator of collections and senior art historian for the past 14 months will be effective March 30. He complained of increasingly heavy administrative duties at the Corcoran, which he praised as ``a venerable and important cultural institution.'' Kelly, a former assistant curator of American art at the National Gallery, will return there April 2 to focus on the systematic cataloguing of its permanent collection of American art. It was Kelly, speaking on behalf of the Corcoran's staff, who reportedly urged gallery director Christina Orr-Cahall to resign last year amid widespread criticism of the Corcoran's cancellation of an exhibit of Robert Mapplethorpe's photographs, which included sexually explicit pictures. Ms. Orr-Cahall rejected Kelly's suggestion, but later reconsidered and resigned in December to become director of the Norton Gallery in Palm Beach, Fla. The Corcoran, the oldest private art gallery in Washington, is still searching for a successor to Ms. Orr-Cahall. Her post is being filled temporarily by Washington museum specialist David W. Scott. Other high-level staff defections have included Jane Livingston, the Corcoran's associate director and chief curator, and Bruce Yenawine, dean of the Corcoran School of Art.

DOC.HEAD: Joint Military Exercises Begin
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak-Soviet military exercises began in the western part of the country Thursday, the state CTK news agency said. The brief dispatch gave no details beyond saying that about 5,000 Czechoslovak and 1,200 Soviet troops _ members of the central group of Soviet forces in Czechoslovakia _ were participating. The exercises began four days after the historic start of a complete Red Army pullback from Czechoslovakia. The maneuvers were first made public in Czechoslovakia as the withdrawals began, and the timing was possibly meant as a signal that the country remains a dependable political ally despite the pullout and its non-Communist leadership. The last of 73,500 Soviet troops is scheduled to leave in mid-1991, marking an end to more than two decades of the Red Army's presence. Soviet soldiers headed a partial Warsaw Pact invasion in 1968, which crushed attempts at political liberalization that became known as the ``Prague Sping.''

DOC.HEAD: Full Calendar Delays Trip to Japan, Visits by Irish, Egyptian
DOC.TEXT: An unexpectedly busy schedule for the Soviet leadership has forced postponement of Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze's trip to Japan and visits by the leaders of Egypt and Ireland, an official said Thursday. Gennady I. Gerasimov, the Foreign Ministry spokesman, told a news briefing the delays were due to the ``full schedule'' of Soviet leaders, including an extraordinary session of the Congress of People's Deputies, which was ordered this week to convene March 12. ``We're guilty,'' Gerasimov quipped to reporters who asked if the postponements were a sign of shifts in Kremlin relations with the other countries. He said the only reason for the delays was the need to focus on domestic affairs. The Supreme Soviet, the nation's legislature, is considering a set of bills designed to give force of law to many of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic and social reforms. In addition, the Communist Party has moved up its nationwide congress, originally scheduled for October, to mid-June. Shevardnadze, a member of the ruling Communist Party Politburo, had been expected to visit Tokyo sometime in March. That trip was designed in part to prepare for the first visit to Japan by Gorbachev, which would be the first by any Soviet leader. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak had been expected to visit Moscow March 19, according to government sources in Cairo. Charles Haughey, the Irish prime minister, had expressed the hope of visiting Moscow while his country holds the revolving chairman of the 12-nation Common Market. That expires in June. Gerasimov said new dates for the visits were being discussed.

DOC.HEAD: Foes, Supporters Agree: Licensing Decision Took Far too Long
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with NCR vote today. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `When the ...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Seabrook, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In the battle over licensing of the Seabrook nuclear plant, supporters and foes agree on one thing at least: The decision was put off too long. ``I never thought it would take this long,'' said former Gov. Meldrim Thomson, a Seabrook proponent who served from 1973 to 1979. ``If any human being could dream up anything worse, they would have to work at it.'' On the other side, anti-Seabrook protester Dianne Dunfey also criticized delays in the ruling by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which today licensed the nuclear power plant to begin producing commercial electricity. Barring further court maneuvering, the NRC decision sets the stage for the 1,150-megawatt reactor to begin operating at full power within three months. The board's decision was by a 3-0 vote and ratified recommendations by the commission's staff and several lower-level boards. The NRC is ``one of the most disreputable of all government agencies,'' said Dunfey, a Seabrook schoolteacher, who was released from jail last week after serving a five days for refusing to pay a fine over a Seabrook-related sit-in. ``It has ignored public input,'' she said. ``It either discarded or amended all of its own regulations any time Seabrook couldn't meet one.'' Asked why the licensing procedure took as long as it did, NRC spokesman John Kopeck in Washington, said, ``There was a legal process that it had to go through _ there were a lot of steps that had to be taken.'' When the plant was proposed in 1968 by Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the cost was estimated at $978 million. That has swelled to $6.5 billion. The utility filed for bankruptcy protection in 1988, in part because of the costs of the plant. Environmentalists have been battling the utility and NRC over Seabrook since 1976, when the Clamshell Alliance staged its first display of civil disobedience shortly before the Aug. 5 groundbreaking. Thousands have since been arrested. The final step in the licensing process for the plant 40 miles north of Boston has done little to calm the emotions that made Seabrook a symbol of the anti-nuclear movement. The main sticking point to licensing has been federally mandated evacuation plans for communities within 10 miles of the plant, which is near popular Hampton Beach. Opponents maintain the area is too densely populated to evacuate quickly. ``I think it's a disgrace,'' said Russ Arscott, a Seabrook resident for 61 years. ``There's no way to evacuate the area. I just hope the pipes all hold.'' Ray Colbert moved to Hampton Beach last year knowing little about the plant, which can be seen from his porch. He said he plans to move to Florida in May, partly because of the reactor. ``I might stay if that thing wasn't so close,'' he said. But ``I've got a 5-month-old daughter. I want to get her the hell out of here before they fire that thing up.'' Others look forward to the day the plant finally produces electricity. ``We need it,'' said Thelma Grinnell, a resident of nearby Salisbury, Mass., for the past 25 years. ``We need something other than fossil fuels. We're destroying the environment.'' The evacuation zone has a population of 148,000, which swells to a summertime peak of 247,000. The plant's operator, New Hampshire Yankee, estimates it could take up to 10 hours to move people out of the zone in an emergency. On a summer day, according to Deputy Massachusetts Attorney General Stephen Jonas, there are more people within three miles of the Seabrook reactor than any other reactor in the country. ``Anybody who's been in a traffic jam (near the plant) during the summer knows that in a panic situation, evacuation would be impossible,'' said Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H. Seabrook proponents, including former Gov. John Sununu, now White House chief of staff, say the plans will work.

DOC.HEAD: For Many in Beirut, Surviving is All That's Left
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: ``Eat! Eat! We must survive this war!'' Amin Daher exhorted his nervous family as exploding artillery shells rocked his apartment in Christian east Beirut. His wife, Angele, wearily picked up the fork that kept slipping from her trembling fingers and rattled against her plate with each shell blast. ``May God enlighten them. May God enlighten them,'' she murmured, picking at a lunch of lentils and rice, fried cauliflower and eggplant and cabbage salad. The Dahers shared the lunch one day recently with a couple of neighbors, spread around a table in one of their apartment's bedrooms that has been turned into a makeshift shelter. Their five-story apartment building, like many built before the civil war began in April 1975, has no basement shelter. Everyone flinched as shells fired by fellow Christians exploded around their building. ``We have to keep going despite the grim future that awaits us,'' Daher said. ``We should never give up.'' The family used to climb down to share the shelter of a neighboring building, but that has come to be increasingly dangerous. Besides, Mrs. Daher has a weak heart and her husband suffers from asthma. So the children fortified the bedroom with stone blocks. The stone protects them from blast and shrapnel, but would not save them from a direct hit. Still, it's better than nothing. When the shelling is heavy, the Dahers and some neighbors crowd into the 10-foot-by-10-foot room and sleep on the floor. They have taken the beds out to make room for everyone. Beside a flickering candle, a small statue of the Virgin Mary stands atop the TV set. The set is of no other use: there is no electricity. ``Life has come down to just filling our bellies. What kind of life is this? What kind of future will my children have?'' lamented the tall, balding Daher, 64, a retired customs officer. The apartment building is in the Ashrafiyeh district, which lies on the Green Line dividing Beirut. The district has been continuously battered since 1975. It was the scene of heavy fighting in the first two years of the conflict between Christians and Moslems. The Syrians besieged it for 100 days in 1978, pounding it with artillery fire. Since then, Moslem gunners and snipers routinely have fired into the buildings, more exposed than most because Ashrafiyeh sits atop the highest hill in Beirut. More than 150,000 people are estimated to have been killed in the civil war, twice as many wounded, and another 1 million, one fourth of the prewar population, displaced. In the current bloodletting, rebel Gen. Michel Aoun's troops are battling the Lebanese Forces militia, commanded by onetime medical student Samir Geagea, for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave north of Beirut. Nearly 700 people have been killed and 2,000 wounded in the confrontation so far. Ashrafiyeh is one of Geagea's two remaining strongholds in east Beirut, which makes it a target for Aoun's artillery and tanks. Aoun holds the districts to the east. The Green Line hems Ashrafiyeh in to the southeast while the Mediterranean lies to the north. The Dahers live with four of their children, sons Nazih, 32, a civil defense worker; Nadim, 28, an administrator with the Labor Ministry; Elie, 25, who works in a boutique; and daughter Nada, 21, a computer major. Their eldest son, Najib, was killed four months after the civil war started, when he was 19. A married daughter, Maha, 30, lives in the mountain resort of Bikfaya, which has escaped most of the fighting. Nazih has been missing since the latest fighting began Jan. 30. He was visiting friends in the port of Jounieh, north of Beirut, when Aoun moved against Geagea. Aoun's troops hold the area between Jounieh and Ashrafiyeh. All the telephone lines have been cut, so one knows if he's alive or dead. ``We just don't know anything about Nazih,'' his distraught mother whispered. ``We sent him a message over the radio that we're all fine. I hope he heard it.'' Nearly one-fourth of Ashrafiyeh's estimated 150,000 inhabitants have fled to safer areas. But the Dahers have nowhere to go, no relatives living in safer zones. As if Mrs. Daher, 54, didn't have enough troubles, Elie is bed-ridden with the flu. ``The doctors in our area have all left. We couldn't find vitamins for him. I hope his condition doesn't deteriorate,'' she said as she squeezed a few shriveled oranges she found in a nearby shop to make juice for Elie. The Dahers' car was hit by a mortar round the second day of the fighting. Their kitchen took a direct hit two weeks later, but no one was hurt. ``We shouldn't be sad about material losses. They can be replaced. But human lives _ '' Mrs. Daher said, her gaze wandered to a framed photo of her dead son on the wall of the shabby living room. The Dahers, like many other Lebanese families, have learned to adjust to the seemingly endless violence. ``We shave every four days and save water by using the water we wash our clothes and the dishes with to flush the toilet,'' Elie said.

DOC.HEAD: New York City Council President Denies In-Flight Tantrum
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Different names for father and son in 3rd graf cq.
DOC.TEXT: The FBI is investigating whether New York's city council president and his wife criminally interfered with an airline flight by throwing tantrums, a newspaper reported today. The incident involved a dispute with flight attendants over whether council President Andrew Stein's wife, Lynn, was entitled to travel in the first-class section on a flight to Puerto Rico. Allegations include that Mrs. Stein pushed an American Airlines flight attendant, who fell to the floor of the airplane; that Stein, the 45-year-old son of millionaire law journal publisher Jerry Finkelstein, called two attendants ``servants''; and that both Steins used obscenities, the Daily News said, quoting unidentified sources. American Airlines confirmed that there was an investigation under way but gave no details of the alleged incident. The Steins denied all allegations, saying the incident was the fault of an incompetent crew. In fact, Stein said, the airline apologized for the Jan. 19 incident and gave them six free round-trip tickets to San Juan worth more than $3,000. Mary O'Neill, spokeswoman for American Airlines in Dallas, said of the incident, ``We understand it's under investigation and we simply cannot comment.'' Asked who was investigating, she replied, ``We undersand it's the FBI.'' The News' sources said several attendants and a cockpit crew member filed reports on the altercation and the airline forwarded them to the FBI. The Steins, their two children and Stein's parents were aboard Flight 677 en route to San Juan for a vacation. Stein said all family members had first-class tickets, his wife's ticket having been upgraded from economy just before boarding. But the News sources said Mrs. Stein had only an economy ticket, and asked a flight attendant shortly after takeoff if she could go talk with her husband in the first-class section. Sources said Mrs. Stein became abusive when an attendant asked her for her boarding pass. Stein joined in with foul language, both tossed personal items at attendants and Mrs. Stein pushed an attendant to the floor, the newspaper's sources said. The Steins are being investigated for interference with a flight, a felony punishable by up to 20 years in jail, and an assault charge is being weighed against Mrs. Stein, the paper reported.

DOC.HEAD: Forbes Mourned in Park Avenue Service
DOC.TEXT: Former President Richard Nixon, actress Elizabeth Taylor, Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca and hundreds of other mourners filled St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church today for a memorial service for publisher Malcolm Forbes. Forbes died Saturday after suffering a heart attack at his estate in Far Hills, N.J. He was 70. The service featured music on a variety of instruments loved by the Forbes magazine owner, including Scottish bagpipes and English horns. Nixon sat in the front pew of the landmark Park Avenue church, near his daughter Julie Eisenhower, Miss Taylor, and former mayor Edward I. Koch. Other mourners included Barbara Walters, Joan Rivers and David Rockefeller. ``Remember that you are but dust, and into dust you shall return,'' the Rev. Thomas Bowers, pastor of St. Bartholomew's, said in his homily.

DOC.HEAD: King Apologizes For Remarks Against Homosexuals
DOC.TEXT: Martin Luther King III apologized today for saying ``something may be wrong'' with homosexuals, which sparked anger among gay rights leaders. King, the son of the late civil rights leader, said the legacy of his father's life was ``the struggle to free this country of bigotry and discrimination.'' In that light, he said he needed to examine his own feelings about the problems faced by gays and lesbians. King, a Fulton County commissioner, enraged gays on Tuesday when he told middle school students in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., that homosexuals have a problem. ``Now something may be wrong in the makeup of that individual if they happen to be that way,'' he said. ``Any man that has a desire to be with another man has a problem, in my opinion. And that applies to any woman who has a desire to be with another woman.'' But today he said the statements were ``uninformed and insensitive.'' ``For this I extend my sincere apology to the entire community and in particular to the gay and lesbian community, certainly which has been hurt most by this incident,'' King said at the brief news conference. He took no questions. Bill Gripp, one of several gay rights leaders who met privately with King after the conference, said he was satisfied with the apology. ``I congratulated him on his statement,'' Gripp said. ``I couldn't have liked it more if I'd written it myself.'' The New York-based Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation called King's remarks ``strange and upsetting,'' and the Atlanta Gay Center requested the meeting with King to discuss the remarks.

DOC.HEAD: Policeman Investigating Suicide Finds Victim is His Son
DOC.TEXT: A senior police officer investigating an apparent suicide Thursday discovered that the victim was his son, authorities said. ``That's my son!'' Athos Epiphaniou cried out in anguish on arriving at the scene, according to other officers. Epiphaniou, chief operations officer of Larnaca town police, was summoned from his office by subordinates after neighbors reported a man had fallen to his death from atop an eight-story building. After the discovery, he was led away from the scene by colleagues, said other police officers, who did not wish to be identified. The officer had said his 26-year-old son, Christakis, who had been studying architecture in the United States, apparently had been suffering from psychological problems, one of the officers added. Epiphaniou said his son left home early Thursday, saying he wanted some fresh air as he was not feeling well, the sources said.

DOC.HEAD: CIA Director: Reversal of Radical Changes in Europe Unlikely
With AM-Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: CIA Director William Webster said Thursday reversing the radical changes in Eastern Europe is highly unlikely with little chance of the Soviets regaining their domination and the Communist Party near ruin. ``As these upheavals continue to gain momentum, they will be progressively more difficult to suppress,'' Webster told the House Armed Services Committee in an unclassified assessment of the dramatic push toward democracy in the Eastern bloc. The result of these sweeping changes is a diminished Soviet threat that significantly reduces the likelihood of an attack on U.S. and Western European forces while increasing the length of time it would take the Soviets to mobilize, he said. The CIA director said a reversal in the reforms could occur in the Soviet Union if President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ousted but that the Kremlin leader recently strengthened his hold on power and his removal is unlikely. Hardliners in the Soviet Union face a daunting task with the call for reforms highly popular and returning the country to the old policies nearly impossible. ``Those demanding an acceleration of reform still have the upper hand ... and many Soviet citizens are pressing for radical change,'' Webster said. Traditionalists, if they succeeded Gorbachev, would have to revive the military policies of the past as well as the costly weapons-buying agenda, or create a new approach, said the CIA chief. ``Either course would be disruptive and expensive, and would result in significantly lower readiness, at least in the short term,'' Webster said. ``More importantly, rebuilding forces to traditional levels would be unpopular with a populace weary of shortages and sacrifices.'' The Soviets' overriding concern would be solving the widespread economic problems, not building up the military. Webster predicted that any successor to Gorbachev would pursue arms controls pacts with the West. ``It would be unlikely ... to seek a broad reversal of the changes that have occurred in Eastern Europe, or to try to revive the Warsaw Pact,'' he said. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, described Webster's comments as ``remarkable,'' and suggested that this assessment puts the United States ``in kind of a win-win situation.'' Aspin made the comments before closing the question-and-answer portion of the hearing to the public and news media. In his statement, the CIA director also raised doubts about hardliners using the Soviet military as a police force that could put down reform movements among the people. ``If faced with large and widespread unrest, they would be severely tested,'' Webster said. ``There is no way to predict how military commanders and troops would respond if ordered to fire on civilians. ``But Soviet hardliners would remember that Romanian armed forces ultimately refused to save the Ceausescu regime from the wrath of its people and instead joined in toppling him,'' he said. Elections in the 15 Soviet republics during the next few months will strengthen the reform effort and pressure the Kremlin to step up the pace of change. Webster predicted that the Baltic States will likely work out an amicable separation from the Soviet Union during the next few years. But ethnic and religious problems in Central Asia and the Caucasus will continue, and Moscow might choose to use its military forces as it did in Azerbaijan. Webster acknowledged that a crackdown on reform efforts, similar to the action China took last June in putting down the revolt in Beijing's Tiananmen Square, could occur elsewhere. But in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, ``it would be much more difficult and costly for hardliners to reverse reform than it has been in China so far.''

DOC.HEAD: More Veterans May Quality for Benefits Under New Court Ruling
DOC.TEXT: Additional veterans may be entitled to cash benefits under the Supplemental Security Income program for the low-income aged, blind and disabled, the government said Thursday. The Social Security Administration said it was launching a public information campaign to let veterans know about a federal court ruling in Montana that could affect their eligibility for SSI benefits. Under the ruling, the government cannot count the extra veteran's benefits that a person receives for a spouse or children when it determines the veteran's eligibility for SSI. The Supplemental Security Income program provides monthly benefits to 4.5 million aged, blind and disabled people who have little or no income and resources. Maximum monthly benefits this year are $386 for an individual and $579 for a couple. The Social Security Administration said it was sending notices to 28 magazines that serve veterans and has asked the Department of Veterans Affairs to help notify people about the change. Veterans who think they might be eligible for SSI benefits should contact their nearest Social Security office or call SSA's toll-free number, 1-800-234-5772. The best times to call are between 7 a.m. and 9 a.m. and between 5 p.m. and 7 p.m., when operators are not as busy. Veterans who have applied for or received SSI benefits since November 1981 should call or visit SSA to see if they are eligible for additional benefits. Individuals who think they might be affected by the ruling should mention the court ruling, known as the Anderson case, when they contact Social Security.

DOC.HEAD: Volcano Quiet After Two Blasts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with situation quiet this morning. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `AN Anchorage...'.
DOC.TEXT: Redoubt Volcano roared back to life with two eruptions inside an hour that sent a gray sooty column more than seven miles into the sky and dropped ash for the first time on Anchorage. The volcano settled down late Wednesday and remained quiet this morning, but tremors beneath the mountain led scientists to believe it may erupt again soon. The volcano, 115 miles southwest of Anchorage, painted clouds a dark gray over Alaska's largest city, then dusted the snow-covered city of 173,000 with abrasive ash. Another snowfall this morning largely covered the ash. An Anchorage hospital handed out several hundred free masks to people complaining of respiratory problems, and some pedestrians wore scarves over their faces. Some flights in and out of Anchorage were disrupted. A moderate eruption was registered shortly before 9 a.m. AST, and a much stronger blast at 9:47 a.m. sent a plume 37,000 feet into the air about an hour later, said Tom Miller of the Alaska Volcano Observatory. ``It's been quiet since the last explosion,'' said John Ewert, another spokesman from the observatory. He added: ``There has been a lot of earthquake activity over the last several days. As long as this activity continues, we see an increased level of concern for explosive activity in the near future.'' The 10,197-foot peak sprang back to life in mid-December after being quiet for more than two decades and has erupted intermittently since. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone, expressing concern that jurors wouldn't be able to get home because of limited driving visibility, recessed the criminal trial of Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood two hours early. At Elmendorf Air Force base, just north of Anchorage, aircraft were put in hangars. ``A big cloud moved over. Nothing fell out of it. After it passed, ash started falling,'' said Sgt. Dave Haulbrook, a base spokesman. A number of Delta, United and SAS flights were delayed or diverted from Anchorage International Airport, which remained open, said Marsha Sampson, a spokeswoman. Anchorage Police were issued masks and air filters for their patrol cars. ``That's just for those whose cars suddenly need a filter change, and for anyone having to work outside,'' said police spokesman Walt Monegan. The Drift River Oil Terminal was evacuated as a precaution, said Dave McDowell of the state Division of Emergency Services in nearby Wasilla. Most of the oil was drained after earlier Redoubt eruptions because of concern that flooding in the adjacent Drift River could damage the tanks and send oil into the fish-rich Cook Inlet. Miller said scientists' ability to predict the mountain's activity remains limited because of equipment damage from an eruption last week. ``We still don't have our summit station,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Post Office Facing a World of Change
DOC.TEXT: Postmaster General Anthony M. Frank says he is optimistic about the future, despite the fact that the post office is preparing to raise rates as it faces the largest dollar loss in postal history. Frank said he is encouraged because productivity has increased in recent months, the pending rate increase will improve finances and more automation is being introduced. Plans for a 1991 increase in the price of sending mail, including a 30-cent stamp for first class letters, are expected to be announced next week. The Postal Service is expected to complete this fiscal year $1.6 billion in the red, Frank told the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee. ``It may seem paradoxical to say so, but I can tell you that I am more optimistic about the Postal Service now than I've been since I came here,'' said Frank, who is just completing two years in office. Frank has set a goal of having bar codes _ those rows of little lines similar to the price codes in grocery stores _ on all mail by 1995 as part of his automation program. With the codes, the majority of mail handling can be done by machine prior to final delivery. ``We expect more changes in the Postal Service in the next five years than in the past 200. And that's not an overstatement,'' Frank told the committee. Labor negotiations this summer offer a chance to increase union cooperation in improving postal operations, Frank added. ``In the labor negotiations we are going to ask our employees' representatives to show some constructive restraint,'' said Frank. Both wage restraint and more flexibility in scheduling are needed to take advantage of automation, he said. No one working for the postal service need fear for their job, however, he said. ``We can make all the adjustments we need to stay competitive through attrition.'' If first-class rates rise to 30 cents, that would mean they have gone up more than inflation since the last hike in 1988. ``That's totally unacceptable to the people who pay our bills and it's unacceptable to me,'' said Frank. ``I've set a goal of getting to the point where our costs will be kept a full 2 percent below inflation ...'' The rate case will also include some lower rates for bulk mail that can be handled by machinery, in an effort to encourage large mailing firms to prepare the mail in a way machinery can deal with it, he said. Asked about an Office of Management and Budget proposal for a special, lower rate for government agencies, Frank said the estimated $220 million cost of that cut would simply have to be shifted to others who use the mail. The post office no longer receives any government subsidy, so it has to cover its expenses with income and any cut in money coming in has to be balanced by charging someone else more. There probably are $200 million in savings available to government agencies if they would simply use the bulk rate discounts available now, Frank said. Rep. William D. Ford, D-Mich., told Frank that he and other committee members plan to oppose an administration proposal to shift $1.3 billion in federal retirement costs to the Postal Service. ``This is simoply an arbitrary grab to get some cash,'' said Ford.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Restores Preferential Tariffs for Panamaf
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday lifted a trade sanction imposed against Panama two years ago during the rule of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The action, part of the gradual lifting of economic sanctions against Panama, restores preferential tariff treatment under the Generalized System of Preferences and the Caribbean Basin Economic Recovery Act. With Noriega facing federal drug charges in Florida, Bush said that Panama ``is taking adequate steps'' to prevent the sale and shipment of drugs and the laundering of drug profits. Bush announced his action during a four-day trip to California.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun's Forces Penetrate East as Fighting Enters Second Month
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Michel Aoun's tanks pierced the defenses of the rival Christian militia in savage fighting Thursday in east Beirut as the showdown entered its second month. Police said at least 14 people were killed and 50 wounded in seven assaults by Aoun's American-made M-48 tanks against the urban lines of Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia. By police count, the fight for control of the 310-square-mile Christian enclave has killed 708 people and wounded 1,984 since it broke out Jan. 30. A police spokesman reported minor progress by Aoun's tanks, which advanced over nine hours across the open terrain to the edge of the urban area of Nabaa, a pocket held by the Lebanese Forces. The advance shattered a 12-day lull that followed a cease-fire called by a neutral mediation committee. ``The tanks are at the entrances to the narrow alleys'' of the densely populated low-income district, the spokesman said. He said it would be ``extremely dangerous'' to push the tanks into the slum-like district, where they would be easy targets for Geagea's experienced street fighters using armor-piercing rocket-propelled grenade launchers. The advance stopped at 2 p.m. after the captain commanding the attack was killed, but the two sides maintained a fierce exchange of howitzer and mortar shells at the rate of about 40 rounds a minute, said the spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said Aoun's tanks had failed to advance along the slopes of Ashrafiyeh, the militia's second stronghold in east Beirut. The neighborhood spills over the highest hill in the Lebanese capital. A dozen fires blazed out of control in Ashrafiyeh and Nabaa. Smoke billowed from the districts, and the fire department said its engines were not able to leave their underground basement centers to combat the blaze due to the intensity of the clashes. Christian radio stations repeatedly interrupted regular programming to flash reports on fires in Ashrafiyeh and Nabaa and urge fire fighters to deal with them. Aoun's command, in a communique, said Geagea's gunners were pounding residential districts under the army's control from multi-barrelled rocket launchers capable of spitting out 40 projectiles a minute. The communique said the militia fire also targeted Aoun's headquarter at the shell-wrecked presidential palace in of Baabda, east of the capital. Aoun's 19,000-strong army controls the southeastern sector of east Beirut as well as Baabda, nearby Hazmiyeh and Fayadiyeh and the Metin mountains. The Lebanese Forces, which has a hardcore strength of 6,000 fighters and can call up a reserve force of 30,000, controls two-thirds of the Christian enclave, including the two pockets in east Beirut. The militia's area also covers the Kesrouan hinterland north of the capital, adjacent Byblos province and part of the Batroun province which borders Syrian army lines. A mediation committee of three independent Christian figures called a cease-fire for 1:30 p.m., but fierce shelling duels persisted throughout the day. The Lebanese Forces command, in a communique, said Aoun's troops did not achieve any significant gains. The communique, repeatedly broadcast by the pro-Geagea Voice of Lebanon radio station, said the militia's defenses were ``solid and the morale of our fighters is very high.'' The militia has 2,000 fighters in the east Beirut pockets linked with its main bases in Kesrouan only by maritime supply lines because Aoun's troops control the road between the areas. A military source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Aoun chose a stormy day to launch his new offensive in an apparent effort to ``benefit from the rough sea which reflects negatively on the Lebanese Forces' maritime supply line.'' The militia had made use of the 12-day lull to stockpile weapons, ammunition, medicines, food, water and fuel supplies, according to the police spokesman. The military source noted that Aoun deployed 130mm Soviet-made howitzers in the battle Thursday instead of the army's standard U.S.-made 155mm guns which reflected ``his bad need for ammunition.'' Geagea's militia captured more than 50,000 155mm howitzer shells when they overran Aoun's depots at the Sarba garrison in Kesrouan early in February, the source said.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo's Daughter Ticketed in Car Crash A Day Late; Police Blame `Oversight'
Precede NEW YORK
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with daughter ticketed, lapse blamed on oversight. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo's daughter has been charged with driving without a valid license, a full day after she was in a traffic accident, police said today. They said the failure to ticket her earlier was an oversight and not favoritism. State officials said the license of the Albany Law School graduate had expired six months ago. Madeline Cuomo, 25, was ticketed Wednesday night, said Albany Police Sgt. Robert Wolfgang. She should have been issued the ticket at the scene of the accident Tuesday night, but the officer hadn't noticed that Ms. Cuomo's license had expired, Wolfgang said. ``In the confusion, it was an oversight that he did not note the expiration of the license,'' Wolfgang said. ``When it was brought to his attention ... he investigated further and issued the ticket.'' Police learned of the expired license by the New York Post, which reported the fact in today's editions. Ms. Cuomo cut her lip when the car she was driving collided with another vehicle at about 8:05 p.m. Tuesday. The driver of the other car, 27-year-old Karen Bellamy of Buffalo, was not injured. Ms. Cuomo told police that the other car was backing out of a driveway when it hit her car, but Ms. Bellamy was not ticketed. Driving without a license is punishable by a fine of between $50 and $200, said state Department of Motor Vehicles officials. Cuomo aides said the governor had no comment on the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Predicts Huge Personnel Reductions
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department may shrink by several hundred thousand employees in the next three or four years as a result of budget cuts and arms control treaties, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Thursday. Cheney, testifying before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, provided an overview of Defense Department policies in a wide-ranging session with lawmakers. Cheney stood by the Bush administration's plan to cut troop levels in Europe, allowing 195,000 U.S. troops in the European central zone and 30,000 troops elsewhere in Europe. The troop plan was ironed out by Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in Ottawa, Canada, last week. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, on Thursday joined Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., in criticizing the plan for failing to give the United States enough flexibility. Air Force Secretary Donald Rice has also questioned the plan. But Cheney said that ``195,000 is the administration's policy.'' The White House has also reaffirmed support for the Baker-Shevardnadze deal. Cheney, meantime, said proposed language in the Conventional Forces in Europe treaty, which the United States and the Soviet Union hope to conclude this year, calls for a demobilization of roughly 30,000 to 35,000 U.S. troops. ``That's the treaty requirement, yes, but we're probably looking at much larger reductions on the basis of budget constraints,'' Cheney said. While he refused to cite hard figures, Cheney said, ``I would speculate that over the next several years _ three or four years _ we are looking at reductions in the overalll size of the Defense Department of several hundred thousand.'' Cheney said the Soviets want a longer time _ five to seven years opposed to three to five years _ to demobilize their troops because Moscow expects difficulty repatriating their forces at home. He also said there may be additional U.S. troop reductions in Korea and Japan. Most of the reductions in the Pentagon's 2.1 million workforce would occur by slowing down the number of people brought into the system, he said. But he said officials are making long-range plans to prepare for those leaving the services, including housing and education. Besides discussing manpower, Cheney pleaded with House members to use their influence so he can channel _ or reprogram _ $852 million from procurement and research programs to the personnel account. Without permission from Congress to make such a change, the Pentagon will be forced to lay off people, freeze promotions and take other drastic management steps, Cheney said. ``This is a classic example of how Congress can do serious damage to our military capability _ long-term damage of the kind none of us wants to see,'' Cheney said. The House and Senate Armed Services Committees as well as the appropriations committees would have to approve reprogramming. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House panel, said he is opposed to reprogramming. The budget crunch occurred because the military was included in deficit reduction cuts mandated by the Gramm-Rudman act. On other issues, Cheney: _Defended the decision to send Egypt some 700 tanks that are to be declared surplus by U.S. troops in Europe. He said the tanks will replace aging equipment, and Israel had been consulted about the deal. _Predicted tough negotiations over the future of two U.S. bases in the Philippines. _Engaged in a heated discussion with Rep. Peter Kostmayer, D-Pa., over the proposed $303 billion Pentagon budget for fiscal 1991. ``You're not going to get $303 billion and you don't deserve it,'' said Kostmayer. At one point, Cheney objected to an interruption by Kostmayer. ``You had your chance, congressman, now it's my turn.''

DOC.HEAD: Talks on Soviet Troop Withdrawal Break Down
DOC.TEXT: Talks have broken down between the Soviet Union and Hungary on a timetable for the withdrawal of Soviet troops, the state MTI news agency reported Thursday. Hungarian Foreign Ministry State Secretary Ferenc Somogyi said there were major differences standing in the way of an agreement, but he did not rule out an accord in the near future. The delegations would report back to their governments, according to MTI. In mid-February, Somogyi had said an agreement permitting the approximately 50,000 Soviet troops to leave Hungary was likely within a month. Unlike Hungary, Czechoslovakia last month reached an agreement with the Soviet Union on the beginning of a three-stage pullback of 73,500 Soviet troops from its territory that is scheduled for completion next year. Most of the Soviet troops arrived in Czechoslovakia with the Warsaw Pact suppression of the ``Prague Spring'' reforms of 1968; they entered Hungary to quash the 1956 anti-Stalinist uprising. Somogyi, who did not detail his country's position, said Hungarians insisted on the earliest possible date for the completion of the withdrawal _ by early 1991 at the latest. On Tuesday, the Hungarian side had expressed optimism an agreement would be likely by March 10. The was no comment from the Soviet delegation, led by Deputy Foreign Minister Ivan Aboimov. The talks began Feb. 1.

DOC.HEAD: President Denies Secret Talks on Lebanon Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 6 grafs with further Bush quotes; adds byline
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today denied reports that any breakthrough is near on release of Americans held hostage in Lebanon and said, ``There are no secret talks going on.'' He told reporters that a spate of recent news reports concerning movement in the hostage situation are ``ridiculous stories.'' However, he said, ``I don't spend a day that I don't think about the hostages ... I will do everything I can,'' to win their freedom. Bush said that when he heard the recent reports of secret U.S.-Iranian talks in Geneva regarding the hostages, which originated with a London-based Arab newspaper, he asked national security adviser Brent Scowcroft to check into their veracity. Scowcroft reported back, ``There are no talks going on,'' Bush said. His denial was in line with statements earlier this week by White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater and other administration officials throwing cold water on reports of progress in efforts to free the hostages. Moslem militants with ties to Iran are believed to be holding 18 Western hostages, including eight Americans, in Lebanon. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped of a Beirut street in March 1985. Bush said he was open to any talks that could free the American captives. ``I hope the hostages will be released. If I see an opportunity for talks in private or in public about this to get them released, I'll do it,'' he said as he left his hotel to visit a new Los Angeles County jail. He said he had read of a supposed conversation he had with French President Francois Mitterrand regarding the hostages. ``There never was such a conversation,'' he said. As to the most recent reports that the United States secretly was talking with representatives of the Iranian government in Geneva, Bush said: ``If I thought a talk in Geneva would result in letting people go free, I would undertake the talks. If I thought the way to conduct those talks was to do it quietly, I would. If I thought the best way to get the hostages out was to publicly have talks in Geneva, I would do that.'' ``I will do everything I can ... to get them out of there,'' the president said. He also said there were no talks ``under way that I know of'' between the United States and Syrian intermediaries.

DOC.HEAD: Warm January Helps Boost Construction Spending
DOC.TEXT: Construction spending rose 1.8 percent in January, the biggest increase in more than a year, the government said Thursday. Analysts said the warmest January on record caused the improvement. The Commerce Department said residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $424 billion in January. The gain was the largest since a 2.3 percent advance in December 1988. The January increase came after a 0.1 percent decline in December. It was the warmest January since the government began keeping track of temperatures 96 years ago, while December was the fourth coldest on record. ``If you average January and December, you come up with a number more in line with what we saw in the previous four months,'' said David Berson, chief economist with the Federal National Mortgage Association. ``December was not as bad as it appeared and January is not as good as it appears,'' he said. Berson said lower mortgage interest rates should produce a slight improvement in the months ahead. Spending on residential building was up 2.9 percent to $195.8 billion on an annual rate in January, largely due to a 2.4 percent gain in single-family homes. Multi-family spending was flat at $20.4 billion. Residential spending accounts for about 50 percent of the total. Non-residential construction spending was up 5.9 percent to an annual rate of $100.8 billion, boosted in part by a 15 percent gain in the industrial category. The often-volatile government sector, however, declined 4.2 percent to $490.9 billion after rising 6.8 percent in December. Government spending represents about 20 percent of construction spending. Leading the fall in that sector was a 13 percent decline in spending on highways and streets.

DOC.HEAD: US Wants IMF to Sell Gold to Help Poorest Countries Pay Debts
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government publicly asked the International Monetary Fund on Thursday to sell about $1.2 billion worth of its gold to give 11 of the world's poorest countries a chance to catch up on their debts. The countries are Vietnam, Cambodia, Guayana, Honduras, Liberia, Panama, Peru, Sierra Leone, Somalia, Sudan and Zambia. All are among the 152 countries in the fund, to which the United States is the largest contributor. The 11 have fallen behind by nearly $4 billion in loan repayments to the fund. David C. Mulford, head of international affairs at the Treasury Department, told a House panel the sales would not affect the world gold market sine because of the arrears, which he said are growing. He added that the governments in arrears would have to promise new eeconomic policies and help pay what they owe, under the fund's supervision, before getting new help.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Rattles S. California's Nerves; Pomona Estimates $20 Million Damage
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with inspections under way, Pomona puts damage at $20 million, other detail. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Southern California...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserColor LA1
DOC.TEXT: One city struck by a jolting earthquake estimated damage at $20 million today as safety inspectors across the region began a street-by-street look at their communities' older buildings and roads. Wednesday's quake measured at 5.5 on the Richter scale and triggered rock slides, broke windows, crumbled a warehouse wall and swayed skyscrapers as far away as Las Vegas, nearly 200 miles from the epicenter. Two people suffered broken legs and one woman went into early labor during the 3:43 p.m. temblor, said Upland Councilman Tom McGilloway, the city's acting mayor. He did not have details on how the injuries occurred. It was the strongest quake in California since the Oct. 17 one in the San Francisco Bay area. begin. That quake, measuring 7.1, killed 67 people and caused $7 billion in damage. About 25 people evacuated an apartment building to spend the night in a Red Cross shelter, he said. ``It felt like somebody picked up the building and dropped it a couple of times,'' said Police Lt. Don Manning in nearby Ontario, about 40 miles east of Los Angeles. ``It was like we went up a foot, then down a foot, then up again.'' Local states of emergency were declared by city officials in Pomona, Claremont and LaVerne, in order to begin a process that would help them seek federal rebuilding aid if needed. Pomona Mayor Donna Davis made a preliminary damage estimate of $20 million, said city fire department inspector Ron Gomez. Pomona City Hall was closed today as workers shoveled out broken glass and repaired other damage, Gomez said. The city of 113,000, the largest town in the immediate vicinity of the epicenter near Upland, is roughly 10 miles south of the epicenter. Michael Guerin of the state Office of Emergency Services said he was awaiting assessments from cities in the area struck by the quake before making a damage estimate for the whole region. Numerous aftershocks, including a shaker measuring 4.8 at 7:24 p.m., kept residents on edge throughout the area. The OES issued an advisory saying equally strong or more powerful aftershocks could occur over the next three days. Southern California Edison said 6,000 customers temporarily lost electrical power. The utility said the San Onofre nuclear plant remained in operation. Charlene Kennedy said she and her mother suffered cuts and bruises when ceiling tiles and boxes of shoes fell on them in a store in Upland. ``We were making our way out the door and I turned and saw a wall of hysterical people running towards us,'' she said. Workers leaped out of windows and dived off a loading dock as a 20-by-70-foot wall collapsed at an auto parts warehouse in nearby La Verne. ``Everything happened so fast trying to get 70 people out of the warehouse it's amazing nobody got seriously hurt,'' said supervisor Stan Sokolowski. A boulder twice the size of a car blocked a main two-lane road through the San Gabriel Mountains. Rock slides blocked mountain roads at several other points north of Upland. Cathryn Lethers, manager of a bar at Mount Baldy ski lodge, said about 25 people were stuck there until rock slides could be cleared. ``I had glasses flying all over the place. Everybody just ran inside. It was pretty scary,'' she said. ``We're all kind of giggling about it now, thanking God that it wasn't the Big One.'' The quake, centered five miles below the surface, ruptured a fault running from the northeast to the southwest, said seismologist Kate Hutton at the California Institute of Technology. It followed a 3.6-magnitude quake at 12:37 p.m. The quake was felt as a fairly short jolt at the epicenter but lasted more than 20 seconds in downtown Los Angeles, said Caltech spokesman Hall Daily. The worst recent Southern California quake struck the Whittier area Oct. 1, 1987. It measured 5.9 and, together with a 5.3-magnitude aftershock Oct. 4, killed eight people, injured more than 200 and caused $358 million in damage. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of 5 can cause considerable damage and 6 severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: President Says Tough Talk Against Crime Not Enough
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 8 grafs new with jail tour; picks up at pvs 3rd graf, Speaking at; deletes pvs 7th graf, Today he, outdated
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today praised law enforcement officials as ``unsung heroes'' as he toured a new 2,064-bed jail that he said proved ``tough talk is simply not enough'' in fighting crime. Bush was given a tour of the not-yet-opened Los Angeles North County Correctional Facility by Sheriff Sherman Block, who showed him the spartan cells in the maximum-security facility. The president said after his brief tour: ``I will never forget it. It was long enough to bring anyone face to face with the results of what institutions like this represent ... Capacity for violence, the power of corruption, the ability to turn our back on right and do wrong.'' A major part of Bush's own anti-crime package is concentrated on prison expansion. Addressing law-enforcement officers outside the prison, Bush said, ``All too often you are the unsung heroes in the war on crime and our assault on drugs.'' Facilities like the new $131 million new jail show that ``tough talk is simply not enough. If you're going to be tough on crime, you've got to be tough on criminals,'' he said. Bush then headed to address a luncheon gathering of the Republican Governors' Association and later was to speak at a dinner of the California Chamber of Commerce. Delving into a complex matter that is the Republican Party's top 1990 political goal, Bush called Wednesday for a fair reapportionment of congressional districts after the 1990 Census. Speaking at a San Francisco fund-raiser for GOP Sen. Pete Wilson, who is running for governor of California, the president also praised the moves toward democracy in many countries, saying, ``Many of our prayers seem to be answered; from Moscow to Managua, change is in the air.'' ``The world has undergone another upheaval, but this time there is no war,'' said Bush, who spoke by telephone with Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev earlier Wednesday in what was believed to be only their third telephone conversation. ``In the Revolution of '89, an idea overcame armies and tanks, and that idea is democracy,'' Bush said. During his four-day swing through California, Bush also is focusing on crime and drugs, the environment and economics and trade. Making California's reapportionment fair to the GOP, Bush said, will require electing Wilson governor so he can block the Democratic-controlled state Legislature from repeating the district boundary map it drew in the early 1980s. ``This is bigger than party politics,'' Bush said at the Wilson fund-raiser in San Francisco before he flew to Los Angeles Wednesday night. ``Gerrymandering violates the spirit of one man, one vote.'' The president said that in the 1981 California redistricting, ``lines were drawn _ crazy, twisted lines, that cut across communities, towns and even streets, without the slightest regard for the will of the people.'' Bush promised: ``Republicans do not seek revenge. We don't seek a gerrymander of our own.'' The Census could give California about six additional seats in Congress, based on its population growth. Reapportionment is of vital importance to both parties and the avowed top 1990 election goal of Republican National Committee Chairman Lee Atwater. But surveys so far show that voters have little interest in the issue. Bush gave an upbeat characterization of his conversation with Gorbachev, vowing to continue such consultations to discuss differences. ``Reason and calmness have replaced rhetoric,'' he said. On Friday, Bush heads to Palm Springs where he will meet with Japan's Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu, on another matter of keen interest to Californians _ fair trade. Wilson has no primary opponent of note and through 1989 amassed $8.25 million for his campaign, compared with $4.6 million raised by state Attorney Gen. John Van de Kamp and $2.29 million by former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein, the two Democrats vying to run against Wilson. Bush called Wilson a champion for crime victims, the environment, and a sound economy. While lauding Wilson's record on protecting wilderness and wildlife preserves, Bush did not mention the prickly issue of offshore oil, on which he and Wilson differ. Bush, a onetime Texas oilman who generally is sympathetic to the industry view, is withholding judgment and reviewing a study on whetherhe
BUST IT

DOC.HEAD: Personal Income Rises, but Spending Slows
DOC.TEXT: Personal income rose 0.8 percent in January despite a new tax bite from Social Security, the government said Thursday. The report also showed consumer spending climbed a narrower 0.6 percent, a pace which analysts attributed to caution in the face of mounting inflation. The Commerce Department said personal income ran at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.60 trillion last month, after gaining 0.5 percent in December. Several factors affected the January income increase, including cost-of-living increases in Social Security and other federal benefits, and a 3.6 percent pay raise for federal workers. Those increases were offset by an increase in taxes withheld for Social Security, as well as a reduction in farm subsidy payments. Excluding these special factors, the deparment said, personal income increased 0.5 percent, the department said. Analysts cited the 1.1 percent increase in consumer prices in January for the slowdown in consumer spending, from a 1 percent gain in December to 0.6 percent in January, or an annual rate of $3.60 trillion. ``Consumers behaved fairly cautiously in January, probably because they had to pay so much for energy and food that they didn't have that much to spend on other items,'' said Michael K. Evans, head of Evans Economics, Inc. The Labor Department said food and energy costs, driven up by the effects of the fourth coldest December on record, accounted for 60 percent of the jump in the January Consumer Price Index. ``Once food and energy prices settle down, consumer spending will pick up,'' Evans said. Personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, totaled $19.9 billion _ down from $36.7 billion in December. But purchases of durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ rose $24.3 billion. Analysts said this spending was spurred in part by automobile sales incentives. Non-durable purchases were up $2.5 billion while spending on services fell $6.8 billion. Consumer spending is considered a barometer of economic health because it represents about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. The key component of the income category, wages and salaries, edged up $16.2 billion in January after gaining $16.8 billion in December. Americans' incomes after taxes rose 0.9 percent, the department said, up from December's 0.4 percent gain. That category, incidentally, doesn't count Social Security withholding as a tax _ the department, instead, treats it as a ``contribution,'' just as it does other retirement program costs. The personal savings rate, as measured against disposable income, advanced 5.9 percent compared to a 5.5 percent rate a month earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Matriarch Displaced For The Second Time In Her Life
LaserPhoto JRL2
DOC.TEXT: Fatima Sufarin wept quietly Thursday as she searched the rubble of what had been her home for the past 41 years. ``I don't know what I'm going to do now,'' said Mrs. Sufarin, a 70-year-old Palestinian who was displaced for the second time in her life when soldiers blew up her two-story house Wednesday. The six-room house was demolished to punish the family for the alleged crimes of Mrs. Sufarin's 25-year-old son Imad, who is accused of throwing a firebomb that wounded an Israeli soldier. Family members say Imad, who is awaiting trial, is innocent. According to the army, more than 450 houses have been destroyed or sealed in thinistas totaled $300,000. According to Ramirez, no funds were received from the Mexican government or the ruling PRI party. The information obtained by U.S. officials indicated the contributions came from the PRI. The initial report of the donation appeared in Newsday. While expressing irritation over the Mexican contribution, the officials said it was not clear whether President Carlos Salinas de Gortari was aware of it. The purported donation, which included cash, T-shirts, posters and other items, was consistent with the support Mexico historically has provided to the Sandinista government. Among hemispheric governments, Mexico was one of the most vigorously opposed to the Reagan era policy of supporting the Nicaraguan Contras. For years, radicals within Mexico's ruling party have acquiesced in the its generally conservative domestic policies. But these forces have played the dominant role in foreign policy and this produced deep mutual mistrust between Mexico and the United States during the Reagan administration. Relations appear to have improved since Presidents Salinas and Bush were inaugurated a few weeks apart a little over a year ago. Mexico has found Bush's more moderate policies more tolerable than Reagan's, while the United States, in turn, has given Salinas high marks for his efforts at curbing drug smuggling and in restoring the country's economic health.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Returns Andy Rooney to ``60 Minutes''
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 6th graf pvs, `Well, we...', to UPDATE with response from gay group. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `In a ...'. SUBS last graf with 4 grafs to CLARIFY that suspension called not a significant factor in ratings drop, sted not a factor, and to add quotes from `60 Minutes' producer.
DOC.TEXT: Humorist Andy Rooney was reinstated today on CBS' ``60 Minutes.'' He said he'll be on Sunday's show with a commentary on the issues involved in his suspension on Feb. 8. ``I'm very pleased,'' said Rooney, whom CBS News president David Burke had suspended without pay after a gay magazine quoted him as saying blacks had ``watered down their genes,'' a comment Rooney denies making. Originally, the suspension was to be for three months, but the lifting of the suspension had been widely expected in recent days. Rooney said ``I think it was a very difficult thing'' for Burke to decide to reinstate him early, praising the news division president. Burke never has specifically said why he suspended the 71-year-old commentator. Late last year, Rooney drew fire from gay and lesbian groups for saying in a Dec. 28 CBS special that ``homosexual unions'' are among things that cause ``self-induced'' deaths. Asked today if he were bitter about his suspension, Rooney was philosophical. ``Well, we all get the bittersweet in our lives,'' he said, adding that he likes a quotation attributed to ABC News anchor Sam Donaldson: ``Only the amateurs stay mad.'' While not directly criticizing Rooney's early reinstatement, the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation complained that he ``has yet to make amends with the gay and lesbian community regarding the series of homophobic comments he made in the last few months.'' The New York-based group had complained to CBS about Rooney's remark on his December show. Its statement today also alluded to a letter in which Rooney said he found the idea of male homosexuality ``repugnant.'' The letter was sent to The Advocate. It appeared along with the gay magazine's article that had in it the controversial quote attributed to Rooney. In a statement announcing Rooney's reinstatement, Burke did not say why he had lifted the suspension early. After the two met last week, there were reports that Rooney would be back perhaps as early as this Sunday. In his statement, Burke alluded to the controversy over his suspension of Rooney, saying he and Rooney had discussed the events that led to his suspension ``as well as the debate that has ensued over the past month.'' ``Painful though these events have been, we have all learned a great deal about how sensitive and fragile our society is _ how thoughts and words can be misunderstood, how deeply people in groups can be hurt if great care is not taken in public discourse.'' He said Rooney ``has consistently stated publicly that he is not a man who holds prejudice in his heart and mind towards any group in our society. Those of us who know him and work with him know two things _ first, that is true, and second, it is time that Andy returned to his proper place on `60 Minutes.''' Since his suspension began, CBS has gotten more than 5,000 calls from viewers, virtually all supporting him. During his three weeks away from ``60 Minutes,'' the program, while still top-rated, has slipped in the ratings, dropping to 18th last Sunday, when it was beaten by a one-time rerun of ABC's hit ``America's Funniest Home Videos.'' However, research experts at all three networks have discounted Rooney's absence as a significant factor on the show's ratings drop. Don Hewitt, executive producer of ``60 Minutes,'' praised Burke's decision to put Rooney back to work early, saying it showed Burke knows the difference ``between what's right and what's expedient.'' Rooney's segment on ``60 Minutes'' usually runs about three minutes. Hewitt, asked how much time he planned to give Rooney this Sunday, replied, ``Whatever he wants.'' He laughed and added: ``What do you say to a 2,000-pound gorilla?''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Leaders and White House Reach Agreement on Clean Air Bill.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 15-19, Among the, with details on provisions.
DOC.TEXT: Senate leaders and the Bush administration reached agreement today on a compromise clean air bill providing tighter controls on emissions from automobiles, electric power plants and factories. Republican and Democratic leaders as well as the White House promised to work for passage of the agreement when the measure comes up for debate on the Senate floor next week. The agreement, the product of three weeks of closed-door negotiations, reflects a middle ground between air pollution controls required by a sweeping bill that cleared a Senate committee last November and the more cautious and less expensive approach advocated by the administration. One aim of the compromise was to defuse the prospect of a filibuster which had been threatened by a group of Midwest senators concerned about the cost of complying with the acid rain provision. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called it a ``sound and comprehensive'' proposal and said he hoped it would avoid any filibuster. Negotiators hoped the compromise would attract enough support so any filibuster attempt would be defeated. Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the minority leader, said he would work to advance the compromise legislation, but urged Mitchell ``not to handcuff anyone'' during the upcoming floor action by rushing to impose a petition to cut off debate on the matter. ``This is a giant step forward,'' Dole said of the compromise. Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., who has voiced concern about the effect of stringent acid rain controls on his state's coal miners, said he would seek additional changes to the bill. But he said, ``I'm not going to engage in any filibuster.'' One element of the compromise would allow electric utilities in the Midwest to acquire credits for any pollution reduction. These credits could be sold to other utilities and in part offset the cost of pollution controls. The breakthrough on the compromise came Wednesday when Senate leaders and the White House agreed to tighter controls on automobile emissions to deal with urban smog and on steps aimed at easing concerns of the Midwest senators over the high costs of controlling acid rain pollutants. President Bush, traveling in California, praised the agreement as a ``big forward step'' and called on the Senate to move quickly on it. The White House, during three weeks of closed-door negotiations, had adamantly opposed a second round of automobile tailpipe controls included in the Senate bill. At the same time, the bill's key sponsors, including Mitchell, argued that the two-stage controls were needed to reduce smog in some of nation's most polluted urban centers. Under a compromise agreement worked out Wednesday, the second round of tailpipe controls, known as Tier 2, would go into effect only if 11 of 27 cities considered to have ``serious'' air pollution problems fail to make enough progress in meeting federal air quality standards by late in this decade. Among the provisions of the compromise: _ Industrial plants would have to use the best available technology to curb releases of 192 toxic chemicals, including carcinogens, and early in the next decade comply with a specific ``health standard'' to limit risks to people closest to industrial plants. _ Under the acid rain provision, electric utility plants will have to reduce annual sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons. Some provisons were included to ease Midwest concerns about high cost of emission controls and concerns from the West that the curbs might inhibit growth. _ Tougher tailpipe emission controls on automobiles would reduce smog-causing pollutants by 22 to 60 percent, depending on the pollutant. A second round of emission curbs would go into effect if at least a dozen of 27 communities with ``serious'' pollution problems failed to achieve federal air quality standards. _ A broad range of industries and businesses would have to comply with tougher controls on smog-causing emissions. The compromise, however, would exempt thousands of smaller polluters, which would have been covered by the original Senate bill. ``This agreement is environmentally sound and strong,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. He said the provisions ``will achieve significant and permanent reductions in pollutants that cause acid rain, will ensure annual improvements to bring our nation's cities into compliance with standards relating to urban smog and carbon monoxide, and will greatly reduce the risk to the public's health from toxic emissions.'' ``By incorporating flexibility and innovation in its approach to achieving pollution reductions, it will allow environmental and health standards to be met in a way that creates maximum choice for both states and regulated industries and places fewer burdens on consumers. It will thus improve the Clean Air Act in a way that promotes both a healthy environment and a sound economy,'' Fitzwater said. The compromise was criticized by environmentalists. ``You could have cities with a total of 80 million people not in (federal air quality) attainment and still not have a Tier 2,'' said Gene Karpinski, executive director of the U.S. Public Interest Research Group, an environmental group. The Senate leaders and the White House agreed to require utility plants to reduce sulfur dioxide emissions by 10 million tons a year by the end of the decade. The talks earlier this week produced tentative agreements on how to control toxic chemicals from industrial plants and on curbing smog-causing pollutants from sources from chemical plants to dry cleaners. A different clean air bill remains in a House committee. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said Wednesday he hoped that bill could come up for floor consideration by April, several months earlier than he previously indicated.

DOC.HEAD: Coors Brews $40 Million Literacy Drive, With Help From Smokey and Sheena
DOC.TEXT: Smokey Robinson and Sheena Easton told heartfelt tales of their own disadvantaged backgrounds Thursday as the pop stars helped launch a five-year, $40 million literacy campaign sponsored by Coors Brewing Co. A key feature of the campaign, also sponsored by MCA Music Entertainment Group and several grassroots literacy organizations, will be a spring concert tour called ``Pass It On'' that will use music to promote the cause of literacy. Robinson and Easton will be among the artists taking part in the tour. Cities and dates will be announced later. ``Coors has a long history of being involved in issues important in this country,'' Peter Coors, president of the Golden, Colo.-based brewery, told a news conference. He added that Coors, like other companies, had come to realize that it was in its self-interest to promote literacy because ``if trends continue, in the year 2000 we'd be hard-pressed to find qualified job applicants.'' The $40 million effort is among the largest corporate commitments ever in the literacy field. It will include $250,000 awards in 1990 to three literacy groups named as co-sponsors of the ``Pass It On'' campaign: SER-Jobs for Progress, a Dallas-based organization aimed at the Hispanic community; the Philadelphia-based Opportunities Industrialization Centers of America; and the National Volunteer Literacy Campaign. Those groups will work together as the ``Coors Literacy Corps,'' committed to training 30,000 adults to read in 1990. Much of the rest of the money will be spent on promoting the concert tour and on a campaign to increase awareness of illiteracy, Coors said. The campaign will urge non-readers to seek help, and will have a toll-free literacy referral and information telephone line (1-800-228-8813). Easton recalled her childhood in a blue collar foundry town in Scotland and how her mother instilled in her a love of reading at an early age: ``When things would get really crazy in the house, my mother would always pick up a magazine or a book and say, `Just give me ten minutes.' I learned from my mother that books hold a magic, a way to escape. I'll always thank her. I didn't want to leave school and work in a factory. My mother gave me the window to the world: books.'' With her mother's encouragement, she went on to college and was preparing for teaching _ until her career took a decidedly different turn. Robinson, who grew up in a family of 10 in a Detroit housing project, credited his father, a self-taught reader with only a fourth-grade education, with instilling in him a love of learning and an ambition for better things. ``In my particular neighborhood,'' Robinson said, ``the odds against my making something of my life were enormous.''

DOC.HEAD: Northrop Details Plea Bargain in Reported Memo
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to CORRECT that newspaper report said probe into alleged $20 billion fraud continues, probe of other aspects of B-2 dropped. Picks up 4th graf pvs, `The memo...'.
DOC.TEXT: The government halted an investigation of alleged fraud by Northrop Corp. in the MX missile program when the company agreed to plead guilty in another case, the corporation says. A memo to employees of the corporation Wednesday said that prosecutors agreed to halt the probe into alleged falsification of MX test data, the Los Angeles Times reported today. Northrop remains the target other probes, including allegations of political payoffs in South Korea and allegations that it defrauded the government by more than $20 billion on the B-2 stealth bomber program, the Times said. Northrop had said the FBI conducted a raid recently at a Northrop B-2 parts factory in connection with the B-2 case. Other investigations of less significant wrongdoing on the B-2 program were dropped as part of the agreement with prosecutors, the Los Angeles Times reported. The memo from Northrop president Kent Kresa, copies of which were obtained by various newspapers, said the company was barred from telling reporters which investigations were halted but was free to inform employees and investors. ``Some other legal issues remain open,'' Kresa wrote. ``We intend to deal with them and to resolve them satisfactorily through legal channels.'' Justice Department officials could not be reached late Wednesday to comment on the memo. Northrop executives declined to comment. Northrop pleaded guilty Tuesday to 34 charges of making false statements to the government and agreed to a $17 million fine. The company admitted falsifying test data on parts for the cruise missile and Harrier attack jet. In exchange, the government agreed to drop 141 counts. Assistant U.S. Attorney William F. Fahey called the agreement ``a very significant victory in our efforts to combat defense contracting fraud and misconduct.'' But Rep. John D. Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee's panel on oversight and investigations, termed the plea bargain ``stealth justice.'' ``This leaves the public and the Congress without the vaguest idea of the rascality Northrop was engaged in or its cost to the public,'' Dingell said.

DOC.HEAD: Glacial Ice Forced Two Tankers to Change Course Before Exxon Spill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with this morning's testimony. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `Do you...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Exxon-Valdez, Bjt
