DOC.TEXT: Joseph Hazelwood's apparent efforts to pull his grounded tanker off a reef did not do additional damage to the crippled ship, a former tanker captain testified today. But Robert Beevers said that by all normal indications, such a maneuver would have torn away additional portions of the gashed underbelly of the 987-foot Exxon Valdez. The witness did not explain why the ship suffered no additional damage, but he said he was certain Hazelwood was trying to extricate it, not stabilize it on the reef. ``I have no reason to think that Captain Hazelwood would lie to the Coast Guard,'' Beevers said. ``I don't think he would tell them anything he didn't intend to do.'' Hazelwood, in his first radio conversation after the ship hit Bligh Reef, said he was trying to extricate it. Under cross-examination by Hazelwood's attorneys, Beevers continued to maintain that Hazelwood should have remained on the bridge of the tanker during its final passage into Prince William Sound. Chunks of glacial ice forced two tankers to change course only a few hours before Hazelwood tried a similar maneuver last March 24. Still another ship preceded the Exxon Valdez into Prince William Sound on March 23 without anyone on board certified to pilot in that area, Beevers acknowledged. On Wednesday, Beevers' testimony was stopped by the eruption of Redoubt Volcano, 115 miles southwest of Anchorage. Superior Court Judge Karl Johnstone sent jurors home early to avoid exposure to falling ash, the first time fallout from the volcano has hit the state's largest city. Hazelwood, 43, was the only skipper whose ship hit Bligh Reef. The tanker spilled nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude, killing countless birds, fish and other wildlife and tarring hundreds of miles of rocky shore in the nation's worst oil spill. The seaman from Huntington, N.Y., is charged with criminal mischief, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. If convicted, he could get 7\ years in prison and $61,000 in fines. Before court was recessed Wednesday, defense attorney Dick Madson had been grilling the retired captain, who earlier accused Hazelwood of reckless actions. ``Do you recall the course of the Arco Juneau?'' Madson asked, referring to a tanker that left Valdez two hours before the Exxon ship. ``Yes,'' said Beevers. ``They went around the ice and cleared Bligh Reef.'' Asked how close the ship came to hitting the reef, he referred to charts and said about five-tenths of a mile. Madson then elicited the information that the Arco Juneau was traveling at full sea speed of 16 knots, or 18.4 mph, while the Exxon Valdez was on maneuvering speed of 12.4 knots, or 14.3 mph, in the same area. ``I didn't say I approved of what they did,'' Beevers interjected. ``Did you consider that master's actions reckless?'' asked Madson. ``Yes, I would,'' said Beevers. ``And do you know if he was prosecuted or not?'' asked the lawyer. ``No, I don't,'' said the witness. Outside court, defense attorneys said no charges were filed against Greg Knowlton, skipper of the Arco Juneau. Beevers maintained that Hazelwood erred when he decided to go around the ice and left the ship's bridge during the maneuver. ``My basic criticism is I thought he made his decision too early without carefully evaluating it'' Beevers said. Other witnesses have described ice reports from the Arco Juneau as guiding Hazelwood's decision. ``The master should be on the bridge,'' Beevers insisted. ``Traditionally, that is his duty.'' The witness has said Hazelwood was particularly reckless because at that point he was the only officer on board licensed to pilot the ship in Prince William Sound. But Beevers acknowledged that another ship, the Brooklyn, chartered to Texaco, had entered Prince William Sound earlier the same day with no one aboard holding a pilot's license. He said he assumed the Coast Guard had waived the requirement. That ship missed the reef by six-tenths of a mile, he said. Beevers also suggested that the Exxon Valdez, with a crew of 19, may have been understaffed, increasing stress on individual members. ``That was certainly the smallest crew on a tanker I'd seen,'' he said. Beevers said the ships he sailed often had a crew of 32, but by the time he quit in 1987, companies were scaling back to save money.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Hardens Stance on Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, under pressure from Likud Bloc hawks, on Thursday hardened his stance on U.S. proposals for convening peace talks with a Palestinian delegation. In an interview with The Associated Press, Shamir ruled out participation of Arabs from East Jerusalem in the process and said there was no need for two exiled Palestinians in a proposed 10-member negotiating team. ``Who needs them?'' Shamir said of a reported compromise proposal to include two deported Palestinians to meet PLO conditions that the team include representatives from the nearly 3 million Palestinians who live outside Israeli-held territory. Shamir said Israel's plan to hold Palestinian elections was not aimed at finding an ultimate solution but an interim self-rule scheme for the 1.7 million Arabs in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. ``We are not going to solve the problem of the Palestinian diaspora. It is not our task,'' he said. Shamir stressed that 130,000 East Jerusalem Arabs would be excluded from the election proposal and from the negotiating team that is slated to meet in Cairo to plan for the balloting. ``It's clear that whoever lives in east Jerusalem will not be able to participate in these negotiations,'' said Shamir. Pro-Shamir Likud sources who demanded anonymity said Shamir had dropped earlier caution designed to encourage compromise and avoid friction with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Labor Party hawks such as Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin. They said Shamir had adopted a tougher line because of an internal revolt against the plan by Likud hawks who could attempt to oust him. The hawks mustered 23 of the party's 40 parliament members to call for a party meeting before Shamir gave his final answer to Baker's compromise proposals. Shamir said the challenge was ``not very serious'' because he had support from ``80 percent or more'' of his party. ``The great majority of my party supports me without doubt or hesitation,'' Shamir said, vowing to provide the Israeli Cabinet with his final position on Baker's proposals ``in a few days or weeks.'' Shamir, in a 30-minute interview wedged between meetings with party officials, lashed out at U.S. officials who said Israel should not settle Soviet immigrants in the predominantly Arab sector of Jerusalem, which was captured from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East War. ``We are very upset by some statements about the immigration of Soviet Jewish people saying that they not be permitted to live in East Jerusalem,'' he said, noting that 100,000 Israelis already lived in the Arab sector. Speaking on army radio, Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Shamir's Likud Bloc said U.S. officials told him in Washington this week that settling Soviet immigrants in East Jerusalem was improper. Netanyahu said such statements raised questions about whether ``a framework exists today to continue the peace process.'' ``These things raise doubts regarding the basis of understanding with the Americans,'' he said. Shamir and Netanyahu spoke before Baker announced in Washington that the Bush administration would consider cuts in Israel's $3 billion annual aid if the overall foreign aid program had to be cut to provide funds for new crisis areas. Shamir Spokesman Avi Pazner had no immediate comment, but the announcement was likely to be viewed here as a form of pressure on Shamir to accept the U.S. proposals. Shamir is also under pressure from the rival Labor Party to make a decision by March 7 on whether to accept U.S. proposals for starting talks. Party leaders reiterated they expected Shamir to make a final decision soon on whether to hold a dialogue with Palestinians in Cairo. Yaakov Tzur, Labor's health minister, said on army radio ``the time has come to make a clear decision. Seven months have passed. ... The Americans and Egyptians have made proposals and we have to honor them without hestiations and go on,'' he said. Vice Premier Shimon Peres, the Labor leader, said in an earlier interview he doubted Shamir could accept the Baker proposals and suggested he might try to form a Labor-led government if Shamir failed to respond positively.

DOC.HEAD: Flood May Be Last Straw for Troubled Copper Town
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials aren't getting many takers for the disaster loans they brought to McCaysville after a devastating flood, leading one merchant to say with dread, ``This might be a ghost town.'' ``Everybody's leaving. Nobody's rebuilding,'' said the merchant, William Jabaley, whose family has owned the town's only department store since 1921. Government spokesman Guido Pettinelli said merchants are taking ``a poor attitude'' in refusing the low-interest loans. The merchants, already suffering hard times before the flood, say they couldn't make the payments. Mid-February flooding caused damage estimated at more than $5.5 million in Fannin County, which includes McCaysville, and $5.3 million in Polk County, Tenn., which includes McCaysville's neighbor, Copperhill. The floods came during two weeks of tornadoes and other storms that prompted President Bush to declare disaster areas in 13 counties in Georgia, 24 in Alabama and two in Tennessee. McCaysville and Copperhill especially suffered because they already had severe economic problems. The two towns have one industry _ Tennessee Chemical Co., a copper mining company that once employed more than 2,000 residents but now only 400. In McCaysville, a town of about 400 phe month because of differences in sales-reporting calendars. Jeffrey Feiner, an analyst at Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc., said: ``We remain somewhat cautious'' given continuing high consumer debt levels and sluggish trends in the financial and real estate markets. Retailers could have a tough time this year coping with the effects of what have been dubbed ``rolling recessions,'' which are rippling through parts of the manufacturing sector, such as the automobile industry. A widely watched barometer of manufacturing health showed a 10th straight monthly decline in the sector during February. The National Association of Purchasing Management's index stood at 48.3 percent in February, up from 45.2 percent in January. A reading below 50 indicates that the U.S. manufacturing economy is generally declining. Monroe Greenstein of Bear Stearns & Co. Inc. said retailers probably will have a mediocre year in 1990, similar to 1989. February marks the start of the fiscal year for many retailers. Analysts were reluctant to attach too much significance to the results because February is typically a slow time for business in the retail trade. January and February are transition months as winter merchandise is cleared out to make room for fresh spring lines. In contrast to the chains that did well last month, Sears, Roebuck and Co., the country's biggest retailer, continued to struggle. The giant Chicago-based general merchant, which began a new merchandising strategy a year ago hoping to reverse years of market-share losses, had a ho-hum February. Sales were virtually flat, at $2.127 billion in the four weeks ended Feb. 24, vs. $2.126 billion a year earlier. Sales at Sears stores open a year or longer edged up only 1.5 percent. Retailers and industry analysts prefer to focus on sales comparisons for stores operating at least a year, called same-store or comparable-store results. Newly opened stores typically enjoy a period of unusually brisk business that isn't sustained over time. One standout among the retailers reporting Thursday was Wal-Mart Stores Inc. The big Bentonville, Ark.-based discount chain said its February sales surged 33 percent to $1.95 billion from $1.47 billion a year earlier. Sales at Wal-Marts open a year or longer posted a healthy 17 percent gain. By either measure, Wal-Mart consistently has been a star performer as it expands across the country. Currently ranked No. 3, there is widespread speculation in the industry that Wal-Mart this year could overtake Sears and K mart Corp. in merchandise sales volume in the United States. K mart, based in Troy, Mich., recently stepped up efforts to respond to the challenge.In a bid to boost sales and profit, K mart will accelerate its store opening and renovation program, taking a $422 million after-tax charge to carry out the plan. K mart's report on last month's sales will be released March 8. Many of the retailers who in recent years have reported their monthly results on the first Thursday of every month will be reporting later in March. There is an effort being made within the industry to reach a compromise on a single monthly reporting date. Here are some reports released Thursday: Dallas-based department store operator J.C. Penney Co. Inc. said sales at its stores and through its catalogs rose 8.1 percent in February to $880 million from $814 million a year earlier. Sales at stores open for at least a year were up 7.2 percent. Melville Corp., the Harrison, N.Y.-based owner of off-price and other retailers, said February sales rose 11.7 percent to $503.2 million from a year earlier's $450.6 million. Montgomery Ward & Co., based in Chicago, reported a 2.5 percent February sales gain to $299 million from $291.8 million. Last year's figures were restated to exclude discontinued lines. Woolworth Corp., the New York-based parent of numerous specialty stores including the Foot Locker sports shoe chain, said its domestic February sales jumped 13.7 percent to $330 million from $291 million. Same-store sales rose 11.7 percent. Harold E. Sells, chairman and chief executive officer, said: ``February's double-digit percentage gains in total and domestic sales were the highest for that reporting period in over 10 years.''

DOC.HEAD: IRS Considers Appeal of Newhouse Ruling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `After weighing...' to CORRECT to million sted billion. Picks up 5th graf, `That uncertainty...
DOC.TEXT: The Internal Revenue Service said Thursday it has not decided whether to appeal a Tax Court decision that overturned a $609.5 million IRS ruling against the estate of publisher Samuel I. Newhouse. The court, in a decision published Thursday, sided with the estate on the only issue in one of the biggest tax disputes in the nation's history: the value of Newhouse's stock in the family's publishing and broadcasting operations at the time of his death in 1979. The IRS had contended that Newhouse's holdings in Advance Publications, Inc., and Newhouse Broadcasting Co. were worth a combined $1.32 billion. The estate, whose executors are his sons, Samuel I. Newhouse Jr. and Donald E. Newhouse, inisted the value was $247.1 million. After weighing weeks of testimony from both sides, Judge John Williams Jr. discounted the value of the stock to $235.6 mllion. ``The experts, whose opinions were well-reasoned, disagreed about almost every issue, and we find that a willing buyer would have been uncertain about the rights and privileges of ... (Advance) common stock,'' he wrote. That uncertainty, coupled with restrictions in Advance's corporate charter that barred an outsider from controlling the company, would depress the stock price, the court reasoned. IRS spokesman Steve Pyrek said agency lawyers are reviewing Williams' 100-page opinion before deciding whether to appeal. The IRS wanted to value Newhouse's stock as if the components of the publishing and broadcasting operations were being sold separately. The estate argued that was not realistic because of restrictions in the corporate charters that severely limited opportunities for breaking up the companies. Williams based his decision in part on a report by Goldman Sachs & Co., an investment banking firm, on the value of Advance. ``Goldman Sachs concluded that only another media company would be interested in acquiring Advance and that none of the major media companies would have considered buying the common stock (by far the largest portion of the estate) without first eliminating the claims of the preferred shareholders,'' Williams wrote. He held that Goldman Sachs was correct in devaluing the Advance stock by 35 percent because of the lack of marketability of the stock and the prohibitions against outside control. Under Advance's charter, owners of Class A voting common stock have exclusive rights to elect the board of directors; Class A and B (non-voting) common-stock owners vote on any merger; holders of preferred stock have the upper hand on any liquidation, and owners of all three classes of stock participate in dividends. At the time he died in 1979, the elder Newhouse owned all the outstanding shares of Class A and B common stock in Advance. Other family members owned all the preferred shares. Media baron Rupert Murdoch, testifying for the Newhouse estate, said he would have found Advance an unattractive purchase because of the difficulty in gaining control of the company and because of federal limitations on media ownership. Douglas McCorkindale, vice chairman of Gannett Corp., said Gannett would not be interested in Advance common stock unless the preferred shares also were for sale. Even in the absence of restrictions on control, Williams wrote, the sheer size of Advance meant that ``the sale of all of Advance's newspaper and magazine properties at one time would have had a seriously depressing effect on the market for such properties.'' The IRS earlier had dropped an effort to add a $304.8 million fraud penalty to the assessment, which would have pushed the total at issue to more than $914 million. Newhouse's media empire was launched in 1922 when he and an associate bought control of The Staten Island (N.Y.) Advance. At the time of Newhouse's death, Advance was the nation's fourth largest newspaper-magazine publisher, with 50 newspapers in 22 markets and the Conde Nast publications, including Vogue, Glamour and House & Garden. Newhouse Broadcasting operates stations, cable systems and microwave facilities in several states.

DOC.HEAD: Juvenile Justice Nominee Called Lacking in Experience
DOC.TEXT: Democrats said Thursday that a conservative nominee to head $70 million in juvenile justice programs lacked experience and they questioned his ties to the Moral Majority. Republicans declared he was fully qualified. ``I am troubled that an individual apparently without the requisite credentials would be nominated for this important position,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. ``The stakes are high if we are determined to protect our youth from becoming involved with drugs and crime.'' The criticism came as the Senate Judiciary Committee took up the nomination of Republican education adviser Robert Sweet as administrator of the Office of Juvenile Justice and Deliquency Prevention. The office distributes millions of dollars in federal grants to state and local agencies to combat juvenile deliquency. Sweet received a cool reception from Democrats who indicated he could have a tough time winning confirmation. The former White House adviser and one-time head of the New Hampshire Moral Majority has drawn critics ranging from the National Parent-Teacher Association to People for the American Way, a liberal Washington group. Some of the antagonism appears to be an outgrowth of fierce political infighting at the Department of Education while Sweet was an aide there in the early 1980s. Former Education Secretary Terrel Bell was highly critical of Sweet in his memoirs, ``The Thirteenth Man.'' Sweet supporters range from the Boys Clubs of America to Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., who has been pointing out that many opponents are financial beneficiaries of the government's junvenile justice programs. ``It's understandable, may I observe, that the grantees would like one of their own to be head of this office, but that may not be such a good idea from the standpoint of prudence,'' Humphrey told the committee. The 52-year-old Sweet, a former high school teacher and textbook salesman, told the panel that he had devoted his entire career to helping young people and that his education background should fulfill a law that requires a juvenile justice administrator with experience in the juvenile justice field. ``I want to be an advocate of helping young people have a better shot at life than they otherwise would have,'' Sweet said. He said he has been studying juvenile justice issues and would be able to quickly grasp details of the job. Some Republicans were quick to back the nominee. ``I believe that Bob Sweet is fully qualified for this position,'' said Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah. ``I know him personally and I support him.'' Sen. Arlen Specter, R-Pa., however, asked the nominee for written answers to a number of questions about juvenile justice issues. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., asked Sweet if he had ever joined an organization such as the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People that would have given him experience with minority youth. Sweet said he had not and that he was ``not much of an association person.''

DOC.HEAD: Co-Defendant Wants Trial Moved From Anti-Castro Miami
DOC.TEXT: The case against Manuel Noriega is so closely linked to Fidel Castro that it should be moved out of militantly anti-communist south Florida, a co-defendant's attorney said in a motion filed Thursday. Samuel Burstyn, an attorney for former Panamanian army Lt. Col. Luis del Cid, said the U.S. District Court trial should be moved to San Francisco, New York or Puerto Rico. Such motions are rarely granted, and judges normally attempt to seat a jury before ruling on a change-of-venue motion. Burstyn said Castro was an unindicted co-conspirator in the February 1988 drug-trafficking indictment against the ousted Panamanian dictator. He said the Cuban leader mediated a dispute between Noriega and Colombia's Medellin drug cartel after a raid on a cocaine laboratory that Noriega was supposedly bribed to protect. The U.S. government ``has already made plain ... its intention to poison the well by emphasizing the role of communist Cuba in the principal conspiracy charges in this case,'' Burstyn said in the motion before Judge William Hoeveler. Burstyn said that during del Cid's unsuccessful attempt to get bond, prosecutors released a photo of del Cid, Noriega and Castro meeting in Cuba. ``Even if an entirely `non-Latin' jury was seated, the pressure on the jury, in effect, to convict Fidel Castro, will be enormous,'' the motion said. Burstyn said south Florida is ``dominated'' by Cubans, Nicaraguans and exiles from other Central American fleeing communist dictatorships. Del Cid, who was indicted for allegedly handling a drug payoff for Noriega, is attempting to negotiate a plea bargain in return for cooperating against Noriega. Burstyn said talks with prosecutors were continuing, but no agreement has been reached. The judge has targeted late November for the trial, but says it would begin by January. Many attorneys, citing the complexity of handling classified documents before and during the trial, say it could be mid-1991 before jury selection begins.

DOC.HEAD: Housing Affordability Declines
DOC.TEXT: Higher prices and mortgage rates dampened the ability of the typical American family to buy a house in January, a real estate trade group said Thursday. ``The increase in mortgage rates should be temporary _ we expect lower rates this spring,'' John A. Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors, said. ``This should improve overall affordability conditions in 1990, especially in areas where there is an ample supply of moderately priced homes,'' he added. The Realtors said their affordability index fell to 104.2 in January, meaning that a family earning the national median income of $33,708 had 104.2 percent of the income needed to qualify for a median priced home costing $96,200. The median means that half of the families earn more and half less, or that half of the houses sell for more and half for less. The median income was up $108 from $33,600 in December, while the median price rose $3,700 from $92,500 a month earlier. The income needed to qualify for a loan on the typical home rose $1,298 from $31,066 in December. Interest rates, meanwhile, rose from 9.96 percent in December to 9.98 in January. The association uses a composite rate reflecting both fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages. The changes meant a $27 increase to $674 in the monthly mortgage payment, which represents 24 percent of the median family's income. The index was down from 108.2 in December, the highest level since it measured 110.5 in January 1989. ``Despite the January decline in overall affordability conditions, the index is over 100.0, which is considered to be a good range,'' said Realtors President Norman D. Flynn. ``However, with the median home price and the average mortgage rate increasing, naturally we will see some people squeezed out of the housing market,'' he added. The Realtors said last month that typical first-time buyers already were unable to enter the starter-home market during the fourth quarter of 1989. The affordability index for them was only 74.4. It was 71 in both the second and third quarters of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Foretich Says He'll Abide By Court Order
DOC.TEXT: The father of Hilary Foretich said Thursday he would abide by a court order not to contact the child he tracked across two continents during a fierce custody dispute. A court issued the temporary order pending a ruling on whether Dr. Erich Foretich can see his 7-year-old daughter for the first time in two years. A date has not been set for the family court ruling. Hilary's mother, Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, went to jail for 25 months rather than reveal the whereabouts of her daughter, whom she said was sexually abused by Foretich. In Washington Thursday, a court ruled that Morgan can have her passport back so she can go to New Zealand. However, the passport is in the possession of the city's Court of Appeals and Judge Herbert Dixon of District of Columbia Superior Court said he could not order that court to return the document. A decision by the appeals court was expected later. Hilary has spent the last two years with her maternal grandparents in New Zealand during Foretich's search. Foretich, a 45-year-old dentist from Falls Church, Va., said Thursday he would abide by the temporary family court order not to contact his child. Asked at Christchurch Airport how he tracked his daughter, Foretich said he did it with ``the help of police departments and private dectives who were able to do these things.'' He said he hoped to see his daughter soon and spent the day consulting with his lawyers. William Morgan, Foretich's father-in-law, has vowed to call police if Foretich approaches the child. ``The reason we're staying in Auckland as opposed to here is to keep some privacy in my daughter's life,'' Foretich said at the airport. ``That's most important, paramount to me.'' He also said he was certain the New Zealand judicial system would rule in his favor. Dixon ordered Morgan to jail for contempt of court in August 1986 for refusing to allow Foretich to visit the girl. Morgan was released three days later by the appeals court, which required her to surrender the deed to her house as bond and turn over her passport. In February 1987, Dixon sent her to jail again, but she was released three days later after agreeing to allow Foretich's visits. In August 1987, Dixon jailed Morgan for a third time. She remained imprisoned until September 1989. In his order Thursday, Dixon noted Morgan remained in contempt of court.

DOC.HEAD: Mongolia Hopes to Speed Up Reforms, Premier Says
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's Communist government hopes to speed up political and other reforms by cooperating closely with a newly formed opposition group, its premier said Thursday. ``Looking at their proposals, we want to help speed up reforms as much as possible,'' Premier Dumaagiyn Sodnom said at a news conference. ``This is not limited to the economy, as we also must reform politics. We are studying their proposals very carefully.'' Long an ally of the Soviet Union, Mongolia has been experiencing some of the democratic pressures sweeping Eastern Europe. All statues of the late Soviet dictator Josef Stalin have been torn down in recent weeks, and last month the Mongolian Democratic Party was established by the reformist Mongolian Democratic Union. It is calling for an end to the Communist Party's nearly 70-year monopoly on power, and a multiparty parliamentary system. The union also seeks the resignation of the Communist Party Central Committee, the Great People's Hural (Parliament) and Council of Ministers, of which Sodnom is chairman. At its Feb. 18 congress, it promised to increase workers' income. ``The new party was formed without a confrontation with the government,'' Sodnom said at the Japan National Press Club. ``The Mongolian Democratic Union is made up mostly of young people. They are among the intellectuals of society, but there are workers too. They are our children.'' Sodnom is the highest-level Mongolian official to visit Japan. He has met with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu and other leading Japanese officials since he arrived Tuesday for a six-day visit. Sodnom told Kaifu Mongolia would pursue democratization and reform its economy, a Foreign Ministry statement said. Japan plans to extend trade insurance to Mongolia and send a delegation to Ulan Bator this month to explore a grant-in-aid, Kaifu said in his meeting with the Mongolian premier. The two met shortly after the two countries' foreign ministers signed a trade agreement granting Mongolia most favored nation status. Two-way trade rose from $30.2 million in 1988 to $43 million last year, according to Japanese figures. ``A valuable step forward was taken today,'' Sodnom said of the accord. ``There is a clear feeling on both sides to encourage cooperation. Many studies are being done now.'' He said the Japanese trade insurance will make it possible for Japan to sell Mongolia materials for the construction of a small-scale steel mill under deferred payment terms. Mongolia is working on foreign investment protection laws and applying for membership in the Asian Developent Bank and other financial institutions to help develop its economy, Sodnom said. ``We have always supported this organization, and so we joined,'' he said. ``We will continue in this direction.''

DOC.HEAD: Son of Civil Rights Leader Apologizes for Speech That Angered Gays
DOC.TEXT: Martin Luther King III apologized Thursday for saying ``something may be wrong'' with homosexuals, and met with angered gay rights leaders to learn more about their concerns. The son of the slain civil rights leader said the legacy of his father's life was ``the struggle to free this country of bigotry and discrimination. This struggle must include a greater commitment to eradicate homophobic violence and discrimination.'' King enraged homosexuals Tuesday when he told middle school students in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., that ``something may be wrong in the makeup of that individual if they happen to be that way.'' ``Any man that has a desire to be with another man has a problem, in my opinion,'' he said. ``And that applies to any woman who has a desire to be with another woman.'' On Thursday, he told reporters that his remarks were ``uninformed and insensitive.'' ``For this I extend my sincere apology to the entire community and in particular to the gay and lesbian community, certainly which has been hurt most by this incident,'' said King, a Fulton County commissioner. Leaders of local gay rights organizations said they were satisfied with the apology, and praised King for his candor. Gay rights leaders met privately with King for about 25 minutes after the news conference and said another meeting was scheduled Friday to lay the groundwork for what King called ``an ongoing dialogue with leaders of the gay and lesbian community.'' Bill Gripp, chairman of the board of the Atlanta Gay Center, said his organization received about 200 calls Wednesday about King's remarks. He said most callers were either surprised or angered by the comments. ``We've all made statements that we regret at times, and I think the important thing here is that the commissioner made a very positive statement, right up front,'' Gripp said.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Two residents have put up a billboard asking a million-dollar question _ how much should Ivana Trump get in her divorce from Donald Trump? The sign was put up Tuesday at an intersection in this central Pennsylvania town. It reads: ``Do you think Ivana Trump should get more than $25 million?'' Mrs. Trump's attorneys have rejected a $25 million sum specified in a prenuptial agreement. In arranging for the billboard, residents Lea Isenberg and Jim Smith had a motivation familiar to real-estate developer Trump _ the profit motive. The billboard gives 900-line phone numbers to call to vote yes or no, for a charge of $1. ``When we first started kicking it around at work, we actually discussed creating our own game titled, `Trump _ the Divorce,''' Isenberg said Wednesday. ``But we found out we could actually make some money through the billboard idea. ``In just two days we've been contacted by people from as far away as San Antonio, Cleveland, Memphis and Detroit,'' she said. During that time they received 54 calls, 58 percent in favor of giving Mrs. Trump more money and 42 percent against it, Isenberg said.

He lives in Japan and she lives here. This weekend they will tie the knot _ with the help of a phone line. Leah Townsend plans to marry Randy Conner, based in Okinawa, Japan, by telephone _ even though the long-distance connection means they will have different wedding anniversary dates. The proxy wedding is set for Saturday at 4 p.m. in Texas, which is 7 a.m. Sunday in Okinawa. Ms. Townsend's half of the ceremony will take place at the home of Conner's parents in the Dallas suburb of Plano. Conner is a communication specialist with the U.S. Air Force. Ms. Townsend is studying education for the deaf at Texas Women's University in Denton. Conner's brother will stand in for him in Texas. State law allows the groom to send notarized papers to the county clerk's office giving consent for a proxy to take his place.

Steve Fisher said he didn't know trouble was brewing on his beer delivery route when at least 43 12-packs fell out of the back of his truck. ``I thought I had the side door locked down, but I guess it wasn't locked down all the way,'' Fisher said. ``What with (Interstate) 40 being as rough as it is, it just jarred everything loose.'' He was called by police about 30 minutes after Wednesday's beer spill to pick up the mess. Fisher had left a trail of canned and bottled brew along the route between two stores. Police said they found 12-packs on at least three corners, but they said it was possible additional containers were swiped from other streets.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Leaders, Bush, Compromise on Pollution Controls
DOC.TEXT: Senate leaders and President Bush compromised Thursday on future air pollution controls for automobiles, factories and electric power plants, enhancing chances that a clean air bill will pass this year. The agreement, after more than three weeks of closed-door negotiations, was viewed as a middle ground likely to attract enough support to thwart continuing regional opposition in the looming Senate debate. Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called the compromise a ``sound and comprehensive'' agreement that will substantially improve air quality over the next decade. He planned to bring the legislation to the Senate floor up on Monday. ``President Bush is extraordinarily pleased with the agreement. It is a milestone, an enormous step forward,'' said Roger Porter, the president's chief domestic policy adviser. Porter said the administration would attempt to expedite Senate passage and seek a similar agreement in the House, where clean-air legislation remains in committee. But the compromise is still likely to encounter stiff industry lobbying, largely because of its estimated $20 billion to $40 billion annual cost to the economy. Some senators also have expressed concern that the bargaining weakened provisions in the original Senate bill that would have required stronger automobile emission controls to combat urban smog. Other have voiced continued concern about the impact of acid rain controls. Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the minority leader, called the compromise ``a giant step forward'' in revising federal air pollution laws for the first time in 13 years. But he cautioned that many senators likely will seek changes when the measure goes to the Senate floor. He urged Mitchell ``not to handcuff anyone'' during the floor action by rushing to cut off debate. The agreement made some accommodations to regional interests, especially those concerned about the local economic cost of acid rain controls. On that score, the compromise continues to require a 10 million ton annual reduction of sulfur dioxide emissions, but allows Midwest utilities to achieve special credits that could be sold to other utilities to recoup some of the costs. Plants that use new technology _ instead of switching away from high-sulfur coal to another fuel _ would receive additional credits for early cuts in emissions, a provision designed to help West Virginia's coal industry. About a dozen senators from the Midwest had threatened to filibuster the legislation if some accommodation were not met to ease their concerns about the high costs of the pollution controls. Mitchell said he still could not discount the threat of a filibuster, but various Senate sources suggested that with the compromise, Mitchell likely would have enough votes to halt debate. Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., said he would seek additional changes to the bill. But ``I'm not going to engage in any filibuster,'' he said. The breakthrough on the legislation came Wednesday when leaders agreed on pollution curbs on automobiles. The compromise eliminates an automatic second round of auto tailpipe controls, although such measures could be put into effect if more than 11 of 27 cities with ``serious'' ozone pollution problems fail to meet federal air quality standards at the end of this decade. The White House had strongly opposed the second round of controls, as had the auto industry. But environmentalists, state pollution control officials in areas with the dirtiest air, and some senators argued the second round of controls are needed to deal with smog in such areas as southern California and the Northeast. In the final days of negotiations, an agreement also came on the acid rain provision, after senators from the West were assured that the utility emission controls would allow for future growth in electric capacity and some accommodation was made to the Midwest region. Earlier tentative agreements were struck on how to curb toxic and smog-causing emissions from industrial plants. Under the compromise, industrial plants will have to use the best available technology to curb releases of 192 toxic chemicals including carcinogens, or cancer-causing agents. Early in the next decade a ``health standard'' that would require plants to reduce emissions further, if the cancer risk to nearby residents is still too high. A broad range of industries and businesses also would have to comply with tougher controls on smog-causing emissions. The compromise, however, would exempt thousands of smaller polluters, which would have been covered by the original Senate bill.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Faces Crisis Over Unpopular New Property Tax
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher faced a crisis Thursday after the resignation of 18 local councilors over her property tax reform. Aimed at bringing home the costs of socalist-run local administrations, the ``poll tax'' has backfired in Mrs. Thatcher's own Conservative Party heartlands, and she is getting the blame. In irate exchanges in the House of Commons on Thursday, socialist Labor Party legislators said Mrs. Thatcher is ``running out of both friends and excuses.'' She retorted the new tax was ``a very much fairer system.'' But rank-and-file legislators acknowledged the party is in deep trouble over the tax, known officially as the community charge, and warned it could cost the next election in 1991 or 1992. Mrs. Thatcher's embattled Environment Secretary Chris Patten, in charge of the tax, said authorities were setting an average charge of around $620 a person _ sharply higher than the $473 government target. Accusing councils of cynically using the new system as an excuse to build up reserves while blaming the government for the high charges, Patten said, ``Nothing could justify behavior like this.'' On Wednesday night, 18 of the 25 Conservative Party councilors on the West Oxford District Council resigned from the party to become independents. The Conservatives automatically lost control of the traditional Tory area near the university city. The rebels complained that after years of following Mrs. Thatcher's strictures on thrift they were forced to set a poll tax of $700 a person, instead of a planned $430. The tax starts this fiscal year. ``This came as the final straw,'' said council chairman Margaret Frost. ``We are people who have been on the political scene for some time _ hard-working, going along with policies, trying to make them work when they patently aren't working.'' The new tax replaces a single property tax levied on the owner of a house or apartment on the basis of the value of the property. The ``poll tax'' is payable by each adult and will bear heaviest on bigger households, while people living alone will be the main beneficiaries. For example, a couple jointly owning a four-bedroomed row house in the Labor-controlled north London borough of Camden who now pay $1,336 a year total will pay $1,002 each in poll tax. Mrs. Thatcher's aim is to make every voter pay local taxes and, she hoped, reject high-spending Labor-controlled local authorities. But instead, big bills are also rolling in from Tory authorities in wealthy districts across the country. Mrs. Thatcher is now threatening to use central government powers to limit the size of the charges a council can set. The last of the 39 county councils in England announced its charges Wednesday night amid some angry scenes in city halls. Hundreds of smaller district councils have to announce their charges by March 18. Protesters chanting, ``Can't pay, won't pay,'' disrupted the meeting of the Conservative-led Somerset County Council in southwest England. Somerset set the tax at $626 a person to help fund a $417.5 million budget _ up 11.3 percent up on last year. At Greenwich, an east London borough, demonstrators threw flour bombs at Conservative councilors, and in Manchester, police were called to guard the council chamber. Local councils get more than half their funds in direct grants from central government. They are responsible for services ranging from schools, the fire department and the local police force to garbage collection. Patten said councils had inceased spending by $5 billion this year, the equivalent of a 35 percent increase in the old property tax. However, local politicians say the higher-than-expected levies are partly because of reductions in central government grants, and high wage demands have forced spending increases. The ``poll tax'' is named after a 14th century tax imposed imposed on a voteless populace, which triggered a Peasants' Revolt in 1380. The government is already unpopular, with record interest rates running at 15 percent while inflation remains high at nearly 8 percent. A Harris Poll in London's Sunday Times this week gave Labor 51 percent of the vote, a 17 point lead and the socialists' most commanding position since Mrs. Thatcher won power in 1979.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Couple Haven't Spoken in Two Years But Share Lotto Jackpot
DOC.TEXT: A couple who stopped talking to each other they broke up in 1988 are splitting an $11.25 million lottery jackpot they won this week with numbers they had chosen when they were dating. After breaking up, Gregory McNally and Deborah Rzepa stayed true to what turned out to be their lucky lottery numbers: 2, 4, 10, 25, 29 and 39. The two learned Wednesday they would split the fifth-largest jackpot in Connecticut Lotto history. It's worth about $225,000 a year to each for the next 20 years. McNally, a 27-year-old press operator for the International Paper Co. in Putnam, said he and Rzepa decided on the numbers while they were dating. After they broke up, neither knew the other continued to play that combination, McNally said. On Wednesday, McNally went to collect his prize at lottery headquarters and his mother and mother-in-law asked who the other winner was. ``I said, `Oh jeez _ that's my ex-girlfriend,''' said McNally, who has since married. ``I couldn't believe it.'' Rzepa claimed her prize and left lottery headquarters about 10 minutes before McNally arrived, said a lottery spokeswoman. Rzepa, 31, told lottery officials she missed watching Tuesday night's Lotto drawing and did not find out she had won until she had read the newspaper. ``I thought to myself, `They look like my numbers.' Then I checked my tickets. I didn't know what to do after that,'' said Rzepa, who is divorced and has two children. Her plans include traveling and immediate retirement from her job as a machine operator at National Patent in Dayville. McNally said he plans to quit his job, but might look for another.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle To Meet With President of Venezuela
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 3 to add date of Quayle visit to Venezuela
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle will confer with Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez in La Guaira, Venezuela, at the outset of a week-long mission to South America, his office announced Thursday. It will be Quayle's second mission to Latin America since the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama frayed U.S. relations with some Latin leaders. Venezuela reportedly had discouraged a Quayle visit in January. Quayle had previously announced he would attend presidential inaugurations in Chile on March 11 and Brazil on March 15. Quayle will fly to Venezuela on March 9 and also make stops in Barbados, Paraguay and Argentina during the six-nation trip. There are no plans for Quayle to add Nicaragua to his itinerary. Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, who upset the Sandinistas' Daniel Ortega in last Sunday's presidential elections, is due to take office there April 25. Quayle's office said his meetings with Perez and other Latin leaders ``will mark the conclusion of the consultation mission assigned the vice president by President Bush in January.'' On Jan. 5, two days after ex-Panamanian ruler Manuel Antonio Noriega surrendered to U.S. authorities, Bush said he would send Quayle to Latin America to assure countries there that the United States wants to remain ``a friendly, supportive and respectful neighbor.'' Bush said the Quayle mission would also signal that the United States will not neglect democracies in this hemisphere even as the East Bloc countries abandon communism. Quayle and Perez will confer on regional issues and recent developments in Latin America. The vice president will then fly to Barbados to meet with Prime Minister Erskine Sandiford and other eastern Caribbean chiefs of government on March 9-10. He will spend March 10-12 in Chile, where Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., will join him in the official U.S. delegation to the March 11 inauguration of President Patricio Aylwin. Aylwin's election is ending more than 16 years of military dictatorship. Quayle will be in Paraguay March 12-13 to meet with President Andres Rodriquez and members of his government. On March 13-14 he will visit Argentina for talks with President Carlos Menem. He will spend March 14-15 in Brazil to attend the March 15 inauguration of President Fernando Collor de Mello. In both Chile and Brazil, Quayle will hold bilateral meetings with leaders from Latin America and Europe, his office said. Quayle is scheduled to arrive back in Washington early on March 16. The vice president visited Honduras, Panama and Jamaica last Jan. 27-29, and attended the funeral of Jose Napoleon Duarte in El Salvador last weekend. Bush himself went to Cartagena, Colombia, on Feb. 15 to confer with the presidents of Colombia, Bolivia and Peru on drugs. He reportedly is considering a major trip to South America in the fall.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Mexican Police Office Arrested; Wanted in DEA Agent's Murder Case
DOC.TEXT: The former head of Mexico's Interpol office who is under U.S. indictment in the torture-murder of a U.S. drug agent was arrested on drug and weapons charges, the attorney general's office said Thursday. Miguel Aldana Ibarra was picked up Wednesday by federal agents at a restaurant on the south side of the city, said Arturo Antelmo, a spokesman for the attorney general's office. Agents later raided Aldana's house in Cuernavaca, 50 miles southeast of Mexico City, and confiscated 2.2 pounds of cocaine, six automatic rifles and several rounds of ammunition, Antelmo said in an interview. He said there were no immediate plans to extradite Aldana to Los Angeles, where he faces charges in the 1985 slaying of Enrique Camarena Salazar, a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent. Aldana was one of five people indicted in January by a federal grand jury on charges of participating in the murder of Camarena and his Mexican pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. Their bodies were found in March 1985 on a ranch 65 miles southeast of Guadalajara. Camarena had been tortured. Camarena had led a series of raids on marijuana plantations allegedly operated by Rafael Caro Quintero, who is serving a 40-year sentence for the murder and 31 more years for drug trafficking. At the time of the murder, Aldana was head of the Mexican branch of the international law enforcement agency Interpol. The same year as the Camarena murder, Mexican prosecutors say Aldana was involved in a major plot to smuggle marijuana into the United States from Mexico. Aldana was arrested in connection with that operation, which also involved Caro Quintero, Antelmo said. According to the spokesman, federal agents in 1985 raided Caro Quintero's Buffalo Ranch in the northern state of Chihuahua and found 9,000 tons of marijuana, the biggest drug bust in Mexico's history. Aldana was arrested on a warrant for involvement in the 1985 case at the Buffalo Ranch, and also for the cocaine and six AR-15 automatic rifles found at his Cuernavaca home, Antelmo said. Aldana, 44, resigned from his Interpol post Jan. 2, 1986, after the weekly magazine Proceso said a drug defendant had testified that a shipment of Colombian cocaine seized at the Mexico City airport was for Aldana. The defendant later recanted, claiming his testimony was made under duress. Since then, Aldana has been a practicing lawyer in Mexico City. The attorney general's office did not explain why it had not arrested Aldana earlier. The Los Angeles indictment charged Aldana participated in the killing of Camarena to protect a Guadalajara cocaine and marijuana cartel, according to the U.S. Justice Department. A dozen people have been convicted in the murder. Aldana was among 19 people named in indictments returned since the original. Also named were Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, whose extradition to the United States on separate charges sparked deadly riots in Honduras in 1988; and Manuel Ibarra Herrera, the former head of the Mexican Federal Judicial Police, the equivalent of the FBI. Ibarra retired from the Judicial Police in 1988 and is a fugitive.

DOC.HEAD: Iran-Contra Jurors Will Face 23-Page Questionnaire
DOC.TEXT: The judge in John Poindexter's Iran-Contra case Thursday released a list of 140 people who could testify or whose names could come up at the former national security adviser's trial. Former President Reagan _ whose videotaped testimony in the Poindexter case is likely to be played back in court _ is on the list of names contained in a questionnaire that prospective jurors will fill out. Poindexter is scheduled to go on trial Monday on charges of conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements. U.S. District Court Judge Harold Greene released a 23-page questionnaire which asks potential jurors whether they ``know or have any connection ... with'' any of the 140 people. Also on the list are former Secretary of State George Shultz, ex-White House chief of staff Don Regan and 18 U.S. representatives and senators. Other names include former national security adviser Robert McFarlane and former Attorney General Edwin Meese III. Potential jurors who know any of the 140 through their jobs or socially likely would be excluded from the jury. The panel will consist of 12 main jurors plus six alternates, chosen from a pool of residents from the District of Columbia. Prospective jurors also will be asked whether they saw, read about or listened to any part of Poindexter's immunized testimony to Congress in 1987 which was broadcast live on national television. No portion of a criminal prosecution may be derived from a defendant's immunized testimony. Similar questions about Oliver North's immunized testimony were asked of prospective jurors last year at North's trial. Potential jurors who said they had been exposed to North's immunized testimony were automatically eliminated from the jury pool. Among the questions prospective jurors will be asked in the Poindexter case: _``Did you see, hear or read about the videotaped testimony of former President Reagan on February 16-17, 1990?'' Transcripts of Reagan's testimony have been publicly released while the videotape was played back in two courtrooms at the U.S. Courthouse. _``Would you be prepared to give the same weight to the testimony of a high official, such as former President Reagan, a member of Congress, or any other high government or military official, as to that of any other citizen?''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Abandoning Bid to Place Cuba Under Special Scrutiny
DOC.TEXT: A former Cuban political prisoner who heads the U.S. delegation to the U.N. Human Rights Commission attacked Cuba on Thursday as one of the world's worst human rights violators. But the delegate, Armando Valladares, also said the United States was abandoning its bid to have Cuba placed under special scrutiny by the U.N. Human Rights Commission. Villadares said the United States has submitted a more moderate draft resolution on Cuba in place of a strongly worded text that failed to win support last year from a majority of the 43 nations represented on the rights commission. Valladares, who spent time in Cuban leader Fidel Castro's jails before coming to the United States, said the new U.S. draft does not condemn Cuba, even though the Communist government ``is one of the world's worst offenders'' on human rights. Cuba recently has intensified its repressive policies, Valladares said. The new U.S. draft resolution focuses on reports that Cuban authorities have taken reprisals against Cubans who testified before representatives of the U.N. rights commission on its first-ever fact-finding mission to Cuba in 1988. The proposed resolution expresses ``great concern'' about these reports and calls on Cuban authorities to honor their guarantees not to take action against Cuban witnesses. The U.S. draft also urges U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to provide the commission with complete records of his contacts with Cuban authorities on human rights issues. ``Our resolution is not based on any feelings of vengeance,'' Villadares said. ``We are not obsessed with Cuba. We would like to have the case of Cuba be dealt with as that of any other country,'' he added. Ambassador Morris B. Abram, the head of the U.S. mission to the United Nations in Geneva, said the U.S. draft ``had a great deal of support'' among commission members. But sources in Western delegations, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the latest U.S. proposal has little chance of winning approval from the commission, which is dominated by Third World members. Last year, the commission rejected a U.S. proposal calling for a new fact-finding mission to Cuba. The 1988 visit resulted in a lengthy but noncommittal report which listed numerous allegations of human rights violations as well as denials by the Havana government. In January, Abram indicated that Washington was still seeking special measures to monitor the human rights situation in Cuba. At the time, he said ``evenhandedness requires that Cuba's well-documented human rights abuses be given the same attention as that (in) Guatemala, Chile and El Salvador,'' which all have been examined by special commission-appointed investigators. Villadares' remarks indicated the United States was abandoning that position. While the U.S. has offered a more moderate proposal, there still have been heated exchanges between the U.S. and Cuban delegations at commission meetings. Cuban Deputy Foreign Minister Raul Roa Kouri accused U.S. authorities of ``trampling upon the rights of millions of U.S. citizens'' and persecuting human rights activists. Cuban delegates attacked Valladares as a ``counterrevolutionary'' who was boring the commission with his statements.

DOC.HEAD: Interim Gov't Takes Steps Toward Privatizing Industry
DOC.TEXT: East Germany took the first step Thursday toward privatizing state industries but set conditions that prevent a wholesale selloff of major assets, apparently to prevent a buyout by West Germans. Also Thursday, the Foreign Ministry called on West Germany to start talks to coordinate a common German position to present at the ``two-plus-four'' conference later this year to steer a course for unification. A ministry statement, carried by the East German news agency ADN, said East Germany recommends that the Germanys' neighbor states should be invited to take part in the talks, although without specifying in what capacity. As of now, other participants in the talks will be the World War II allies: the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union. Poland has been asking to participate. It is worried by West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's refusal to give unconditional guarantees that a united Germany would not claim territory ceded to Poland at the end of World War II. In another political development, the parliament said Thursday that 35 political parties have registered to run candidates in the March 18 elections, although no candidate lists have been made public yet. According to plans set out Thursday by the interim government of Communist Premier Hans Modrow, massive factories run by the state are to be offered to East German investors on March 15, although land and fixed assets will be prohibited from outright sale to foreign buyers. The Communist-led government repeatedly has expressed its fear of being bought out by the wealthy West Germans. The conversion to a more Western-style of industrial management is set to begin only three days before the elections, and the parliament to be seated by that vote could choose to revise the plans. The privatization plan addresses some of the concerns of West Germans seeking to merge the two economies, although it stops short of the full-scale conversion to market principles sought by West German industrialists. Economic reform commissioner Wolfgang Krause said the assets to remain in public ownership would be under control of the parliament, which could make exceptions to the sales restrictions. He said other details of the conversion remained to be settled by the newly elected government. Government spokesman Wolfgang Meyer said the interim step toward privatization would give industry managers more autonomy while hindering ``arbitrary sale of assets and property.`` East Germany's economy has ground to a halt in recent weeks as the nation awaits the outcome of its first democratic balloting. The lack of detail offered on the privatization plan likely reflects the interim leaders' reluctance to make major changes without a public mandate. Parliament secretariat chief Herbert Kelle told the Communist Party newspaper Neues Deutschland that 35 parties have registered for the elections. Hans-Andreas Schoenfeldt, spokesman for the election commission, said a final list of parties and candidates would not be released until March 9. Three minor parties were rejected because they failed to fulfill requirements that they present a platform and a list of party leaders, Neues Deutschland quoted Kelle as saying. Schoenfeldt said he thought moves to postpone the vote by the German Social Union, a member party of the Alliance for Germany, would be unsuccessful. He said East Germany has no institution that could rule on the party's petition to postpone the vote and allow small parties more time to prepare their campaigns. Meanwhile, West Germany's mass-circulation Bild newspaper reported that East German and West German finance officials have agreed to a currency union by July 1. The report, to appear in Friday's edition, said officials in a joint currency commission decided that East German citizens' savings would be exchanged over a period of time at a one-to-one rate. Only savings deposited in East German bank accounts before Jan. 1, or possibly before last Nov. 9, when the Berlin wall was thrown open, would be converted, the newspaper said. The paper said cash up to 1,000 marks could probably be exchanged at parity. Amounts over 1,000 marks would be cashed at a less favorable rate. The East German government declined to comment on the report, and West German government spokesman Dieter Vogel last week denied that any decisions have been made.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf of last, NEW YORK-dated item in package to CORRECT name, location of hospital to New Britain General Hospital in New Britain, sted Middlesex Memorial in Middletown.
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins' circle of supporters grew by at least one when he became a grandfather for the second time, a spokesman said Thursday. Kalila Dinkins Hoggard was born Wednesday at New Britain General Hospital in New Britain, Conn., said mayoral spokesman Tom Kelly. ``Mother, daughter and grandparents are all doing fine,'' Kelly said. Kalila's parents, Donna Dinkins Hoggard and her husband, Jay, also have a son, Jamal, 3. ``Kalila'' is Arabic for beloved, the mayor's office said. Her grandfather's first name means ``beloved'' in Hebrew.

DOC.HEAD: Legislation Would Ban Pesticide Exports
DOC.TEXT: Pesticide companies would be banned from exporting agricultural chemicals that can't be used in the United States if legislation introduced Thursday in the House and Senate becomes law. It's the broadest swipe at the pesticide industry by Congress since use of chemicals in farming became a high profile food safety concern. ``If the EPA says it is too hazardous to be used on U.S. grown foods, then it is too hazardous to be used on foreign grown foods,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee. He said a loophole in the law allows U.S. chemical companies to manufacture here and ship overseas pesticides considered probable carcinogens. ``FDA testing has discovered these banned and unregistered pesticides in foreign food imported to the United States, completing what many call the `circle of poison,''' said Leahy. Leahy and Sen. Al Gore, D-Tenn., co-sponsored the measure in the Senate and Reps. Mike Synar, D-Okla., Leon Panetta, D-Calif., and Dan Glickman, D-Kan., are sponsoring it in the House. Gore said that among the chemicals that would have to stop production in the United States are chlordane and heptachlor, which are made only in his home state by the Velsicol Chemical Corp. of Memphis. ``These chemicals are killers. We know that,'' said Gore. ``Velsicol has the same responsiblity of every manufacturer to act in a responsible way and to protect public health.'' Gore said he is co-sponsoring the bill because one of the ``leading offenders is in my home state'' and he is concerned about the safety of his constituents who could be eating imported foods grown with cancer-causing chemicals. Donna Jennings, a spokeswoman for Velsicol, said chlordane and heptachlor are temporarily off the U.S. market because they are still under review by the Environmental Protection Agency. She said the products are used to kill termites and protect germinating seeds from other pests. While alternative chemicals exist for use in the United States, there are some regions of the world, like the tropics, where weather and pest conditions prevent other products from being effective, she said. ``I don't think U.S. regulators should make decisions for other countries about what they do and do not need,'' said Jennings. In addition to health concerns, Glickman offered a pure business reason why the chemicals should be kept away from foreign countries. ``Continued foreign use of EPA-banned pesticides gives foreign farmers a competitive advantage over American farmers who produce their crops in a safe and healthful way. These chemicals increase crop yields,'' said Glickman, who serves on the House Agriculture Committee. National Agricultural Chemicals Association president Jay Vroom, however, said the bill would hurt business for U.S. chemical manufacturers. ``A unilateral approach to a global issue does no good and only puts U.S. manufacturers at a disadvantage, and may drive importing countries to suppliers that may supply far less environmental stewardship with their products,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pulitzer Prize Winning Author Dead at Age 79
DOC.TEXT: Josephine Johnson Cannon, who won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction in 1934 for the novel ``Now in November,'' has died at age 79. The author, who wrote under her maiden name Josephine Johnson, wrote 11 books in all, including novels, short story collections and poetry. One of her most recent books was the 1969 work ``Inland Island.'' She had been a regular contributor to the monthly Ohio Magazine. She died Tuesday of pneumonia at Clermont Mercy Hospital. Her husband, Grant Cannon, who died in 1969, had been editor of the Farm Quarterly in Cincinnati. Mrs. Cannon was born in Kirkwood, Mo., and attended Washington University in St. Louis. The body is being donated to the University of Cincinnati for medical research. No funeral service is planned. A memorial service is to be arranged in late spring, the family said. Survivors include a son, Terence Cannon, of Hoboken, N.J., and two daughters, Annie Cannon, of Camptonville, Calif., and Carol Cannon, of Philadelphia.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-DEA Official Says Drug War Misdirected
LaserPhoto NY23
DOC.TEXT: A leading federal drug agent who resigned this week says the nation's multibillion-dollar drug war is being compromised by inexperienced leaders and a politically fueled demand for quick success. Robert Stutman, until Wednesday chief of the New York office of the Drug Enforcement Administration, maintained in an interview that efforts to stem drug smuggling _ a focus of the drug war _ are virtually futile. In unusual remarks for a prominent law enforcement official, Stutman said the Bush administration has overemphasized the role of law enforcement in fighting drugs. He urged greater attention to education and treatment. ``For too long American policy-makers and others have depended on people who carry a badge to solve the problem, and it's not going to happen that way,'' Stutman said. ``The problem is we continue to try to sell the American public on short-term answers. And that's what law enforcement is.'' Stutman, 46, a 25-year DEA veteran, said he believed that inexperience in the federal Office of National Drug Control Policy, led by former Education Secretary William J. Bennett, was contributing to the policy flaws. ``I'm not sure the people who are presently setting policy have the experience level and are dealing enough with what's happened in the past,'' he said. ``One of the attitudes I saw in Bennett's office was, `We don't want to even hear what happened in the past, because that's all been a failure.''' The result, he suggested, is repetition of failure. For example, he said, when Bennett last year proposed a drive to clean up drugs in Washington, D.C., DEA officials privately derided the project as ``ODALE revisited,'' after a failed 1972 street-level drug-fighting program, the Office of Drug Abuse Law Enforcement. Fred La Sor, a spokesman for Bennett's office, disagreed with Stutman's suggestion that its leaders had been ignoring the expertise of others. More broadly, he said: ``We have to do what we have to do. Congress is asking for results. The White House is asking for results. The American public is asking for results. We're going after results, and I think we're getting some.'' La Sor said the year-old drug policy office was focusing, in part, on interdiction because the U.S. government handles that work alone, while state, local and private programs share treatment and education efforts. Stutman, however, argued that interdiction is essentially ineffective. He noted that the seizure of 43 tons of cocaine between Oct. 1 and Nov. 15 had no impact on the drug's price and availability. And in the 1970s, when federal agents staunched the supply of Turkish heroin, Mexican heroin promptly took its place, he said. ``I would have thought we could have learned from that mistake,'' Stutman said in the interview Tuesday. ``And yet we are continuing to depend ... on a drug-specific policy that says, `let's stop cocaine from Colombia, Peru and Bolivia.' ``My argument is it's almost an impossible situation,'' he said. ``Does it deserve attention? Absolutely. But that isn't where we should be putting our emphasis, our leadership and our money, which are clearly much more needed in the prevention area.'' Stutman, who led the New York DEA office for nearly five years, quit to join Stutman Tankel Strang and Hayes, a firm that advises corporations on anti-drug strategies for their work forces. He also is co-writing a book and is a drug consultant for CBS News.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmaker Announces Winners of `Ought-to-be-a-Law' Contest
DOC.TEXT: A legislator took his power to the people with a ``There Ought To Be A Law'' contest and received suggestions such as banning kissing in cars and requiring people to use common sense. State Rep. Larry Wennlund selected the two winners Thursday and said he will introduce the ideas this spring during the Illinois General Assembly session. The winner in the under-18-year-old category was Dawn Downing, a freshman at Joliet West High School, who suggested insurance stickers be placed on license plates to make it easier for police to spot uninsured vehicles. In the adult category, Deborah McCormick of Joliet won with her call for mandatory drug and alcohol tests for all drivers involved in fatal traffic accidents. About 600 people in this northeastern Illinois community of 3,500 offered their 2 cents on what should be the law of the land, Wennlund said. ``If the message is to seek more input from your constituents, I think it's a healthy message,'' he said. Here are some of the suggestions that didn't win: _ No naked movies on television, no Playboy channel in Illinois, and no school for 300 years, submitted by a third-grade class at Lincoln Elementary School in Monmouth. _ Pregnant woman be given stickers _ set to expire shortly after their due dates _ to allow them to use handicapped parking, from Beverly McNulty of Berkley. _ All state residents be required to have and use common sense, from a 70-year-old constituent whom Wennlund declined to identify. _ No drinking in Illinois, no drugs and no kissing in cars, from a second-grade class at Lincoln School. Wennlund said the winners, selected by a panel of five journalists, would be invited to Springfield this spring to track the progress of their bills. He said he came up with the idea for the contest last year, when an educator suggested school-bus drivers be tested annually for drugs and alcohol. ``Ninety percent of laws come from one special interest group or another,'' said Wennlund. ``Those generated from the average citizen many times make a lot more sense.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Press for Hard Line on Japanese Trade, But Delay Legislation
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ (AP) _ Democrats on Thursday urged President Bush to take a hard line against Japanese trade barriers when he meets with Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu this weekend, but they delayed action on retaliatory legislation. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., told Bush in a letter he should go into the meeting Saturday in California with the new prime minister armed with specific proposals for opening the Japanese market to more U.S. exports. ``The time for talking about the problem is coming to an end and the time to actually produce results is here,'' Gephardt said, referring to a continuing annual $50 billion U.S. trade deficit with Japan. Bush and Kaifu are meeting just a week after trade negotiators for the two countries made little progress in talks in Tokyo on removing structural barriers that effectively keep U.S. products and services out of the Japanese markets. U.S. officials had hoped for more progress after the ruling Liberal Democatic Party's large victory in Japan's parliamentary election Feb. 18, but the last round of talks remained focused largely on technical matters. ``Our negotiators are now complaining openly about Japanese intransigence,'' said Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., chairman of the Senate Finance Committee's trade subcommittee. Baucus had planned to asked the committee Thursday to approve a bill directing the administration to retaliate with new U.S. barriers to Japanese goods if Tokyo doesn't agree by a June 17 deadline to lower its barriers to American wood products. The deadline, established by the 1988 Trade Act, also applies to Japanese barriers to U.S. satellites and semiconductors. Baucus, however, agreed to withhold the bill after U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills told him in a letter Thursday the administration is prepared to retaliate on its own ``should the negotiations not conclude satisfactorily and on time.'' ``Hopefully, President Bush and Prime Minister Kaifu can make progress on these isses this weekend,'' he said. Baucus estimated that Japanese tariffs, building codes and other structural barriers are effectively keeping out between $1 billion and $2 billion in U.S. forest products at a cost of 10,000 jobs in this country.

DOC.HEAD: Sunday Landing for Shuttle; Flight Going `Satisfactorily'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 6th pvs, `About the ...' to UPDATE with solid rocket boosters arriving at NASA hangar for assessment.
DOC.TEXT: A $500 million spy satellite glided from the space shuttle on Thursday and Atlantis' astronauts streaked toward a Sunday landing, NASA sources said. The sources said the 37,300-pound satellite was ejected from the shuttle's cargo bay early Thursday. Atlantis will land at 1:34 p.m. EST Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base in California, said the sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The shuttle was launched in darkness early Wednesday and progress of the mission has been cloaked under a Pentagon-imposed news blackout. A brief announcement Thursday by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said Atlantis' ``expected landing day'' was Sunday at Edwards, but the agency did not announce a time or mention the satellite. About the shuttle and its five-member, all-military crew, the statement said: ``The crew is doing well and orbiter Atlantis continues to perform satisfactorily.'' The shuttle's solid rocket boosters arrived around midday Thursday at a NASA hangar at the Cape Canaveral Air Force Station for several days of assessment, said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. The boosters separated two minutes and eight seconds after liftoff and fell into the Atlantic 169 miles from Kennedy Space Center. They were retrieved by two ships and towed back. According to sources, the satellite carried by Atlantis is a powerful space snoop capable of taking high resolution photographs from orbit and evaesdropping on electronic communications around the world. The satellite, the sources said, was placed into a high inclination orbit that will fly over much of the Soviet Union, including portions in the north not previously observed by a shuttle-launched satellite. By covering most of the Soviet Union, the satellite may play a role in verifying Soviet compliance with arms agreements. Atlantis' is commanded by Navy Capt. John O. Creighton. The other crew members are Air Force Col. John H. Casper, the pilot, and mission specialists Marine Lt. Col. David C. Hilmers, Air Force Col. Richard M. Mullane and Navy Cmdr. Pierre J. Thuot. Atlantis' flight is the 34th shuttle mission and the sixth dedicated solely to the military.

DOC.HEAD: Agency Imposes Fine, Calls for Show Changes
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators fined Walt Disney World $1,000 and ordered the installation of high-density padding, nets or airbags to safeguard performers in its Indiana Jones stunt show. In a citation disclosed Thursday, the Occupational Safety and Health Administration said actors risked falling onto concrete from heights of 28 feet in recreating adventure scenes from the Indiana Jones movie series at the Disney-MGM Studios theme park. The agency began investigating the show in October after two performers were injured in falls. The lack of fall-protection devices constituted a serious violation of federal safety standards, said the agency's area manager, Larry Falck. The show, which has an Egyptian setting, opened last May. Falck said the agency could not demand that Disney make certain changes, such as adding guardrails, without destroying the sense of danger the show tries to convey. ``We're saying, `OK, you don't necessarily have to do that because it's certain to ruin the show, but at least put in fall-protection devices such as airbags, high-density pads or nets, so that if they fall at least they're not going to be hurt,''' Falck said. Disney spokesman John Dreyer said the company would not contest the fine and would make the necessary changes without ruining the illusion of danger. ``I think it will be the same exciting show as it is,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Lacalle Sworn in as New Uruguayan President
LaserPhoto MVD2
DOC.TEXT: Luis Alberto Lacalle, a career politician and scion of one of Uruguay's most prominent families, was sworn in Thursday to replace Julio Sanguinetti as president of this South American nation. Before the swearing-in at Congress, Lacalle, his wife and three children attended a Roman Catholic Mass at Metropolitan Cathedral, the first time those two ceremonies have been linked in this agnostic country of 3 million since 1894. Lacalle, 48, takes over a once-prosperous beef- and grain-exporting nation that is suffering economic problems and is still troubled by the after-effects of a military regime that ruled harshly from 1973 until Sanguinetti was elected president in 1985. The military issue dogged Sanguinetti and his Colorado Party during his entire five-year term but apparently was resolved when an amnesty of officers accused of human rights abuses during the military's crackdown on leftist subversion was upheld by referendum last April.
