The political stability and freedom that marked this nation from the last century until the military's 12-year rule was upheld when Lacalle and his National Party won the Nov. 26 elections. Lacalle's top priority is reforming Uruguay's economy, which like neighboring Argentina and Brazil, has been dominated by the state and the powerful labor movement for decades. Lacalle's goals include slashing inflation by more than half to 50 percent his first year, balancing a fiscal deficit and shoring up the social security system that once was the envy of many Western nations. Lacalle has political backing for his proposed reforms, including tax hikes and the sale of money-losing state companies. But the leftist labor confederation Interunion Workers Plenary has indicated it will resist any plan that cuts jobs or benefits. Sanguinetti referred to organized labor as ``the biggest obstacle to my administration. ... They are completely politicized and don't understand reason.'' Those attending the civil ceremony included the presidents of Argentina, Brazil, Colombia, Bolivia and Paraguay as well as President-elect Patricio Aylwin of Chile. After the ceremony at Congress, Lacalle and Vice President Gonzalo Aguirre were driven to Government House in a 1937 Ford convertible that belonged to the president's grandfather, Luis Alberto de Herrera, the National Party's dominant figure this century.

DOC.HEAD: Disagreement On How To Stop Food-Garbage Hauls By Truckers
DOC.TEXT: Truckers, lawmakers and the Bush administration failed to agree Thursday on how best to stop trucks from alternating loads of garbage or chemicals in the same vehicles used for food hauls. ``While there has been almost universal agreement on the need to end these most egregious practices, unfortunately, garbage backhauling is still legal and is still occurring every day,'' Rep. Chris Smith, R-N.J., told a Senate Commerce subcommittee on surface transportation. Nearly a year ago, a Pennsylvania newspaper first reported that refrigerated food-hauling trucks known as ``reefers'' were being loaded with municipal solid waste at a transfer station. In October, truckers told a House panel about the related practice of hauling chemicals and juice back to back. Concern by food companies has helped pressure truckers to avoid the practice, said J. Terry Turner, executive director of the Interstate Truckload Carriers Conference. ``Since last July, the problem of transporting solid waste by truck has been addressed by the marketplace,'' Turner said in a prepared statement. ``Most, if not all of my refrigerated carriers, have been required by their customers to certify that they do not transport solid waste in their refrigerated trucks.'' The practice is called backhauling because it often occurs after trucks have hauled food loads to the East. Rather than return to the Midwest empty, they carry garbage. A trucker testified last August that he liked hauling garbage because it could not be harmed en route. Rep. William Clinger, R-Pa., said his office was tipped last week about a truck that carried beef and was now hauling infectious medical waste. ``And its next load was to be boxed beef,'' Clinger said. ``Of course, this incident has been reported to the Department of Agriculture, but there's not much more that can be done so long as the practice remains legal.'' Clinger also showed a photo of a methane gas cloud rising from a garbage-carrying truck that had previously delivered a load of avocadoes to New York City. He said the refrigerated truck was photographed following an accident last year on Interstate 80 near Clearfield, Pa. The House Public Works and Transportation Committee and the House Energy and Commerce Committee are trying to reconcile differences between bills they have approved to end backhauling. Among the disagreements Thursday was which federal agency should take the lead. Wilson S. Horne of the Agriculture Department's Food Safety and Inspection Service told the panel that USDA would not comment on two pending Senate bills, since both placed enforcement responsibility with the Department of Transportation. But Alan I. Roberts, a hazardous materials specialist with DOT, said his agency opposed the Senate proposals because lead responsibility more properly rests with USDA and the Food and Drug Administration, with help from DOT. Turner, the trucking group spokesman, said the answer lies in requirements to ensure better packaging of solid wastes. ``The trucking industry did not create this problem and we should not be viewed as the villains,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Troops Kill 31 Moslems in Kashmir as Million March
DOC.TEXT: Indian troops shot and killed 31 demonstrators on Thursday as an estimated 1 million Moslems marched through the streets of Srinagar chanting ``Independence,'' witnesses and hospital sources said. Hospital sources said at least 100 people were admitted to two hospitals in Srinagar, with 25 or more in serious condition. Witnesses said troops fired on two separate processions of separatists and sympathizers as they strode toward a prayer ground to join comrades demanding the independence of Moslem-dominated Kashmir from predominantly Hindu India. The sources and witnesses spoke on condition of anonymity. In New Delhi, a government spokesman confirmed 18 deaths in the incidents. ``The situation is very bad, very tense. Our head count is 18, but there is confusion,'' said the spokesman, who cannot be identified under standing briefing regulations. Suspected Moslem separatists assassinated a senior Jammu-Kashmir state government official on Thursday in this center of the separatist campaign, government officials in Srinagar said, speaking on condition of anonymity. They said Pushker Nath Handoo, assistant director of the state information department, was shot as he was about to get into his car outside his home. Handoo was a Hindu, India's religious majority, but a minority in Kashmir. Witnesses said about 1 million people took part in a procession to the U.N. Military Observers office in Srinagar, chanting: ``What do we want? Independence!'' and ``We want freedom!'' It was the latest in daily demonstrations in Srinagar this past week to push the secessionist demand. The army fired on Moslem militants at 2 p.m. in Zakura Nishad crossing, six miles from Srinagar, the summer capital of Jammu-Kashmir, killing 23 people, witnesses and doctors at a hospital said. They said three hours later, soldiers fired on Moslems in Bemina area, three miles from Srinagar, and at least eight people were killed. The deaths brought to 145 the number of people killed in the latest round of secessionist violence that flared Jan. 20 following a government crackdown on Moslem militants. Ghulam Rasool Mir, among those wounded by army gunfire, said at Soora Medical Institute in Srinagar the trouble began when soldiers, passing by the procession in three trucks, snatched a flag held by march leaders and the crowd retaliated by hurling stones. He said the soldiers first fired in the air, then at the crowd. Another victim, Abdul Gani Dar, said the procession had grouped in neighboring towns and was marching to the Idgah, or main Moslem prayer ground, in Srinagar to merge with a larger procession. In New Delhi, the government spokesman said the army fired after a mob attacked a vehicle. ``The firing was more in self-defense, because the mob had become violent,'' he said. The movement for an independent Kashmir has mostly been led by the area's Moslems, who form about 65 percent of Jammu-Kashmir state's 6 million people. Kashmir, once a princely state, was divided between India and Pakistan after the two lands were partitioned following the end of British colonial rule in 1947. Srinagar and the surrounding areas of the valley became part of Indian-held Jammu-Kashmir state. Moslems make up 12 percent of India's 880 million population and Hindus comprise 82 percent. Sikhs, Christians and Buddhists make up the rest. Kashmiri militants earlier campaigned for union with Pakistan, but now demand independence and the status of a neutral nation. India has fought two wars with Pakistan over Kashmir.

DOC.HEAD: Illegal Drug Production Up Worldwide
DOC.TEXT: Production of illegal drugs increased worldwide in 1989 as drug abuse rose and efforts to curb international trafficking were undermined by corruption, the State Department said Thursday. But the department's annual report also noted some bright spots: Cocaine seizures were up in the United States, Latin America and the Caribbean, and major cocaine traffickers were captured, jailed and extradicted to the United States. ``There were encouraging developments which were counterbalanced by major problems,'' said Melvyn Levitsky, the assistant secretary of state for international narcotics matters. Levitsky, testifying at a House panel on international narotics control, was peppered with questions by lawmakers who were skeptical about the success of the war on drugs and the accuracy of the report. ``It seems to me ... we are slipping badly on this,'' said Rep. Larry Smith, D-Fla., noting that production of coca leaf increased in 1989 despite eradication efforts. Citing Peru, where eradication efforts have been stymied by guerrilla activities, Smith asked: ``Why don't they (the Peruvians) do something?'' Levitsky said Peru was ``resource-starved.'' Members also asked why a Jan. 5 memo written by one of Levitsky's subordinates was watered down. The memo, obtained by The Washington Post, criticized the government of Bolivia for ``a total lack of commitment to the anti-drug war.'' The memo said Bolivian President Jaime Paz Zamora had appointed a number of corrupt officials to key anti-narcotics roles, according to the Post account. But the annual report cites ``encouraging signs'' of a new commitment by the Bolivian government. The author of the memo, Kirk Kotula, was unavailable for comment. But Levitsky said he was angered that the newspaper had obtained the documen, which was one of several used to prepare the report. Under law, countries which do not cooperate in anti-drug efforts are ineligible for U.S. assistance. But in the four years since the law has been in effect, no U.S. ally has been declared to be uncooperative or, in State Department language, ``decertified.'' Two countries _ Laos and Panama _ were certified, reversing their status from last year. But the United States told those two countries _ as well as the Bahamas, Bolivia, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru and Thailand _ what U.S. officials think ought to be achieved in the drug arena in the coming year. Afghanistan, Syria, Burma and Iran _ all counties which do not receive U.S. assistance _ were not certified because there is no evidence those countries are taking steps to halt drug production and trafficking, he said. Other countries that were certified included Belize, Brazil, Colombia, Ecuador, Hong Kong, India, Jamaica, Malaysia, Morocco, Nigeria and Pakistan. President Bush granted Lebanon a waiver of certificatin based on national interest grounds. In other areas, the report praised the Colombian government for its ``vigorous attack'' against the cocaine cartels. It said international cooperative efforts led to the freezing of millions of dollars in drug-related assets and that there were openings for meaningful cooperation in anti-drug efforts with Panama, Laos and the Soviet Union. On the other hand, the report said, opium production doubled in Burma, partly because of a cessation of law enforcement activities and the inability of other countries to influence Burmese policy. In addition, it said, ``flagging political will and corruption among officials restricted progress in a number of major drug-producing and trafficking countries.''

DOC.HEAD: Donetsk Miners Walk Out to Press Political Demands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with strike held. Picks up 3rd pvs, `If the ...
DOC.TEXT: Miners in the Ukrainian coal-mining capital of Donetsk went on a six-hour strike Thursday to press demands that the entire local Communist Party leadership resign, Soviet television said. The afternoon shift at a number of mines stayed off the job, according to the TV news show ``Vremya.'' But the Soviet news agency Tass said many miners at a strike committee meeting were reluctant to go along, saying the walkout would aggravate the grave economic situation. Nikolai Volynko, committee co-chairman, said the group called on afternoon shift personnel to stay home in a ``warning strike.'' If the party officials do not quit as a result, Volynko said, the committee will call on miners throughout the region to walk off the job Friday. He spoke by telephone from the Ukrainian city 500 miles south of Moscow in the Donentsk Basin, the top Soviet coal-producing area that was rocked last summer by strikes as miners demanded better living and working conditions an local autonomy. On Feb. 7, a mass rally held in Donetsk forced the resignation of the local party chief, A. Vinnik. But a week later, another rally demanded the entire local party bureau quit. Eight members of the Donetsk strike committee went on hunger strike after the bureau resolved not to tender resignations until a regional party conference, scheduled April 6-7. Volynko said information gathered by the strike committee showed that a general strike Friday would be joined by the ``absolute majority'' of all mines in the region. But Interfax, the news service of Radio Moscow, said its correspondent reported that in the Donetsk area ``many mines have failed to support the call for industrial action.''

DOC.HEAD: Ind., N.Y., Neb. Officials Back Civil Rights Law Change
DOC.TEXT: A national mayors' organization and two state attorneys general endorsed legislation Thursday that would reverse recent Supreme Court decisions on minority hiring in government. In testimony before the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, Indianapolis Mayor Richard Hudnut III and New York Attorney General Robert Abrams called for passage of the proposed ``Civil Rights Act of 1990.'' Hudnut spoke for the United States Conference of Mayors and Abrams for himself and Nebraska Attorney General Robert Spire. ``It must be understood that there are people in our society who have been excluded from the mainstream of opportunity for too long, and that without some kind of proactive government policy they will continue to be excluded,'' Hudnut said. The hearing focused on efforts to counter the effects of the 1989 Wards Cove decision, which critics complain transferred the burden of proof in certain discrimination cases to plaintiffs. Under the decision, plaintiffs must prove an employer wrong who argues that some employment practice they are complaining about was based solely on a neutral, non-discriminatory consideration. The proposals would reinstate a standard that had been in existence since 1972 for state and municipal employees. That required the employer to prove that the employement practice under attack was not discriminatory. Abrams argued that the old Griggs standard, as it was known, has benefited employers as well as plaintiffs. As attorney general of New York, Abrams must argue civil rights cases on both sides. ``The result has been the development of selection procedures that better serve to identify those who are truly capable of performing the job,'' he said. The civil rights enforcement activities of the Nixon, Ford and Carter administrations, Abrams said, ``served to bring about racial and ethnic diversity in law enforcement.'' ``Congress and several presidential commissions have found that such diversity is essential to the reduction of citizen mistrust of our law enforcement activities,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: WEDNESDAY
THURSDAY
Arts Students Have a Little Fun With Monet's Famed Impressionist Work
DOC.TEXT: The hordes of reverent Impressionist painting fans crowding the Museum of Fine Arts to pay Claude Monet's grainstacks homage have inspired a few neighborhood art students to produce a work of their own. ``A New Light,'' which the students erected with hay bales outside the School of the Museum of Fine Arts, casts exactly that on the famed works featured in ``Monet in the 90s: The Series Paintings.'' Playing on the way the French master captured sunlight and shadows as they shifted throughout the day on a grainstack outside his back door, the students are offering a similar peek at a one-story, modern haystack framed by a free-standing, faux-gilt frame. ``It's something we came up with in response to the exhibit across the street,'' Margaret Tittemore, one of three students who conceived the project, said Thursday. ``We're all affected when there's a blockbuster show over there.'' Among the more than 200 ``series'' paintings Monet did in the 1890s were 30 each of grainstacks and the Rouen Cathedral, 24 paintings of poplars and 18 of the Japanese bridge over his water lily garden at Giverny. The exhibition, which is in Boston through April 29, includes 86 works on loan from cities around the world and is the largest series ever assembled. The students said they like Monet as much as anyone, but the internationally publicized collection's arrival has also meant a battle for parking places, crowded sidewalks and limited access to the museum. So they're taking a little harmless revenge by poking fun at the whole affair. ``This is not a great public art statement. It's just a fun look at Monet for the 1990s,'' said Tittemore, who has been documenting Boston's shifting light on film the way Monet captured the rural French atmosphere on canvas. The students replaced the artist's 19th century grainstack with a 20th century haystack, made up of 100 machine-packed bales brought in from Sunny Rock Farms in Walpole for $2.75 each. ``It's a lot like what Monet saw except it's in cold Boston instead of sunny France,'' said Elizabeth Nordberg, a Boston University student. ``It catches your eye.'' Nestled amid snow-laden shrubs on the edge of one of Frederick Law Olmsted's urban parks, the bulky straw ``sculpture'' is an incongruous sight. Passersby, bundled against the cold, cast an eye and sometimes stopped briefly to contemplate the midday shadows and bits of sun that streaked the sculpture early Thursday. A French woman and her young charge were out walking when the haystack caught the child's quizzical eye. ``That's a sculpture,'' she said in Monet's native tongue. ``And it's not very pretty.'' They didn't stop to ponder the piece. ``Not everyone gets it,'' said Cliff Pfeiffer, a guard at the red-brick art school's front desk. ``A lot of stodgy museum-goers who are coming to see the exhibit don't seem to get the humor.'' But the haystack has found a home among the art students, who are enjoying the tongue-in-cheek humor ... and something more. ``It might be a jibe at what's going on next door, but there's also some art to appreciate,'' said Laila Streiff, a film maker and former student. ``When you see the frame it signals ``art'' and encourages you to look at the design and what is going on in the texture of the hay.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Administration May Support Cuts to Free Money for New Democracies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts new 3rd graf, The secretary, to move up reference to peace discussions, reflect that Cabinet meeting now set for Sunday
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration could support cutting U.S. aid to Israel and Egypt if similar cuts were applied to other nations as a way of freeing money for emerging democracies, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Thursday. Baker told a House subcommittee that ``we're willing to stand up and be counted'' on such a plan because it would result in the flexibility to put foreign aid money where it is most needed. The secretary also told the panel he has done ``pretty much all we can do'' to bring the Israelis into talks with a Palestinian delegation aimed at setting up elections in the occupied territories. An Israeli Cabinet meeting was scheduled for Sunday. In answer to a question by Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, Baker said administration support for the cuts would ``depend on whether we do it in a non-discriminatory manner.'' In his busy Middle East diplomacy, Baker said, he has not found any significant reduction in tensions. But he added: ``At the same time, we must find a way to respond to changes in Eastern Europe, in Panama and in Nicaragua.'' ``If these leaders are not able to produce for their people, we will rue the day'' that the United States fell short in providing aid, he said. ``We are talking about supporting an extraordinary outbreak of freedom and democracy.'' Baker also said he did not want to see a repetition of the current year's budget crunch, in which some friendly countries that expected U.S. aid got little or nothing because 90 percent of the aid budget was already earmarked by Congress for specific other recipients. ``We ought not to be hidebound by what's been done over the past 10 years,'' Baker said. He said economic aid to all of Africa totaled just $14 million this year ``because there's no one up here lobbying for them.'' His comments were the clearest indication yet that the administration would accept cuts to Israel and Egypt, which get the largest slice of U.S. aid as a result of their participation in the Camp David Middle East peace accord a decade ago. Israel is receiving $3 billion this year and Egypt $2.1 billion, out of an overall budget of roughly $10 billion for bilateral aid. The administration has asked Congress for the same amounts for both countries next year. Baker left himself some latitude, saying he could also support a total elimination of earmarks or the creation of a new discretionary fund which the administration could use to meet new needs that develop during the year. He also said he could support enlargement of the overall foreign aid budget. But he acknowledged that those outcomes are unlikely. Earmarks have been almost sacred in Congress because of the political clout of the countries which receive them and because of lawmakers' view that such spending guidance is their prerogative as keepers of the federal purse. It is equally difficult to increase foreign aid spending because of the popular notion that money spent overseas is wasted. Bush has proposed an increase of about $800 million for fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1, to an overall level of $15.3 billion. But potential new aid recipients have been popping up faster than the budget can accommodate them. Already there are demands for new aid to Eastern European countries emerging from Soviet domination, reparations to a newly democratic Panama, and support for the new democratic government in Nicaragua. Earlier this year, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., proposed finding the money for such needs by cutting 5 percent from the top current aid recipients. The administration denied planting the idea with Dole at the time, but expressed agreement with its goal of increased flexibility in distributing aid money. In his testimony, Baker also said the administration would support $400 million in loan guarantees for Israel to build housing for an influx of Soviet Jewish refugees, but only if Israel offers assurances that it would not put any new settlers in the occupied territories of the West Bank and Gaza strip. The money is expected to be added to an upcoming supplemental appropriations bill and is likely to win congressional approval because of Israel's strong support on Capitol Hill. Israel has declined to provide such assurances about future settlement, but has contended that in the past that about 1 percent of refugees have settled in the territories. ``Settlements are not conducive to the peace process'' because they aggravate tensions with Palestinian residents, Baker said. ``We see them as an obstacle to peace... It is not unreasonable to ask some assurances these funds will not be used to create new settlements or expand old settlements in the occupied territories.'' Baker also said ``we're coming very close to the time when we will know one way or the other'' whether Israel will accept a proposal for talks with a Palestinian delegation about elections among the 1.7 million Palestinians in the territories. Baker has been expressing growing impatience with Israel's failure to respond to his proposals, aired during his meetings with the foreign ministers of Egypt and Israel. ``We've really done pretty much all we can do, we think, from our end, and we are waiting for a response from the Israeli government,'' Baker said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Making $78 Million Available For New Housing Program
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 6th graf pvs with background on program; SUBS grafd 5-8 to CORRECT reference to Home Loan Bank Board, which was abolished as part of S&L bailout; picks up 7th graf pvs, `Savings and...
DOC.TEXT: The government opened the competition Thursday for nearly $80 million that savings and loans and other financial institutions will be able to use to offer cut-rate loans to promote affordable housing. Under the program, included in last year's legislation to bail out the S&L industry, the $78.7 million will be used to buy down the interest rates on certain housing loans, making the financing affordable to those whose incomes otherwise would be insufficient to make monthly payments. Housing and Urban Development Secretary Jack Kemp, who announced opening of the bids in his capacity as chairman of the Federal Housing Finance Board, said the loans could add 20,000 units to the nation's stock of low- and moderate-income housing. Other industry officials, speaking privately, said that number could be significantly lower but that no firm estimate was possible until proposals for the money are submitted. Federal Home Loan Bank officials who participated in the drafting of the program have said the $78.7 million to be spent on interest buydowns should generate between $500 million and $1 billion in housing loans, with the amount again depending on the terms of the accepted proposals. ``This new program will be of significant help to us as we work to meet our national goal of safe, decent and affordable housing for all Americans,'' Kemp said in a statement. Over administration objections, Democrats inserted the affordable housing program into President Bush's S&L bailout, which was enacted Aug. 9. In recent weeks, members of Congress and consumer advocates have complained about administration foot-dragging in starting the program. Savings and loans and other financial institutions affiliated with the Federal Home Loan Bank system, such as some credit unions and savings banks, will have to compete for a share of the $78.7 million, under rules to be published Friday in the Federal Register. Each of the 12 regional Federal Home Loan Banks will establish a fund for the program, as was required by the S&L legislation. The regional banks are located in Boston, New York, Pittsburgh, Atlanta, Cincinnati, Indianapolis, Chicago, Dallas, San Francisco, Seattle, Des Moines, Iowa, and Topeka, Kan. Kemp said higher priority will be placed on applications which detail proposals that meet three or more of the following priorities: Encouraging home ownership; expanding low-income rental stock; making federal property available for low-income housing; promoting activities by non-profit and community groups; empowering tenants through resident management and homesteading; advancing fair housing compliance; and creating permanent housing for the homeless. The application period runs through May 2. During that period, Kemp said the government also would accept public suggestions for changes to subsequent offerings under the program.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Rules Out Drafting Border Treaty Before Unification
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Thursday rejected a Polish proposal that the two Germanys formulate a treaty recognizing the border with Poland, which is nervous about possible land claims by a reunited Germany. Kohl said working out such a treaty must be left for a united Germany. However, Foreign Minister Roland Dumas of France joined Polish officials and others who are pressing for such an accord. Poland wants the agreement as reassurance that a reunited Germany would not renew claims to land that the Western allies took from Germany and transferred to Poland at the end of World War II. In his comments to reports, Kohl reiterated that ``no one wants to make a connection between the question of German unity and a moving of the borders.'' He has previously said such an assurance should satisfy Poland. However, he has refused to say unequivocally that no land claims will be made. Such a position might upset some right-wing West Germans whose vote could help Kohl's Christian Democratic Party in elections set for December. In his comments Thursday, Kohl also raised the prospect again of both German parliaments simply making a declaration _ not starting work on a treaty _to respect the postwar borders. Such declarations, however, would probably just restate a West German parliamentary assurance made in November, which left the final say up to the leadership of a united Germany. Kohl has come under sharp criticism abroad and at home for his position on the lands east of the Oder and Neisse rivers once held by Germany and now part of Polish territory. About one-third of Poland was part of Germany before the war. His refusal to say a united Germany would never lay claim to that land is seen as a major stumbling block on the road to German unification. In addition to Poland and France, the United States, Britain and others have voiced concern about Kohl's stand. In his comments Thursday in West Berlin, French Foreign Minister Dumas said, ``Putting off the (German) response in order to wait for the constitution of a single parliament isn't reasonable.'' ``This border is inviolable. ... That should be said to all the peoples concerned, and first of all to the Poles,'' he said during his luncheon address at West Berlin's press club. He added that Poland should take part in international discussions leading to German reunification, as it has asked. Poland has suggested that the two German governments and Poland draft a treaty to recognize the present borders, with the document to be signed after a united German government comes into existence. Splitting with Kohl, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher indicated support for the idea. Kohl's position puts him at odds with Genscher's liberal Free Democratic Party, the junior partners in the Bonn coalition government. Kohl has shown increasing irritation in recent weeks with the prolonged international outcry over his position on the issue. During his press conference Thursday, he said, ``In the international arena, in East and West, currently the Germans are facing criticism and a prevailing mood that we might disregard all the interests of our neighbors,'' said Kohl. ``I have always said that a united Germany must be a part of the total European architecture,'' Kohl said. The chancellor said the Germans will ``take into consideration the interests of our neighbors.'' But, he added, ``that doesn't mean we should neglect our own interests.''

DOC.HEAD: How Seabrook Would Begin Moving Toward Full Tilt
With AM-Seabrook, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government decision Thursday to give the Seabrook nuclear plant a commercial license begins a months-long process leading up to the reactor generating electricity at full power. Seabrook operator New Hampshire Yankee cannot just throw a switch now that it has a Nuclear Regulatory Commission license. First it must conduct two to three months of tests. During the past several weeks, operators brought the reactor systems from ``cold shutdown,'' 150 degrees, to ``hot standby,'' heating the primary coolant water to 557 degrees at 2,235 pounds per square inch pressure. The water was heated by rapidly circulating it through the cooling system. The next steps are to slowly withdraw control rods made of silver, cadmium and indium from the uranium fuel core. Then operators will gradually dilute the boron concentration in the cooling water to create fission, or the splitting of atoms. Boron absorbs neutrons, which careen into uranium atoms, splitting them and releasing more neutrons, creating a chain reaction. At 1 percent of full power, there would be 1 billion times 1 billion fissions per second, raising the temperature at the center of the plant's fuel pellets to 1,700 degrees. Plant spokesman Ron Sher said the first fission would take place within a week or two, with the plant operating at a fraction of 1 percent of full power. It would be the second fission reaction at the plant since it was completed in July 1986; the first was in June 1989 during low-power testing, when the plant operated at up to 3 percent of capacity. Fission in the reactor core would heat the highly pressurized water circulating through the primary cooling system, a closed loop of piping, and create steam out of water in a second closed loop. The steam would drive turbines, which would drive an electrical generator. Seabrook could reach the ability to produce electricity for customers within a month, at about 10 percent power, Sher said. When that threshold is crossed is a matter to be decided by Seabrook's various owners and the government boards that regulate them, he said. When the plant got to about 50 percent of full power, it would be shut down so NRC inspectors could evaluate performance.

DOC.HEAD: Man With Knives Becomes 14th Person Killed by New York Cops in 1990
DOC.TEXT: A man armed with three large kitchen knives was shot and killed in his home by police Thursday as he allegedly lunged at them, the Police Department said. David Cotto, 20, was the 14th civilian killed by city police this year. Nine of the 11 shots fired by the officers struck Cotto, who was pronounced dead shortly after 5 a.m. at his parent's apartment in Brooklyn, said police spokesman Sgt. Norris Hollomon. The incident began as Cotto and an upstairs neighbor, Carl Billeci, 35, were drinking and playing cards in Billeci's apartment. The two men began arguing and brawling, Hollomon said. Cotto returned to his family's apartment on the first floor. His parents called police because Cotto was acting irrationally, Hollomon said. Sgt. Vincent Guzzo, 41, and Officers Joseph Galli, 44, and Patrick Balsano, 33, arrived at the apartment and found Cotto armed with two 12-inch kitchen knives, a 10-inch kitchen knife and a long barbecue fork, Hollomon said. Cotto was threatening to stab himself, the sergeant said. Guzzo sprayed Mace on Cotto to try to subdue him, but the young man became enraged and lunged at the officers, Hollomon said. The officers yelled at Cotto to stop, but when he did not respond, fired their guns. The three officers were treated for minor injuries, cuts and emotional trauma. Cotto had an arrest record dating back to 1985. He was convicted for robbery and resisting arrest in 1987, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Small Cars Sustain Expensive Damage In Bumper Tests
DOC.NOTE: Eds: The second take is an agate tabular list of the cars tested and the damage each sustained
DOC.TEXT: Small cars driven into barriers and poles at 5 mph to test their bumpers sustained damage ranging from $769 to $3,838, an insurance study said Thursday. The most damaged among 16 1990-model cars tested was the Daihatsu Charade SE; the least was the Honda Civic DX, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety said. ``Every bumper we tested this year did a poor job of preventing damage, and some were downright lousy,'' said Brian O'Neill, president of the institute. The institute, financed by the insurance industry, buys the cars, runs each one into flat barriers, front and back, into a front angle barrier and then backwards into a pole, all at 5 mph. O'Neill said bumper performance has deteriorated since 1982 when the Transportation Department rolled back federal requirements that car bumpers be able to sustain 5 mph crashes without damage to the vehicle. The new requirement lets cars sustain certain damage in a 2.5-mph test. Collision energy rises as the square of speed, so cars in the new test must handle only about one quarter of the collision energy in the old test. A 1981 Ford Escort sustained no damage in any of the institute's four tests, O'Neill said, while damage to a 1990 Escort totalled $1,718. Hyundai Excel bumpers were weakened during the 1990 model year, he said. An Excel tested before the change sustained $561 damage in the rear-into-pole test, while the same model with the weaker bumpers cost $721 to repair. Eight cars that sustained no damage when run forward into a flat barriers, sustained damage costing between $200 (for the Honda Civic) and $718 (for the Mazda 323 Protege SE) when run into an angled barrier, the institute said. Among seven cars with no damage in rear barrier tests, damage in the rear-into-pole test ranged from $479 for the Dodge Shadow to $1,404 for the Ford Escort, the report said. The institute said it found that Toyota Corollas manufactured in Japan and exported to the United States have more protective bumpers than Corollas built in California or nearly identical Geo Prizms which are built in the same plant. The Prizm had $267 worth of damage in the front barrier test, while the the Japan-built Corolla, whose bumper assembly weighs two pounds less, had none, the institute said.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: European Storm Death Toll Reaches 82
DOC.TEXT: Fierce, frigid winds and blizzards battered Europe on Thursday and added to the suffering brought on by foul weather this week that killed 82 people. Britain, France and West Germany were hit hardest. Nineteen people were known dead in France, 18 in Britain, 16 in West Germany, nine in Belgium, seven in Switzerland, six in Italy, three in East Germany, and one each in Austria, Greece, Ireland and the Netherlands. Gale-force winds, peaking at 112 mph, buffeted western and northern Austria and claimed that country's first victim Thursday, a 26-year-old brewery worker whose car was hit by a falling tree, police said. Suffering the worst damage from flooded villages, blocked roads, downed power lines and uprooted treees were France, Britain and West Germany. Some towns along Denmark's North Sea coast were flooded. The Danish search for a West German and his 6-year-old son who ventured out on a fishing trip in a small boat Monday was called off and the two were presumed drowned. Zermatt, the popular Swiss ski resort, remained cut off by snow. Winds reached 125 mph on the 11,408-foot Jungfraujoch Wednesday night and Swiss authorities warned of avalanche risks in many parts of the Alps. Rail, streetcar and automobile traffic were disrupted in much of West Germany Thursday by winds up to 95 mph. Schools were closed in Munich. Stretches of the Autobahn around Frankfurt were blocked for hours, delaying thousands of people trying to get to work. West German police reported four new deaths, including a 48-year-old Turk killed when his car swerved to avoid a falling tree. Many people were injured. Officials said a man was trapped under a fallen tree for three hours before being rescued with serious injuries. Prince Charles, the 41-year-old heir to the British throne, and Princess Diana interrupted a weeklong skiing holiday in Switzerland to fly to Wales in freezing rain and driving wind to meet some of the 800 residents evacuated from the seaside resort of Towyn after its sea wall broke. ``Things like this always bring out the best in the British,'' Charles said after visiting nearby Bodelwyddan Castle, where 150 people took shelter. Charles, the Prince of Wales, wore a Welsh leek in his lapel in honor of St. David, the principality's patron saint. Wind-whipped seas devastated the seaweed harvest off Wales, denying Welshmen their traditional St. David's Day breakfast delicacy of laverbread, which is made with the plant. New flooding hit Towyn and neighboring Kinmel Bay and Pensarn on Thursday as the tide crashed over the damaged sea wall, police said. Snow fell throughout Scotland and Northern Ireland and closed roads and caused many accidents in north and eastern England. A cedar tree crashed through the roof of 14th-century St. Margaret's Church at Starston, in Norfolk. Strong winds and high tides caused an 80-minute suspension of ferry services from Dover to France. In France, storms that began Monday killed at least 19 people, the Civil Defense Center for Operations and Administration said. It said more than 82 have died since the end of January. The National Forest Office said storms destroyed about 100,000 trees in Normandy alone since Jan. 25. French authorities reported four more deaths during Wednesday's storms. An uprooted tree killed two firemen, a wave swept a man out to sea, and a piece of his roof hit a man and killed him as he worked in his garden. A French motorist died Thursday trying to avoid a fallen tree, police said. President Francois Mitterrand visited the hard-hit coastal towns of Fecamp and Etretat in Normandy. Belgian police said two children died Wednesday night in a house fire in Meerbeek near Brussels after fallen trees blocked firefighters' vehicles. A couple died when their car hit a tree blocking a road southeast of Brussels. Austria's Voralberg province and the Motorbahn leading from Vienna to Salzburg were severely affected by the storm.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian President on Hunger Strike to Press Demand for U.S. Aid
DOC.TEXT: President Guillermo Endara went on a hunger strike Thursday, apparently to protest plans to drastically cut a Bush administration request for U.S. aid to rebuild Panama. Endara set himself up in the Metropolitan Cathedral, announcing his strike was ``in solidarity with my fellow citizens in Panama who suffer malnutrition because of poverty.'' He made no explicit mention of U.S. aid. However, he hinted broadly at the underlying purpose of his fast when he told the National Assembly in a speech shortly before: ``Let God enlighten those who have the decision to undertake efforts to provide the necessary financing to solve our people's most urgent problems.'' On Wednesday, Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee that deals with foreign aid, vowed he would cut the $500 million aid proposal sharply because it was too much to give to Panama. ``I guarantee you that's not going to happen,'' Leahy said, referring to the aid package. ``There will be no half a billion dollars.'' ``I wouldn't support that, and I'm not sure many others will,'' he said in an interview. Leahy said congressmen would prefer to give some of the money, if it is available, to emerging new democracies in Eastern Europe. He also said he would like to see more go to meet humanitarian needs in Africa. In his speech broadcast on Panamanian radio and television, Endara said he would continue to work in coming days, despite his fast. He did not say how long the hunger strike would last. In Los Angeles, President Bush announced he had lifted the last sanctions against Panama imposed for its failure to cooperate in drug-fighting efforts. The move will allow low tariffs and fees on Panamanian imports. Most of the economic sanctions were removed in December, when U.S. forces invaded, overthrew military leader Manuel Antonio Noriega, and put Endara in office. Noriega awaits trial in Florida on federal drug-trafficking charges. Endara was widely recognized as the winner of last year's Panamanian elections, which Noriega annulled. Panama's economy has been battered by the sanctions and by fighting during the U.S. invasion. A crowd of supporters accompanied Endara on Thursday as he sat in the cathedral, two blocks from the presidential palace. He was surrounded by bodyguards, and several doctors were in attendance. Talking to reporters, Endara also called his fast part of Lent, saying it was an appropriate time for him to express ``human solidarity'' with his people. It is the second hunger strike by Endara, a portly politician of 53, in less than a year. Endara went on the first fast on Sept. 19 to protest repression by Noriega's now-disbanded Defense Forces. That fast lasted a few days.

DOC.HEAD: Warm Temperatures Break Records in Midwest, Gulf Coast Gets Drenched
DOC.TEXT: The northern Plains and the upper Mississippi Valley basked in record high temperatures Thursday while Texas and Gulf Coast areas were drenched in rain. Temperature records were broken in Duluth, Minn., with 48 degrees, breaking the record of 43 set in 1956; in Marquette, Mich., with 48 degrees, topping the previous record of 45 degrees in 1985 and in St. Cloud, Minn., with a reading of 56 degrees, one degree higher than the 1918 record. A foot of snow fell at Valdez, Alaska, between midnight Wednesday and 10 a.m. Thursday and a foot of snow was forecast to fall by Friday morning. Valdez had more than 100 inches of snow on the ground Thursday, with a total snowfall this season of 473 inches. Showers and occasional thunderstorms extended across southeast Texas Thursday morning. There were reports of locally heavy rain including about 3 inches of around Corpus Christi, Texas, since Wednesday. At noon Thursday, rain extended across southern and northeast Louisiana, central and northern Mississippi, northern Alabama, Tennessee and south central Kentucky. Rain also developed over northern and central California. There were only a few showers by late morning but rain was forecast to be widespread by Friday. The low temperature for the nation Thursday morning was 9 degrees below zero at both Caribou and Houlton, Maine. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 16 degrees at Limestone, Maine, to 80 degrees at the Air Force Base near Tampa, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Companies Fined Millions For Rigging Bids For School Milk
DOC.TEXT: The Southland Corp. and Borden Inc. agreed to plead guilty to conspiring to rig bids for school milk contracts in Florida and pay fines totaling $3.5 million, the Justice Department said Thursday. Court papers filed in U.S. District Court in Tampa also charged the two companies with conspiring to rig bids for contracts to supply milk to federal military bases in Florida and Puerto Rico and the Kings Bay Naval Submarine Base in Georgia. Southland, which operates 7-Eleven convenience stores, and Borden each agreed to plead guilty to felony bid-rigging charges, the Justice Department said. The plea agreements settling the criminal anti-trust charges were submitted to a federal judge in Tampa for approval. According to court papers, the bid-rigging conspiracy in counties on the Florida peninsula began in the early 1970s and extended through at least July 1988. Under the arrangement described in the court papers, the conspirators discussed submitting bids and agreed which company would be the low bidder for specific school districts. Borden and Southland's Velda Farms Division participated in a scheme to rig bids for the 1987-88 school year in Clay, Volusia, Brevard, Highlands, Hardee, Pasco, Polk, Sarasota and Lee counties, according to court papers. Southland was also charged with rigging bids in Charlotte County. The company sold its Velda Farms Division in 1988 when it spun off its dairy-processing holdings in a deal with Dallas-based Morningstar Foods. Borden also admitted to participating in a separate bid-rigging scheme involving in Leon, Franklin, Bay, Escambia, Walton and Santa Rosa counties on the Florida panhandle. As part of the plea agreement, Borden agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle the government's civil claims. Southland agreed to settle civil claims for $2 million. So far, the Justice Department's anti-trust division has brought 14 prosecutions in the continuing investigation of bid-rigging among dairy suppliers in Florida. The probe has netted convictions of three companies and nine individuals. The investigation ``should put an end to the cynical bilking of our nation's armed forces and the outrageous theft of millions of dollars from Florida's school-milk programs,'' said Judy Whalley, acting assistant attorney general in charge of the anti-trust division. Southland spokeswoman Cecilia Norwood, said the company has cooperated with the investigation since 1988. She said there was no evidence that senior Southland management or 7-Eleven personnel were aware of the bid-rigging scheme. The scheme was ``confined to a few former Velda Farms employees in Florida who chose to ignore a longstanding clearly stated company policy,'' she said. A Borden spokeswoman at the company's headquarters in Columbus, Ohio, who was authorized to speak on the case had left for the day, said a secretary who answered the telephone.

DOC.HEAD: Leading Opposition Movement Sets Condition for Return to Talks
DOC.TEXT: Bulgaria's leading opposition movement is unwilling to return to negotiations on the country's future if the Communists balk at political reform, a spokesman said Thursday. Also Thursday, more than 70,000 people attended a Communist-sponsored rally at a Sofia sports stadium, an apparent response to a huge opposition protest meeting on Sunday. Sunday's demonstration for democracy and political reform drew at least 150,000 people. Official Bulgarian media put the number even higher. The rally Thursday, which was broadcast live on state television and organized by the Sofia party organization, was marked by the old-style waving of Communist banners and speeches and testified to the strength of the ruling party. The Communists in Bulgaria, unlike those in other Soviet bloc countries, have retained much of their clout in national politics, and their moves toward democracy have been hesitant and somewhat half-hearted. Addressing the crowd in the stadium, Communist Party chief Alexander Lilov appealed for calm and patience and warned fellow Communists ``not to give in to provocations of the opposition.'' He accused the opposition of being increasingly aggressive, and cited as a case in point the temporary ``occupation'' of the downtown Georgi Dimitrov mausoleum during Sunday's demonstration. ``We are a strong, one-million (member) party, and we have an important role to play in the future of this country,'' said Lilov, cheered by the participants. In an interview Thursday, opposition spokesman Georgi Spassov of the Union of Democratic Forces said the Communists will have to make further reforms if negotiations are to continue. The talks were suspended Feb. 12. In one major reform, Communist leaders decided last week that a new law on parties, to be adopted by the Communist-controlled parliament next week, would ban party cells from factories, offices and other institutions. But the opposition says the Communists are stalling on other political reforms and have ignored the Union of Democratic Forces on such decisions as the appointment of a new radio and television chief. The current chief is said to have been firmly entrenched in the party apparatus for 20 years. Also angering the opposition is the fact that a week after committees representing all parties in the talks submitted a document on Bulgaria's political future, the Communists came up with a new document that was totally different. ``In that draft the Communist Party redefined the role of the round table (talks) as dealing with the economic crisis only, not with the political system,'' Spassov said. ``But the economic crisis cannot be overcome without removing the totalitarian political system.'' He said the Communists are still reluctant to relinquish power. ``If the Communist Party does not sign the political agreement that was prepared by the (committees) there will be no round table (talks),'' Spassov said. He accused the Communists of planning to railroad through Parliament key legislation that neither the opposition nor other groups have had a chance to discuss or amend. He singled out the law on political parties, a law on property and a law on names. The law on names is a sensitive issue because it affects primarily the 1.2 million Turks who had to change their Moslem names in a violent campaign spearheaded by deposed Communist leader Todor Zhivkov. Zhivkov was ousted in November as political reform swept the rest of the East bloc. Spassov predicted that Bulgaria's deep economic crisis will eventually ``crush'' the Communists, whose popularity he said is dwindling daily.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Pan Am Security Was Relaxed Before Flight 103 Bombing
DOC.TEXT: Nine months before the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, the airline abandoned a key safety procedure at Frankfurt Airport requiring all checked baggage to be accompanied by passengers, a London newspaper reported Thursday. The Independent said investigators now believe the relaxation in security gave terrorists the opportunity to smuggle the bomb onto the plane in an unaccompanied suitcase without fear of detection. The newspaper said its information was based on an internal Pan Am memorandum. It said the memo was sent on March 28, 1988, to Pan Am's security staff in London and Frankfurt, West Germany. In New York, a Pan Am spokesman confirmed the existence of the memo and that the procedure concerning unaccompanied luggage had indeed been changed. But he insisted Pan Am did so with the approval of the FAA. Asked if Pan Am allowed unaccompanied bags on flights, the spokesman, Jeff Kriendler, said: ``Only if the bag had been X-rayed, as per the approved FAA procedure.'' ``We did not abandon or eliminate (a procedure), we changed a procedure with the verbal approval of the FAA,'' he said. Kriendler said approval had been given verbally by Ray Salazar, FAA's director of civil aviation security, at a March 1988 meeting with security heads of Pan Am and other airlines. In Washington, FAA spokesman Bob Buckhorn said he did not know whether Salazar gave such approval, ``but X-raying baggage is certainly a security procedure that's acceptable.'' He said Salazar was out of town. All 259 people on board Flight 103 died when it exploded over Lockerbie, Scotland, on Dec. 21, 1988. Fiery, falling wreckage killed 11 on the ground. Flight 103 originated at Frankfurt Airport. During a stopover at London's Heathrow Airport, baggage and passengers were transferred to a larger aircraft to make the trans-Atlantic crossing to New York and Detroit. Investigators have reconstructed large portions of the Boeing 747, including the forward cargo hold area where the bomb exploded and the container in which the bomb was loaded. The Independent said the first layer of suitcases in the container belonged to passengers who boarded in London. Bags above that layer, where the bomb was located, were from connecting flights, including Frankfurt, it said. Scottish police have said the bomb, made of powerful plastic explosives, was hidden in a radiocassette player. They believe it either started or passed through the Frankfurt Airport. West German police have maintained there is not enough evidence to confirm where the bomb originated. The newspaper said FAA regulations prohibit airlines from loading unaccompanied baggage onto aircraft, even if it has been X-rayed. ``To avoid the time-consuming process of matching up transit passengers with their baggage and removing the bags of no-show passengers, Pan Am decided that unaccompanied baggage from feeder flights could be loaded into aircraft provided it cleared X-ray checks,'' The Independent said. It quoted Daniel Sonesen, then Pan Am's assistant director of security, as writing in the memo: ``We fixed the problem by purchasing X-rays. ... In the event of a no-show interline pax (passenger) ... his bag is load(ed) into the belly (and) we go!!!'' It quoted the memo as saying Salazar approved the new procedure. The newspaper did not say specifically that the person who checked in the baggage with the bomb failed to board the flight, only that ``no check was made that the passenger to whom the bomb bag belonged had in fact boarded the flight.'' Scottish investigators said in December that Ahmed Jibril's radical Palestinian group, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestinian-General Command, was one focus of their investigation, but not the only one. They said they were also interested in Mohammed Abu Talb, a member of another radical Palestinian Group imprisoned in Sweden on unrelated bombing charges, and other unidentified groups and individuals.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Votes To Keep Current Caribbean Trade Agreements
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Finance Committee balked Thursday at offending U.S. sugar and shoe producers in continuing but not expanding special trade benefits to Caribbean and Central American allies. Without dissent, the panel approved making permanent former President Reagan's 1983 Caribbean Basin Initiative (CBI) that otherwise would expire in 1995. However, it rejected amendments by Sens. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., and Bill Bradley, D-N.J., that would have reduced by 50 percent the current tariffs on rubber-sole, canvas-top tennis shoes and establish a floor on sugar quotas. The committee's chairman, Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, urged rejection of the amendments. ``In some ways I'd like to go beyond what we've done,'' he said, ``but the key is avoiding crippling controversies.'' The initiative was intended to lift the region's depressed economy through a combination of direct aid and an elimination of tariffs, quotas and other trade barriers to encourage the development of its exports. Excluded from the duty-free importation, however, were textiles, clothing, luggage, shoes, dinnerware, leather products and other ``sensitive'' goods that compete directly with U.S.-made products. Special rules also exist for sugar and beef products. Critics contend the initiative has failed to a large degree because U.S. budget deficits have forced a reduction in direct aid at the same time falling quotas on sugar imports to protect U.S. producers have constrained the market for the region's single biggest export product. Quotas on allowable sugar imports from the region as well as other producers such as Australia and the Philippines have fallen from a total 3.2 million tons the year the initiative was passed to 1.2 million tons last year. ``All the benefits (of the initiative) have been lost to the decline in sugar imports from the quotas,'' said Bradley, whose amendment would have raised the quota on U.S. sugar imports from world exporters to 1.6 million tons. It was defeated on a 9-5 vote. Packwood's amendment was defeated on a 10-6 vote after Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., complained it could cost the jobs of 300 workers at a plant in his state which assembles tennis shoes. Similar legislation was approved by the House last fall.

DOC.HEAD: Police Use Batons to Disperse Striking Teachers
DOC.TEXT: Police used batons Thursday to break up a protest by about 2,000 striking teachers who marched through this capital city demanding a pay hike, the national news agency reported. The country, which has been hit by a series of strikes in recent months, is suffering its worst labor unrest since independence from Portugal in 1975. The teachers, who have been on strike since Feb. 19, marched past the Ministry of Education on Thursday and chanted ``the teachers want more money!'' the AIM news agency said. No injuries or arrests were reported after baton-carrying police waded into the crowd, AIM said. Before the march, the teachers voted to extend their walkout, despite threats of disciplinary action if they don't return to work Monday, the news agency reported. The teachers want a wage increase of 10 percent to 45 percent, AIM said. The news agency did not say how much they now make. However, this southeastern African country is one of the poorest in the world, with many workers earning no more than $40 a month. Mozambique's economy has been devastated by a 13-year-old guerrilla insurgency against the leftist government.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Allow Terminally Ill To Tap Life Insurance Benefits
DOC.TEXT: People with less than a year to live could have tax-free access to their life insurance benefits under legislation introduced Thursday by Sens. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., and Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn. Dying patients whose doctors have certified they will live less than 12 months could decide for themselves how best to use the money to cover high medical, nursing home or other expenses. ``This bill is of enormous importance to the families of the terminally ill and the terminally ill,'' said Bradley. ``I think it's our obligation to show compassion for them.'' Bradley said life insurance benefits paid after death are non-taxable. The proposed legislation would make them non-taxable before death. He said the bill would protect the Medicaid eligibility of insured patients who choose not to cash in their life insurance policy. ``We hope to get this passed this year,'' Bradley said. ``There's very little revenue cost. I find it difficult to imagine there's going to be much opposition to this.'' Patients with cancer, AIDS or other debilitating diseases who are forced to leave their jobs could use the proceeds of their insurance to avoid financial devastation, Lieberman said. Given the failure of catastrophic care legislation in Congress last year, the lawmakers said the measure offers help to some Americans facing astronomical health costs. According to Lieberman, more than 100 million Americans have life insurance coverage. However, he and Bradley had no estimate of how many Americans might take advantage of their benefits while still living. Several American insurance firms have begun offering customers the option of freeing up their life insurance benefits in their last months. The nation's top life insurer, Prudential Insurance Co. of America, in January began offering policyholders with $25,000 coverage or more the option to use their death benefits at no extra cost. Newark, N.J.-based Prudential requires allows them access to the coverage if a doctor certifies they have only six months or less to live. According to Joe Vecchione, a Prudential spokesman, 26 states have approved Prudential's living benefits coverage since it went into effect Jan. 26. Connecticut Mutual also has a living benefits policy, Lieberman said. Rep. Barbara Kennelly, D-Conn., has introduced similar legislation in the House.

DOC.HEAD: Serbian Leader in Kosovo Calls for Uprising Against Ethnic Albanians
DOC.TEXT: An influential leader of the minority Serbs in troubled Kosovo province has called for an armed uprising against the majority ethnic Albanians, newspaper reports said Thursday. The daily Borba said Bogdan Kecman, leader of an organization of Kosovo Serbs called Bozur, told a rally Wednesday that Serbs should ``arm themselves and get ready for the decisive battle'' against ethnic Albanians. About 3,000 Serbs who attended the rally in the provincial capital of Pristina ``greeted Kecman's speech with wild applause,'' Borba said. Kosovo has been the scene of a decade of open strife between ethnic Albanians, who represent 90 percent of the region's 1.9 million population, and Serbs, who claim they are being driven out of their homeland. Kecman reportedly said that Yugoslavia's president, Janez Drnovsek, should resign for what he called a failure to protect Serb interests in Kosovo. Kosovo Serbs ``will no longer tolerate enemies of any sort,'' Kecman was quoted as saying. He is highly popular among Serbs in the province. Tensions remain high in Kosovo, where at east 60 ethnic Albanians have died in violent clashes with security forces since March of last year. The violence flared when Serbia, the largest Yugoslav republic, changed its constitution a year ago, giving it nearly total control of Kosovo. The province already had been administratively part of Serbia. Serbian authorities claimed the changes were necessary to protect Kosovo Serbs from alleged harassment by ethnic Albanians. Also Thursday, the first political negotiations between the ethnic Albanian opposition and Serbian independent groups ended in the central Yugoslav town of Mostar with an appeal to federal authorities to start withdrawing troops from the province. The appeal also urged Kosovo citizens to refrain from demonstrations and strikes. A spokesman for the organizers in Mostar said Serbian authorities failed to show up at the meeting despite earlier pledges that they would come. Serbia's leadership and Kosovo Serbs previously have rejected any talks with ethnic Albanian opposition movements, claiming their leaders are separatists who want the province to secede from Yugoslavia and join neighboring Albania.

DOC.HEAD: Macheteros Leader Lauds U.S. Columnist for Opposing Statehood
DOC.TEXT: A nationalist leader said Thursday that conservative columnist Patrick Buchanan was right in opposing statehood for Puerto Rico even though it's for ``racist'' reasons. Filiberto Ojeda Rios, self-proclaimed leader of the clandestine Macheteros nationalist movement, said Buchanan was correct in believing that ``if we become a state, a new Northern Ireland will spring up here.'' ``This man is right when he says that if statehood sees the day, there will be a revolution in Puerto Rico,'' Ojeda Rios said on a radio talk show. The Irish Republican Army is struggling to expel British troops from Northern Ireland, a British colony. In a column published in the Washington Times and other newspapers this week, Buchanan wrote that he opposed statehood for the Spanish-speaking U.S. commonwealth, saying it would ``convert us into a bilingual nation.'' He said it would be impossible to impose English on Puerto Ricans. Buchanan's article appeared in Spanish on Wednesday in the San Juan daily El Mundo. A vote has been set for June 1991 giving Puerto Ricans a choice among independence, statehood, or more autonomy. The United States took control of Puerto Rico at the end of the Spanish American War in 1898. The Caribbean island's commonwealth status allows the island largely to govern itself. Ojeda Rios said that while Buchanan ``objectively'' described what would happen if the island became the 51st state, he also said Buchanan ``is a racist who can't see Puerto Rico as part of the United States because of his racist and discriminatory mentality.'' Ojeda Rios is one of 19 people charged in connection with the 1983 robbery of $7 million from a Wells Fargo depot in Hartford, Conn. He is free on bail awaiting trial in Connecticut. The Macheteros claimed responsibility for several bombings and other attacks on U.S. government installations on the island during the 1970s and early 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Military-Style Program Wouldn't Help Federal Prisons, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Military-style boot camps used in 14 states as an alternative punishment for lawbreakers are not suitable for the federal prison system, its top official said Thursday. Only about 60 of the more than 54,000 federal prisoners fit the criteria most states use for placing offenders in boot camp, said J. Michael Quinlan, director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons. However, Quinlan told a Senate subcommittee the federal system was developing a prototype Intensive Confinement Program that would expose selected inmates to a highly structured environment as in boot camp. He also voiced qualified support for the camps on the state level but only as alternatives to probation, parole and other forms of punishment that don't involve incarceration. They should not replace imprisonment for criminals who should be behind bars and should not be considered a tool for reducing prison crowding, he said. ``Most offenders sentenced to prison should be there to enhance public safety,'' Quinlan said. A Justice Department study found that 95 percent of state prisoners were violent criminals or repeat offenders, while the rest were either burglars or drug traffickers, he said. The Governmental Affairs Subcommittee on Oversight of Government Management conducted the hearing to explore the feasibility of boot camp in the federal prison system and of lending federal assistance to state camps. Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich., the panel's chairman, said the camps could prove especially useful in preventing youthful offenders from becoming hardened criminals. ``Prisons are too often nothing but graduate schools of crime, releasing young offenders who are even more violent and anti-social than when they entered prison,'' he said. ``Boot camps are a chance to break that cycle.''

DOC.HEAD: Diplomat Debunks Notion That Cuba Will Fall
DOC.TEXT: Cuba's top diplomat in the United States dismissed on Thursday suggestions his homeland will undergo an anti-communist upheaval similar to the one in Eastern Europe. Jose Arbesu, head of the Cuban Interests Section, said in a rare public appearance that unlike Eastern Europe, Cuba's revolution was home grown and was not ``imposed from abroad.'' Cuba also differs from Eastern Europe because it faced social, economic and political problems that were created as a result of ``57 years of governments allied to North American (U.S.) monopolies,'' he said. ``The conditions of poverty, illiteracy and desperation which were products of the colonial relations meant that the only way to overturn those conditions was to become the owners of our own resources,'' Arbesu added. He spoke to a gathering on Capitol Hill sponsored by the Center for Development Policy, a liberal research group. Arbesu, a veteran of numerous postings abroad, has headed the Cuban mission in this country since last spring. The United States and Cuba have not had full diplomatic relations since 1961 and deal with each other instead through the so-called interests sections. Arbesu said the revolution has raised life expectancy, lowered infant mortality and has a solid record in the war against illiteracy and in cultural development, benefits which are universal and free of charge. ``All of this was made possible because our economy has developed despite a 28-year blockade, and because of the political will of the Cuban people,'' he said. ``What other countries in the Third World can exhibit such achievements?'' Although Cuba is aware that ``very serious'' difficulties could lie ahead, he said, there has been no change in Cuba's economic and commercial relations with the Soviet Union. According to U.S. estimates, Cuba receives more than $6 billion in various forms of assistance from the Soviet Union. U.S. officials also have said that the Soviets no longer provide Cuba with surplus oil for resale to other importing countries for cash, a profitable business for Cuba in the mid-1980's. Arbesu made no reference to Cuba's criticism of Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's reform program, highlighting instead continued Soviet-Cuban cooperation. As an example, he said the two countries agreed recently to add $250 million worth of new staples into commercial exchange. ``We have had and now maintain fraternal relations with the Soviet Union based on friendship and cooperation,'' he said. ``Our exchanges have been just, but they have not developed on the basis of begging or charity, nor without giving anything in return, nor conditioned on the political or ideological behavior of the Cuban revolution, as it has been portrayed here.'' Under questioning, Arbesu rejected the suggestion that the defeat of Nicaragua's leftist government _ a close ally of Cuba's for years _ will have a major impact on the island. He said the Cuban revolution survived for almost 20 years before the Sandinistas came to power in Nicaragua.

DOC.HEAD: Benin Leader Calls for Strikers to Return to Work
DOC.TEXT: The prime minister of Benin appealed to striking workers Thursday to go back to their jobs as he took up a 10-month mandate to bring democracy and economic stability to his West African nation. Benin state radio, monitored in Abidjan, reported that Prime Minister Nicephore Soglo promised to pay government workers who received none of their salaries in January and February. The workers began strikes and protests that helped force President Mathieu Kerekou to relinquish power Wednesday. Kerekou, a brigadier general who seized power in a 1972 coup, remains head of state and chief of the armed forces. But at a national conference of leaders, he was stripped of his post as defense minister, and Soglo was named to head a new transitional government and organize democratic elections in January 1991. None of Kerekou's aides are allowed to sit on the new Cabinet. Kerekou said he agreed to step aside ``in the national interest and for the greater interest of the people of Benin.'' There was no indication Thursday how workers were reacting to Soglo's appeal for them to return to work on Monday, a day before he is expected to name his advisers and inaugurate the new government. Cotonou Radio said the interim leader had tried to impress on strike leaders the need for austerity measures imposed in agreement with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank in return for loans. Benin's economy has been bankrupted by Marxist-Leninist economics. Benin, a former French colony, is one of the world's poorest nations with a per capita income of $310 and a foreign debt of nearly $1 billion. Western economists say Kerekou's efforts to impose centralized controls hampered economic growth. Austerity measures introduced since Kerekou was forcd to negotiate with the International Monetary Fund in 1986 have failed to revive the shattered economy.

DOC.HEAD: Minority Leaders Hail Jury Verdict In `Skinheads' Trial
DOC.TEXT: Five members of a ``skinhead'' group were found guilty Thursday of racially motivated hate crimes against Jews, blacks and Hispanics, acts the U.S. attorney general called ``simply intolerable in a free society.'' An all-white federal court jury deliberated for about four hours before convicting all five men of two counts of conspiring to violate the civil rights of minorities. The five vandalized a Jewish synagogue and harassed blacks and Hispanics at a Dallas park. Former skinhead members testified that the group, known as the Confederate Hammerskins, had planned to pump poison gas into the temple. Prosecutors characterized the trial as the government's first major assault against white supremacist groups. The term ``skinheads'' refers to the short-cropped hair worn by members to show unity. Each of the charges carries up to 10 years in prison and a $250,000 fine. U.S. District Judge Barefoot Sanders said the earliest possible sentencing date would be April 19. All five remained in custody. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh vowed further prosecutions of hate crimes, saying ``acts of racial and religious hate, such as those disclosed by the evidence in Dallas, are simply intolerable in a free society.'' ``Let the word go out that the federal government intends to bring to bear the full force of the law on every such act that comes to its attention,'' Thornburgh said in a statement. The trial drew attention from such groups as the New York-based Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, which called the verdict ``a major victory in the continuing battle against hate-inspired violence by skinheads around the country.'' ``The average American is fed up with racist ignorance,'' said Richard Dockery, director of the southwest office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. ``We have people tired of being afraid to live in their own homes,'' Dockery said. ``They have to lock themselves up in their homes live like animals. They can't walk the streets, they can't use their parks.'' The defendants were Jon Lance Jordan, 19, of Garland; Sean Christian Tarrant, 20, and Daniel Alvis Wood, 20, of Dallas; Michael Lewis Lawrence, 22, of Tulsa, Okla.; and Christopher Barry Greer, 25, of Irving. A third count of the indictment charged Wood, Lawrence and Jordan with firearms violations. Lawrence was cleared of the firearms charge; Wood and Jordan were convicted. Wood already has been sentenced to 10 years in prison and fined $5,000 by a state judge for spraying swastikas and anti-Semitic slogans on the synagogue, Temple Shalom in north Dallas. Rabbi Kenneth Roseman, whose Temple Shalom was vandalized, praised the jury's verdict, but added, ``Just because five people have been convicted, doesn't mean there aren't more radicals and bigots around.'' On Wednesday, Justice Department prosecutor Barry Kowalski urged jurors ``to tell these five men they can't conspire and stalk Dallas like racist spirits in the night.'' Defense attorneys countered that the men were being tried for their beliefs and suggested witnesses who testified against them were doing so only to escape prosecution. They said their clients had a right to exercise free speech even if their beliefs are unpopular. Another group, the Non-Racist Skinheads of Dallas-Fort Worth, showed up Thursday to congratulate Kolwalski, the prosecutor. The group claims to be opposed to the Nazi skinheads.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: To update with reaction, INSERTS 8th graf: ``The agreement,'' INSERTS 17th graf: ``We did,'' and ADDs 7 grafs.
DOC.HEAD: Senate Leaders, Bush, Compromise on Pollution Controls
DOC.TEXT: Senate leaders and President Bush compromised Thursday on future air pollution controls for automobiles, factories and electric power plants, enhancing chances that a clean air bill will pass this year. The agreement, after more than three weeks of closed-door negotiations, was viewed as a middle ground likely to attract enough support to thwart continuing regional opposition in the looming Senate debate. Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, called the compromise a ``sound and comprehensive'' agreement that will substantially improve air quality over the next decade. He planned to bring the legislation to the Senate floor on Monday. ``President Bush is extraordinarily pleased with the agreement. It is a milestone, an enormous step forward,'' said Roger Porter, the president's chief domestic policy adviser. Porter said the administration would attempt to expedite Senate passage and seek a similar agreement in the House, where clean-air legislation remains in committee. But the compromise is still likely to encounter stiff industry lobbying, largely because of its estimated $20 billion to $40 billion annual cost to the economy. Both industrial and environmental groups issued statements Thursday denouncing the compromise. Some senators also have expressed concern that the bargaining weakened provisions in the original Senate bill that would have required stronger automobile emission controls to combat urban smog. Other have voiced continued concern about the impact of acid rain controls. ``The agreement fails to require the controls we need to provide clean air in the nation and in New Jersey,'' said Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., who participated in some of the private discussions, but said he would not support the compromise on the Senate floor. Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., the minority leader, called the compromise ``a giant step forward'' in revising federal air pollution laws for the first time in 13 years. But he cautioned that many senators likely will seek changes when the measure goes to the Senate floor. He urged Mitchell ``not to handcuff anyone'' during the floor action by rushing to cut off debate. The agreement made some accommodations to regional interests, especially those concerned about the local economic cost of acid rain controls. On that score, the compromise continues to require a 10 million ton annual reduction of sulfur dioxide emissions, but allows Midwest utilities to achieve extra credits and allowances that could be sold to other utilities to recoup some of the costs.
