Plants that use new technology _ instead of switching away from high-sulfur coal to another fuel _ could delay compliance for two years would receive additional credits for early cuts in emissions, provisions designed to help West Virginia's coal industry. About a dozen senators from the Midwest had threatened to filibuster the legislation if some accommodation were not met to ease their concerns about the high costs of the pollution controls. Mitchell said he still could not discount the threat of a filibuster, but various Senate sources suggested that with the compromise, Mitchell likely would have enough votes to halt debate. Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., said he would seek additional changes to the bill. But ``I'm not going to engage in any filibuster,'' he said. ``We did not have a choice between the good, the bad and the ugly. We had a choice between ugly, uglier and ugliest,'' said Sen. Christopher Bond, R-Mo., who during the private talks sought to work out provisions to ease the plight of Midwest utilities that rely heavily on high-sulfur coal. The breakthrough on the legislation came Wednesday when leaders agreed on pollution curbs on automobiles. The compromise eliminates an automatic second round of auto tailpipe controls, although such measures could be put into effect if more than 11 of 27 cities with ``serious'' ozone pollution problems fail to meet federal air quality standards at the end of this decade. The White House had strongly opposed the second round of controls, as had the auto industry. But environmentalists, state pollution control officials in areas with the dirtiest air, and some senators argued the second round of controls are needed to deal with smog in such areas as southern California and the Northeast. In the final days of negotiations, an agreement also came on the acid rain provision, after senators from the West were assured that the utility emission controls would allow for future growth in electric capacity and some accommodation was made to the Midwest region. Earlier tentative agreements were struck on how to curb toxic and smog-causing emissions from industrial plants. Under the compromise, industrial plants will have to use the best available technology to curb releases of 192 toxic chemicals including carcinogens, or cancer-causing agents. Early in the next decade a ``health standard'' would require plants to reduce emissions further, if the cancer risk to nearby residents is still too high. A broad range of industries and businesses also would have to comply with tougher controls on smog-causing emissions. The compromise, however, would exempt thousands of smaller polluters, which would have been covered by the original Senate bill. Environmental groups, meanwhile, chastised the negotiations and said the compromise agreement severely weakened the original Senate bill. ``The back-room dealing has generated bad deals for the American people,'' complained Richard Ayres, chairman of the National Clean Air Coalition. But industry did not like the agreement either. The Edison Electric Institute called the agreement ``unnecessarily costly'' for the nation's utilities. The Chemical Manufacturers Association called the tougher controls on toxic chemicals too stringent and politically motivated and ignoring scientific facts about health risks. The agreement is ``far from what business and industry would consider acceptable,'' said William Fay, administrator of the Clean Air Working Group, industry's umbrella lobbying organization on clean air issues. ``There's no question the bill has been improved but there are still some real problems,'' said Helen Petrauskas, vice president for environmental engineering at Ford Motor Co. Though the bill avoids any requirement that automakers sell a specific number of cars that burn clean fuels, which favors industry, the exhaust standards are still tougher than the industry would like, she said.

DOC.HEAD: NRC Grants Embattled Plant Full-Power License
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 24th graf: ``Public Service,'' to note utility in reorganization
DOC.TEXT: The Seabrook, N.H., nuclear power plant won federal permission Thursday to produce commercial electricity after two decades of protests and legal struggles that made it a symbol of the national anti-nuclear movement. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted 3-0 to grant a license for Seabrook to operate at full power but delayed issuing it for two weeks _ to allow an expected appeal in federal court. Two of the commission's five members abstained from the vote because of involvement in Seabrook issues prior to becoming commissioners. Opponents have long maintained that people near the plant would be trapped in a nuclear emergency, and officials in Massachusetts, with a border just two miles from Seabrook, said they would indeed take the case to the U.S. Court of Appeals in Washington. Foes also claimed a broader victory, contending that as a result of the long fight against Seabrook, no utility would be willing to risk the monetary and other costs of trying build and open another nuclear plant. The commission's ruling ratified recommendations by its staff and several lower-level boards that the plant is safe and that evacuation plans would work. ``I would be happy to live within two miles of this plant and I wouldn't worry about it at all,'' said NRC Chairman Kenneth Carr. However, Massachusetts Attorney General James Shannon said, ``We will be in court in the next few days. ... There has never been a licensing issue which has been so legally vulnerable.'' Massachusetts officials along with New Hampshire anti-nuclear groups have coordinated the Seabrook opposition. At the white-domed plant overlooking the Atlantic ocean, 75 protesters sang and chanted slogans, and 10 blocked the plant gate by sitting down in the driveway. When they refused to leave, they were arrested. Another Seabrook opponent was arrested when he posted a sign that read ``Shame'' over one posted by plant workers reading ``License Approved!'' At the NRC meeting, utility executives hugged each other after the ruling while Seabrook opponents said that their fight against Seabrook had helped stall the nuclear power industry. ``I feel great, I'm delighted,'' said Ted Feigenbaum, chief operating officer of New Hampshire Yankee, the company that operates Seabrook. ``We will be starting the plant up as soon as the license is received, no later than March 15.'' He said it would take two to three months for the 1,150 megawatt plant to reach full power. Feigenbaum said opposition to Seabrook contributed to its current $6.5 billion price tag, which will be felt by ratepayers in the Northeast. ``We're going to have to deal with this long licensing process,'' Feigenbaum said. ``It took too long and all this litigation hasn't added one iota to the safety of the plant.'' In a New Hampshire news conference, New Hampshire Yankee President Edward Brown said the NRC decision ``marks the end of a long, convoluted, challenging licensing battle. For us, the decision represents a triumph of reason, professionalism, perseverance and common sense.'' While opponents had expected Thursday's vote, they said the losing battle over Seabrook should help win a larger war against nuclear power. ``The price paid to finally secure Seabrook's license has been so great that no utility will ever again be willing to risk the high economic costs, the bad public relations and the protracted political fight necessary to bring a nuclear power plant on line,'' said Ken Bossong of Public Citizen, one of several groups opposed to Seabrook. In the mid-1970s during construction of the plant, thousands of anti-nuclear protesters flocked to Seabrook and hundreds were arrested in acts of civil disobedience. The protests picked up again last summer as the plant drew closer to a full-power license. The Seabrook construction period was marked by a sharp decline in public and investor support for nuclear power. According to Public Citizen _ a private group active on many issues and opposed to nuclear power _ 111 U.S. reactor orders were canceled and 11 operating plants were retired during Seabrook's construction. NRC Chairman Carr noted that there are no new applications for nuclear plants before the commission and an NRC spokesman said the last request was filed in 1978. The licensing decision comes at a time when New England faces acute energy problems marked recently by the skyrocketing price of home heating oil and, in the past several summers, a shortage of electricity during heat waves. Seabrook can produce enough electricity to power a million New England homes. Seabrook has been plagued by financial troubles, a situation that opponents say could affect plant safety. First conceived in 1968, Seabrook was to have been a twin-reactor power plant costing $1 billion. By 1986, with one reactor ready to operate, the partially completed second reactor was mothballed. Since then the cost has continued to climb. Northeast Utilities of Berlin, Conn., is awaiting final state and federal approval of a $2.3 billion buyout of Public Service Company of New Hampshire, which owns 36 percent of Seabrook, the largest single share. Public Service, which could not collect any of the cost of Seabrook from customers until it started generating electricity, sought court protection from creditors under under federal bankruptcy laws in 1988, the first private utility to do so since the Great Depression. Opponents also have argued that there are, as yet, no long-term plans on what to do with the nuclear waste Seabrook would produce. But Carr dismissed that concern. ``The disposal of radioactive waste is not a technical problem,'' Carr said. ``It is a political problem.''

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Patrol Indian Town as National Election Violence Kills 98
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers patrolled the north Indian town of Meham Thursday, the flashpoint of election violence that left 13 people dead in Meham and a total of at least 98 dead nationwide, police and news reports said. Incomplete results showed former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party losing heavily in elections Tuesday to eight state legislatures and the governing National Front coalition and its electoral ally, the Hindu right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party, making major gains. Besides Wednesday's deaths in Haryana state's Meham constituency, at least 80 people were killed Tuesday in eastern Bihar state during voting for state assemblies and by-elections and others died in Gujarat and Maharashtra states. Rival supporters fought pitched battles in Meham on Wednesday when another vote was ordered in some balloting centers following allegations of electoral fraud. A police spokesman in Chandigarh, the state capital, said three people died in the fighting and 10 were killed when police fired to control rioting mobs. Voting was suspended and the army was called out to keep the peace, said the spokesman, who cannot be identified under briefing rules. Newspapers blamed Om Prakash Chauthala, Haryana state's chief minister, for most of the vote fraud in Meham. He was running for the Haryana state assembly from the Meham district. ``Armed gangs were seen moving from booth to booth in the chief minister's constituency and getting the ballot papers stamped in his favor,'' The Hindu newspaper said. Voting results indicated the Congress Party was being voted out of power in at least five of the eight states where elections were held this week. United News of India said the National Front and Bharatiya Janata Party won most of the seats in Orissa, Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat, Himachal Pradesh and Rajasthan states and were set to form governments, either in tandem or singly. Complete results from Bihar, Arunachal Pradesh and Maharashtra states were not expected until Friday. United News said the National Front and Bharatiya Janata won 702 of 996 results announced so far, and Congress 197. Left-wing groups and independents took the other seats. In all, 1,610 seats were at stake and Congress put up candidates in all but 30 races. The National Front and Bharatiya Janata each fielded about 1,000 candidates, agreeing to ``friendly contests'' in some constituencies.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Approves Program to Encourage Volunteers
DOC.TEXT: The Senate approved a $125 million program of grants Thursday to encourage volunteer work ranging from fighting illiteracy to cleanup drives in the nation's forests, woods and parks. ``The basic idea is to challenge young people and old people alike to give something back to america for all that its given to them,'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., said as the Senate approved the measure, 78-19. The measure would authorize $125 million for volunteer programs through the end of the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1. It would earmark $25 million for school-based programs, involving teachers aides, tutoring and the teaching of reading. It also would provide $35 million for a youth service corps, involving park and forest cleanup programs for volunteers 16 to 25 years old. A program for individuals 17 and older would focus on service in education, environment, public safety and other fields, and would be authorized to receive $25 million. Also authorized would be a $25 million Points of Light Foundation sought by Republicans in keeping with President Bush's campaign remark that the needy in America would be helped through volunteer efforts from ``a thousand points of light.'' The foundation would encourage volunteerism. States would bid for grants under the plan. The money would be distributed by a $4 million Commission on National and Community Service to be established under the bill. All the money would have to be appropriated in annual bills, and the appropriations could be less that the amounts authorized, which act as ceilings on appropriations. The bill was a slimmed-down version of the legislation that initially went into the hopper. It took Kennedy, the bill's floor manager, four days to shoehorn it through a balky Senate as lawmakers kept attempting to pile on amendments, some unrelated to volunteerism. The longest fight came over a proposed amendment sponsored by Sen. William Armstrong, R-Colo., to allow Big Brothers and other volunteer groups in the District of Columbia to bar homosexuals from activities involving minors. After hours of wrangling, the Senate adopted a Kennedy substitute which would allow volunteer groups to bar homosexuals if they had been convicted of a crime or were currently charged with one. ``It's just plain wrong for any arm of government to force private volunteer groups to unite adult homosexuals with minors as companions and role models,'' Armstrong said later. Lawmakers sought to attach provisions concerning the Nicaraguan elections and the repression of dissent in China. Liberals praised the bill as one that would usher in a new spirit among Americans. ``What we do in this bill is begin to get away from the values of Wall Street and go back to the values of Main Street, of neighbor helping neighbor,'' said Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., Some volunteers would receiving living allowances and other stipends as well as education and housing benefits. As the final vote neared, Sen. Rudy Boschwitz, R-Minn., took the floor to condemn the notion of paying volunteers. ``A young person has got to feel like a chump if he's not paid under this bill.'' He said benefits paid to some volunteers under the program, including living allowances and health insurance, were ``not in keeping with the spirit of volunteerism.'' He also warned against expansion of the program, citing a danger that the Senate would ``beget some broad programs, perhaps some very broad programs, that are going to cost millions, perhaps billions, each year.''

DOC.HEAD: Expert Agrees Hazelwood Should Not Have Tried to Move Tanker
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Hazelwood's efforts to move the grounded Exxon Valdez off a reef was reckless because the skipper was not ``dead certain'' of his ship's location, a marine salvage expert testifed Thursday. But William Milwee Jr., of Portland, Ore., acknowledged under heated cross examination that no matter what Hazelwood had done after the ship grounded, the Exxon Valdez could not have moved anywhere. ``There is absolutely no question this ship would not have moved using its engines alone,'' said Milwee. ``No matter what Capt. Hazelwood did?'' asked defense attorney Michael Chalos. ``No matter what Capt. Hazelwood did,'' responded the witness, ``but Capt. Hazelwood did nothing to try and determine that.'' Milwee said Hazelwood should have taken ``soundings'' to determine exactly how solidly his ship lay aground on Bligh Reef. But he conceded on cross examination that such ``soundings,'' in which a lead line is dropped over the side of a vessel, might not have been accurate because of the amount of oil in the water around the ship. The Exxon Valdez, a 987-foot tanker, spilled nearly 11 million gallons of Alaska crude oil within the hour after it ran aground in Prince William Sound. It was the nation's worst oil spill, killing countless birds, fish and other wildlife and blackening hundreds of miles of rocky shoreline. Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y., is on trial charged with criminal mischief, a felony, and three misdemeanors, reckless endangerment, operating a vessel while intoxicated and negligent discharge of oil. He could face 7\ years in prison and fines of $61,000. A key element in the charges against him is recklessness, about which each of the prosecution expert witnesses was asked. Milwee was the second witness in a row to say he considered Hazelwood's actions as meeting the legal criteria for being reckless by consciously disregarding ``a substantial and unjustifiable risk.'' There has been dispute at Hazelwood's trial over whether the skipper, by maneuvering the ship forward, risked capsizing it or causing further damage to its gashed underbelly. Milwee and another prosecution expert witness, Robert Beevers, said Hazelwood did the wrong thing. But Beevers acknowledged before leaving the stand that no additional damage occurred because of Hazelwood's efforts. Milwee, a former Navy salvage expert who now works as a consultant, insisted that Hazelwood should have tried to secure the ship on the reef if he was unsure of the extent of the grounding. ``If you try to re-float her there is a chance of doing additional damage,'' he said. He added that Hazelwood's actions after the grounding were consistent with trying to get the ship off the rocks. ``You shouldn't attempt to move a ship in any way until you have knowledge of the water that lies around it,'' he said, stressing that his advice to a captain in such a situation is: ``Find out what you've got.'' Assistant District Attorney Brent Cole asked the witness how certain a captain should be of a situation before he attempts refloating. ``Dead certain,'' said the witness. But on cross examination by Chalos, Milwee was confronted by a reference book that he himself had used in preparing his opinions. The book contained 14 points of advice for action by captains of grounded ships. As Chalos read off each of these suggestions, the witness acknowledged that Hazelwood had done almost all of the recommended procedures, including alerting the engine room, lowering lifeboats, sending a distress message and calling for tugs to stand by. On each of the points, Chalos asked him: ``Was that a correct action?'' ``Correct action,'' answered the witness.

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Colombian Guerrilla Group Declares Truce
DOC.TEXT: A leftist guerrilla group declared a unilateral truce Thursday to allow peaceful balloting in March national elections, and a radio report said two other important rebel groups would soon follow. The People's Liberation Army, a Maoist group, said in a communique it would refrain from any attacks until April 1. A spokesman read the communique over a crackling telephone line during a live radio broadcast by the Caracol network. Caracol did not say from where the broadcast orginated. Caracol, citing informed sources, said two other groups, the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia and the National Liberation Army, also would declare unilateral cease-fires in the coming days. The total estimated strength of the three groups is 5,000 to 10,000 armed rebels. Estimates by security forces of the total number of armed insurgents in Colombia vary from 10,000 to 20,000. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, is the country's largest guerrilla group with an estimated 5,000 armed members. It recently declared its willingness to negotiate a truce if the government changes the constitution to allow more political participation. The National Liberation Army is led by a defrocked priest and inspired by the teachings of Fidel Castro. Unlike FARC, it has said it will never negotiate with the government and has carried out a number of attacks in recent weeks in an effort to disrupt legislative and municipal elections to be held March 11. Meanwhile, army troops killed six leftist guerillas belonging to FARC in gunbattles late Wednesday near the northeastern towns of Labranzagrande and Arauca, police said. Also Wednesday, National Liberation Army guerrillas attacked the northern towns of Banco and Tamalamequito in an effort to pressure residents not to vote, the Magdalena state police said. The administrator of Banco's airport was killed in the attack. In the cocaine capital of Medellin, dynamite attacks Wednesday against four energy company facilities left 30 percent of the city's residents without electricity, local officials said. A group calling itself the Popular Militiamen telephoned local radio stations to claim responsibility for the attacks, which they said were in response to a recent increase in the city's electricity rates. In another sign of escalating political tension, officials of the Patriotic Union Party said several men wearing military uniforms painted death threats against party members on walls in Segovia, a town 265 miles north of Bogota. A group calling itself Death to Revolutionaries of the Northeast left a message in the mayor's office threatening to kill him and other local party leaders if they did not leave town within three days, Caracol reported. Patriotic Union officials have blamed right-wing death squads for Monday's assassination of the mayor of the northern town of Apartado, also a member of the Marxist-oriented party. The party leaders also blamed the death squads for the killings this week of six other party members, a freelance journalist and three leaders of an agricultural cooperative. The party's president, Diego Montana, said 72 members have been assassinated so far this year. Earlier this week, party leaders demanded the dismissal of Defense Minister Oscar Botero and three army brigade commanders, accusing them of responsibility for waging an ``extermination campaign'' against the leftist party. President Virgilio Barco said the allegations would be investigated, but suggested the accusations might be an attempt by the party to gain sympathy among voters before the elections.

DOC.NOTE: EDs: Recasts first two grafs, CORRECTS downtown to Century City in 6th graf bgng: ``He was,'' now 8th graf: ``As Bush,'' SUBS graf 11 pvs: ``He gave, now 13th graf: ``Reagan gave,'' to show Reagan testified at trial, not Bush
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and his predecessor Ronald Reagan disagreed in a social chat Thursday on when the Contra rebels in Nicaragua should disarm. The disparity cropped up when Bush stopped in to visit Reagan at his Los Angeles office. The former president was asked by reporters during a photo session if the Contras should lay down their arms now that the Nicaraguans have ousted Sandinista President Daniel Ortega in their elections. Reagan replied, ``Don't you think it might be time enough for us to wait and make sure that there is a civilian government in place in Nicaragua, because the Sandinistas had their arms and their weapons long before any Nicaraguan citizens picked up arms and became the Contras?'' Reagan's administration built the Contras from a handful of stragglers into a force of some 12,000 fighters. Both Ortega and the U.S.-backed candidate who beat him, Violeta Chamorro, have also demanded the Contras lay down arms. Bush earlier Thursday said he was confident the Contras would disarm. Asked if he was directly calling on them to do so, he told a news agency reporter, ``Yes. Put it on the wire.'' As Bush sat next to Reagan in the former president's highrise suite in the Century City offfice neighborhood, reporters asked Bush if he concurred with Reagan's comment. Bush said he had already expressed himself on the subject, and then fell back on his sometime rule of declining to answer questions at photo sessions. Reporters asked Reagan to elaborate on whether he believes the Contras should stay together until Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration on April 25, as the Contras have said they want to do. ``Well, I don't know whether to wait that long or not, but things could take place foreshadowing what the situation would be earlier than that,'' Reagan replied. He did not explain further what he meant. Bush, as Reagan's vice president for eight years, endorsed the policy of providing the Contras military assistance. Reagan gave videotape testimony last week in the trial of his natiojnal security adviser, John Poindexter, who is charged with obstructing congressional inquiries into the Iran-Contra diversion of profits to the Contras from arms sales to Iran. Bush broke last year with his predecessor's military-oriented policy on Nicaragua, endorsing a diplomatic solution, and the regional peace process that led to last week's election. Contra officials initially said they would not give up until Mrs. Chamorro takes office, because the Sandinistas still control the nation's large military and police forces. They have since said they will hold talks with Mrs. Chamorro on their conditions for disarming. Bush administration officials have said since the election that there is no longer any reason for fighting, and the Sandinistas announced a unilateral cease-fire. When Bush refused to answer reporters' questions, Reagan said his successor was ``doing exactly what is right for him. Just have a little more freedom now.'' Bush laughed, leaned over and touched Reagan's arm and said, ``We have a slight difference in policy.'' Bush's visit with Reagan was purely a social call, said press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. The two sat on couches in front of windows looking out on a skyscraper view of the city. A plate of assorted cookies was on the glass coffee table in front of them.

DOC.HEAD: Did The CIA Bring Down S&Ls?
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf with committee staff director comment
DOC.TEXT: A former Justice Department prosecutor told congressional investigators the FBI instructed him to drop his investigation of CIA links to failed savings institutions, a House subcommittee chairman said Thursday. Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., chairman of the House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions, said staff aides, following up allegations published by The Houston Post, interviewed the former prosecutor twice. The prosecutor ``told the staff that while pursuing a bank failure investigation, he was told by FBI agents to drop the investigation of one of the individuals connected with the bank failure because that individual had `CIA connections,''' Annunzio said in a letter to Rep. Anthony C. Beilenson, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee. ``The prosecutor was also told that the individual involved had a `get out of jail free' card,'' Annunzio said. One of the FBI agents present confirmed the prosecutors' account, the congressman said. Annunzio refused to identify the prosecutor. Lloyd Monroe, a Brown University researcher who prosecuted bank fraud cases while with a Justice Department organized crime task force, was quoted by the Houston newspaper as saying he believes the CIA masterminded or condoned some S&L fraud. Three weeks ago, Annunzio asked CIA Director William Webster to appear at a closed session of his panel to respond to the allegations. Webster declined. The CIA labeled the allegations ``scurrilous and unsubstantiated'' and said it would be inappropriate for Webster to appear before a Banking subcommittee. Annunzio asked Beilenson, whose committee has jurisdiction over the CIA, to investigate. ``I do not think a well-respected former Justice Department prosecutor and a former FBI agent would make up something so serious as the CIA charges,'' Annunzio said. Daniel Childs, director of the intelligence committee staff, said the staff would conduct a preliminary investigation to determine if a full-fledged probe is warranted. He said it was too eqarly to tell if Webster would be asked to testify.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says No Hostage Talks in Progress
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS three grafs, Reagan comment
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday there are no talks under way for the release of American hostages in Lebanon but said he was willing to undertake private or public discussions if that would win their freedom. ``I will do everything I can, privately, openly _ whatever it takes _ to get them out of there without trading for hostages,'' Bush said. He said a spate of recent news reports suggesting movement in the hostage situation were ``ridiculous stories.'' ``We're not in the negotiating process,'' Bush said. In a brief exchange with reporters, Bush repeatedly denied that there were any secret discussions under way in Geneva or elsewhere about the hostages. Despite Bush's comments, the sister of one hostage, just back in New York from an overseas mission on behalf of her brother, said she was optimistic that the hostages would be released soon. ``I assume they're talking as they always have done through third parties,'' said Peggy Say, referring to the United States government. She is the sister of Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for the Associated Press and the longest-held of the eight Americans and 10 others held hostage in Lebabon. Anderson was kidnapped in Beirut on March 16, 1985. ``I was reassured traveling throughout Europe, the Middle East and Africa, there will be a release without conditions. There will be no ransom. There will be influence by everyone concerned for a positive conclusion and building bridges,'' she said. ``That isn't to say my optimism means there's going to be a release today or next week or next month.'' ``The Syrian commitment is 100 percent,'' she said. Saying he hoped there would be some movement, Bush said, ``I'd love to see them release these hostages.'' The president repeated his exhortation to Iran, which is believed to have influence over the hostage-takers, that goodwill will beget goodwill. ``And goodwill means releasing kidnapped prisoners,'' Bush said. ``And so that's where it stands.'' Bush said, ``I don't spend a day that I don't think about the hostages, but there are no secret talks going on. ``And I have read some of the most ridiculous stories, printed with anonymous sources, failing t do anything other than repeat rumors.'' He said he saw one story saying he had talked with French President Francois Mitterrand about the hostages, and the story was denied but then cropped up again. ``There's something going on that's crazy,'' Bush said, referring to the stories. Bush said he called in Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, after reading stories that talks had been held in Geneva on the hostages. He said he asked Scowcroft, ``Are there any talks, have there been any, direct, indirect, in Geneva? And he said, `No.''' Bush said, ``Now, let me tell you something. If I thought a talk in Geneva would result in letting people go free, I would undertake the talk. ``And if I thought the way to conduct that talk was to do it quietly, I would do it in that manner,''he continued. ``If I thought the best way to get the hostages out were to publicly have talks in Geneva, I would do that. But there aren't any.'' Former President Ronald Reagan also was skeptical of the hostage stories. During a meeting with Bush, Reagan was asked by a reporter if he had any words of caution for the president regarding the hostages. ``Well, the way most leaks turn out, the caution, I think would be, wait until somebody could prove it,'' Reagan said. It was an attempt to win the hostages' freedom that led Reagan to sell arms to Iran in secret.

DOC.HEAD: Costa Rica Asks for Extradition of American Linked to Bombing
DOC.TEXT: The Costa Rican government will ask the United States to extradite John Hull, who has been linked to the 1984 bombing of a Nicaraguan rebels' news conference in which four people were killed, a Foreign Ministry source said Thursday. The source, who did not want to be identified by name, said the Costa Rican Embassy in Washington will present the extradition request on Monday. Hull skipped bond and fled to the United States last July after living 20 years in Costa Rica. He owned a ranch near the Nicaraguan border and has been accused of having ties to the Reagan administration and of supplying weapons to the U.S.-backed Contra rebels. Hull, a native of Princeton, Ind., who acquired Costa Rican citizenship during his years in the Central American country, was released from a hospital Thursday in Evansville, Ind., where he had been treated for heart problems. Attempts to reach him in his home in Patoka, Ind., have not been successful. In January, Costa Rican officials accused Hull of responsibility for a 1984 bombing that resulted in the deaths of three journalists and a Nicaraguan rebel along the Costa Rican-Nicaraguan border. The target of a May 31, 1984, explosion in a house in Penca, Nicaragua, is believed to have been Eden Pastora, a Contra rebel commander at the time who had defected from the Sandinista government. Instead, the victims were Linda Frazier, an American reporter, two Costa Rican journalists attending Pastora's news conference and the rebel. Pastora and about a dozen other people were injured. Hull has called the charges ``politically motivated'' and has denied involvement with the Contras, drug trafficking and the bombing. The bomb was hidden in a camera case by a man posing as a photographer who was traveling with a stolen Dutch passport. Maximo Esquivel, a judge in northern Costa Rica, was quoted in Thursday's editions of The New York Times as saying he signed the extradition order last month. Esquivel's office said the judge would not make any statement about the matter when The Associated Press contacted his office by telephone Thursday in Quesada, about 100 miles north of San Jose. Prosecutor Jorge Chavarria said that Hull and Felipe Vidal, a Cuban, planned the bombing to avenge Pastora's statements linking Hull to the CIA. The whereabouts of Vidal and the man who placed the bomb have not been determined. Hull was jailed last year in Costa Rica, accused of drug trafficking to help the rebels and of violating Costa Rica's neutrality, but was released on $37,000 bond and fled to Indiana. Before his legal problems, Hull was a wealthy rancher in Costa Rica's northern San Carlos province. Judge Esquivel's jurisdiction is in the same province. Hull's attorney in Costa Rica, Juan Sobrado, told The Associated Press by telephone, ``The charges against my client lack foundation.'' The lawyer said, ``It's part of a Sandinista design to liquidate the Contras.'' Sobrado said that if there is any proof against Hull that he should be tried in the United States, ``where it would be easy to show that the accusations are false.'' ``Hull did not flee Costa Rican justice, only a change in jurisdiction,'' the attorney added.

DOC.HEAD: Celebrations, Protests Quickly Follow Seabrook License Approval
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with 125 protesters at plant, 72 arrested, details, quote from Ehrenburg; picks up 10th graf, ```Should the ...' INSERTS 2 grafs after 14th graf, ```We haven't ...,' to UPDATE with comment from state Senate majority leader; picks up 15th graf, `In Washington ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Seabrook, Bjt
LaserPhotos CR3,5
DOC.TEXT: Seabrook nuclear plant workers cheered and raised a sign proclaiming victory and protesters blocked gates outside the complex Thursday after the government allowed it to begin producing power. About 125 protesters demonstrated at the three gates to the plant. By the time the protest ended around 7:30 p.m., about 6{ hours after it began, police had arrested 72 people, including 25 juveniles who were not charged, said town police dispatcher Tarnya Janvrin. The government announcement flashed in the plant's reception center shortly before noon, said Edward Brown, president of Seabrook operator New Hampshire Yankee. Maintenance workers Richard Young and Earl Chafe had a sign ready and hoisted it on a billboard. ``Startup '90: We Have the Power,'' it read. ``It's about time,'' said Young, who has worked at the long-delayed plant for more than a decade. The 3-0 Nuclear Regulatory Commission licensing vote gave opponents a stay of up to two weeks to file legal appeals, which foes have promised. The plant has been the subject of anti-nuclear protests since before its 1976 groundbreaking. Plant spokesman Dave Scanzoni noted that a flurry of appeals in mid-1989 delayed low-power testing only briefly. ``We expect the same situation would happen and we'd be producing electricity very soon,'' he said. When news of the approval reached 50 demonstrators outside the gate, they began singing ``We Shall Overcome.'' Kurt Ehrenberg, a veteran protester, became the first to be arrested after he walked through the main gate and posted on a guard shed a sign that read ``Shame'' over one declaring ``License Approved!'' As protesters chanted slogans, 10 teen-agers sat down in the driveway to the gate. They were arrested, as were some 20 demonstrators who walked through the gate later. Most of the 47 adults arrested were charged with criminal trespass; two were charged with disorderly conduct and others with blocking traffic, Janvrin said, reading from a news release. As police took Ehrenberg away to book him on a disorderly conduct charge, he called out, ``I'm not a criminal; the real criminals are (Gov.) Judd Gregg and the NRC.'' Gregg, a Republican, called the NRC vote ``a major step forward in resolving the issue,'' but said the final word will rest with the federal appeals court. ``Should the court affirm this decision, then the final step will have been made and the plant should be turned on,'' Gregg said in a statement. Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis denounced the NRC action. The former Democratic presidential candidate had fought licensing on grounds that communities near Seabrook, including six in his state, could not be evacuated safely in event of an accident. He promised to keep fighting. ``Besides battling in court we will also encourage congressional investigations ... to hold the NRC accountable for its actions,'' he said. Plant spokesman Ron Sher defended Seabrook's federally mandated emergency plans, which are expected to be the focus of the court battle. ``We haven't just developed plans that are adequate; we've developed plans that work,'' Sher said this week. State Senate Majority Leader Edward Dupont hailed the watershed vote. ``We need the energy from Seabrook,'' said the Republican lawmaker, a long-time Seabrook supporter. ``I'm very positive that today is a good day for New Hampshire.'' In Washington, D.C., Ralph Nader's Public Citizen organization called licensing a Pyrrhic victory for the nuclear industry. ``The price paid to finally secure Seabrook's license has been so great that no utility will ever again be willing to risk the high economic costs, the bad public relations and the protracted political fight necessary to bring a nuclear power plant on line,'' the group said in a statement. But Brown said Seabrook's triumph could inject new life into the nation's dormant nuclear power industry. ``Some have called Seabrook Station a bellwether for the future of the entire nuclear industry in the United States,'' he said. ``I can't predict if that will be true or not, but if the licensing of our plant helps to preserve the option of generating electricity by nuclear power in our country, then I believe we have made a very important contribution to America's energy future.''

DOC.HEAD: War of Words Goes On
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs last graf with three grafs to reflect later passage of resolution
DOC.TEXT: Peace in Nicaragua apparently has not spilled over into the United States Senate, where a bitter debate over past U.S. policy erupted late Thursday and prompted one senator to ask plaintively, ``Why can't we just shut up for a change?'' The extended exchange began when conservative Sen. Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo., offered a non-binding resolution congratulating opposition candidate Violeta Chamorro on her Sunday election victory and insisting that the current leftist government of Daniel Ortega turn over all power, including the military, to her. Wallop's resolution called ``deplorable'' an Ortega assertion that his party would continue to ``govern from below'' and said it was a violation of his commitment to abide by the results of the election. Chamorro ``won it all. She'll be the president of the army, the police and the people,'' said Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. Sen. Christopher Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat from the opposite end of the ideological spectrum, then rose to offer a different version, one that included mention of Costa Rican President Oscar Arias' role in starting regional peace negotiations. But debate soon ranged far from that topic. Senators got bogged down in an argument over which was most responsible for Nicaragua's free elections: former President Reagan's policy of arming the anti-Sandinista Contra rebels, or Arias' 1987 peace initiative. ``To suggest that the Contra aid program would have produced the events on Sunday is ludicrous on its face,'' Dodd argued. Then Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., who had been an official observer in Nicaragua on Sunday, came to the floor shaking his head. ``I can't believe my ears. The best conceivable outcome has taken place in Nicaragua, and we are keeping the battle alive in the Senate.'' His voice growing louder, Danforth added: ``Cool it! Cool the rhetoric! Why can't we just shut up for a change? ... Why do we have to rub it in with Ortega? Why do we have to reach over there and tweak his nose?'' Passions finally cooled when the two sides agreed to withdraw the resolutions and enter what Wallop called ``some negotiations in good faith'' to work out a compromise. On a voice vote later in the evening, the Senate passed a resolution commending the Nicaraguan people ``for their recent successfully held election.'' The resolution called for ``a spirit of reconciliation by all parties and for a peaceful transition of power.''

DOC.HEAD: Philippines' Enrile Says Charges Against Him Are Lies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout, UPDATING with new complaint filed against Enrile, other. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Opposition Sen. Juan Ponce Enrile dismissed as a ``total fabrication'' on Thursday charges that he aided a failed coup against President Corazon Aquino. Officials also filed a new complaint against Enrile, claiming he misappropriated funds during the administration of the late President Ferdinand Marcos. Enrile, 66, was among seven people indicted Tuesday in connection with the failed coup last December. He is the most prominent figure charged in any of the six coup attempts against Mrs. Aquino. When he was defense minister in February 1986, Enrile turned against Marcos and led the military mutiny that drove Marcos into Hawaiian exile, where he died, and swept Mrs. Aquino into office. Enrle was fired as defense chief in November 1986 after his followers tried to overthrow the new government. At a news conference Thursday at a suburban police headquarters where he was in detention, Enrile said the charges of ``rebellion with murder'' were phony and were meant to harass him for opposing Mrs. Aquino. He is the country's lone opposition senator. ``Do you think that now that I am in detention, the Aquino government will be stable? I don't think so,'' Enrile said. ``Mrs. Aquino will find out that her case is based on nothing else but lies.'' Foreign Secretary Raul Manglapus defended the arrest. He said it will not damage the country's image abroad because because it shows the Aquino government is determined to tackle internal problems. Enrile's lawyer, Renato Cayetano, said Thurday he will ask a lower court handling the charges to defer arraignment pending a Supreme Court decision on his client's petition for freedom. Arraignment has been set for Monday. The senator's lawyers, who include two former Supreme Court justices, asked the high court to rule the charges were illegal and unconstitutional. Under the law, rebellion is punishable by up to 12 years, and murder by a maximum sentence of life in prison. Also Thursday, Solicitor General Francisco Chavez filed a complaint alleging that Enrile; businessman Eduardo Cojuangco; Rep. Clara Lobregat and 16 other people misappropriated at least $4.5 million in government funds while acting as administrators of the government's investment fund for the coconut industry. The complaint, filed with the Presidential Commission on Good Government, was the fourth against Enrile and the sixth against Cojuangco and Lobregat in connection with the investments fund. The commission will decide whether to seek an indictment. On Wednesday, Mrs. Aquino denied opposition charges that the arrest of Enrile, her archenemy, was motivated by vindictiveness. As Marcos' martial law administrator from 1972 to 1981, Enrile ordered the imprisonment of thousands, including Mrs. Aquino's husband, Benigno Aquino Jr., who was later assassinated. The opposition has also accused Mrs. Aquino of trying to stifle dissent with the arrest. Military dissidents say it is a prelude to martial law. Troops have been on maximum alert in the Manila area since Tuesday to prevent any reprisals from Enrile supporters. On Thursday, court proceedings were halted and employees evacuated Quezon City Hall after a bomb threat, but police found no explosives. Police defused a homemade bomb Wednesday at a shopping mall in the Manila financial district.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Sandinista Military in Nicaragua Suffers Desertions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS four grafs after 15th `They gave' with military confirmation of desertions, quotes, editing to conform; picks up 17th pvs, `Medina said...' DELETES penultimate graf as outdated.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA4
DOC.TEXT: Young soldiers have begun to desert from the Sandinista armed forces as the deadline nears for President Daniel Ortega to step down from office, draftees and draftees' relatives said Thursday. Ortega was defeated in Sunday's election by Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, who has promised to abolish the draft after she is inaugurated on April 25. Some deserters are apparently planning to hide out until that happens. Her office announced meanwhile Thursday that the president-elect will send a special mission to the United States next week to seek economic aid for Nicaragua, ravaged through the years by economic mismanagement and U.S.-imposed sanctions. It said Francisco Mayorga, 41, who has done postgraduate work at Yale, will head the mission. Mayorga has often been mentioned as possible minister of economy after Mrs. Chamorro takes office for a six-year term. ``It will be an exploratory mission to have an initial picture of what's needed, which we will combine with offers for aid already arriving from Western Europe and Latin American countries,'' Mayorga told reporters. He said his team will visit Washington and New York for talks with World Bank, Inter-American Development Bank and International Monetary Fund officials. Although the leftist Sandinistas agreed to give up power to Mrs. Chamorro and her United National Opposition alliance, they have presented tough demands as transition teams meet to discuss terms. The Sandinistas want the economic structure they set up left alone; UNO wants to decentralize the economy, privatize state enterprises and free the marketplace. The Sandinistas also want the military structure left intact, especially if the U.S.-supported Contra guerrillas don't disband; UNO wants to depoliticize the military and reduce its size. Both sides want the Contras to disband immediately, but Contra leaders say not until Mrs. Chamorro is inaugurated. Ortega has insisted on keeping the draft, where soldiers get leftist political indoctrination alongside military training. Mrs. Chamorro wants ``children to go back to school'' and the government to stop ``making a soldier of every child.'' Widespread desertions, as reported on Thursday, could undermine the Sandinista position and the authority of Defense Minister Humberto Ortega, Daniel Ortega's brother. Juan Carlos Medina, 18, said Thursday that 40 of 60 young men in his Sandinista air force unit, posted at the main air base at Managua's international airport, deserted this week. He said, ``They took our weapons away on Monday and didn't give them back. Maybe they didn't trust us.'' ``They gave me an unsigned weekend pass. I changed into my (civilian) clothes and just walked off base,'' Medina went on. ``Nobody asked me any questions. But I'm not going back.'' One military source, speaking on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press that President Ortega had ordered the military not to stop draftees from leaving. Lt. Col. Rosa Pasos, the Defense Ministry spokeswoman, denied there was an Ortega order along those lines. But she said it was normal to have desertions under the current circumstances. She added that it was up to commanding officers to decide how to react to the desertions. ``We could, by law, go and get them,'' Ms. Pasos said. But, she added, no deserters are being chased down because, ``We definitely don't want to have people who don't want to be with us,'' she said. ``And anyway, we're going to reduce the army.'' Medina said he has 11 months to go before completing the two-year compulsory military service for all boys age 16. ``I left because Dona Violeta is going to do away with the service. So, why wait?'' he said. Maria Antonieta Mendoza said her grandson, 17-year-old Jose Manuel Nunez Lopez, deserted from his Sandinista People's Army unit in San Nicolas, near the northern city of Esteli. ``He just showed up here last night with nine other boys from his unit,'' said Mrs. Mendoza. ``They had been hitchiking all day. I almost died. I told him, what if they come and kill you?'' Mrs. Mendoza, who said she had raised Nunez since infancy, let him sleep the night, then early Thursday sent him into hiding with friends. He has six months to finish his military service and will turn 18 this month. ``They were treating those boys so badly, making them eat only spaghetti for two weeks and digging tunnels,'' she said. She said he told her of other desertions in northern Nicaragua, a battle area with the Contras. Mrs. Mendoza said her grandson told her the officers ``are hiding all the weapons in tunnels. That they're going to leave only the old weapons for Dona Violeta.'' Witnesses in Juigalpa reported seeing army trucks taking 600 boxes of munitions out of an army depot in Construction Ministry trucks; an army source said they were slated to be hidden at ministry facilities. Medina said air force officers have said they will not turn their weapons over to the new government. ``They'rave our cards ready, that we would be allowed to leave on March 5. We (draftees ) decided to wait until the 5th and if they don't let us go, we're leaving.'' Meanwhile, Ortega gave a speech to journalists at Voice of Nicaragua, saying he would fight to keep the station from becoming ``a voice of the government,'' even though it has always been the government radio station.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Ends Panama Sanctions, Tours Prison in Anti-Crime Event
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 9-10: ``In his,'' from dinner speech
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Thursday lifted the last sanctions against Panama, imposed for its failure to cooperate in drug-fighting efforts, and then toured a maximum-security prison, saying ``tough talk is simply not enough'' in battling crime and narcotics. Bush, in a day-long series of appearances in Los Angeles, also held a fund-raising luncheon with Republican governors and was to address the California Chamber of Commerce at dinner. In addition, Bush met with former President Ronald Reagan, who took a more cautious approach than Bush on the question of disarming the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. Bush said he had sent a message though diplomatic channels urging the Contras to lay down their arms after the defeat of leftist President Daniel Ortega. Reagan, however, in response to a reporter's question, said, ``Don't you think (there) might be time enough for us to wait and make sure that there is a civilian government in place in Nicaragua?'' Bush, asked if he shared Reagan's concern, declined to comment except to say, ``We have a slight difference in policy.'' On Friday, Bush will fly to Palm Springs for a two-day summit with Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu to try to repair relations strained by trade tensions. ``It's going to be an interesting meeting,'' Bush told Reagan. ``We've got to move forward on some of the tough problems we have.'' He said Kaifu was ``a very good man.'' In his dinner speech, Bush told businessmen that he strongly supports drug testing of prospective employes. ``We need to make it very clear, to every American, that if you do drugs, you don't get hired,'' Bush said. He also urged them to donate ``some time and expertise to the emerging businesses now struggling in Eastern Europe. Work with our neighbors to the south _ in Panama and in Nicaragua as the transfer of power takes place.'' Most of the economic sanctions against Panama were removed in December following the U.S. invasion and the toppling of Manuel Antonio Noriega, who now awaits trial in Florida on federal drug traffiking charges. The final remaining sanction was a denial of low tariffs and fees on Panamanian imports. That was imposed in 1988 because of a finding that Panama, under Noriega, was not cooperating fully with the United States in battling drugs. Bush said the U.S.-backed government of Guillermo Endara was ``taking adequate steps'' to prevent the sale and shipment of drugs and the illegal laundering of drug profits. ``All sanctions have now been removed against Panama,'' said White House deputy press secretary Stephen Hart. Interviewed by Cable News Network, Endara called the sanctions news ``excellent'' and said, ``We in Panama are very, very thankful for Mr. Bush Separately, Bush certified that 20 countries where narcotics are produced or transported were cooperating with the United States to fight drugs. The certification is necessary for them to be eligible to receive U.S. foreign assistance. The countries include Panama and Colombia. Bush said he was including Lebanon on the list as a matter of U.S. national interest. Bush said he had decided not to certify Afghanistan, Burma, Iran and Syria. Bush, on the second day of a four-day trip away from Washington, spent the morning touring the North Los Angeles County Correctional Facility, a $134 million, high-tech jail built to house 2,064 inmates. It opens next week. The president said a tour like his, although brief, ``does concentrate the mind. It was long enough to bring anyone face to face with the reality of what institutions like this represent.'' He said jails were ``the ultimate proof of the community's determination to protect itself and serve justice.'' Noting that no federal money was used to build the jail, Bush said, `That's a sign that your vibrant community ... knows that in the fight against crime and drugs, tough talk is simply not enough.'' ``And if you're going to be tough on crime, you've got to be tough on the criminals,'' Bush said. ``Talk to any law enforcement officer and they'll tell you what that means: No more revolving door. No more criminals out on the street because there isn't enough cell space to hold them.'' He also called for tougher state and federal laws against crime and for stiffer penalties, including the death penalty for anyone who murders a law enforcement officer. He said the federal government was doing its part, spending $1.5 billion this year to build new prisons to house 24,000 inmates. Bush said he is asking Congress to add $374 million more to the prison-construction budget in 1991. At the prison, Bush also told law enforcement personnel not to be dismayed by the indictments last week of 10 sheriff's deputies and the wife of one of them on charges of skimming profits from drug dealers. ``Don't let it get you down,'' Bush said, noting that they had the largest sheriff's department in the world with 11,000 people. ``Keep your heads high. Some bad apple turns up, an officer abuses your trust or ours by doing wrong _ we must be that much more dedicated.''

DOC.HEAD: First Woman Confirmed as Surgeon General
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Antonia Coello Novello was confirmed by the Senate Thursday night as surgeon general, the first woman and first Hispanic to hold the post. The action came on a voice vote without debate. She suceeds C. Everett Koop, who stepped down in December, in the nation's top health post. The surgeon general is the head of the Public Health Service. A 45-year-old pediatrician and expert on AIDS in children, Dr. Novello has been deputy director of the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, one of the National Institutes of Health.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Seek New Targets In Wake of Communism Collapse
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs: ``Rep. Newt,'' with grafs 4-8 bgng: ``Vice President,'' with remarks by Quayle
DOC.TEXT: Conservative leaders, while proclaiming the global decline of communism cause for celebration, began looking Thursday for ``new problems and new threats,'' to keep their movement together. At the opening of the 17th annual Conservative Political Action Conference, David Keene, chairman of the American Conservative Union, said movement activists, once highly suspicious of George Bush, have been ``somewhat pleasantly surprised'' by him. ``I think most conservatives are relatively pleased with the direction the administration has taken,'' said Keene. Vice President Dan Quayle, considered the top conservative voice in the administration, said the conservatives should congratulate themselves for the victories of democratic movements in Central America and Eastern Europe. ``We are the ones who created the environment for the Berlin Wall to fall,'' Quayle said at the organization's dinner Thursday night. Although delivering his speech just a few feet from where Nicaraguan Contra leader Adolfo Calero sat, Quayle barely touched on the future of the U.S.-backed rebels now that a new president has been elected freely in that country. ``Why do you think it is that the people of Nicaragua had a chance to vote for freedom and democracy and the people of Cuba have never had the chance to vote for freedom and democracy?'' the vice president asked. ``The reason is very elementary: In Nicaragua we supported the democratic resistance; in Cuba we abandoned the resistance. Let us not make that mistake again.'' Earlier Thursday, Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, noted that the Democrats have won only one of the last six presidential elections and said, ``We can beat the left. The question is, can we govern?'' He said people would not be asking conservatives, ``What are you going to do about health care? What are you going to do about drugs and violent crime? What are you going to do about education?'' The Georgia congressman said that ``governing is incredibly harder than opposing.'' Gingrich reminded the conservatives that many of them were disappointed in Ronald Reagan, a movement hero, and said ``We will be disappointed in Bush; we're going to be disappointed in the president that follows.'' He added that conservatives should ``cheerfully get everything that we can today, and come back in the morning for more.'' But, he warned, the movement must learn not to turn its internal fights into holy wars. Keene, who has described anti-communism as ``the glue that holds the movement together,'' said that the decline of communism as a threat had forced conservatism into ``a period of reshaping itself.'' ``There will be new problems and new threats,'' he said. He said developments overseas were forcing ``conservatives and Republicans to focus on other problems. All in all, I would prefer to have that problem than an armed and aggressive Soviet Union.'' He said that while some defense-oriented conservative groups were having trouble raising money, those with a populist, social platform were doing well. Attendance at C-PAC was about the same as at the 1989 conference, said Keene, who acknowledged that the peak years were the first few years of the Reagan presidency.

DOC.HEAD: 3 Dead, 27 Hurt as Train Hits Auto on Grade-Crossing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with details of crash, injuries, one car involved sted two, police comment. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A train struck an auto on a grade-crossing outside Belfast Thursday night, killing three people and injuring 27 others, officials said. The accident occurred at Slaught Crossing, 25 miles northwest of Belfast. Officials said there was no indication it was connected with Northern Ireland's sectarian and political fighting. The train was traveling from Belfast to Londonderry, Northern Ireland's second-largest city 65 miles northwest of the province's capital. Two of the train's three cars were derailed in the crash, and one of them toppled 25 feet down an embankment, police in Belfast reported in a statement. Killed in the accident was a couple riding in the car and a train passenger, the Royal Ulster Constabulary, Northern Ireland's police force, said in a statement. The couple's two teen-age sons, reported in satisfactory condition at Ballymena's Waveney Hospital, were among the 27 injured. Working under floodlights, firemen used cutting gear to free those trapped in the wreckage. Five were reported in serious condition, hospital authorities said. Rescue workers told of hearing screams and cries for help from trapped passengers as they arrived on the scene in darkness and heavy snow. Accident investigators from Northern Ireland Railways, the board that runs the province's state-run network, began an immediate investigation. How the auto came to be on the crossing as the train approached was not immediately known but bad weather may have played a part. Large parts of the British-ruled provinces were blanketed with snow Thursday. Initial reports of the train striking two cars proved false, police said. The mainly Roman Catholic Irish Republican Army fighting British rule in Northern Ireland has sometimes attacked trains and often blown up tracks.

DOC.HEAD: Quake Damage to Southern California Put at More Than $12.7 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with regionwide damage estimated at more than $12.7 million; picks up 4th graf, `Wednesday's 3:43 p.m. ...' SUBS grafs 13-15, `Pomona Mayor ...,' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Pomona estimate downgraded to $10 million, sted $20 million, details on damage; picks up 16th graf, `Also in ...' Lucile in 8th graf is cq.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA10
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of aftershocks continued to rattle Southern California on Thursday, the day after a strong earthquake jolted the region, causing more than $12.7 million in damages, officials said. Safety inspectors in Los Angeles and neighboring San Bernardino counties began checking gas and water lines and older, unreinforced brick and masonry buildings in communities that sprawl beneath the San Gabriel and San Bernardino mountains. The estimate of more than $12.7 million in damages to private and public property, including $10 million in damages to the town of Pomona, was ``very preliminary,'' cautioned Mike Guerin of the state Office of Emergency Services. The figure was based on reports from cities and counties, Guerin said. ``They, and we, acknowledge the numbers are incomplete.'' Wednesday's 3:43 p.m. quake measured 5.5 on the Richter scale and was centered three miles northwest of Upland, 40 miles east of Los Angeles. It was the most serious temblor to hit California since October's magnitude-7.1 quake in the San Francisco Bay area, which left 67 people dead and sparked fears of the massive earthquake predicted for the state in coming years. Dozens of aftershocks continued to shake Southern California on Thursday, with the day's strongest, magnitude 3.0, at 12:55 p.m. ``We just had a nice little aftershock,'' Claremont Assistant City Manager Bridget Distelrath said. ``We just get big eyes. They're very short, they don't last long enough to get under a table.'' Immediately after Wednesday's jolt, there was a 5 percent chance of a larger quake within three days, based on historical statistics, said seismologist Lucile Jones of the U.S. Geological Survey in Pasadena. But she said that by Thursday, the probability had dropped to 2 percent or 3 percent. Injuries from the quake appeared to be minor. Cuts, bruises and a few broken bones were the chief complaints, officials said. State Office of Emergency Services officials said it appeared that Upland, La Verne, Pomona, Ontario and Claremont were most affected, with Pomona and Claremont each declaring emergencies. La Verne City Council members on Thursday afternoon decided to withdraw an emergency declaration issued the day before. They learned damage was likely to range only between $500,000 and $750,000, said Mayor Pro Tem Thomas R. Harvey. ``Things are much better than we ever expected,'' Harvey said, adding 62 buildings in La Verne were reported damaged. Pomona Mayor Donna Smith said during the afternoon that her city's damage estimate was $10 million, down from an earlier figure of $20 million. City officials said they decided after a tour of Pomona that the damage was not as bad as initially thought, although city inspectors declared 301 buildings damaged and 17 uninhabitable. Smith said there was extensive damage to grandstands at the Los Angeles County Fairgrounds. Pomona City Hall was closed as workers shoveled out broken glass and replaced it. Smith said the building would reopen Friday. The city of 113,000 is the largest in the immediate vicinity of the epicenter. Among the damaged structures was the historic Phillips Mansion, which was built in 1875 and was the home of one of the area's founding families, said Smith. A chimney on the mansion crumbled and crashed through the roof. Also in Pomona, brick and concrete trimming from a wall of the chapel of the Trinity United Methodist Church tumbled through a roof and into an unoccupied Sunday school nursery below. About 40 children in a day care center in the building escaped injury. ``It's lucky the Sunday school nursery wasn't being used at the time. I understand there was a brick in a crib,'' said Helen Tayles, an office manager for the Pomona Unified School District, which operates the center. The children were moved to another building while inspectors examined the church and its buildings. Damage was estimated at $50,000. In La Verne, about 40 structures were damaged, including a 20-foot by 70-foot wall at an auto parts warehouse that collapsed, said Assistant City Manager Jeff Allred. At least 70 workers ran for their lives, but no one was seriously injured, said supervisor Stan Sokolowski. In Upland, about 25 reports of minor damage were being investigated, officials said. The city library, where books flew off shelves, remained closed for cleanup, the officials said. City Hall, where a picture window shattered, was open for business, as were schools. Officials in San Bernardino County said it would take several days before they could attach a dollar amount to the damage, which appeared to be minimal. ``We're pretty much back to a normal mode here. We came through it pretty much unscathed,'' said Al Langworthy, emergency preparedness planner for San Bernardino County. ``The greatest concern we had was the short failure of our 911 system and the total overload of conventional phone lines,'' Langworthy said. Rock slides that blocked mountain and canyon roads were cleared by the California Highway Patrol. The quake, five miles below the surface, ruptured a fault running from the northeast to the southwest, said seismologist Kate Hutton at the California Institute of Technology. It followed a 3.6-magnitude quake at 12:37 p.m. The worst recent Southern California quake struck the Whittier area Oct. 1, 1987. It measured 5.9 and, together with a 5.3-magitude aftershock on Oct. 4, killed eight people, injured more than 200 and caused $358 million in damage. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. An earthquake of 5 can cause considerable damage and 6 severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: House Fire Claims Seven Victims
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Christor is cq in 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: An early morning house fire so intense it thwarted all efforts at rescue killed seven people Wednesday, including three children. By the time firefighters were called to quell the blaze in a one-story frame house in Delta Township outside Lansing at 2:15 a.m., the home was engulfed in flames, and rescuers were kept at bay. ``It was all in flames when I came out,'' said neighbor Larry Riker. ``The windows were popping out.'' Delta Township Fire Chief Victor Hilbert identified the dead as David Forquer and his wife, LeAnne, and their children, Michael, 8, Christor, 6, Nona, 5, and Louis, 3. Another man who apparently also was living in the house was killed, said Hilbert, who didn't release the man's name. The roof and floor of the home fell into the basement, hampering efforts to find bodies, Hilbert said said. The stress of sifting through the charred rubble took a heavy toll on the more than 40 firefighters who were at the scene, Hilbert said. ``We've had a number of people emotionally collapse over this. Some of them just cried it out,'' he said. The tragedy shocked the neighborhood, said resident Gary Moyer. ``It's been hard on them. A couple of them went to work this morning and had to come home. It's bad enough for the parents, let alone them little kids,'' said one neighbor, Gary Moyer. ``The worst part is it just went up so fast there just wasn't anything anybody could do about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Heating Oil Leaks Into Waterway from Barge
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 4-5, `The spill...Environmental Protection,' with 6 grafs to UPDATE with oil globs washing ashore at Coney Island, CORRECT that six oiled birds disappeared, sted rescued; picks up 6th graf, `The earlier Exxon...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Exxon Valdez-Alaska
DOC.TEXT: About 27,000 gallons of heating oil spilled into a busy waterway Wednesday a few miles from the Statue of Liberty when it was loaded onto a leaking barge at an Exxon Corp. terminal, the Coast Guard said. Exxon Corp. offered to help the Coast Guard clean up the spill, but said the barge wasn't an Exxon vessel. The No. 6 heating oil was being loaded at Exxon's terminal by private contractors when it spilled into the Kill Van Kull, a waterway that separates New Jersey from the New York City borough of Staten Island. The early-morning spill occurred just a few miles from the confluence of the Van Kull and Arthur Kill, the scene of the Jan. 1-2 spill that leaked 567,000 gallons of heating oil from a pipe connecting Exxon Co. USA's terminal with the company's Bayway refinery in Linden, N.J. The waterway is a busy barge and tanker route that connects with Upper New York Bay. The spill spanned the 3{-mile length of the Kill Van Kull and the sheen of thin layers of oil was spotted near the Statue of Liberty on Liberty Island, about five miles to the northeast. Environmental officials said eight bands of oil, measuring up to 500 feet wide and three miles long, were sighted in Lower New York Bay, as close as 50 to 60 yards from the New Jersey shore. By nightfall, there were reports of globs of oil washing ashore on Staten Island, and at Coney Island at the mouth of New York Bay. Clean-up crews set booms around the damaged barge and skimmer boats worked the waterway. Experts weren't immediately able to gauge the damage to wildlife, said Rick Fulton, spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection. Six oil-soaked birds were spotted floundering near the waterfront, but they disappeared by the time rescuers arrived, said Peter Cohen, director of the Hudson County emergency management office. The earlier Exxon spill is still under investigation by the state and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and by local agencies. The company was indicted on criminal charges Tuesday by a federal grand jury in Alaska in the Exxon Valdez tanker spill, which unleashed nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into Alaska's Prince William Sound on March 24. Exxon could face $700 million in penalties for the two felony and three misdemeanor charges. Coast Guard Lt. Jeff Crawley said Wednesday's spill came from a 12-inch by 6-inch hole in the barge, owned by Eklof Marine of Staten Island. State officials said the hole was caused by a tugboat attempting to position the barge, but Coast Guard officials couldn't confirm that. A secretary at Eklof's offices said the company had no immediate comment. An Exxon news release said oil bought by Eklof for an international customer was being loaded onto the barge and said Exxon wasn't involved in the accident. ``Exxon has offered its full cooperation to the Coast Guard and the barge owner in assistance with the spill response,'' said Exxon spokesman Jack Holleran. Environmentalists expressed concern that tides and wind could move the slick into areas of New York Harbor that serve as breeding grounds for migratory waterfowl.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Wife of Henry Miller Arrested for Illegal Marijuana Possession
DOC.TEXT: Police said Thursday the Japanese ex-wife of writer Henry Miller has been arrested on charges of illegal possession of marijuana. Hoki Tokuda, 56, was arrested Sunday when police found a package containing 1 gram of marijuana resin at her Tokyo home, said an official at Tokyo's Metropolitan Police Department, speaking on condition of anonymity. Ms. Tokuda, born in Tokyo, worked as an actress and a singer after studying piano and music composition at a college in Canada. She went to Los Angeles in 1966 to perform as a jazz singer at a restaurant, and married Miller the following year, according to police. After her divorce from Miller in 1978, Ms. Tokuda returned to Tokyo and continued her career as an actress. She also manages a small jazz club in Tokyo. Miller is considered one of the most influential American writers of the 20th century. Among his works are ``Tropic of Cancer,'' ``Tropic of Capricorn'' and ``Nexus.'' Miller died in 1980. Convicted violators of Japan's Narcotics Control law face up to 10 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Southern California Temblor Recalls Bay Area's Big One
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT that game was third of series, sted first.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-LA Quake
DOC.TEXT: The strong earthquake in Southern California on Wednesday recalled the far greater tragedy that struck the San Francisco Bay area _ and was shared by much of the nation via television _ on Oct. 17. As millions of Americans were tuning in to watch the third game of the World Series between the San Francisco Giants and cross-bay rival Oakland Athletics, the picture began to shake. Viewers were seeing the first effects of a quake measuring 7.1 on the Richter scale. The temblor, centered far south of San Francisco, killed 67 people, injured about 3,000 and did $7 billion in damage. Dozens of buildings collapsed in San Francisco's marina district, and some blocks of apartments were consumed by flames fed by natural gas leaks. A 50-foot section of the top deck of the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge fell in. Damage was widespread in Santa Cruz and Watsonville, cities nearer the quake's center many miles south of San Francisco. Worst, by far was the collapse of 1{ miles of elevated deck on the Nimitz Freeway in Oakland. Over the next few days, rescuers tunneled into the rubble to pull out 43 bodies _ and one survivor, Buck Helm. The so-called ``Miracle Man'' died later of injuries. The ground at the quake's center, in a wooded area called area called Loma Prieta in Santa Cruz County, has become a tourist attraction of sorts. The San Francisco earthquake of 1906, which occurred before the Richter scale was devised, has been estimated at 8.3 on the Richter scale.

Prosecutors are pressing their investigation of Mayor Marion Barry by issuing a new series of subpoenas for city records, as Barry prepares for a June trial on charges of cocaine possession and perjury. Barry pleaded innocent Wednesday to five misdemeanor cocaine charges and three felony perjury counts at a federal court arraignment. U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson scheduled a June 4 trial. ``We will not plea bargain, and the mayor is not considering resigning,'' Barry's attorney, R. Kenneth Mundy, said after the nine-minute court proceeding. ``The mayor is confident he will be vindicated at trial.'' U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens would not comment on the possibility of a plea bargain, but said the probe was continuing ``with respect to a variety of allegations'' involving Barry and various city services.

In a confirmation of time-honored ways, a study today concludes that the old-fashioned stethoscope is just as good as electronic monitors _ and maybe even better _ for checking babies during birth. The researchers found signs that cerebral palsy may be more common among infants whose births are electronically monitored, possibly because the monitors led doctors to wait longer before acting to rescue a baby in distress. But they cautioned that this finding could be a statistical fluke. Experts said, moreover, that monitors are likely to remain in use, in part because they require less manpower in the delivery room. Electronic fetal monitors were introduced in the early 1970s and now are a fixture of delivery rooms everywhere. Still, doctors have only recently begun rigorous testing to see if the machines help produce healthier babies.

While environmentalists generally praise the criminal indictment of Exxon Corp. in the massive Alaskan oil spill, some are bemoaning the fact that no individual corporate officials were charged. ``There are some people hiding behind the corporate cloak,'' Erik Olson, an attorney for the Natural Wildlife Federation, said Wednesday. ``If you are not punishing the individuals, you are only punishing some ethereal corporate, artificial entity.'' But proving criminal legal violations against individuals would be much more difficult than bringing charges against the corporation and its subsidiary, Exxon Shipping Co., legal experts say. ``A corporation doesn't act through one person but may act through a combination of individuals. So no one of them had a requisite criminal intent,'' said Norman Bernstein, a Washington environmental lawyer who represents large corporations.

Bench warfare has broken out in the city's subways, as the Transit Authority yanks seats from stations to force the slumbering homeless to find other accommodations.
