DOC.TEXT: In a sign of the recession gripping Wall Street, slumping investment firm Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. announced 2,000 layoffs and a comprehensive business review expected to produce further cutbacks. The move announced Wednesday follows 800 job cuts late last year, a senior management overhaul and $1 billion in capital infusions by parent American Express Co. to prop up the securities company's financial position. Shearson President Howard L. Clark Jr. said the latest cuts are part of a broad-based program that would save the company $400 million in costs a year.

The U.S. economy grew at its slowest pace in more than three years in 1989, the government said Wednesday. Analysts welcomed a slight upward revision in fourth-quarter activity reported Wednesday, but many remain anxious over prospects for this year. The Commerce Department revised the fourth-quarter gross national product upwards from 0.5 percent to 0.9 percent, which in turn boosted overall 1989 economic growth to 3.0 percent from last month's 2.9 percent estimate.

Existing home sales declined 2.2 percent in January as rising mortgage interest rates combined with the usual winter lull to brake sales to their slowest pace since last summer, a real estate trade group said. The National Association of Realtors said Wednesday that resales of single-family homes totaled a seasonally adjusted 3.48 million units in January, down from 3.56 million one month earlier. It was the slowest pace since last August's 3.44 million rate.

Of the nation's 10 highest income communities, fully half are suburbs of Washington, D.C., according to the Census Bureau. What's more, if the District of Columbia were a state it would rank third in per capita income among the states, the bureau said Wednesday in releasing final per-person income figures for 1987. Among counties, the top per capita income was $23,169 in Falls Church, Va., followed by $22,200 in Alexandria, Va., and $22,181 in Arlington, Va.

Regardless of whether Exxon Corp. ever goes to trial on criminal charges, the oil giant's indictment in connection with its Alaska oil spill could cause Exxon's disaster-related expenses to snowball beyond the $2 billion it already has spent, experts said. Dan Riesel, an environmental attorney with the law firm Sive, Paget & Riesel, said Wednesday a number of outcomes are possible in the Exxon case, including an eventual dismissal of the charges. In the event of a conviction or a plea bargain, however, criminal proceedings against Exxon could benefit those who have filed civil lawsuits and swell Exxon's financial burden, said Riesel.

Recent upheavals in Japan's capital markets may put a financial squeeze on Japanese industry and slow economic growth, analysts say, but few believe a recession will result. ``Economic conditions are still strong,'' Hiroshi Kadota, of the Japan Federation of Economic Organizations' Financial Affairs Bureau, said Wednesday. ``Investment is expanding. The capital markets are returning to a normal trend.'' Japanese industry for years has been able to raise capital for growth at relatively little cost, but its fabled markets have shown signs of sputtering lately.

SEATTLE _ Clothing retailer Nordstrom Inc. has been hit with a second class-action lawsuit in as many days, this time from a union that accuses the company of widespread violations of wage and hour laws. United Food & Commercial Workers Union Locals 1001 and 367 and five current and former Nordstrom employees filed their suit Wednesday in King County Superior Court seeking back pay and penalties on behalf of approximately 50,000 present and former company workers in Washington, Oregon, California, Virginia, Utah and Alaska. The union said claims in California alone could total as much as $200 million. A U.S. District Court suit was filed here Tuesday by three Nordstrom shareholders who alleged they and other stockholders suffered financial losses because Nordstrom officers failed to disclose the company's wage problems.

Toyota Motor Corp. and Ford Motor Co. recalled some of their mid-1980s cars because of potential cruise control and emissions problems. A Toyota spokeswoman said Wednesday that about 120,000 1983-84 model Camrys and 1984-model Corollas were being recalled because of a cruise control problem that could cause high engine speed. Ford said it was recalling about 16,000 1986 Ford Escort and EXP and Mercury Lynx cars made for sale in California.

Media companies are running to the doctor. The media venture that produces the Lifetime cable network joined the rush on Wednesday when it disclosed plans to offer commercially-sponsored TV programs on health care topics for replay throughout the day in the waiting rooms of pediatricians, obstetricians and family practitioners. Officials said the service, called Healthlink Television, would be distributed on videocassettes to a projected 3,000 waiting rooms beginning sometime in the April-to-June quarter.

The stock market rose broadly Wednesday and blue chips managed to extend this week's winning streak. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials gained 10.13 points to close at 2,627.25. The dollar rose against most major currencies. Gold prices were mostly lower. Bond prices tumbled. Soybean oil futures bounded to 7{-month highs; corn futures advanced; most wheat futures retreated; oil futures slipped; precious metals were mixed; cattle futures rose and pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Poling in Ford's Hot Seat Beginning Today
DOC.TEXT: A three-year clock starts ticking today for Harold Poling as he takes over as head of the nation's second-largest automaker. Poling, who becomes chairman and chief executive officer of Ford Motor Co., set the timer last November when it was announced he would replace outgoing Chairman Donald Petersen. The 64-year-old Poling, a year older than Petersen, said he would be serve for only three years before giving way to another. ``Ideally, you'd like to have a CEO with a long future out in front of him,'' said auto analyst Charles Brady of Oppenheimer & Co. of New York. The transition promises to be a smooth one. Petersen and Poling worked closely together through the last decade, when Ford moved from a struggling company that lost $1.5 billion in 1980 to a leaner automaker that posted an industry record $5.3 billion in profit in 1988. Despite its successes, Ford still must contend with a sluggish new car market and toughening competition from Japanese makers, factors that combined to trim the company's profits to $3.84 billion last year. Poling has only three years to face those challenges, and observers already are speculating on his successor. Edward Bowman, deputy dean of the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania, said the decision by Ford directors to give Poling a limited term ``would imply that they weren't quite ready in terms of succession planning, that they weren't ready to name somebody else for a normal term.'' Speculation for a chief executive to lead the company in the mid-1990s and beyond centers on Allan Gilmour, a Ford executive vice president who today adds the title of president of the Ford Automotive Group. ``That seems to be the scuttlebutt right now,'' Brady said. ``I think that may, in fact, be the plan.'' Petersen came up through Ford's product development ranks. He has been credited with freeing designers and engineers in the early 1980s to work together in developing the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable cars of the mid-1980s, which helped lift Ford from the financial doldrums. ``I really think that Petersen made the necessary adjustments in the product plan,'' Brady said. ``The key addition he made was to leave product planning to the product planners.'' Poling, who rose through the automaker's financial operations, would be well served to follow that lead, Brady said. ``I think he's got to challenge (product planners) with the charge that this is a very intensely competitive game,'' he said. ``That's all he's got to do in the product area.'' Bowman agreed. ``I think he would be a nut in that three-year period to mess with any product decisions,'' he said. Although Poling will have a limited amount of time as chief executive, he has his work cut out for him. The U.S. auto industry is at or near the bottom of what some analysts have called a recession that began in October. Companies would like to wean American consumers from incentives that have become ingrained in car buying and are eating away at corporate profits. The nation's Big Three automakers, sales-leader General Motors Corp., Ford and No. 3 Chrysler Corp., also are taking steps to eliminate costs and streamline operations as they try to hang on to market share in the face of stiff competition from Japanese models, both imports and American-made cars. That, Brady said, is where Poling can leave his mark. ``His real test will be in raising the levels of productivity,'' Brady said. ``If he can follow through with the productivity increase while the programs continue in the Petersen manner, it will be one of the best one-two punches of all time.'' Poling will become the fourth company chairman not a member of the Ford family. The two Fords now in company management are cousins William C. Ford Jr., 32, and Edsel Ford II, 41, both great-grandsons of company founder Henry Ford.

DOC.HEAD: Lifetime Cable Producers Join Rush to Doctor's Office TV
DOC.TEXT: Media companies hope to stake a claim to a spot in the doctor's waiting room. The media venture that produces the Lifetime cable network became the latest company to try to get in the door when it disclosed plans Wednesday to offer commercially-sponsored TV programs on health care topics. The one-hour programs with nine minutes of ads would be offered for replay throughout the day in the waiting rooms of pediatricians, obstetricians and family practitioners. Officials said the service called Healthlink Television would be distributed on videocassettes to a projected 3,000 waiting rooms beginning sometime in the April-to-June quarter. A new program would be distributed every month. The venture expects the number of participating waiting rooms to reach 20,000 by the end of the first year and ultimately reach 50,000 of the estimated 68,000 multi-doctor offices available in those medical specialities. At least two other media companies have been considering similar advertiser-supported video projects and several are already in waiting rooms with magazines designed for young mothers. Their creators are touting them as more efficient than the traditional mass media for reaching captive audiences with pitches for products ranging from diapers to automobiles. Whittle Communications, based in Knoxville, Tenn., is considering making programs on either health care or entertainment topics available for use in waiting rooms and recently acquired a Florida company that was about to launch that type of service. Whittle already publishes six quarterly magazines called Special Reports that are in about 19,000 doctors' offices. Frederick N. Doner Communications Inc. of New York has been testing what it calls the Good Health Channel in a handful of waiting rooms over the past two months. Family Media Inc., also of New York, recently launched a magazine specifically targeted at women in doctors' waiting rooms. The waiting room ``is now becoming a cluttered scene'' for advertisers, said Richard Kostrya, media services director at the advertising agency J. Walter Thompson. He said a serious unresolved question was whether people in such settings are receptive to advertising. The Healthlink Television project has the backing of some large media companies. The venture producing it, Hearst-ABC-Viacom Entertainment Services, is jointly owned by Hearst Corp., Capital Cities-ABC Inc. and Viacom Inc. The same concern now produces Lifetime Television, a cable network aimed at women that is available on systems serving 46 million households, and Lifetime Medical Television, which produces TV programs for the medical community. Thomas F. Burchill, president and chief executive of Hearst-ABC-Viacom Entertainment, declined to specify how much the creators were prepared to spend on the project, but said they had ``deep pockets'' and would ``invest the necessary funds to make a success of it.'' The American Academy of Pediatrics, an organization with 38,000 members, has agreed to collaborate on producing programs, approve all program content and screen the ads in return for an unspecified royalty fee. Pitches for tobacco or prescription drugs will not be accepted. Burchill said different programs would be created for each of the three medical specialties. A typical program would include short segments on several topics such as childhood nutrition, car safety or choosing a day care center. The venture plans to loan a television set and video player to participating physicians who are expected to run the show continuously during the work day. David Moore, president of Healthlink Television, said ad rates would start out at about $500,000 a year for a 30-second commercial in the pediatricians' waiting rooms while charges on the programs aimed at patients of the family practitioners and obstetricians would be about $200,000 to $300,000 a year. Burchill said his company's experience in producing medical programs and the backing of the pediatrics group should help Healthlink compete with other waiting room services. But he said advertisers also will get an incentive the others cannot offer _free ad time on the Lifetime cable network if the audience for Healthlink fails to meet expectations.

DOC.HEAD: Dart Group Settles SEC Dispute
DOC.TEXT: Dart Group Inc. has settled a federal complaint alleging it had acted as an investment company because its main assets stemmed from the sale of stocks in a series of takeover bids for retailing companies. Without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Dart Group agreed on Wednesday in effect not to buy and sell securities as its primary business unless it registers as an investment company. The Securities and Exchange Commission, which as been investigating the retailer since 1988, accused Dart Group in a civil complaint in Washington federal court of violating securities laws by acting as an unregistered investment firm. The SEC charged that since 1984, when it sold off the Dart drug store chain, ``a majority of the total consolidated assets of Dart Group have been composed of securities.'' According to the SEC, companies that engage primarily in trading, investing and reinvesting securities constitute investment companies that must by law register with the SEC. Dart Group, which is controlled by Herbert Haft and his son Robert, made a string of hostile attempts for retailers including Safeway Stores Inc., Supermarkets General Corp., Dayton Hudson Corp. and, most recently, a $4.32 billion bid for Kroger Co. in September 1988. Dart Group never acquired its targets, but the Hafts profited handsomely from their stock in the companies and earned reputations as corporate raiders. Observers questioned whether they were serious about acquiring a retailer. Dart Group, based in Landover, Md., said in a statement it had resolved the SEC matter and added that it ``is not now an investment company and does not intend to become an investment company.'' The company said it had 1989 sales of more than $900 million from 575 retail stores such as Trak Auto, Crown Books and Shoppers Food supermarkets. Dart Group said it also has real estate holdings. Rudolph Gerlich Jr., a branch chief with the SEC's enforcement division, said the case was significant because it showed that even firms with large operating subsidiaries still can be classified as investment companies if they meet legal requirements. Gerlich warned other companies that the SEC will be ``looking at your assets and your income and if they are primarily securities, we won't hesitate to more closely scrutinize the company, and where appropriate, to require registration as an investment company.'' In October 1988, Dart disclosed that the SEC was investigating whether the firm should be forced to register as a company that invests in securities for a pool of small investors. Dart Group was never forced to take that step, but the Hafts have not made a hostile bid since then.

DOC.HEAD: Investor Group Urges Motorcycle Maker Eliminate RV Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: An investor group with a 7.26 percent stake in Harley-Davidson Inc. wants the last U.S. motorcyle maker to get rid of its recreational vehicle subsidiary. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday, businessman Malcolm I. Glazer said he sent a letter to Harley's management suggesting it sell or spin off its Holiday Rambler Corp. division. ``Either transaction would allow Harley-Davidson to concentrate its efforts on what it does best _ manufacturing motorcycles,'' Glazer said in the Feb. 26 letter to the Milwaukee-based company's president, Richard F. Teerlink. The letter suggested a meeting at Teerlink's office on March 5 to discuss the matter. Teerlink rebuffed the request for a meeting. ``The future growth of Holiday Rambler offers a significant long-term opportunity for our shareholders,'' he said in a statement. ``Therefore, we believe that Holiday Rambler should remain a part of the company.'' Glazer, an investor and businessman, with offices in Rochester, N.Y. and Palm Beach, Fla., revealed last October that he and members of his family had acquired a 6.24 percent stake in Harley, the nation's only remaining motorcycle manufacturer. At that time. Glazer said he might seek to acquire a controlling interest or sell off all or part of his group's shares. Glazer, in 1988, acquired 9.9 percent of the Formica Corp. at $12 a share and was rebuffed in a $20-a-share buyout offer before the laminated products company went private. In the letter to Teerlink, Glazer disclosed he now holds 7.26 percent or 626,500 shares of Harley's common stock. Glazer's letter said he believed Harley's common shares would be greatly enhanced if ``the Holiday Rambler division is divested and the proceeds distributed to shareholders as a special dividend'' or the division is ``spun off as a publicly traded corporation with the shares of the new entity being distributed to current Harley-Davidson shareholders.'' Holiday Rambler employs about 2,200 in northern Indiana and had sales of $351.9 million. In 1983 the Reagan administration imposed five years of stiff tariffs against imported motorcycles that had been beating Harley's product. The tariffs were removed in 1987 after the company announced it no longer needed protection.

DOC.HEAD: Seabrook Ready to Receive License, Many Residents Wary
With PM-Seabrook, Bjt
LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dianne is cq
DOC.TEXT: People who live in the shadow of the Seabrook nuclear power plant say it's hard to believe a decision on licensing the reactor is at hand. Many are against the plant and say they fear what would happen if an accident occurred. ``I think it's a disgrace,'' said Russ Arscott, a Seabrook resident for 61 years. ``There's no way to evacuate the area. I just hope the pipes all hold.'' Ray Colbert moved to Hampton Beach last year knowing little about the plant, which he can see across Hampton Harbor from his porch. He said he plans to move to Florida in May, partly because of the reactor. ``I might stay if that thing wasn't so close,'' he said. But ``I've got a five-month-old daughter. I want to get her the hell out of here before they fire that thing up.'' Others look forward to the day the plant finally produces electricity. ``We need it,'' said Thelma Grinnell, a resident of nearby Salisbury, Mass., for the past 25 years. ``We need something other than fossil fuels. We're destroying the environment.'' The years-old controversy about licensing centers on federally mandated evacuation plans for communities within a 10-mile radius of the plant, including Salisbury and five others in Massachusetts. Opponents say the area around the plant, which is located two miles from popular Hampton Beach and 40 miles north of Boston, is too densely populated to be evacuated safely in an emergency. ``Anybody who's been in a traffic jam (near the plant) during the summer knows that in a panic situation, evacuation would be impossible,'' Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., said in a telephone interview Wednesday. ``Why should I have to leave everything I worked for and own just because of a siren blast from a plant I hate?'' asked Herbert Sanborn, a 79-year-old Seabrook resident. Seabrook proponents, including former New Hampshire governor and now White House chief of staff John Sununu, say the plans will work. Sununu refused to comment on Seabrook this week, but his support was vocal as governor. ``It may be a surprise ... but we run the analogy of an (evacuation) experiment at 7:30 each summer day,'' Sununu said during a 1983 debate. ``At 7:30 that beach is crowded ... and at 11 at night that beach is empty.'' Although they disagree on licensing, opponents and proponents agree that the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has taken too long to make a decision. ``I never thought it would take this long,'' said former Gov. Meldrim Thomson, a Seabrook proponent who served from 1973-79. ``If any human being could dream up anything worse, they would have to work at it,'' Thomson said. ``We've been told over and over again that we've built the best and safest plant that's ever been built. It's ridiculous that it hasn't been licensed.'' Veteran anti-Seabrook protester Dianne Dunfey was equally critical of the NRC, but from the other side of the issue. The NRC is ``one of the most disreputable of all government agencies,'' said Dunfey, who was released from jail last week after serving a five-day term for refusing to pay a fine following a sit-in at Gov. Judd Gregg's office. ``It has ignored public input,'' said Dunfey, who teaches school in Seabrook. ``It either discarded or amended all of its own regulations anytime Seabrook couldn't meet one.''

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Firm Cuts 2,000 More Workers
DOC.TEXT: The struggling house of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. said it would lay off 2,000 more workers and acknowledged that the recession on Wall Street could cost still more jobs at the nation's No. 2 brokerage. Wednesday's move follows 800 job cuts late last year, a senior management overhaul and $1 billion in capital infusions by parent American Express Co. to prop up the securities company's financial position. Shearson President Howard L. Clark Jr. said the latest reductions are part of a broad cost-cutting program that would save the company $400 million a year. He said a review of the investment bank's operations could lead to the elimination of certain businesses and the paring down of others. Shearson officials said the latest layoffs, which will be completed by the end of March, would occur in all divisions. ``These steps are necessary to position ourselves for long-term success in the decade ahead,'' said Clark, a former American Express executive who took over Shearson last month after the ouster of Peter A. Cohen, who led the firm's bold expansion in the 1980s. Clark said the cost cutting and business review would result in significant one-time charges that would depress first-quarter earnings. As part of the review, he said Shearson would consider shrinking or closing down businesses, selling entire units, entering partnerships in some markets with other Wall Street firms or expanding in some areas. One potential union reportedly failed. Wall Street sources said American Express and Primerica Corp., parent of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., held talks about merging some areas to improve operating efficiency but they ended without a deal this week. However, The New York Times reported that talks were continuing about a possible merger of Shearson and Smith Barney, which would create the nation's largest brokerage. Under a proposed stock-for-assets swap, Primerica would receive a large portion of American Express' stake in Shearson and the two companies would be partners as parents of the merged brokerages, the newspaper said, citing unidentified people involved in the talks. Primerica Chairman Sanford I. Weill, the man who built up Shearson in the 1970s and sold it to American Express in 1981, would take over as chairman of Shearson, the Times said. The new layoffs would reduce Shearson's work force to 33,500 from a peak of 46,000 in January 1988. The cuts come amid a general industry slowdown since the October 1987 stock market crash that has cost more than 40,000 jobs. ``Shearson like other firms is readjusting to the new market realities,'' said John Kriz, a securities industry analyst with Moody's Investors Service Inc. Perrin Long of Lipper Analytical Services said he expected Shearson to cut up to 3,000 more jobs this year and reduce its reliance on businesses such as investment banking and trading in favor of retail brokerage. The latest cuts came two days after American Express said it would inject $750 million into Shearson to shore up its finances, following a $250 million infusion in December. In return, American Express increased its ownership stake in Shearson. Analysts said the injection was designed to quell widespread rumors on Wall Street about Shearson's financial condition following the recent collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. American Express had planned to shore up Shearson's finances and reduce its stake in the brokerage to about 45 percent from 61 percent under a complex recapitalization plan involving the issue of $250 million of new Shearson stock. But weak market conditions forced the company to abandon the offering. Long estimated the new infusion would give American Express about 72 percent of Shearson. But he said if Shearson's financial position improves, the parent still would need to consider whether to sell the firm, spin it off to shareholders or assume 100 percent ownership.

DOC.HEAD: Additional Indictments in Yen and Soybean Pits
DOC.TEXT: Some previously indicted traders in the Japanese yen pit at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the soybean pit at the Chicago Board of Trade have been indicted on additional counts. The added charges come as part of a wide-ranging federal undercover investigation at the exchanges, which has resulted in the indictments of 48 people, including a clerk. On Wednesday, assistant U.S. Attorney Daniel Gillogly filed superseding indictments against 16 Japanese yen traders and 13 soybean traders who were originally indicted last August. Sources told the Chicago Sun-Times and the Chicago Tribune that prosecutors were able to broaden and refine the original indictments because of information they received from cooperating defendants. The traders are charged with violating the Commodities Exchange Act, lying to a federal agency and mail and wire fraud. The superseding indictments added eight new counts to charges against those in the yen pit, bringing the total to 393 counts. Those charged in the Soybean Pit now face a total of 734 counts. Trial for the yen traders is expected to begin May 21 before U.S. District Judge William Hart. The accused soybean traders are scheduled to go on trial June 12 before U.S. District Judge George Marovich.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Officials `Hiding Behind Corporate Cloak,' Environmentalist Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 10, To win, to CORRECT ``felony convictions'' to ``felony charges.''
DOC.TEXT: While environmentalists generally praise the criminal indictment of Exxon Corp. in the massive Alaskan oil spill, some are bemoaning the fact that no individual corporate officials were charged. ``There are some people hiding behind the corporate cloak,'' Erik Olson, an attorney for the Natural Wildlife Federation, said Wednesday. ``If you are not punishing the individuals, you are only punishing some ethereal corporate, artificial entity.'' But proving criminal legal violations against individuals would be much more difficult than bringing charges against the corporation and its subsidiary, Exxon Shipping Co., legal experts say. ``A corporation doesn't act through one person but may act through a combination of individuals. So no one of them had a requisite criminal intent,'' said Norman Bernstein, a Washington environmental lawyer who represents large corporations. The company's failure ``may be in a sense the failure of the system, a combination of people's judgments rather than one individual consciously saying, `I don't really care about the intentional grounding of this ship,''' Bernstein said. A federal grand jury in Alaska handed up a five-count criminal indictment against Exxon on Tuesday in the 10-million-gallon spill by the tanker Exxon Valdez in Alaska's Prince William Sound on March 24. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh didn't rule out the possibility of more charges, telling reporters the investigation was continuing. His statement Tuesday indicated that prosecutors may be trying to determine if there is evidence to charge individuals. Responsibility often is so fragmented in large corporations that it is difficult to prove that a series of individuals knowingly committed crimes, said Judson W. Starr, former head of the Justice Department's environmental crimes unit. But criminal behavior is ``easier to prove against corporations. They can accumulate bits and pieces of knowledge,'' Starr said. To win convictions on the two felony charges it has brought, the Justice Department must prove that Exxon ``willfully and knowingly'' failed to ensure the Exxon Valdez was manned by crew members capable of safely operating the tanker. The ship's captain, Joseph Hazelwood, is on trial in Anchorage on state charges arising from the spill, including operating a vessel while intoxicated. In the days before Tuesday's indictment, the Justice Department endured a storm of criticism from Alaskan officials and environmental groups after reports it was about to reach a plea-bargain agreement with Exxon. Alaskan officials charged the settlement would have compromised the state's civil suit against the oil company. But Assistant Attorney General Richard B. Stewart defended the government's handling of the negotiations, denying claims that it might have agreed to a settlement that would have allowed Exxon to avoid its responsibility for the cleanup. In its dealings with Exxon over several months, the department always insisted on ``a guilty plea to serious charges'' and ``very, very substantial fines, entirely unprecedented in the environmental context,'' Stewart said Wednesday. The proposal was tailored ``to deal with an unresolved and developing situation,'' he said. ``It will be many years before we have a full understanding of the extent of the damage.'' The government proposed requiring Exxon to pay $150 million ``up front'' to finance pilot restoration projects and environmental studies to assess ways of repairing the damage, he said. Once that phase was completed, Exxon also would have been required to pay up to $500 million as demanded by federal trustees to finish the cleanup, Stewart said. If that amount proved insufficient, the government would have been free after four years to file civil suits to get more money. The Justice Department showed the proposal to Alaskan officials at Exxon's request because the company did not want to be in a position of paying twice for the same cleanup, Stewart said. The government made changes to accommodate concerns raised by Alaska, he said, adding that the proposal was rejected by both Alaska and Exxon.

DOC.HEAD: Book: Iacocca Tried Coup While at Ford
DOC.TEXT: Lee Iacocca, while president of Ford Motor Co., tried to stage a coup by saying then-Ford Chairman Henry Ford II was senile and incapable of running the nation's No. 2 automaker, a new book says. The book by former Ford executive Walter Hayes said Iacocca, now chairman of Chrysler Corp., made the move while Ford was traveling in China in 1978. Later that year, Iacocca was fired by Ford, grandson of the company's founder, became Chrysler's president and rose to chairman in 1979. The biography of Ford, who died Sept. 29, 1987, is to be published in June. Review copies of ``Henry: A Memoir of Henry Ford II,'' were distributed Wednesday. Hayes, who retired as vice chairman of Ford of Europe last year, said Iacocca met with Ford directors George Bennett and Joseph Cullman and ``argued that Henry, still not 60 years of age, was senile and not up to the job and indicated that there were others in the company who shared his opinion.'' Ford learned of the meeting, the book said, and ``did not believe it, but it took little detective work to persuade him that what he had heard was true. Lee Iacocca wanted to take the company away from him and, more astonishingly, seemed to think he could do it.'' A spokesman for Iacocca said the account was untrue. Iacocca could not be reached for comment. Chrysler spokesman Steve Harris did not immediately return phone calls seeking comment today. In his accounts of the late 1970s, Iacocca said his efforts to change Ford were repeatedly rebuffed by Henry Ford. ``He (Ford) hated firing people,'' according to Hayes' book. ``That is why he did it so badly. ``From the day he made up his mind to replace Lee, it took him three years and an act of insubordination to stiffen his sinews sufficiently to do the deed.''

DOC.HEAD: Personal Income Up 0.8 Percent in January
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 10th graf, The key, to correct December to January and November to December.
DOC.TEXT: Personal income, boosted in part by a federal employee pay raise, rose 0.8 percent in January while consumer spending increased 0.6 percent, the government reported today. The Commerce Department said incomes totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.60 trillion after rising 0.5 percent in December. ``The January increase was boosted by cost-of-living adjustments to several federal transfer payment programs and by a pay raise for federal government employees,'' the department said. The 3.6 percent federal pay raise added $3.5 billion at an annual rate to government payrolls. The January income boost was offset somewhat by an increase in personal contributions for social insurance programs and by a decrease in subsidy payments to farmers. Consumer spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.60 trillion following a 0.6 percent gain in December. Consumer spending is watched closely as a barometer of economic health because it accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. The report showed that Americans' incomes after taxes rose 0.9 percent, up from December's 0.4 percent gain. Americans' savings rate, savings as a percent of disposable income, rose 5.9 percent against December's 5.5 percent increase. The key component of the income category, wages and salaries, edged up $16.2 billion in January following a $16.8 billion gain in December. Payrolls at manufacturing companies, hit hardest by the Federal Reserve's high-interest policies, fell $2.1 billion after a $200 million increase in December. On the spending side, the $19.9 billion increase in personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, was down from December's $36.7 billion advance. Purchases of durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ rose $24.3 billion, while purchases of non-durable goods edged up $2.5 billion. Spending on services fell $6.8 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern's Hartsfield Hub Shrugs Off Ill Effects of Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to clarify release time
DOC.TEXT: The roar of Eastern Airlines jets overhead means Harold Echols is selling yogurt again. A year ago, Echols and his concession stands at Atlanta's Hartsfield international airport were hit hard by the Eastern strike that prompted a temporary shutdown of the airline and took a multimillion-dollar bite out of the local economy. The strike by Eastern Machinists, pilots and flight attendants, which began March 4, 1989, emptied all of Concourse C and half of Concourse B at Hartsfield. For Echols, whose Airport International Concessions Inc. runs a variety of shops, the grounding of Eastern translated into an immediate 32 percent drop in sales, weekly losses exceeding $40,000 and several layoffs through the early months of the strike. ``We couldn't do a thing about it,'' Echols said. ``Just pray and look for better times.'' Now that Eastern planes are flying again, Echols and others at the world's second busiest airport are much happier. Indeed, the airport itself has recently reclaimed the ``second busiest'' title (to Chicago's O'Hare International), which it briefly surrendered in the depths of the strike. Miami-based Eastern began rebuilding last fall with Hartsfield as the center of its operations. The pilots and flight attendants ended their strike in November. For the time being, Eastern concourses are busy again with passengers and employees. Eastern Machinists continue to picket at Hartsfield, a constant reminder they're still on strike. But the airport and the city of Atlanta seem to have withstood the shock. ``Initially it was a sizable impact, but it was very short-lived,'' said Jim Cranford, Hartsfield's business manager. ``They're flying less flights but not that much less than pre-strike because they've slowly come back.'' Cranford said in the three years prior to the strike, Eastern contributed about $25 million annually to the airport's operations, including payments for such things as terminal rental, security, landing fees and insurance. Now, that figure is closer to $22 million. Atlanta-based Delta Air Lines, the No. 1 carrier at Hartsfield with about 50 percent of the airport's traffic, contributes more than $30 million annually, Cranford said. Eastern currently owes the airport about $1.6 million in pre-strike bills, but that money is frozen because of the airline's bankruptcy court proceedings, Cranford said. The airline also owes about $1.1 million for February, he said, but it has been paying bills promptly since starting up after the strike. The airline says it currently has 270 departures a day out of Atlanta, compared to 289 daily right before the strike. ``The worrisome question is, will they succeed in the long run?'' said airport spokesman John Braden. ``Eastern is so ingrained in Atlanta,'' Braden said. ``They were born here. Eastern was established here before Delta. We consider them an Atlanta airline, so we'd hate to see them leave from the standpoint that they're ours.'' Donald Ratajczak, director of the Economic Forecasting Center at Georgia State University's College of Business Administration, said the local economy has begun to climb back from the jolt caused last spring by the strike, which took a big payroll bite worth $700 million annually. Ratajczak said Atlanta hasn't totally recovered. ``The new Eastern doesn't have the same economic clout as before,'' he said. ``But it's sure better than it was last March.''

DOC.HEAD: Poland May Be Candidate For Debt Reduction, U.S. Treasury Official Says
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Treasury Undersecretary David C. Mulford suggested today that Poland is a candidate for reduction of the $10 billion it owes to banks under the plan proposed by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. Mulford told a congressional panel that he and Brady were in Poland last weekend and that the question of reducing Poland's debt is under discussion. He noted that Mexico has just signed an agreement with creditor banks, the first negotiated under the Brady strategy. Mulford also said that Poland has just made another agreement to delay payments on the $27 billion that it owes to creditor governments, including the United States. Poland has a total debt of more than $40 billion. Mulford was testifying before the subcommittee on international organizations of the banking committee in the House of Representatives.

DOC.TEXT: Florida citrus baron Ben Hill Griffin, listed in Forbes magazine as one of the 400 richest Americans, died at his home today after a long illness. He was 79. His secretary, Donna Respress, said Griffin died early today. She had no other details, but said services would be announced later today. Forbes' October 1989 issue put him 261st on the list of wealthy Americans, and said he was worth $390 million. Griffin was a Democratic member of the Florida Legislature for 12 years, serving in both the House and Senate between 1956 and 1968. He ran unsuccessfully for governor in 1974, losing to the incumbent, Reubin Askew. Griffin studied agriculture at the University of Florida in the early 1930s and went on to become the school's largest benefactor. His gifts totaled $14.7 million. Griffin started his citrus empire in 1933, when his father gave him 10 acres of groves as a wedding present. His company, Ben Hill Griffin Inc., owned more than 10,000 acres of citrus groves and 85,000 acres of ranch and timberland in Central Florida. The Griffin family sold its packinghouses and a huge juice processing plant to Procter & Gamble Co. in 1981, which introduced its juice under the Citrus Hill brand name. Doug Bournique, executive vice president of the Indian River Citrus League, described Griffin as one who ``personifies the citrus spirit, the citrus legacy in the state of Florida.'' Last year, Hill resigned as president but remained as chief executive of publicly held Alico Inc., which controls more than 175,000 acres of Florida land managed of leased for various uses, including rock mining, oil and mineral exploration and citrus production. Both companies are now headed by his son, Ben Hill Griffin III.

DOC.HEAD: Du Pont Agrees To Build $1 Billion Complex In Spain
DOC.TEXT: Du Pont and the Spanish government are to invest $1 billion over the next 12 years to build a high-tech industrial complex in the northern region of Asturias under an agreement signed Thursday. Industry Minister Claudio Aranzadi said Spain agreed to put up $300 million, not counting an undisclosed sum by the Asturian regional government, to win the complex, which is to employ 1,000 people in the hard-pressed region by 2001. Du Pont Chairman Edgar S. Woolard, Jr. said the complex, to be inaugurated in 1993 with a $200 billion Nomex fiber plant, would produce a range of chemicals, fibers and polymer products for the fast-growing European market. ``We will bring some of our highest-technology, most specialized products into this site with the objective of supplying the entire European market,'' said Woolard, who signed the agreement with Aranzadi. He said the project would further Du Pont's goal of doubling its annual $5 billion European sales of chemicals, plastics and fibers over the next decade. Both Aranzadi and Woolard said they expected the eventual investment to exceed the agreed-upon $1 billion and added the presence of Du Pont would act as a magnet for small- and mid-sized companies making finished products. Even without the additional companies, Du Pont Iberica Chairman German Lastra said, the complex could be expected to indirectly create an additional 4,000 to 5,000 jobs in the area. The site of the complex is in the Tamon Valley, 6 kilometers (3.7 miles) from the city of Aviles, which is near the Atlantic Ocean. Woolard said it would be at least six months before the company would decide on the product to follow Nomex, an aramid fiber used in aerospace and protective clothing now made exclusively at a Du Pont plant in Richmond, Virginia. But he said the company's commitment to the overall project was firm. ``Du Pont would not be opening this site if there were any possibility that we were going to build Nomex and stop. It would not be of interest to us,'' Woolard said. Construction on the Nomex plant is to begin in August, with production expected to start at the start of 1993, Woolard said. The plant is to employ 300 people. Du Pont Iberica now concentrates mostly on marketing in Spain and Portugal, where it employs 300 people and had sales last year of $200 million, the company said. In Europe, Du Pont employs 20,000 people in 14 countries, and registered $11 billion in sales last year, company officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Appellate Court Extends Sentence For Immigrant Tycoon
DOC.TEXT: An Appellate Court Thursday upheld the conviction and stiffened the sentence of Refaat El-Sayed for fraud and insider trading in the biggest white-collar case ever to reach a S instead of the five years earlier imposed. The court acquitted Gaston Portofaix, the financial manager of El Sayed's former company Fermenta AB, on four counts of swindling. A district court found El-Sayed guilty last July on 14 counts of swindling investers, perjury, insider trading and fraud. He told reporters after Thursday's verdict that he was a scapegoat for the board of his failed company. ``That, and maybe the fact that I did not fall on my knees, cry and say I have wronged, forgive me, may be the reason why I'm convicted in this way,'' he said. El-Sayed, who immigrated in 1964, parlayed his 1981 purchase of the failing biotechnical company Fermenta into a financial empire. His success began to unravel when it was discovered his claim to gave a doctorate degree was phony. The disclosure led to a closer look at the company's transactions, and El-Sayed was found to have put misleading information in annual reports to improve the company's profits and credibility.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were narrowly mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade after rallying in the previous session. Soybean traders were looking for direction after a fairly strong runup Wednesday. Prices were fractionally higher in early trading but buying interest was limited by reports of increased farmer selling of soybeans after Wednesday's close and by slack European demand for soybean meal. Corn futures were fractionally higher, boosted by news that Mexico bought about 188,000 metric tons of U.S. corn overnight. The wheat market was down slightly, pressured by a lack of significant new export business and by forecasts for more precipitation today in some winter wheat areas. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent to 2} cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.90{ a bushel; corn futures were { cent to } cent higher with March at $2.47{ a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 1} cents higher with March at $1.43 a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to \ cent higher with March at $5.67 a bushel. DOC.HEAD: With PM-Seabrook, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS last graf to UPDATE with today's vote.
DOC.TEXT: Here are some key dates in the history of the Seabrook nuclear power plant:
_ May 20: Public Service Company of New Hampshire announces plans to build a single reactor, 860-megawatt nuclear power plant. Project shelved in 1969 mainly for financial reasons.

_ Feb. 1: Public Service revives the project with two 1,150-megawatt reactors, the first planned for commercial operation in 1979, the second in 1981. It initially estimates the project's cost at $973 million.

_ Jan. 5: Ron Rieck becomes the first anti-Seabrook protester arrested after a 36-hour sit-in atop a weather tower at the proposed construction site. _ July 7: Nuclear Regulatory Commission approves construction permit. _ Aug. 1: Anti-nuclear Clamshell Alliance holds first civil disobedience at Seabrook; 18 arrested. Subsequent protests result in about 3,200 arrests, including 1,414 arrests in a May 1977 demonstration that helped make Seabrook a symbol of the U.S. anti-nuclear movement. _ Aug. 5: Groundbreaking. _ September-November: Construction permit suspended, then reinstated within NRC in dispute over environmental effects of nuclear waste.
_ Nov. 9: Environmental Protection Agency revokes earlier approval of cooling system.
_ Aug. 1: Construction resumes following EPA reapproval of cooling system tunnels.
_ Feb. 15: Federal appeals court overturns approval of cooling tunnels. _ Aug. 4: EPA reaffirms approval of tunnels. NRC reinstates construction permit.

_ March 28: Three Mile Island nuclear plant accident in Pennsylvania. NRC subsequently orders 10-mile emergency planning zones around all U.S. commercial reactors, and mandates design changes. _ May: State law barring advance billings for power plants enacted; Public Service forced to borrow more money for Seabrook, raising costs.
_ Sept. 8: Owners effectively agree to halt work on Unit 2. Construction never resumes.

_ March: Public Service discloses a consultant's $9 billion cost estimate for both reactors and lays off most of Seabrook work force; banks freeze company's short-term credit. _ June 23: Public Service obtains $90 million short-term borrowing, owners vote to resume construction on Unit 1.

_ April 29: After the Chernobyl nuclear disaster in the Soviet Union becomes public, Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis says he will delay filing required evacuation plans for the six Massachusetts communities within Seabrook's 10-mile zone. _ July: Plant officials announce completion of Unit 1 and say they are beginning work on their own evacuation plans for Massachusetts, as allowed by NRC. _ Oct. 17: NRC grants Seabrook license to load nuclear fuel and conduct some non-nuclear tests. Fuel loading completed by end of month. _ Nov. 6: Seabrook owners announce they have formally canceled Unit 2, which is 25 percent complete.
_ Nov. 25: NRC finds evacuation plans adequate for low-power testing. But owners encounter new financial problems before the NRC could give final approval for testing.

_ Jan. 28: Public Service files for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of federal bankruptcy code. _ Dec. 21: NRC rules that Seabrook owners' finances don't pose a significant safety concern for low-power testing.

_ May 26: NRC issues license for low-power testing; tests delayed by problems with a valve. _ June 13: Reactor achieves first atomic chain reaction. _ June 22: Valve trouble requires premature halt to tests, but operators delay shutting down the reactor. Seabrook shakes up management and pays fine stemming from a critical NRC review. _ Nov. 7: The Atomic Safety and Licensing Appeal Board raises questions about New Hampshire evacuation plans. The board orders the lower-level Atomic Safety and Licensing Board to review several issues, including adequacy of emergency beach shelters and role of teachers in a nuclear accident. _ Nov. 9: The licensing board authorizes issuance of a full-power license; subject to review by the full commission. The board approves evacuation plans for Massachusetts and says concerns about those plans raised by the appeal board should have no impact on licensing. _ Nov. 13: Members of the Massachusetts congressional delegation call for an investigation of NRC procedures. _ Nov. 16: The NRC said it would override two lower-level boards and immediately begin a review leading to a decision on licensing. _ Dec. 12: U.S. House panel opens inquiry into NRC procedures.

_ Jan. 18: NRC board hears final recommendation from its staff in favor of a Seabrook license. _ Feb. 21: NRC announces it will decide on full-power license on March 1. _ March 1: The NRC licensed the power plant to begin producing commercial electricity. The NRC decision, made in a 3-0 vote ratifying recommendations by the commission's staff and several lower-level boards, sets the stage for the 1,150-megawatt reactor to begin operating at full power within three months.

DOC.HEAD: Beech Aircraft Corp. Destroys Prototype Of Revolutionary Airplane
DOC.TEXT: The prototype of a revolutionary Beech Aircraft Corp. plane has met a controversial death in the California desert where it emerged. Ignoring the pleas of at least one aviation museum and the airplane's designer, Beech has destroyed the original, experimental version of its Starship business aircraft. Because of its graphite and epoxy all-composite construction and its futuristic design, the Starship has attracted much attention since the original model was unveiled in 1983. Some observers said Beech's action reflected the acrimony that exists between top Beech officials and innovative aircraft designer Burt Rutan, who had a major role in the design of the Starship and whose company built the experimental model. A demolition crew hired by Wichita-based Beech broke up the 85-percent scale ``proof-of-concept'' model of the Starship last week. It was being stored in hangar at the Mojave, Calif., airport where it was built and first flown in 1983. A Beech official said Tuesday dismemberment was the usual fate for experimental models. ``We were done with it. It had served its purpose,'' said spokesman Mike Potts. The Experimental Aviation Association, which maintains an air museum in Oshkosh, Wis., had asked Beech to turn the aircraft over to the museum. The company refused. ``We did not believe the airplane was representative of what we ultimately built and certified,'' Potts said, citing many changes in design and construction that were made in the Starship before commercial production began. Potts also said the plane was not in display condition. But EAA President Tom Poberezny said the original Starship model had historic significance, whatever its condition. In addition to having a major role in the original design, Rutan's company, Scaled Composites, built the experimental model. Rutan said the subject of what to do with the experimental model came up a year ago, when Beech officials indicated they wanted to destroy it. ``We got back to them and told them there was nobody here that would take a hammer to it,'' Rutan said. When he heard the plane was going to be demolished, Rutan said he talked to Beech President Max Bleck ``who told me it was none of my business.'' Last fall, Bleck told one industry trade publication that key design and construction problems Beech encountered in developing the Starship for commercial sale were caused largely by inaccurate data gleaned from Rutan's experimental model. Rutan is widely known for his innovative aircraft designs, including the Voyager aircraft that flew around the world non-stop without refueling in 1986 and a new all-composite, low cost military aircraft designed to provide close air support to ground troops. The latter plane was unveiled Monday. At one point, Rutan was an employee of Beech, which bought Scaled Composites in 1985 and launched several other experimental aircraft development programs. Then in 1988, the year after Bleck became president of Beech, the company was sold back to Rutan. Wayman-Gordon, a firm headed by former Beech president James Walsh, now owns Scaled Composites, where Rutan continues work on experimental aircraft.

DOC.NOTE: $adv04
For Release Sunday, March 4
DOC.HEAD: From Variety to Specialty, Woolworth Not Just a Nickel and Dime Operation
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: For Woolworth Corp., America's shopping malls are like hundreds of laboratories, where it tests ideas to create new national chains that specialize in merchandise ranging from costume jewelry to running shoes. The retailer once known for dowdy dimestores that sell trinkets and doodads has become the owner of an unusually wide variety of stores. It isn't just the owner of variety stores. Woolworth's powerhouse of more than 40 different specialty chains is paced by its all-star Foot Locker. Analysts say the company may have more of what it will take to outrun the competition than any other big American retailer. A record of 29 straight quarterly profit improvements illustrates the New York-based company's successful retailing science. This past week Woolworth reported record earnings for the fourth quarter and full year. In 1989, the company earned $329 million, or $5.11 a share, up 14 percent from $288 million, or $4.47 a share, in 1988. Revenue rose 9.1 percent to $8.82 billion from $8.09 billion. Harold E. Sells, chairman and chief executive officer, said Woolworth will follow a proven formula in trying to keep the streak alive. ``We feel we know the specialty store business as well if not better than any other retailer in the world. That's what we're going to stick to _ what we know best,'' he said in an interview. The company constantly examines properties to see if they meet the rigorous standards necessary to join the fold, maybe taking a serious look at a couple a month. Candidates must have the potential to go nationwide and have better financial performances than the corporation's overall goals of a 13 percent return on investment and a 20 percent annual return on beginning common equity. Acquisitions in recent years have been small, of about 100 stores or fewer each. Sells said bigger deals could be forthcoming. ``Our balance sheet is very strong today. We have the capability of doing a major acquisition if the opportunity did present itself,'' he said. But don't look for Woolworth to go after any department stores currently on the block, such as the upscale Saks or Marshall Fields. ``We have no plans at all to become interested in any of the chains that are on the market today,'' said Sells. Areas in which Woolworth does have interest include anything to do with serving an aging population, health and beauty aids and deep discount drugs, where it already has a presence with its Rx Place stores. Woolworth's apparel operations were restructured recently to accomodate a possible acquisition. What Woolworth seems to excel at is devising its own concepts or spinning strings of small stores by linking existing chains. New free-standing shops are evolved from individual departments in its variety stores. Afterthoughts, for example, a retailer of costume jewelry, handbags and accessories, is one of Woolworth's successful specialty retailers and it sprung from the variety stores. Champs Sports, a sporting goods retailer, was the offspring of a union of two Florida-based chains. Over the past two years Woolworth has expanded Champs to 199 stores from 90 when the match was made. Sells said by 2000, there should be 1,000 Champs dotted throughout almost every major U.S. mall. ``Landlords love it because of the size,'' Sells said, noting that mall owners who want a sporting goods tenant but don't want to commit huge amounts of space prefer to lease to Champs, which packs an assortment of athletic merchandise into about 4,500 square feet. Sells, an Arkansas native who began his retailing career in 1945 at the Kinney Shoe Corp., which Woolworth acquired in 1963, said the company tries to cultivate an entrepreneurial spirit. ``We encourage our operating people in the divisions to come up with new ideas _ a new niche of specialty store retailing that we may not be in today but we feel there's an opportunity,'' said Sells. If Sells and a handful of colleagues approve, the concept gets tested. In this phase Woolworth opens about five stores, investing a couple of hundred thousand dollars in each. After a year to two, Woolworth decides whether it has a winner. ``For a million dollars we can do this experiment,'' Sells said. ``We consider that our R and D money.'' A mall, he said, is ``like our laboratory.'' Not all experiments work out well. Last year Woolworth gave the heave-ho to two unprofitable duds: Frame Scene, a retailer of prints and frames, and Face Fantasies, a bargain-priced cosmetics outlet. Woolworth makes the best of its flops by refilling the retail space with more promising concepts, said Sells. Kurt Barnard, a New York-based retail consultant, said much of Woolworth's strength lies in its clout with landlords and streamlined buying ability. Having numerous popular stores within the same mall gives Woolworth an advantage in negotiating leases. Having stores with overlapping focuses _ for instance Afterthoughts and Woolworth variety stores _ makes ordering inventory more efficient and economical. If Woolworth has had a weakness it could be the five-and-ten-cent stores operated by the century-old-plus general merchandise division. The company has recognized its shortcoming; about 200 U.S. Woolworths were closed in the second half of the 1980s and many of the rest were renovated and remerchandised. A smaller, leaner version of the variety stores _ pared to core brisk sellers such as budget cosmetics, greeting cards, candies and seasonal items like Christmas decorations and Halloween masks _ have become familiar mall inhabitants. Woolworth Express shops do $250 to $300 per square foot in sales and average about 6,000 square feet in size. The regular variety stores, averaging 17,000 square feet, did $110 in sales per square foot in 1988. In the future, one real plus for Woolworth is its experience outside its home turf. It runs stores in Australia, Canada and West Germany. Woolworth has a toehold in Europe that could prove beneficial. Foot Locker has the muscle to become the dominant sports shoe chain in Europe, as it is in the United States, analysts say. Before World War II Woolworth ran 32 stores in what is now East Germany and Poland. The stores were taken over by the government. Sells said the company is awaiting the outcome of March 18 elections in East Germany and if signs are favorable Woolworth will try to open for business there again. ``We have somewhat of an advantage,'' Sells said. ``People remember the Woolworth name.''
DOC.HEAD: End of Adv Sunday, March 4

DOC.NOTE: $adv04
For Release Sunday, March 4
DOC.HEAD: Foot Locker Leads Pack of Prosperous Woolworth Chains
With BC-Woolworth
DOC.TEXT: Woolworth Corp., formed last June as the holding company for the 111-year-old F.W. Woolworth Co., also is the parent of dozens of specialty retail chains operating in the United States and abroad. The company, from its headquarters in a historic landmark building in Manhattan, oversees an empire of mostly small stores. Many evolved after Woolworth undertook a major corporate reconfiguration in the early 1980s. ``Woolworth restructured before it became a buzzword,'' Chairman and Chief Executive Officer Harold E. Sells says. In one stroke, Woolworth closed 372 struggling Woolco discount department stores in the United States. It shed a 52.5 percent stake in Woolworth in the United Kingdom. At the same time, ``We decided to explode our specialty store concept,'' Sells says. The Foot Locker chain of athletic shoe stores was launched in 1974 by Woolworth's Kinney Shoe Corp. division. Kinney had joined the Woolworth fold 11 years earlier. Foot Locker became the leading growth vehicle for Woolworth in the 1980s. By the end of last year, more than 1,300 Foot Lockers were operating worldwide, up from around 200 at the start of the decade. Sales at Foot Locker reached an estimated $1.2 billion in 1989. Its success spawned Lady Foot Locker, designed to attract women who might have been put off by the male-oriented jock approach of Foot Locker. The two begat Kids Foot Locker. There are now 511 Lady Foot Lockers in the United States and Canada and 23 the junior version. The popularity of Foot Locker and its offspring coincided with a boom in fitness that has shown staying power. ``It will continue to be strong in the '90s and into the next century,'' Sells predicts. He notes that Foot Locker isn't dependent on sports fanatics for business; an estimated 80 percent of all shoes sold in a Foot Locker aren't sold for a specific sport. Woolworth intends to extend its Foot Locker chain in Europe, where it already is operating in West Germany. The acquisition, now in the final stages, of Profoot Nederland BV assets will further Foot Locker's expansion plans. Profoot, selling sports shoes and apparel, has 10 stores in the Netherlands and 4 in Belgium. Here are brief descriptions of some other chains that are pieces of the retailing company that got its start when Frank Winfield Woolworth opened a five-and-ten-cent store in Lancaster, Penn., in 1879: _Afterthoughts, made up of 349 boutiques, sells costume jewelry, handbags and other accessories. It operates under the name Rubins in West Germany. _Champs Sports is a 199-store chain of athletic goods stores. The company expects to open these shops aggressively in the 1990s and have around 1,000 of them by 2000. _Herald Square Party Shops carry party goods, greeting cards and stationery at 26 stores. _Kids Mart-Little Folk shops are low-priced brand-name infants' and children's apparel chains of 435 stores. _Raglans is a unisex casual apparel 42-store chain in Canada. _Richman Brothers and Anderson-Little stores sell men's and women's apparel and furnishings in 288 stores. _Susie's is a chain of 224 women's clothing stores in the United States.
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Sunday March 4

DOC.HEAD: Union Sues Nordstrom Over Wages, Decertification Campaign Announced
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS with 12 grafs to update with pro-Nordstrom demonstration and campaign to decertify union; edits below to tighten and conform; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Employees rallied in support of their Nordstrom bosses today and announced a decertification campaign against a union that has sued the fashion retailer over alleged violations of wage and hour laws. About 250 people attended the rally outside Nordstrom's flagship store one day after the suit by two United Food & Commercial Workers locals and five current and former Nordstrom employees. The suit was filed in King County Superior Court on behalf of approximately 50,000 present and former company workers in Washington, Oregon, California, Virginia, Utah and Alaska. It was the second class-action suit in as many days. The first was filed by shareholders who said Nordstrom should have known the wage and hour problems would hurt the company's earnings. The effort to remove UFCW Locals 1001 and 367 as bargaining agent for about 1,500 Nordstrom workers in the Seattle-Tacoma area was announced today at the pro-company rally at Westlake Plaza. Dozens attending the rally carried signs saying ``Nobody Asked Me _ I Support Nordstrom'' and chanted, ``One, two, three, four. No more union any more,'' and ``We love Nordstrom.'' Marv Treadwell, who works in the men's suits department in Tacoma, said petitions calling for an election on whether to retain representation by Local 367 had been signed by 40 percent of the workers eligible to vote at his store. Greg Helean, a women's shoe sales clerk in Bellevue, said similar petitions would be circulated starting today in Seattle. On Tuesday three Nordstrom shareholders filed suit in U.S. District Court, claiming they and other stockholders suffered financial losses because of the pay problems and that company officers failed to disclose those problems. Nationally, Nordstrom has 60 stores and employs about 30,000. Local 1001 president Joe Peterson said in a telephone interview that union officials were preparing more complaints accusing the company of unfair labor practices after getting numerous complaints of management pressure to sign petitions supporting Nordstrom, attend the rally and support a decertification campaign. Larry McCarger, assistant to the regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, said the decertification petitions probably would not be considered until pending unfair labor practice complaints are resolved _ a process that could take three months or longer. The board also could dismiss the petitions if they are found to be the result of company violations of labor laws or regulations, McCarger said. Nordstrom has a near-legendary reputation for customer service, with polite and attentive sales clerks, a no-questions-asked return policy, and personal notes from employees to good customers. But on Feb. 15, the Washington Department of Labor and Industries ruled Nordstrom had violated state laws by failing to pay some employees for time worked outside normal working hours. The state, acting on a UFCW complaint, said workers had not been properly compensated for such things as attending meetings, delivering merchandise to other stores and customers, doing inventory work or writing thank-you notes. In releasing its annual earnings Monday, Nordstrom said it had made a $15 million provision for expected back pay claims by employees and adopted a procedure to handle the claims. The charge against fourth-quarter earnings was cited by the company as one reason why profits fell 34 percent in the period ending Jan. 31. Peterson called the $15 million too little and threatened the suit if Nordstrom failed to negotiate a back-pay settlement with the union. Nordstrom said claims forms had been sent to sales clerks in states other than Washington. In Washington the forms must be reviewed by the state's labor office and by the two union locals.

DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished lower Thursday after a dreary session on London's Stock Exchange, pushed down by a poor performance earlier in Tokyo and an uninspiring start on Wall Street. Trading got off to a rocky start in the wake of the news of another dramatic drop in Tokyo. This sent the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index below the key 2,250 level from which it was not able to recover. Wall Street's early performance made matters worse, market watchers said. By the close of the London day, the Dow Jones industrial average was off 0.67 point at 2,626.58. Traders described the market as quiet and featureless. ``It's one of the worst days for business in recent memory,'' one London dealer said. ``I've spoken with dealers all over the city and we're all in the same boat.'' At the London close, the FT-SE 100-share index was 17 points, or 0.8 percent, lower at 2,238.4, close to its session low of 2,236.0. The Financial Times 30-share index fell 16.5 points to close at 1,764.9. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 9.12 points to close at 1,215.89. Volume came to a light 376.9 million shares, little changed from 365.9 million shares Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier to Unveil New Campaign, First Bottles Seen at Soccer Match
DOC.TEXT: Perrier will unveil plans to relaunch its sparkling water worldwide next week, the company said Thursday after giving soccer fans a sneak preview of bottles filled since benzene contamination prompted a global recall two weeks ago. Anne Lamour, a spokeswoman for Source Perrier SA, refused to say whether new cases of the popular drink would be shipped around the world simultaneously or sent a few at a time to the 120 countries affected by the recall. No specific date has been set for the announcement of the plan and details of new production methods. The company has increased production at Perrier's spring at Vergeze in southern France, but Mrs. Lamour declined to say whether 160 million new bottles had been filled to replace recalled stocks. Perrier had issued a statement on Monday that its water could return to stores within two months, once the company implemented new procedures to prevent a recurrence of the contamination. Perrier withdrew 72 million bottles from the United States markets in early February after traces of benzene were discovered in Perrier samples from several markets. The recall was expanded worldwide on Feb. 14 after contamination was found in other countries. The naturally occuring benzene entered Perrier's bottling line when workers failed to replace a filter carrying carbon dioxide gas from the underground spring to the bottling plant, executives said. About 22,000 soccer fans got the first public glimpse of Perrier bottled since the recall during a soccer match Wednesday between France and West Germany. Company repesentatives displayed two cases of the pear-shaped, 1-liter bottles with green letters reading ``nouvelle production,'' but the water was not for sale. When the recall was announced, Perrier executives said it might take 2{ months to restock shelves with untainted water. Mrs. Lamour said original estimates have proven correct that the recall would put a $35 million dent in Perrier's profits. Perrier sent a telex to domestic distributors last week saying they would receive new bottles March 1, but Mrs. Lamour said that date has been pushed back to at least next week. The French recall has been voluntary. The company asked distributors to return the bottles to Vergeze for cleaning and refilling or to destroy them on site. Mrs. Lamour said about 48 million of the 50 million bottles on French shelves before the recall have been accounted for, with a quarter of those refilled.
