DOC.HEAD: Government Decides Not to Prosecute in Harrods Takeover
DOC.TEXT: The government said Thursday it would not pursue a criminal prosecution in connection with the 1985 takeover of Harrods' owner House of Fraser PLC by the Al-Fayed brothers. The decision by the Serious Fraud Office and the Director of Public Prosecutions comes after a 20-month investigation. It was a major setback for Roland ``Tiny'' Rowland, the Lonrho PLC chairman who was a rival bidder for Harrods. He has waged a long, expensive and very public campaign to have the 615 million-pound ($1 billion) takeover reversed. At one point during the bitter feud, House of Fraser Chairman Mohamed Al-Fayed said ``only God'' would take the world-renowned department store away from him. The authorities also said they had dropped their objection to the publication of a report resulting from a Department of Trade and Industry investigation into the takeover. Trade Secretary Nicholas Ridley said in a written reply to a question in the House of Commons that he would publish the report on Wednesday. ``I do not intend to take any further action,'' he said. Lonrho said Thursday that it welcomed what it called the ``overdue'' decision to publish the report. ``When the public and the City sees the contents of the report, there will be a demand for action. Lonrho is not permitted to comment on the report until it is published. Lonrho will then make its views clear.'' The City is London's financial district. Lonrho, which has failed in its repeated attempts to have the takeover referred to the Monopolies and Mergers Commission, had pressed for the release of the report, which it says supports its criticisms of the Al-Fayeds. Lonrho repeatedly has alleged that the Al-Fayeds misrepresented their background and wealth to win Harrods, allegations which they have denied. A year ago, Lonrho published what it said were extracts from the trade department's report in a special midweek edition of its Sunday newspaper The Observer. The trade department immediately blocked its circulation. The trade secretary at the time, Lord Young, said he wanted to publish the report but that he had been asked by the Serious Fraud Office not to divulge details, to avoid prejudicing any criminal proceedings. Those objections were dropped Thursday. In a statement, the public prosecution and serious fraud offices said their directors were ``now satisfied that all lines of inquiry have been pursued and that the evidence available is insufficient to afford a realistic prospect of conviction for any criminal offense relating to any matter of substance raised in the report.'' House of Fraser issued a statement saying it was heartened that the episode was behind it and that it could now concentrate of developing the business. ``It is doubtful that any takeover here or abroad has been subjected to such exhaustive scrutiny,'' it said. Al-Fayed thanked his friends, colleagues and customers ``who have been so kind and constantly supportive during an unsettling past five years.''

DOC.HEAD: Varian Names Rockwell Executive as Chairman
DOC.TEXT: Varian Associates Inc. has named an outsider, J. Tracy O'Rourke of Rockwell International Corp., as chairman and chief executive officer to try to turn around the electronics company's flagging fortunes. O'Rourke, 54, who succeeds Thomas D. Sege, was one of three executive vice presidents and chief operating officers at Rockwell. Sege, Varian's chief executive since 1981, was appointed Wednesday as vice chairman of the board. Varian's board began a search last summer for a replacement for Sege, 63, who said he wanted to step out of the CEO's role prior to reaching 65. While many industry analysts were unfamiliar with O'Rourke, they said his track record created hope that the company could begin to improve its financial performance. ``The bottom line is the guy's a heavyweight, very heavyweight, and I can't be more positive on what this means for Varian going forward,'' said Stephen J. Balong, an analyst at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. in New York. Varian has about 12,000 employees and had 1989 sales of $1.3 billion. It produces systems and components for communications, defense, scientific, medical and industrial markets worldwide.

DOC.HEAD: Four in 10 Still Jobless After Manufacturing Recession
DOC.TEXT: About four in 10 workers laid off at steel mills and manufacturing centers in the depressed Monongahela Valley since the early 1980s are still out of work, according to the results of a survey released Thursday. In addition, those who are employed bring home paychecks of 40 to 68 percent less than their former wages. The survey, which was drafted by steel industry and labor groups, covered responses of 3,500 workers who lost their jobs during the steel industry's recession in the early- and mid-1980s. Questionnaires were sent to 16,000 of the estimated 40,000 workers laid off in the last decade. ``This is not only wrong for the people who are trying to live, but this is a waste of resources for the area,'' said Mike Stout, the study's coordinator and a staff member of the Tri-State Conference on Steel. The survey says 18 percent of respondents once used computers, 11 percent operated heavy equipment containing computers, 22 percent monitored quality-control systems and 38 percent read blueprints. Stout said, ``It's a problem that has been forgotten and covered up for a long time.'' Stout once worked at USX Corp.'s Homestead works, where the workforce was cut by 6,000 in the 1980s. Other major cutbacks in the 1980s were 7,800 workers at Westinghouse's Turtle Creek plant, 3,800 workers at USX's McKeesport plant and 3,500 at LTV's Pittsburgh works. In addition to lower or no wages, the workers reported family breakups, fewer benefits, poorer working conditions and unsafe workplaces. Workers who responded were listed on the rolls of the United Steelworkers of America, United Electrical Workers and the Pennsylvania division of the AFL-CIO. One-third who are employed said they work part-time and 57 percent said they were discriminated against because of their ages. The average age of the respondents was 50. ``No one wants a 54-year-old ex-steelworker who belonged to a union,'' wrote one respondent. The survey criticizes politicians for relying on jobs in service industries to try to pump life back into local industries, Stout said.

DOC.HEAD: Wheat Futures Dive On Slack Demand, Good Crop Weather
DOC.TEXT: Wheat futures prices fell sharply Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting sluggish export demand and improved growing conditions for the hard red winter wheat crop. Corn futures also closed lower while soybeans ended mostly higher. Wheat futures had risen strongly last week and early this week amid expectations that a small number of delivery notices would be posted Wednesday, the first day for players to announce their intentions to deliver grain against the March wheat contract. No March wheat delivery notices were posted Wednesday, validating market expectations, and on Thursday traders focused on the market's bearish supply-and-demand factors. ``Export business remains very lackluster and the hard red winter wheat has benefited from improved soil moisture,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc., a brokers' advisory service in Chicago. A National Weather Service six-to-10-day outlook issued Wednesday predicted above-average rain for winter-wheat areas, which prompted further selling, Karlin said. At the close, wheat futures were 4\ cents to 5\ cents lower with the contract for delivery in March at $3.89 a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to 1 cent lower with March at $2.46\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1{ cents higher with March at $1.43{ a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 3 cents higher with March at $5.67\ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Down This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 211,559 cars and light trucks this week, down from last week's 218,524, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 247,038 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 130,815 cars this week, compared with 138,029 a week ago and 153,560 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 80,744, compared with last week's 80,495 and last year's 93,478. Canadian automakers were to build 25,142 cars this week, up from 23,531 a week ago and up from last year's 19,870. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 20,504, compared with 20,063 a week ago and 22,088 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Drexel Says It Not Taking Money From Brokerage Unit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs to CORRECT judge's first name to Howard; PICKS UP 6th graf pvs, `Barry J....
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Drexel-Congress Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An attorney for Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. said Thursday that the company is not siphoning money from its brokerage subsidiary, which is liquidating billions of dollars in securities and other assets. Creditors of the collapsed Wall Street firm raised concerns that money available to satisfy what they said were about $500 million in claims against the brokerage subsidiary was being reduced. The brokerage firm, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., is not subject to the Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings of its parent. Drexel has liquidated more than 86 percent of some $47 billion in securities holdings as well as other assets since the bankruptcy filing Feb. 13. Also, the Securities and Exchange Commission said in court papers that it is Drexel's largest creditor and asked to be placed on the main committee negotiating in bankruptcy court. But U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Howard C. Buschman III delayed a hearing on the motion, which claims that Drexel owes the SEC $150 million for a fund to compensate investors allegedly defrauded by Drexel securities law violations. Barry J. Dichter, an attorney for creditor Banco de Portugal, said about $500 million in creditors' claims exist at the subsidiary level. He said he was concerned that money being generated by Drexel's liquidation would be transferred to the parent and made subject to claims in the bankruptcy case. ``That cash that's being generated ... is creditors' cash, not the parent's cash,'' Dichter said. In the days leading up to the bankruptcy filing, the parent company took about $300 million from the subsidiary to meet short-term debt payments after it was unable to borrow money in the credit markets. It filed for bankruptcy after defaulting on some debt and failing to obtain bank loans. Drexel attorney Alan Miller said in court that Drexel's subsidiaries were liquidating ``at arm's length'' from the parent and were not sending money raised by asset sales into the parent. Also Thursday, Buschman postponed a hearing on a motion by First City Bancorp. of Texas seeking a court-appointed examiner to oversee Drexel's books and one by Drexel asking that three board members monitor the liquidation. The parties agreed to the delay to negotiate. The judge held a closed hearing with attorneys for the SEC, California Public Employees' Retirement System and creditors committee to try to resolve the motions seeking spots on the panel. Reporters for The Associated Press, The New York Times and the Los Angeles Times objected to the closed-door session, which the judge said constituted a settlement conference and therefore was permissible. Drexel has paid the SEC $200 million for a $350 million fund to compensate investors. Final installments are due in September and in September 1992. The fund is part of a deal in which Drexel last year pleaded guilty to six felonies and began paying $650 million in penalties to resolve charges stemming from a government insider trading investigation. Both the parent and subsidiary signed the agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Champion Farmer Spills Beans About Secret Formula
LaserPhoto CU1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf bgng Hassenbring's yield... to CORRECT spelling to Hasselbring.
DOC.TEXT: Walter Hasselbring's secrets for achieving the nation's highest corn yield are a lot of bull. The national corn king credits his top-notch crop to generous applications of the real thing from his cattle and his buffalo herd, Illinois' largest. But he teases unsuspecting visitors with another success secret, telling them he grew 296 bushels per acre last year by serenading his corn. ``I tell them plants respond to music, so at crucial times I stroll through my cornfields singing to the plants and you can almost see them grow,'' chuckled Hasselbring, who has grown the nation's best-yielding corn crop seven times in the last 15 years. The National Corn Growers Association sponsors the contest, and 2,057 farmers entered during the 1989 growing season. There were seven divisions, depending on the type of tillage, the area of the country and whether irrigation was used. ``Farmers compete not only to see who can grow the most corn but also to come up with new management ideas that could make all farmers more efficient,'' said John Campen of the St. Louis-based association. Hasselbring's yield was the highest in the 1989 contest, said Campen, and established a U.S. record, topping his 1975 mark of nearly 289 bushels per acre. His winning yield was more than twice the 138-bushel-per-acre average in Iroquois County, where Hasselbring farms 1,800 acres in east-central Illinois with his two sons. ``You can do everything else right, but if you don't get the rain, you won't win,'' Hasselbring said in an interview Wednesday. A high level of fertility also is crucial. Hasselbring uses about 300 pounds of nitrogen per acre _ roughly twice his normal rate. He adds manure from his cattle herd and his 105 buffalo. Farmers pay $50 to enter the competition. They plant a contest plot of at least 25 acres. Hasselbring's corn went in May 5, and the growing season was ideal. As the crop matured, Hasselbring walked his contest field. ``I could tell things were looking up,'' he said. ``After all these years farming, you just get an inkling of what's going on. But, when it was harvested, it was even more than we expected.'' Judges approved by the National Corn Growers Association supervise the harvest of at least 1.25 acres from each contest plot. Hasselbring's was combined Nov. 13-14. Rules require farmers to harvest at random intervals so they cannot pick the best area of the field. University of Illinois agronomists Fred Welch and Bob Hoeft agree with Hasselbring that shooting for 300-bushel yields on a large acreage is a big gamble given high growing costs and the inability to control weather. ``Winning might not mean getting the best dollar-return for your inputs, and it is profit, not a record yield, that is really important for commercial farmers,'' Welch said. Although the national corn surplus is approaching 2 billion bushels, the idea that more corn means less profits isn't what would keep farmers from adopting high-yield techniques, Campen said. It is the expense of producing such yields. ``The economics, at least today, on a broad scale basis wouldn't warrant it,'' he said. Officials at Fred Gutwein & Sons Inc., a family-owned corn and soybean seed company based in Francesville, Ind., that provided hybrids to Hasselbring, said his success improved Gutwein name recognition and sales. ``Our hybrid met the challenge,'' said sales manager Eric Gutwein. ``But, it takes a very special individual like `Duke' Hasselbring to achieve the pinnacle seven times.''

DOC.HEAD: Fell $1.90 Billion in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 499 money market mutual funds fell $1.90 billion in the latest week to $388.79 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline for the seven-day period ended Wednesday followed a $3.59 billion rise the previous week to an all time high of $390.69 billion. The Washington-based mutual fund trade group originally had reported the rise as $3.57 billion to a record $390.68 billion but revised the figures this week. The institute said the subsequent drop reflected an investor shift out of money market funds into stocks and bonds, which showed surprising strength relative to other investments. It said for the latest week, assets of 245 general purpose funds fell $151.5 million to $132.4 billion, assets of 101 broker-dealer funds fell $598.6 million to $164.86 billion, and assets of 153 institutional funds fell $1.15 billion to $91.54 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds in the week ended Tuesday remained unchanged from the previous week at 7.65 percent, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.65 percent from 7.67 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 43 days, unchanged, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.27 percent as of Wednesday from 6.28 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, remained unchanged at 5.07 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.87 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, unchanged from the previous week. Yields were 7.94 percent on 1-year CDs, up from 7.93 percent; 7.96 percent on 2{-year CDs, up from 7.95 percent; and 8 percent on 5-year CDs, up from 7.99 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Independent Label Gets Bid from British Group
DOC.TEXT: Thorn EMI, which has been expanding its music operations beyond its Capitol Records label, has offered to buy or distribute Geffen Records, the home of Cher, Guns N' Roses, Whitesnake and Aerosmith. Geffen, one of the last big independent U.S. labels, has had a close relationship with Time Warner Inc.'s music division, which manufactures and distributes its records in return for a 50 percent share of profits. Geffen Records' 10-year deal with Warner expires at the end of the year, but Geffen owner David Geffen said he hopes to reach a decision on the fate of his company well before then. Geffen previously denied seeking a buyer for his West Hollywood-based label, which is said to be worth as much as $750 million. He said he is still talking with Time Warner and that Thorn had ``made me an offer,'' although he added, ``that's hardly a deal.'' Sharon Christians, director of corporate affairs for Thorn EMI in London, would not say if an agreement was near but acknowledged that talks had occurred. Thorn EMI has been expanding its music portfolio recently, responding to consolidation in the music industry and a booming international market for entertainment. It purchased a 50 percent stake in Chrysalis records last year, and Thorn EMI officials have said they are close to making a deal to buy a 50 percent stake in Hungary's state recording company, Hungaroton, for $15 million. The conglomerate's pretax profit for the six months ending Sept. 30 was $171 million, up 12 percent from the previous period.

DOC.HEAD: TVA Cutting Nuclear Staff By 1,400 Employees
DOC.TEXT: The Tennessee Valley Authority said Thursday it will cut about 1,400 jobs from its nuclear power plants by Oct. 1. TVA nuclear chief Oliver Kingsley Jr. said the reductions, which will include layoffs, will lower TVA's nuclear force to 6,100 salaried workers. The cuts are the second phase of a job reduction plan announced last April. TVA had projected it would have 6,800 employees at its six nuclear plants on Oct. 1. Kingsley said the cuts reflected TVA's progress in recovering from safety and management problems that forced it to shut down its nuclear program from August 1985 until May 1988. He said the cuts would ``move TVA a step closer to making its nuclear power staffing levels comparable to industry averages by 1992.'' TVA also plans to reduce its nuclear contractors by more than 75 percent this year, from a current level of about 2,700 hourly workers. TVA had 14,380 annual and hourly nuclear employees when it restarted Sequoyah Nuclear Plant in early 1988 after a 33-month outage and continued repairs on two other plants. More than 4,000 jobs were eliminated over the next year, and in April 1989 TVA announced plans to cut its total nuclear staff to 9,363 employees by Oct. 1 of that year and to 7,508 _ including 6,800 salaried workers _ by Oct. 1, 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Glut Prompts Plunge in Oil Futures
DOC.TEXT: A virtual glut of gasoline prompted heavy selling of petroleum futures Thursday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. On other commodity markets, coffee futures surged to new 7{-month highs; precious metals advanced; grain and soybean futures were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. On the New York Merc, West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 28 cents to 37 cents lower with the contract for delivery in April at $21.17 a barrel; wholesale home heating oil was 1.13 cents to 1.93 cents lower with April at 54.63 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .80 cent to 2.43 cents lower with April at 55.81 cents a gallon. The April gasoline contract led the way down, trading as low as 54.70 cents a gallon amid reports of burdensome gasoline supplies. ``We've got so much of it, as a matter of fact, that on the East Coast they're having some difficulty finding available storage for all this stuff,'' said Jim Ritterbusch, energy analyst with PaineWebber Inc. He said demand for gasoline was off about 5 percent from a year ago, possibly reflecting weakness in the economy. The price slide runs contrary to the normal seasonal pattern of rising prices for petroleum products at this time of year as some oil refiners shut down to retool for greater gasoline production after concentrating on making heating oil for the winter months. Peter Beutel, head of the energy trading group at Elders Futures Inc., said the so-called turnaround season is already underway but the markets aren't responding as they usually do. ``It just seems at this point, there is too great a supply and not enough demand,'' he said. Coffee futures rose sharply for the second straight day on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange, reaffirming a strong upward trend linked to tight near-term supplies and constructive chart signals. Some support stemmed from reports that Mexican roasters may need to import up to 400,000 132-pound bags of coffee to meet a domestic shortfall caused by a Christmastime freeze. Analyst Celeste Georkakis of Cargill Investor Services Inc. said the market was unlikely to encounter much resistance until the May contract approaches $1 a pound, a price last recorded for that contract on July 6. Coffee futures settled 1.02 cents to 3.94 cents higher with March at 96.75 cents a pound, the highest settlement of a near-month coffee future since July 5. Gold and silver futures rose modestly on New York's Commodity Exchange. Silver's rally, the second in as many days, erased the rest of the losses posted Wednesday. Gold futures settled unchanged to 10 cents higher with April at $409 a troy ounce; silver was 2.5 cents to 3.1 cents higher with March at $5.154 a troy ounce. Wheat futures fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting slack export demand and improved growing conditions for the hard red winter wheat crop. Corn futures also closed lower while soybeans ended mostly higher. Wheat settled 4 cents to 5 cents lower with March at $3.89\ a bushel; corn was \ cent to } cent lower with March at $2.46\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 2\ cents higher with March at $1.43{ a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 3 cents higher with March at $5.67\ a bushel. Frozen pork-belly futures fell steeply and hog futures also retreated on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange amid concerns over heavy hog slaughter levels and weaker-than-expected cash markets. Cattle futures advanced for the third day in a row on expectations for stronger cash markets. Live cattle futures finished .07 cent to .47 cent higher with April at 75.92 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .22 cent higher with March at 80.50 cents a pound; live hogs were .05 cent to .40 cent lower with April at 49.95 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .50 cent to 1.23 cents lower with March at 50.12 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises, Gold Price Up Marginally
Preced LONDON BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar continued its climb against most major foreign currencies Thursday, boosted by reports showing strength in the U.S. economy and by economic uncertainty in Japan. Gold prices were slightly higher. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a bid for gold at $406.70 a troy ounce as of 4 p.m. EST, up 5 cents from late Wednesday. The National Association of Purchasing Management said the nation's economy declined in February for the 10th consecutive month, but at the lowest rate since last June. In other economic reports, the Commerce Department said personal income rose 0.8 percent in January, consumer spending increased 0.6 percent and construction spending rose 1.8 percent for the month. The construction figure was the biggest increase in more than a year. Craig Sloane, a currency futures analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co., said the reports ``seemed to paint the picture that the economy is doing all right.'' Traders said the Federal Reserve sold dollars in an attempt to halt the currency's rise against the yen, but the intervention appeared to have limited impact. The yen was weakened by the slump in the Tokyo stock market, said Chris Mendell, a vice president at Security Pacific Bank in Los Angeles. The market's key Nikkei index fell 762.41 points, or 2.20 percent, closing at 33,829.58. Sloane said the dollar flirted with the 150-yen level, but never reached it. The West German mark continued to be hurt by concern that a plan for exchanging East German marks for their West German counterpart would cause inflation, Ms. Mendell said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 149.78 yen from 148.52 yen Wednesday. Later, in London, the dollar traded lower at 149.67 yen. But in New York, the dollar rose to 149.85 from 149.08 late Wednesday. The dollar has not closed that high against the yen in New York since June 15, when it reached 151.30 yen. The dollar also rose against the British pound. In London, one British pound cost $1.6655 late Thursday, cheaper for buyers than Wednesday's $1.6895. In New York, the pound closed at $1.6640, down from $1.6752 late Wednesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late rates Wednesday, included: 1.7194 West German marks, up from 1.7074; 1.5095 Swiss francs, up from 1.5010; 5.8070 French francs, up from 5.7695; 1,267.25 Italian lire, up from 1,260.75; and 1.1910 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1927. Late rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.7145 West German marks, up from 1.6955; 1.5060 Swiss francs, up from 1.4900; 5.7935 French francs, up from 5.7300; 1.9307 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9070; 1,266.00 Italian lire, up from 1,250.00; and 1.1899 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2072. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold for current delivery rose 10 cents a troy ounce to $406.20. Earlier, gold closed in London at a bid price of $407.75 a troy ounce, down from $407.90. In Zurich, it also closed at a bid $407.75, down from $407.79. In Hong Kong, gold closed at $405.85 bid, down from $409.25. Silver traded late in London at $5.16 bid a troy ounce, up from $5.10. In New York, silver for current delivery rose to $5.154 an ounce from $5.127 late Wednesday on the Commodity Exchange.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Advance Despite Continued Economic Slowdown
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Prices closed higher on Wall Street Thursday as the stock market found a silver lining in a downbeat report on the economy. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 8.34 to 2,635.59. Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by about 4 to 3 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 843 up, 633 down and 493 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to a moderate 157.93 million shares, down from 184.41 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 185.31 million shares. The monthly survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management indicated that the manufacturing economy declined in February for the 10th consecutive month, but at the lowest rate since last June. The financial markets at first believed the report was unlikely to prompt the Federal Reserve to nudge interest rates lower. The bond market responded negatively, with the Treasury's bellwether 30-year bond off about $6.87 for each $1,000 in face value by late afternoon. Wall Street initially took its cue from the reaction among bond traders, but then began to move ahead on its own. Analysts said Wall Street has begun to accept the fact that interest rates aren't going to come down anytime soon, in part because U.S. rates must stay high to remain competitive with yields in West Germany, Japan and other countries. The market also realizes that higher rates are necessary to control inflation, the analysts said. Jack Barbanel, president of First Global Asset Management Inc., said the market, instead of focusing on interest rates, was more concerned about the possibility of recession. Traders interpreted the purchasing managers report as a signal that the economy, although slowing, won't tip into a recession, he said. But traders lack conviction in the strength of the stock market, Barbanel said, noting that as the market reached its high _ with the Dow Jones average crossing 2,655 _ investors began to take profits. The market shrugged off another sharp loss on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average fell 762.41 points, or 2.20 percent, Thursday, closing at 33,829.58, but there was no perceivable impact in New York. The most active issue on the NYSE was Union Carbide, which fell 2 to 22\ after the chemical company decided against a restructuring. USAir Group fell 1 to 31. A published report said investor Marvin Davis had acquired 5 percent of the airline's stock. Among blue chip stocks, Philip Morris fell 1 to 36, AT&T was up [ to 39~ and Exxon slipped { to 46{. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $9.770 billion, or 0.31 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.45 to 183.52. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.00 to 383.02, and S&P's 500-stock composite index advanced 0.85 to 332.74. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market picked up 1.38 to close at 427.21. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 354.04, up 1.14.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Measures Rise
DOC.TEXT: The three main measures of the nation's money supply each rose in the week ended Feb. 19, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose $1.7 billion to a seasonally adjusted $800.6 billion from a revised $798.9 billion in the previous week. The central bank said the measure known as M2 rose $4.1 billion to a seasonally adjusted $3,256.7 billion from $3,252.6 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose $3 billion to a seasonally adjusted $4,072.2 billion from $4,069.2 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 6.4 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 3.9 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,230.5 billion, a 6.9 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,050.6 billion, up 3.4 percent, while M1 rose 5.0 percent to an average of $795.3 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $136 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $1.659 billion the previous week. The decline refloected the bank's reclassification of about $1.5 billion of Fed borrowings to the extended credit category. _The Federal Reserve said net borrowed reserves averaged $364 million in the two weeks ended Feb. 21, compared with net free reserves of $388 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $300.6 billion in the two-week period ended Feb. 21, up from $298.5 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: K mart Profits Going To Fight Expansions By Wal-Mart, Others
DOC.TEXT: With Wal-Mart Stores Inc. gaining like an Arkansas rabbit on K mart Corp.'s position as the nation's second-largest retailer, K mart has decided it's time for a makeover. K mart has been revamping old stores, opening new ones and trying to update its ``blue light special'' image under a five-year, $2.3 billion chainwide makeover aimed at fending off expanding competitors. Faced with newer stores by such expanding chains as Wal-Mart, from Bentonville, Ark., and Minneapolis-based Dayton Hudson Corp.'s Target discount chain, K mart has been trying to rouse customers with a brighter, higher-intensity atmosphere, expanded product offerings and new services. The stores are moving their usual popcorn and tobacco counters away from front-and-center, shedding dull linoleum and cluttered aisles and offering such new products as fax machines to attract customers. ``Retail is energy: their saliva glands are going, their credit cards are hot,'' said Michael Crosson, an outside designer hired to help shape the chain's future. This isn't goodbye to blue-collar customers who have flocked to decades of K mart ``blue light specials'' and ``midnight madness'' sales. Those will continue, K mart spokesman Orren F. Knauer said. But in a departure from its past, K mart has been stocking more brand-name merchandise to appeal to customers, and those household names will be better displayed in the new stores, Chairman Joseph E. Antonini said this week. Events of the past week showed the task K mart faces in trying to perk itself up. Antonini said on Monday that K mart would take a $640 million charge against its 1989 earnings to pay for speeding up its five-year, $2.3 billion chainwide makeover. As a result, K mart is expected to report only minimal or flat earnings next week. It reported 1988 profits of $802.9 million on sales of $27.3 billion. Meanwhile, smaller but faster-growing 1,400-store Wal-Mart announced record sales and profits for 1989, with earnings up 28.5 percent to $1.1 billion on sales of $25 billion. Wal-Mart on Thursday reported its sales February sales were up 33 percent, while at its stores open a year or longer sales were up 17 percent. ``It's not if, it's when Wal-Mart will pass them by at their present growth rates,'' said Frederick Marx, an independent retailing consultant based in Bloomfield Hills. But Marx predicted a shifting lead, with K mart never far behind. Wal-Mart, though growing fast in small-town America, won't be able match K mart's immense array of store sites in metropolitan areas, he said. Fighting back will mean changes at almost all of K mart's more than 2,300 discount stores, Antonini said. He announced plans to build 250 new stores, enlarge 620, relocate 280, close 30 and refurbish about 1,260 in the five-year program. Prototypes already are operating in the Detroit suburbs of Royal Oak and Rochester, Mich., and Virginia Beach, Va. Both new and old stores have adopted folksy Wal-Mart style ``people-greeters.'' At K-mart's old-style store in Port Huron, on Lake Huron 60 miles north of Detroit, a greeter with a rag grinned recently as he wiped melted snow from carts just in from the parking lot and pushed them toward incoming shoppers. In the new store, instead of a whiff of the popcorn, candy and tobacco counter of old, shoppers are greeted by gleaming floors, bright lights and wide-open spaces. The popcorn counter was moved to a cafeteria area right of the entrance. Rest rooms are easy to find, stylish graphics mark the cosmetics area, videos play among the sporting goods and the stores have bold signs and bigger stocks of merchandise on the shelves. ``Look at the jewelry area,'' Knauer said. ``It's the same product we sell in the other stores, but the fixturing is more department-store like. It makes the product look better.'' Crosson, executive vice president of Jon Greenberg and Associates Inc. in Berkley, said such perceptions amounted to reality, in retailing. ``It's no longer just a bigger dime store, it's a discount department store,'' he said of K mart. Crosson's firm has designed stores for retail establishments including Abercrombie & Fitch, and chains owned by New York-based Mercantile Stores, which include Cincinnati's McAlpin's, Denver's Joslin's and Florida's Gayfer's department stores.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Japan Report Progress in Supercomputer Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix slug.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Japanese negotiators moved closer Thursday to an agreement on Japanese government purchases of supercomputers, an area in which the United States contends Japan discriminates unfairly against foreign sellers, officials said. Under U.S. trade law, trade officials must report to Congress by the end of April on the progress of negotiations aimed at removing unfair barriers imposed by trading partners. Japan has been cited for alleged restrictions on satellites, forestry products and supercomputers. ``The talks have reached an interesting phase in that we are talking about the actual terms of a new arrangement'' for procedures to be used by the Japanese government in buying supercomputers, said a U.S. official who participated in the negotiations. The official, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity, said an August 1987 agreement had failed to result in any purchases of U.S. supercomputers by the Japanese government. ``The purpose ... is to achieve open, competitive procurement procedures, but we don't think we've achieved that yet. We hope by a new agreement to arrive at a situation in which the market opportunities for U.S. companies truly increase,'' he said. Supercomputers are extremely expensive, complex machines used for weather forecasting, defense systems and other applications where a huge number of calculations must be performed quickly. The talks followed negotiations late last month on forestry products and satellites and on economic structures in the two nations that have prevented a reduction in Japan's trade surplus with the United States, which last year totaled $49 billion. All three rounds of talks failed to achieve significant results, officials said, adding to trade tension between the two nations. Under the ``Super 301'' clause of the U.S. trade law, the United States can impose penalty tariffs of up to 100 percent on countries that fail to remove their trade barriers in negotiations after they are cited for unfair practices. ``I think there is an intention on both sides to reach an agreement'' on supercomputers, said the U.S. official. Foreign Ministry officials said U.S. negotiators called on Japanese agencies to consider the actual performance of supercomputers when evaluating competing bids, rather than the ``catalog,'' or theoretical performance, and to give priority to computers that surpass, rather than merely meet, bidding standards. In the past, the U.S. official said, Cray Research Inc., the only major U.S. manufacturer of supercomputers, has lost bids because it offered higher performance at a higher price than Japanese competitors. U.S. officials in the past also have criticized ``academic discounts'' offered by Japanese computer makers to universities and government agencies. In this week's talks, Japanese negotiators said they were aware that such practices were unfair and pledged to enforce the country's Anti-Monopoly Law, the U.S. official said. Japan has refused to negotiate trade disputes under the threat of punitive tariffs, and Noboru Hatakeyama, director general of the Ministry of International Trade and Industry's Trade Policy Bureau, denied that the talks fell under the U.S. trade law. ``We are receiving requests for improvement of our system for purchasing supercomputers,'' he said. ``We have asked companies to raise prices to a moderate level and increased our per-unit budget for supercomputers in the fiscal 1990 draft budget,'' he added. ``We have decided to raise the budget so American firms can sell their computers without excessive discounts.'' Japanese negotiators pledged to fully open up government procurement of supercomputers, but called on the United States to do the same, the U.S. official said. The U.S. government has not bought any foreign supercomputers, although some Japanese machines now are competitive with U.S. designs in speed. ``My position in response has been that as world leaders, they should not hesitate to do better than we do in the United States,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pan Am Says Creditors Agree To Defer $100 Million in Payments
DOC.TEXT: Financially strapped Pan Am Corp. said Thursday it had reached agreement with two creditors to defer about $106 million in payments. The airline company did not identify the creditors beyond saying they are aircraft manufacturers and aircraft engine manufacturers. About $62.5 million of the payments were deferred earlier, and were the subject of a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said. The deferral of those payments expired Wednesday, spokeswoman Pamela Hanlon said. Pan Am said the first scheduled repayments are due in this year's fourth quarter and will extend through the fourth quarter of 1991, subject to certain mandatory prepayments under certain, undisclosed circumstances. The company also agreed to pledge additional assets, including spare parts, as collateral, it said. In addition, Pan Am said it reached agreement with a third creditor that allowed the company to refinance three Boeing 747s through sale-leaseback agreements. The proceeds to Pan Am from those agreements, completed Thursday, was $65 million. Pan Am has been rumored to be seeking a merger partner for several months to ease its cash-flow problems. The New York-based company has lost nearly $2 billion since 1981 and is saddled with about $840 million in debt.

DOC.HEAD: More Mixed Signals Suggest Economy Stuck in Neutral
DOC.TEXT: A variety of statistical reports released Thursday by the government and private business provided more evidence of a sluggish, but not totally out-of-sorts economy. One private report showed a continuing decline in the manufacturing economy in February, but many of the nation's retailers reported modest improvement in their fortunes during the month. The government, meanwhile, reported a mix of pluses and minuses. Construction spending and personal income were up in January, but so were home prices and mortgage rates. The reaction to the mixed signals was generally positive on Wall Street, where stock prices closed higher on the belief that the economy had not weakened enough yet to prompt a decline in interest rates. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 8.34 to 2,635.59. Below are some of the highlights from the various economic and business reports: _The National Association of Purchasing Management said the U.S. manufacturing economy slowed for the 10th consecutive month in February, although the rate of decline was at the lowest since last June. The survey of purchasing executives at over 300 industrial companies showed some signs of strength in new orders and production, but the overall index remained weak. The index rose to 48.3 percent from 45.2 percent in January, but a reading below 50 indicates the economy generally is declining. _Major chain stores reported some growth in February sales, but the outlook for the retailing industry remained grim. Industry analysts gave warm weather the credit for boosting sales in what is normally a slow month for stores. One standout among the retailers was discounter Wal-Mart Stores Inc., which said its February sales surged 33 percent, while sales at stores open a year or longer were up 17 percent. In contrast, Sears, Roebuck and Co., the country's biggest retailer, reported sales were flat. _The Commerce Department said construction spending rose 1.8 percent in January, the biggest increase in more than a year. Economists credited the warmest January since the government began keeping track of temperatures 96 years ago. Residential, non-residential and government construction spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $424 billion in January on the largest gain since a 2.3 percent advance in December 1988. _Housing affordability declined in January, according to the National Association of Realtors, whose monthly survey showed evidence of higher prices and mortgage rates. The Realtors' affordability index fell to 104.2, meaning that a family earning the national median income of $33,708 had 104.2 percent of the income needed to qualify for a median priced home costing $96,200. The index was down from 108.2 in December, the highest level since it measured 110.5 in January 1989. _Personal income rose 0.8 percent in January despite a new tax bite from Social Security. The report by the Commerce Department also showed consumer spending climbed a narrower 0.6 percent, a pace which analysts attributed to caution in the face of inflation. The Commerce Department said personal income ran at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.60 trillion last month, after gaining 0.5 percent in December. Analysts cited the 1.1 percent increase in consumer prices in January for the slowdown in consumer spending, from a 1 percent gain in December.

DOC.HEAD: Exercise Equipment Company Files for Reorganization, Faces Suits
DOC.TEXT: Nautilus Sports-Medical Industries Inc., which makes the popular Nautilus exercise equipment, has filed for bankruptcy court protection from creditors. In documents filed in federal bankruptcy court in Roanoke, Va., the Dallas-based company listed $38.6 million in liabilities and $27.3 million in assets. The company was moved to Dallas in 1987, about a year after it was purchased by Ward International Corp., a diversified firm owned by Dallas investor Travis Ward. Company attorney Ed Creel said Nautilus has received new financing from its current lenders, who will continue funding the company during its attempt to reorganize under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code. He said Nautilus had spoken to several prospective buyers. Most of Nautilus' 250 employees work in the company's manufacturing plant in Independence, Va., Creel said. He said he did not think the bankruptcy court filing Tuesday would prompt layoffs. ``It is unlikely that our customers will notice any changes in our operation,'' John Urmston, Nautilus' chief operating officer, said in a statement. Creel said the company faces extensive litigation, but declined to comment further on what factors drove Nautilus to seek reorganization.

DOC.HEAD: Union Sues Nordstrom Over Wages, Decertification Campaign Announced
LaserPhoto SE2
DOC.TEXT: About 250 employees rallied Thursday in support of Nordstrom Inc., the fashion retailer whose sterling service reputation has been sullied by accusations of systematic wage law violations, and opened a campaign to decertify their union. Accusing the United Food & Commercial Workers of threatening their livelihoods, dozens of workers carried signs saying ``Nobody Asked Me _ I Support Nordstrom'' and chanted, ``One, two, three, four. No more union any more,'' and ``We love Nordstrom.'' Organizers of the rally also solicited funds to help pay for a full-page advertisement to appear Friday in The Seattle Times. ``The truth is that Nordstrom treats us fairer than the union does,'' Joe Dover, a shoe sales clerk with 11 years of experience in Bellevue, said at the rally. ``It's time to let the consumers hear both sides of the story,'' Dover said. ``I say the consumers support Nordstrom because Nordstrom has been good to them for so many years.'' The rally added to the controversy over pay practices, labor relations and declining profits at Nordstrom, which employs about 30,000 workers at 60 stores in six states. Nordstrom built a near-legendary reputation for customer service from polite and attentive sales clerks. However, in response to complaints brought by the sales clerks' union, the Washington Department of Labor and Industries ruled Feb. 15 Nordstrom had engaged in a pattern of requiring employees to perform uncompensated work. Tasks at issue included having workers attend meetings, deliver merchandise, check inventory, write thank-you notes and perform other chores without pay outside normal working hours. The state agency ruled Nordstrom must pay two years' worth of back wages for such tasks, and the company set aside a $15 million reserve to cover claims from Washington state workers. The union has claimed the provision was inadequate and on Monday filed a class action suit on behalf of 50,000 present and former company workers in Washington, Oregon, California, Virginia, Utah and Alaska, claiming wage and hour violations. UFCW contracts covering about 1,500 clerks in the Seattle-Tacoma area, Nordstrom's only unionized sales personnel, expired Aug. 1. Last week, ruling on a complaint by the union, the National Labor Relations Board accused Nordstrom of bypassing the union and bargaining directly with employees over whether they are owed back wages. Union complaints on other issues remain under review, said Larry McCargar, assistant to the agency's regional director. Local 1001 president Joe Peterson said the company ``has conducted an illegal campaign to get rid of the union. We're going to keep on with our campaign to get a fair contract.'' But Jack McMillan, Nordstrom's president, said Thursday's rally represented a backlash against the union. ``They've pulled out everything they can think of. The press coverage has been, we think, unfair to us in the extreme. Now the employees and the customers are coming to our defense,'' he said. Dozens at the rally cheered as Marv Treadwell, who works in the men's suits department in Tacoma, said petitions calling for an election on whether to retain representation by Local 367 had been signed by 40 percent of the workers eligible to vote at his store. Greg Helean, a women's shoe sales clerk in Bellevue, said similar petitions were being circulated in the Seattle area.

DOC.HEAD: Turner Broadcasting Reports $111 Million Fourth-Quarter Loss
DOC.TEXT: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. on Thursday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $111 million because of a refinancing last October to retire long-term debt. The media conglomerate reported improvement in all divisions _ entertainment, news, professional sports, syndication and real estate _ for the quarter ended Dec. 31, 1989. The company attributed the loss to a refinancing of substantially all its long-term debt and redemption of outstanding shares of its Cable News Network Inc. subsidiary. Turner borrowed $900 million under a bank credit agreement and issued new debt at lower interest rates. A $123 million charge for the quarter came from payments associated with retiring old debt. The quarterly loss compared with an $18.1 million loss in the same 1988 quarter. Revenue was $292.8 million, up from $224.3 million in the same period a year ago. For the full year, Turner reported a net loss of $70.6 million, compared with a loss of $94.5 million in 1988. Revenue was $1.06 billion, up from $804 million a year earlier. ``Absent the one-time charge resulting from the refinancing, we would have had our first net profit since 1985,'' Turner chairman and president Ted Turner said in a statement. Turner said the news segment, Cable News Network and Headline News, continued to grow with revenue up 28 percent and operating profit up 57 percent for the year. Syndication and licensing revenue rose 30 percent, due to increased video sales, new pricing strategies for classic catalogue films and the addition of World Championship Wrestling. The only segment to report a loss was professional sports, which lost $3.89 million. Turner is a majority owner of the Atlanta Braves baseball team and the Atlanta Hawks of the National Basketball Association.

DOC.HEAD: Sponsor of Tobacco Ad Restrictions Says Outright Ban Won't Work
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 4th graf pvs, bgng: `Under questioning...' to correct Neal's political party; picks up 5th graf pvs, bgng: `Opponents of...' Also on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: Tobacco should be outlawed but probably never will be, a House subcommittee chairman said Thursday, as lawmakers studied ways to keep people from becoming cigarette addicts. ``I would love to legislate tobacco out of existence and make it criminal,'' Rep. Thomas A. Luken, D-Ohio, told lawmakers from North Carolina, a tobacco-growing state. Luken is chairman of a House subcommittee studying legislation aimed at keeping tobacco companies from directing advertising campaigns toward women, young people and minorities. Under questioning from Reps. Stephen L. Neal, D-N.C., and Howard Coble, R-N.C., Luken said an outright ban on tobacco wouldn't work, noting the nation's experience with Prohibition in the 1920s and the current debate over legalizing drugs. Opponents of advertising restrictions argue that supporters really would like to see smoking outlawed. ``Advocates of bans really want to ban smoking, not advertising for smoking,'' said Rep. Alex McMillan, R-N.C. and a member of the transportation and hazardous materials subcommittee that Luken chairs. Luken's proposed bill would limit print advertising to text only _ there could be no pictures and no logos. It would also ban advertising directed at minors and ban billboard advertising except in sports facilities. In addition, it would ban sports events such as the recent Virginia Slims tennis tournament in Washington, which critics say link smoking with athletics and inserts brand names into sporting news copy. Finally, the bill would grant states and local governments broader authority to regulate advertising ``within the limits of the Constitution.'' The tobacco industry argues that it is not trying to recruit new smokers with targeted campaigns. It denies trying to reach youthful smokers. But Luken and other advocates of restrictions say that because 390,000 smokers die each year, the industry must recruit thousands of new smokers each day. Panelist Jim Slattery, D-Kan., said it was clear that tobacco companies were targeting youths. He argued that the language, illustrations and basic promotional gimmick of the tobacco campaign _ free T-shirts and posters _ clearly indicate a campaign aimed at hooking new smokers. He showed a brochure that was mailed to a 14-year-old from Connecticut offering free cigarettes after the youth responded to a free ``Camel'' cigarette T-Shirt offer. ``How many T-shirts do you write in for?'' Slattery asked his colleagues. ``I contend that when you give away T-shirts you are targeting children, not targeting adults,'' he said. ``You don't hang around the same places I do,'' countered R.J. Reynolds spokesman Dan Fishel in a telephone interview from Winston-Salem, N.C. Fishel pointed out that it screens out minors who call in requests for T-shirts, and pointed out that the promotional material requires a signed affidavit that the person requesting material is over 21. He said he has received only three calls in 15 months from parents whose children ordered T-shirts. He had no marketing data on the age breakdown for people responding to the T-shirt campaign. But the mother of the 14-year-old said several of her son's friends had ordered the T-shirts. The woman, who asked to remain anonymous to protect her son's identity, said he was 13 when he called for the shirt and his voice had not begun changing. She said she was particularly upset because her father had just died as a result of emphysema acquired after years of smoking.

DOC.HEAD: New Chemical May Replace Alar
DOC.TEXT: Initial tests by a Washington apple grower have identified an organic chemical that may serve as a substitute for Alar, which was banned as a probable carcinogen last year after a national scare. But a scientist for the U.S. Department of Agriculture said Thursday it was too early to tell if the grower's initial results will hold up, and that the chemical would require at least two more years of study. Eric Curry of the USDA in Wenatchee said such testing generally requires three orchards in three locations around the state for three years. Spray-N-Grow, a Houston-based company, said initial results on an orchard owned by a Yakima-area grower found trees treated with the chemical produced apples with a significant increase in uniformity of color, sweetness, firmness and harvest time over untreated apples. Bill Muskopf, president of Spray-N-Grow, said the chemical ``provides the same benefits (as Alar) while remaining completely organic and totally non-toxic.'' Alar was a synthetic chemical growers used for two decades before a private consumer group issued a report last year saying consumption of apples treated with the chemical increased cancer risk in children. The Environmental Protection Agency banned the chemical later in the year. Unlike Alar, Spray-N-Grow is an organic chemical, a micronutrient that has been proven non-toxic in private tests, company officials said. It has been used by commercial vegetable growers and home gardeners for several years, the company said. The Alar scare pushed prices for organic apples far above those for chemically treated apples. Organically grown red apples were selling for $1.29 at a Seattle market Thursday, compared to 39 cents per pound for other red apples. Alar's most significant benefit was retaining the internal firmness of apples during months of cold storage. That will be tested with the new chemical this year, Spray-N-Grow said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit: Sizzler Restaurants Trying To Oust Major Franchisee
DOC.TEXT: One of the nation's largest Sizzler restaurant franchisees said Thursday the Sizzler company is trying to ruin his business so it can take over his restaurants and control the Chicago market. Anthony Basile, president of FBN Food Services Inc. and Midwest Restaurant Concepts Inc., is suing Sizzler Restaurants International Inc. in federal court for $15 million in real damages and $10 million in punitive damages, alleging fraud and breach of covenant of good faith. Mark Weisberger, general counsel for Los Angeles-based Sizzler, declined comment on the lawsuit, citing a company policy. Basile said his 21 Sizzler steakhouse restaurants in the Chicago area and three in southwestern Michigan make him the third-largest Sizzler franchisee in the country. He contends that Sizzler's inconsistent advertising policies contributed to a decline in his stores' sales and a $3.5 million loss for him and his partners. Basile said Sizzler has offered to buy back his restaurants for about half their asset value of $15 million. ``They just did not want to see us succeed because they wanted the market back,'' Basile said in a telephone interview. ``They want to come back into Chicago because Chicago represents an excellent opportunity for future growth.'' Basile, who said he worked as a national food-industry consultant before buying his first eight Sizzler restaurants from the company in 1987, contended the Chicago market could support 50 to 60 Sizzler stores. Franchisers sometimes buy back stores from franchisees so they can shrink the contractual territory boundaries of those stores and put more stores into the same market, said Don Boroian, chairman of Francorp, a franchising consulting firm outside Chicago. Basile said the contract he signed in 1987 required him to contribute money to a local Sizzler advertising cooperative that was controlled by another, larger Sizzler franchisee. The cooperative bought advertising for all Sizzler restaurants in the area. Basile said that in 1988, the other franchisee was in financial trouble and told him to buy its 12 restaurants or it would withhold advertising dollars. Basile said he subsequently learned from the company that the other franchisee was not required, as Basile was, to contribute to the advertising fund. So Basile said he agreed to buy out his competitor _ giving Basile a monopoly in the Chicago market. He said he then sought help from Sizzler in reviving the troubled stores, only to be refused.

DOC.HEAD: Decline in U.S. Economy Eased Slightly in February, Survey Says
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 7th graf to CORRECT figures for 30-year bond; picks up 8th graf pvs bg'ng, Prices were ...
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. manufacturing economy slowed in February for the 10th consecutive month, although the decline was at the lowest rate since last June, according to a survey of the nation's purchasing managers released Thursday. The National Association of Purchasing Management said the figures showed that although certain manufacturing indicators reflected further strength, the sustained decline pointed to a continued underlying economic weakness. The trade association said its index rose to 48.3 percent in February from 45.2 percent in January. A reading below 50 indicates the U.S. manufacturing economy generally is declining; above 50, that it generally is expanding. The February reading was the highest since June's 48.8 percent, the group said from its headquarters in Tempe, Ariz. The report, which is closely watched on Wall Street, sent bond prices lower in early trading. Bonds tend to lose value on indications that the economy is picking up steam, because that implies the Federal Reserve may not be inclined to ease interest rates for fear of triggering inflation. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond dropped } point, or $7.50 for every $1,000 in face value. Its yield, which rises when prices fall, climbed to 8.60 percent from 8.53 percent late Wednesday. Prices were moderately higher on the stock market, which appeared little affected by the report. The new-orders portion of the group's survey showed that segment expanding for the first time since May, while the production segment registered overall growth for the first time since last June. In addition, both new-export orders and imports continued to show increased growth, the group said. The employment portion of the survey declined for the 12th consecutive month, but the rate of decline was the lowest since June. Supplier deliveries were faster for the 10th consecutive month and at a significantly greater rate than in January, when many shortages of delivered goods resulted from severe cold weather, the group said. Prices of goods declined for the ninth consecutive month and at the greatest rate of decline since December 1982. ``Although the first increases registered in production and new orders since mid-1989 are encouraging, the continued improvement in supplier deliveries and significant decline in prices suggests a lack of any underlying strength in the economy,'' said Robert J. Bretz, chairman of the trade group's survey committee and director of materials management at Pitney Bowes Inc. The report is based on a monthly survey of purchasing executives at over 300 industrial companies. The figures are adjusted for seasonal factors.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Extends Guaranteed Rebate
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. announced it will extend its guaranteed rebate program through March for most its cars and trucks, except its popular minivans and LeBaron convertibles. The nation's No. 3 automaker guarantees that if the rebate on a given vehicle is increased before Sept. 30, the buyer will get the difference. Current rebates range from $500 to $2,500. In its announcement Wednesday, the company didn't comment on how much the rebate extension will cost. In general automakers don't report such costs. Chrysler took a $664-million fourth-quarter loss in 1989 and is in the middle of a plan to cut $1.5 billion in annual costs by the end of this year.

DOC.HEAD: Four Senior Editors Resign in Protest
DOC.TEXT: Four of Pantheon Books' six senior editors have resigned, citing ``the removal'' of Managing Director Andre Schiffrin as just the most visible step to date in the publishing house's decline. The resignations were the latest to rock the publishing industry, which has seen several management shakeups and pressure on profits in recent months. Alberto Vitale, chairman and chief executive of Pantheon parent Random House Inc., announced Schiffrin's resignation on Tuesday. Schiffrin had joined Pantheon in 1962, shortly after its acquisition by Random House. ``It's clearly a forced resignation and everybody knows it,'' said Tom Engelhardt, one of the four senior editors who resigned Wednesday. The Washington Post quoted unidentified sources as saying Schiffrin was forced out after refusing to cut his staff and the number of books issued. Vitale said Schiffrin's resignation ``was not requested.'' Schiffrin did not return messages left at his office. In resigning, the four senior editors cited Pantheon's history as a voice for the otherwise unheard. And in an accompanying statement, Engelhardt expressed concern that in a publishing world increasingly dominated by ``a few men ... and a handful of relatively faceless media conglomerates,'' independent voices are being drowned out by the bottom line. ``Pantheon was founded in 1942 to protect an imperiled culture,'' said the statement from the four editors. ``We sought to continue that tradition by bringing into public view the forgotten and the iconoclastic, the quirky and the profound, the crises faced by other cultures, and by our own.'' Founded by German exiles Helen and Kurt Wolff, Pantheon last year published more than 100 books. Its authors have included Simone DeBeauvoir, George Kennan, Ralph Nader, Herbert Gans, Jean-Paul Sartre and Noam Chomsky. Engelhardt and fellow departee Wendy Wolf maintain that Random House is considering significantly cutting the list of books Pantheon will publish, Wolf says by more than a third. Vitale conceded that Pantheon has incurred ``substantial'' losses over at least the last five years, but said there are no current plans to cut its list. ``It may be necessary. I don't know,'' Vitale said. ``We'll have to ask Fred Jordan after awhile.'' Jordan was named Tuesday as Pantheon vice president and publisher, succeeding Schiffrin. Affirming his own commitment to preserve Pantheon's character, Jordan said management had not suggested cutting back on publishing plans. Vitale stressed that a solution to Pantheon's problems would be based first on publishing considerations, not financial. But at least some authors sided with the departees. Studs Terkel, who wrote seven books for Pantheon, said he would no longer publish with it. ``Pantheon has always been a classy publisher, and Andre was a symbol of that,'' Terkel told The New York Times. ``His firing is a barbaric act.'' In a letter to the Times, Terkel and nine other Pantheon authors said Schiffrin's termination, like the December departure of Robert L. Bernstein as chairman and president of Random House, resulted from their being unable ``to meet the demands of the proprietors'' to put ``short-term return upon investment'' above the ``criteria of cultural vitality and literary excellence.'' Random House and Pantheon belong to the publishing empire controlled by Samuel Irving Newhouse Jr. and Donald Edward Newhouse. Jordan previously was executive vice president and editor in chief of the Grove Weidenfeld publishing company, which was put up for sale Tuesday following recent resignations of top editors and losses estimated at $15 million last year. Schiffrin's and the senior editors' resignations are effective March 15. The other senior editors are James Peck and Sara Bershtel.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Boomers Starting to Become Midlife Boomers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling of name, Hollimann to Hollmann, in 11th graf: ``The frequency,'' and in 15th graf ``Hollimann's report,'' now bgng: ``Hollman's report,'' Also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Baby Boom, the massive generation that overcrowded schools and colleges and flooded the job market, is becoming the Midlife Boom. The number of Americans aged 35 to 44 increased by 9.5 million between 1980 and 1988, the Census Bureau reported Thursday. ``This is an average annual increase of 3.9 percent _ four times the pace of growth of the total population,'' reported Frederick W. Hollmann in a study of the population by age, sex and race. The leading edge of that group turned 35 in 1981 and was 40 in 1986, heading into middle age. Middle age has no formal census definition, although some dictionaries list it as the ages 40 to 60. The aging boomers boosted the 35-to-44 age group from 25.9 million in 1980 to 35.3 million in 1988, the report said. As the huge generation born between 1946 and 1964 has aged, it has affected many segments of society from baby food makers to school builders to the makers of blue jeans and business suits. Now the impact may fall back to the baby food market, as the post-World War II children begin having their own delayed families. The population under age 5 is rising again and those in elementary school, after declining for several years, began increasing again in 1985. In their 20s the Baby Boomers created something of a Baby Bust by postponing marriage and children while pursuing education and careers, population experts report. Now many are catching up in their 30s, a sort of echo of the Baby Boom, although birth rates are still nowhere near those recorded after World War II. ``The frequency of childbearing among women has increased slightly since the early part of the decade, primarily in the later ages of childbearing,'' reported Hollmann. At the same time the elderly population is growing rapidly, centenarians in particular. The larger population aged 100 or more results from several factors including something of a baby boom back in the 1880s, a substantial immigration from Europe early in this century and improvements in health care during this century. There were 54,000 centenarians in 1988, up from just 14,000 in 1980. Hollmann's report summarizes a wide variety of population trends including: _The population aged 14 to 24 declined by 5.6 million between 1980 and 1988 as the last of the Baby Boom turned 25. _The nation's black population was 30.3 million in 1989, up from 26.9 million in 1980. Blacks increased by 1.5 percent in 1988, nearly twice the white growth of 0.8 percent. _Hispanics, who can be of any race, grew from 14.8 million in 1980 to 19.9 million in 1988. _The fastest growing segment of the population was Asians and Pacific Islanders, up 70 percent in the 1980s. They increased from 3.8 million in 1980 to 6.5 million in 1988. _American Indians increased from 1.4 million to 1.7 million over the decade.

DOC.HEAD: Open Cases Against Northrop Include Alleged $20 Billion B-2 Overcharge
DOC.TEXT: Serious criminal investigations are continuing against Northrop Corp., including allegations of $20 billion in B-2 bomber overcharges, despite a plea-bargain that disposed of scores of criminal charges, sources close to the probes said Thursday. Northrop pleaded guilty Tuesday to 34 charges of lying to the government and agreed to pay a $17 million fine. Northrop admitted falsifying test data on parts for the cruise missile and Harrier attack jet. In exchange, the government agreed to drop 139 other counts of making false statements and two counts of conspiracy. The government also dropped several probes into allegations of improper testing of MX missile parts and accusations the company fraudulently bought MX parts outside normal channels. But investigations continue into whether Northrop bribed South Korean officials, bilked the government while auctioning property seized by the Customs Service, and overcharged on B-2 parts, according to congressional investigators and those involved in civil suits against the company. The plea-bargain settlement was sealed, and Northrop officials said the company was unable to discuss it with reporters under the deal worked out with federal prosecutors. But in a memo to staff left in the company's lobby, Northrop President Kent Kresa described how the MX probes had ended but ``some other legal issues remain open.'' Those include a criminal probe of the B-2 program, prompted by a civil ``whistle-blower'' lawsuit that seeks damages of $20 billion, the sources said. Northrop has acknowledged that FBI agents raided its B-2 parts plant in Pico Rivera on Feb. 15 and seized documents related to the program. ``You can hardly raid them one week and let them plead out the next,'' said an aide to Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., whose House Subcommittee on Investigations has conducted extensive hearings into allegations of Northrop wrongdoing. Dingell released a statement protesting the sealing of the settlement. ``The criminal justice system is supposed to be available for review by all our citizens, but this represents stealth justice,'' he said, a reference to the B-2 stealth bomber's supposed ability to hide from radar. Grand juries in Los Angeles and Honolulu continue probes of whether Northrop made political payoffs to South Korea, and a Texas grand jury is looking into the allegations that Northrop cheated the government in auctioning Customs Service contraband, said the Dingell aide, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Herbert Hafif, the lawyer for the Northrop employees who filed the suit alleging B-2 overcharges, said he had learned the federal criminal probe into that case was continuing. Hafif is the lead attorney on several of the ``whistle-blower'' suits, in which present or former employees can sue on behalf of the government and share in any damages recovered. Northrop's guilty plea in the cruise missile criminal case will be admissible as evidence in Hafif's mirror civil lawsuit in the case. In that case, which goes to trial this year, Hafif said he will seek between $20 million and $30 million in damages from the aerospace company. He also pointed out that while the criminal MX cases have been dropped, civil lawsuits remain to be tried.
